HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Bond Prices In Rebound

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices rebounded yesterday after a four-day decline, as investors showed stronger demand than expected at a $12 billion auction of five-year Treasury notes.
The 30-year Treasury bond rose about 12/32 of a point in price, or $3.75 per $1,000 in face value, pushing its yield down 4 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 6.83 percent. 
 Prices of short- and intermediate-term issues also rose, and the yield on the two-year note slipped 7 basis points, to 6.01 percent.
"Yield levels are very attractive, and investors are realizing that they're sitting on a lot of cash and should be buying," said Patrick Retzer, who manages $300 million of bonds at Heartland Advisors in Milwaukee. "The auction going well is what kept us from plunging enough to drive yields through the 7 percent level."
The Government sold five-year notes at a yield as high as 6.415 percent, less than the 6.423 percent traders expected. Yesterday's sale, initially scheduled for March 28, was delayed because Congress failed to pass a bill raising the national debt ceiling to $5.5 trillion from $4.9 trillion in time for the auction to proceed as planned.
Treasury traders warned, however, that the positive auction did not signal an end to the bond market's recent rout. The auction "restored a good tone to the market, but I don't think we've turned around all the bears," said Morton Swinsky, co-head of Treasury trading at Fuji Securities in New York. "There are still more bears than bulls."
Extending today's gain will prove difficult, said Anthony Karydakis, senior financial economist at First Chicago Capital Markets. "In most people's minds, 7 percent represents the ultimate objective, and it could be yields hover around these levels, between 6.75 percent and 7 percent, in the next couple of months."
Bond prices fluctuated yesterday, rising, then falling, before rebounding. Initially, bonds gained on speculation that the highest Treasury yields in seven months would attract demand at the auction, particularly from foreign investors.
"For a lot of foreign investors, today is the first day back since the big jump in Treasury yields," said David Capurro, who manages $500 million of bonds at Franklin Resources in San Mateo, Calif.
The jump in yields began Friday, when the Government reported that the economy added more jobs than expected in March, as it had in February. Now, "we think the bond market is favorably priced," Mr. Capurro said.
Following are the results of the Treasury's auction of five-year notes:

HEADLINE: George Jenkins, 88, Founder Of $9 Billion Grocery Chain

BYLINE: New York Times Regional Newspapers 

DATELINE: LAKELAND, Fla., April 9

 BODY:
George W. Jenkins, founder of Publix Supermarkets, the nation's ninth-largest grocery retailing chain and one of its most innovative, died on Monday at the Lakeland Regional Medical Center, a company spokeswoman said. He was 88.
Mr. Jenkins suffered a stroke and had been confined to a wheelchair since 1989. 
 Mr. Jenkins was widely known as the state's largest commercial employer and head of a chain of stores that was a leader in introducing many innovations, including electric-eye doors and frozen food cases. He was also a benefactor of many civic, educational and charitable organizations.
"George made a tremendous contribution to our business climate, but perhaps more importantly, he was a true civic leader who had a deep dedication to improving our communities," Gov. Lawton Chiles said.
Mr. Jenkins started his supermarket empire in 1930 when he opened his first store in Winter Haven with $1,300. Today the Publix chain has more than 514 supermarkets in three states and employs nearly 100,000 people. Sales exceeded $9.4 billion in 1995.
George Washington Jenkins Jr. was born Sept. 29, 1907, in Warm Springs, Ga. He was one of eight children of a general store owner. He was 12 when he started working in his father's store, which sold "everything from coffins to collar buttons," he once said.
When Mr. Jenkins was 16, the boll weevil attacked the area's cotton crops. The farmers could not afford to pay their bills, spelling economic disaster for the general store. His father moved to Atlanta to open a grocery market. A year later, the son also moved to Atlanta, briefly studying electrical engineering and then than taking a series of odd jobs.
Among them was a job working for the Piggly Wiggly grocery chain, starting as a clerk. In June 1925, he hitched a car ride and traveled to Tampa, where he went to work for another Piggly Wiggly, starting as a "broom pusher" and stock clerk making $15 a week. Within a few weeks, he was promoted to store manager of a Piggly Wiggly in St. Petersburg, a reward for hard work and long hours. He was later promoted to store manager in Winter Haven, the company's biggest store.
Four years later, the Florida boom collapsed and Mr. Jenkins's store began to fail, and the chain was sold to an operator in Atlanta.
Mr. Jenkins said he then "turned in my apron, took the money I had saved to buy a new car -- about $1,300 -- and in 1930 opened my own store next to the one I'd left."
In 1930, Mr. Jenkins formed a corporation, Publix Food Stores Inc., and by 1935 he had two stores.
Back in Lakeland, Mr. Jenkins mortgaged an orange grove for $25,000, closed his two stores, "and, in 1940, opened the prototype of the marble, tile and stucco palaces which were to follow."
The revolutionary design of that store included several features that at the time had been rarely seen in a grocery store in Florida or anywhere else: electric-eye doors that would open automatically, fluorescent lighting, air-conditioning, 11,000 square feet of selling area, wide aisles, frozen-food cases, open-air dairy cases and a paved parking lot.
Within a few years he bought J. A. Powell's Lakeland Grocery Company, with its chain of 19 All American stores, beginning the business that formed the core of the Publix chain.
The Publix chain continued to grow. In recent years, about 20 new stores were added each year. The innovations kept coming, too. Electronic scanners to read prices automatically were introduced in 1977. In 1982, Publix began putting automated bank tellers in its stores. In 1984, the chain began testing debit cards, allowing customers to pay for their food using their bank cards.
In 1940 he married Lee Savings, but she died less than two years later. The couple had no children, but Mr. Jenkins his wife's daughter from a previous marriage, Delores Socia.
In 1947, Mr. Jenkins married Anne MacGregor of Atlanta. They had six children and were divorced in 1974.
Mr. Jenkins is survived by a brother, Charles H. Jenkins Sr. of Lakeland.
In addition to Delores, who lives in Lakeland, his surviving children are Howard Jenkins of Tampa, David Jenkins of Los Angeles, Carol Jenkins Barnett of Lakeland, Julie Fancelli, of Lakeland and Italy, and Nancy Jenkins of Palm Beach, Fla., A third son, Kenneth Jenkins, died in 1974. Mr. Jenkins had 14 grandchildren and nine great granchildren.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Chip Sales Indicator Falls to 5-Year Low

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, April 9

 BODY:
The semiconductor industry's leading indicator plunged to a new five-year low in March, reflecting the continued slowdown in personal computer sales and rapidly falling prices for memory chips.
The Semiconductor Industry Association, which is based in San Jose, Calif., today reported a book-to-bill ratio of 0.80 for the three-month period ending in March, down from a revised figure of 0.89 in February. The trade group issued its report after the close of the stock market, and analysts said it could set the stage for a selloff of semiconductor stocks. 
 In other signs of chip industry weakness, Advanced Micro Devices Inc. reported first-quarter earnings that fell well below analysts' expectations, and the company warned that it saw further pressure on profits. And Motorola Inc., while registering results that modestly exceeded estimates, reported declining orders in the semiconductor portion of its business.
"The manufacture of chips is going through a very difficult transition from robust, really fantasy-level growth to extreme oversupply," said Rick Whittington, an analyst with the Soundview Financial Group. "The growth last year was never as strong as we thought because of the massive inventory buildups," he said. Companies that added manufacturing capacity in anticipation of continued growth must now face declining orders while burdened with higher fixed costs and higher employee levels, he added.
Many analysts predicted last year that the semiconductor industry had escaped its normal cyclical status, and was poised for an era of virtually limitless growth, as more and more products came to depend on chips. Now, some are saying the growth last year was exaggerated by personal computer manufacturers stocking up to meet an anticipated huge surge in sales keyed to the introduction last August of the Microsoft Corporation's Windows 95 operating system. Without the surge, computer makers now have big inventories of chips to work down, sending prices plummeting.
The book-to-bill ratio compares the rate of orders with shipments, and is measured in dollars, not units, so it does reflect price shifts. Thus a ratio of 0.80 indicates that for every $100 worth of computer chips shipped, only $80 worth were ordered, an indicator of declining sales. Analysts had expected a number closer to 0.88.
In January, the ratio fell to 0.93, dropping below the break-even point of 1.00 for the first time in five years.
Semiconductor orders in March totaled $3.33 billion, down 12.5 percent from $3.81 billion in February, and a 14.5 percent drop from the $3.9 billion in new orders in the comparable period a year ago.
Shipments also fell in March, to $4.16 billion, down 3.1 percent from the $4.29 billion recorded in February, but up 23 percent from $3.39 billion in the comparable period a year earlier.
"Based upon the obvious inventory correction in the U.S. market that started at the beginning of the quarter, it's no surprise that the March book-to-bill numbers are weak," Doug Andrey, the Semiconductor Industry Association's director of information systems and finance, said in a statement. "Worldwide, however, the market outlook for the chip industry is still very bright."
Mr. Andrey cited surging worldwide sales of microprocessors, which he said should offset the slump in the United States market. But analysts said that factor primarily benefitted the Intel Corporation, the dominant supplier, and that there was little positive news for other companies.
The outlook from Advanced Micro was bleak. "The current industry-wide downturn in demand for integrated circuits in the personal computer segment makes projections about future prospects problematic," W. J. Sanders 3d, the company's chairman and chief executive, said in a statement. "We do not expect an upturn in demand until those inventories have been brought down to support consumption levels."
For the quarter ended March 31, Advanced Micro reported earnings of $25.3 million, or 18 cents a share, down 70 percent from $84.3 million, or 66 cents a share, in the comparable period a year earlier. Analysts with Zacks Investment Research had estimated per-share earnings of 32 cents. Sales fell 13 percent.
Motorola reported first-quarter earnings of $384 million, or 63 cents a share, up 3.2 percent from $372 million, or 61 cents a share. Motorola said results would have been flat without a more favorable tax treatment in the most recent quarter. Analysts with First Call had estimated earnings would fall to 57 cents a share. Sales rose 16 percent.
Motorola said semiconductor sales increased 14 percent, to $2.1 billion, but that orders declined 5 percent. Operating profits for the chip business were higher but would have been flat except for a net gain realized from a real estate transaction, the company said.
Both Advanced Micro and Motorola reported their results after the stock market closed today.

HEADLINE: Stadium Plan Would Scuttle M.T.A. Hopes

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

 BODY:
The proposal to build a baseball stadium on the West Side of Manhattan would kill the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's longstanding plan to develop the site and generate millions of dollars for transit improvements.
The M.T.A. owns the site, the railyard west of Penn Station. A consultant's report, praised by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, estimated the cost of the stadium at $1 billion, but that figure includes no money for buying the site from the M.T.A. 
 Some authority officials worry that the stadium proposal could lead to a standoff between the city and the M.T.A., like the one that has stalled redevelopment of the Coliseum site on Columbus Circle for years.
Worse, they fear that Gov. George E. Pataki and Mr. Giuliani, eager to keep the Yankees from going to New Jersey, will force the M.T.A. to give up the property with little or no compensation, sacrificing money that could have gone toward projects like renovating stations, modernizing signals and acquiring trains and buses.
E. Virgil Conway, the M.T.A. chairman, said yesterday that such concerns were premature, and that determining which agencies would profit from a stadium and to what extent is "light-years away." He said he had been consulted about building a stadium on a platform above the railyard, but he would not say by whom or to what extent.
"The conversations are not of a nature that I can discuss," he said.
For more than a decade, the M.T.A. has harbored visions of development above the railyards, with the profits going to capital improvements in its subway, bus and commuter rail network. Though the real estate market has been weak for years, the potential for such sources of income has become especially important to the authority in the last year, as city, state and Federal subsidies for transit have been cut.
Mr. Conway said he considered the stadium proposal exciting, and dismissed the previous development plans for the site as "something that's not going to happen." Though real estate developers' views of the M.T.A.'s prospects for building above the railyards were not generally positive, Mr. Conway's assessment nevertheless came as a surprise to many other M.T.A. officials.
Several officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said they were concerned that the authority had barely been consulted about a stadium, even though the city and state commissioned a study of the site, and the state has been considering the idea of a stadium over the rail yard since 1993.
While city officials have talked avidly of striking a deal with the Yankees in which the city would receive a share of stadium revenues, there has been no mention of any of that money going to the transit system. Like Mr. Conway, John S. Dyson, Deputy Mayor for Economic Development and an M.T.A. board member, said yesterday through a spokeswoman that such talk would be premature.
But one M.T.A. official said: "It's not premature for the city to talk about what to do with this property, and it's not premature for the city to talk about making money off it. But for some reason, it's premature to include the agency that owns the property in any of this. What does that tell you about their intentions?"
The M.T.A. spent $196 million building the railyard between 10th and 12th Avenues and 30th and 33d Streets. It lies well below street level and most of it is open to the sky. Completed in 1987, it allowed Long Island Rail Road trains to be stored, cleaned and repaired at a site near Penn Station between their morning and evening runs, rather than shuttling back and forth during the day from Manhattan to yards in Queens and on Long Island.
The yard was designed to accommodate pillars that would support an enormous concrete deck above it and buildings atop the deck. The plan was to turn it over to a developer and collect part of the builder's lease income.
The M.T.A. drafted a proposal to turn the site, plus the block north of 33d Street and west of 11th Avenue, into a mini-city, with 8.3 million square feet of office and retail space, a 718-room hotel, 3,600 residential units and two parks. That proposal, which M.T.A. officials concede was probably too optimistic, was completed in 1989, just in time for the real estate market in New York City to take a nosedive from which it has only partly recovered.
Mr. Conway, appointed chairman last year by Mr. Pataki, derided the plan as unrealistic and said the authority had long since abandoned it.
But some current M.T.A. officials, along with others who recently left the agency, said that as far as they knew, it had merely been shelved, waiting for a healthier real estate market. They said they still thought the site could generate several million dollars in annual income.
"As far as I knew, it was still very much on the radar screen," a current executive said. "It's a valuable asset that we've invested a lot in, and even if it's not ripe for development in the current climate, that doesn't mean it won't be in a couple of years."
Lewis Rudin, a major developer and property manager, agreed cautiously. "In this market, it wouldn't happen," he said. "But it very well could be a developable property in a few years." Even if the site cannot be developed, it is rare that one governmental agency would take the asset of another without compensation.
The west 30's, where an old post office is being converted to a soaring new Penn Station, with shops and restaurants, is not an attractive place for offices and homes, he said. "That new Penn Station might be the impetus that it needs," he said. "The Javits Center was supposed to be, and it wasn't."
But Edward S. Gordon, a major commercial real estate broker, said any prospect for developing the site "is so many years off it isn't worth discussing."
Real estate professionals agreed, however, that a new baseball stadium would be just the sort of catalyst that would make the rest of the neighborhood desirable, sparking a building boom there.
Ultimately, what kind of deal is struck for the right to build over the rail yards will depend on the Governor and the Mayor. The Governor appoints six of the M.T.A. board members including the chairman, and they often vote as a bloc in accordance with Mr. Pataki's wishes, giving them effective control of the 14-vote board. Mr. Giuliani's appointees hold another four votes, who also tend to vote as a bloc, so when the two groups are allied, they hold an insurmountable majority.
Louis R. Tomson, the Governor's liaison to the M.T.A., said Mr. Pataki has not taken a position on the stadium proposal or on the authority's role in it. But the Governor has strongly expressed a desire to keep the Yankees in New York.
The city, the state and the Yankees commissioned a study by the architectural firm of Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum on options for a new or renovated stadium for the team. The option favored in the report was a multi-use, 70,000-seat stadium with a retractable roof, above the rail yard, between 11th and 12th avenues, for $1.06 billion.
But while the analysis included costs for the immense platform above the tracks, highway improvements, parking and other considerations, it made no mention of the M.T.A.
Transit advocates said they feared a stadium could actually become an expense for the M.T.A., because it would require new bus routes to the stadium, perhaps even a new trolley or subway line. And, they said, it is clear that Mr. Giuliani is behind the project.
"This site should be a revenue source for the M.T.A., and it looks like they want to turn it into a revenue drain," said Gene Russianoff, staff attorney for the Straphangers Campaign. "It seems like the mayor's last thought in this entire affair is its impact on the transit system."

Metropolitan Transportation Authority officials say building a baseball stadium on the West Side of Manhattan would foil their longstanding plans to develop a railyard west of Pennsylvania Station. HEADLINE: 13 Cattle Quarantined in Mad Cow Disease

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 9

 BODY:
Thirteen head of New York cattle have been placed under quarantine by state agriculture officials because of concerns they could be carrying mad cow disease, although there is no evidence the animals are infected.
The State Department of Agriculture and Markets is negotiating with three farmers to destroy the animals, which were imported from Britain before the Federal Government placed an embargo on British cattle in 1989. 
 Two of the cattle are in Cobleskill in Schoharie County; 10 are in Stormville, Dutchess County, and 1 is in Holcomb, near Rochester. The cost of buying and destroying the cattle is put at around $90,000, and Gov. George E. Pataki said the money would be made available.
"We have a tentative deal at that price for all 13," the Agriculture and Markets Commissioner, Donald R. Davidsen, said today. "We're in the process of getting the papers around and getting them signed. I'm hopeful that these animals will be ours to be put down this week."
In addition to the actions in New York, 20 other states began ordering the killing of British cattle.
Some of the cows in New York are used for breeding and others are pets. Mr. Davidsen said they were examined twice a year by the Federal Department of Agriculture and found to be healthy. But he said just the potential hazard to humans is reason enough to destroy them.
"It seems like an appropriate thing to do," Mr. Davidsen said. "Maybe we're erring on the side of prudence, but now's the time to do this."
In Britain, mad cow disease has been linked to a rare brain disease in humans.

HEADLINE: Quayle Gets Cool Welcome in Russia

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 9

 BODY:
On his first trip to Russia, former Vice President Dan Quayle discovered that the friendship between this country and the United States is beginning to fray.
Mr. Quayle, who now lectures and writes a syndicated column, delivered a buoyant speech today about democracy and the future of nuclear security to the Russian Academy of Sciences. But his elderly, distinguished audience of mostly sociologists and historians wanted to teach him a thing or two about international relations. 
 "You can't tell Russia what its position should be on the NATO issue," Grigory L. Bondarevsky, a political scientist, chided. Even though Mr. Quayle had not raised the issue of NATO expansion, Mr. Bondarevsky was one of several specialists who complained about it.
The political scientist also took Mr. Quayle to task for the United States military aid to Pakistan, for not doing enough to stop Islamic terrorism, and for raising the issue of democracy in Russia while "failing to bring it up in your relations with China."
"I was not expecting it," Mr. Quayle said afterward. "I welcomed it. It showed me that there are some very sensitive political issues here."
Mr. Quayle, who said he wanted to acquaint himself with Russia's political climate and gather material for his speeches and columns, arrived in Moscow on Monday for four days of private meetings with Russian politicians and leading public figures, under the auspices of the American University in Moscow.
But his encounter at the Russian Academy of Sciences gave him a strong dose of the new, somewhat sour mood infecting Russian society.
"His speech wasn't too bad," Mr. Bondarevsky said grudgingly after the meeting. "But it was a little simple. It was all right as a campaign speech, but not for here. We expect a higher standard."
In his speech, Mr. Quayle argued that a return to a socialist economy in Russia would only result in "shared poverty," while free market reform would eventually lead to "greater prosperity."
But Mr. Quayle also offered a brash new proposal for resolving security issues, suggesting that the "six powers" of the world -- the United States, Russia, Europe, Japan, China and India -- form a new kind of security council to discuss nuclear safety and ways to stop the spread of chemical, biological and atomic weapons.
Mr. Quayle told his audience, "This does not mean that the United Nations should be replaced, nor will it prevent any country of acting in its own interest, but it will provide a more effective forum for discussing these crucial issues."
In an interview later, he explained that given the tensions between Russia and the West over expanding NATO to include some of the former Warsaw Pact countries, his plan could help ease Russia's concerns over exclusion.
"It gets people thinking about nuclear arrangements and international relationships Russia could and should have," he said. "I wanted to talk about ways to include Russia and emphasize its importance."
American officials in Moscow said they had not previously heard of Mr. Quayle's proposal, and found it "baffling" because "it could lead to a duplication of effort."
But some Russians found it encouraging. "It's not a bad idea," said Sergei Rogov, director of the Institute for USA and Canada studies.
Mr. Quayle said the six-power security group was an idea he had flirted with while Vice President, but had not advanced publicly because it was not favored by the Bush Administration. He decided to try it out in Russia. "I figured, let's put something new out there instead of just rehashing what they have basically heard in the past," he said.
After two days in town, Mr. Quayle said he was surprised by the amount of construction going on in Moscow, particularly by the restoration of Christ the Savior Cathedral near the Kremlin. "That would have been unthinkable a few years ago," he said.
In Moscow, Mr. Quayle also discovered that the access to top officials he once had as Vice President had lessened since leaving office; several meetings he had scheduled for today and Monday were canceled at the last minute. He said he was not sure whether he would meet with President Boris N. Yeltsin, or his main challenger in the Russian election in June, Gennadi A. Zyuganov, the Communist leader, who left town today on a campaign trip.
Mr. Quayle expressed wry amusement over the sudden cancellation of his meeting with Igor Malashenko, the chief executive of the privately owned television network, NTV. Mr. Malashenko, who will keep his job while he advises Mr. Yeltsin's campaign, was summoned to a campaign strategy meeting.
"Can you imagine Dan Rather working for Clinton?" he asked. "It's not yet what we would call a free press."

HEADLINE: Smokers More Likely to Bear Retarded Babies, Study Says

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, April 9

 BODY:
Pregnant women who smoke are 50 percent more likely to have mentally retarded children, according to a study released today.
Smoking during pregnancy was previously linked to low birth weight, infant mortality and lower intelligence in children. This study was the first to connect smoking with retardation, said Dr. Carolyn D. Drews, an associate professor of epidemiology at Emory University who headed the research. 
"I certainly think there is more study that's needed," Dr. Drews said. "If these data represent a true finding, it's one more reason for women to stop smoking during pregnancy."
The researchers interviewed the mothers of 221 Atlanta-area children with mental retardation of an unknown cause and 400 other mothers in a control group.
The study, published in the April issue of Pediatrics, the journal of the American Academy of Pediatrics, found:
*Women who smoked while pregnant were 50 percent more likely to have mentally retarded children.
*About 35 percent of women who gave birth to retarded children reported smoking as few as five cigarettes a week during pregnancy.
*Women who smoked during the last six months of pregnancy, when a fetus develops many organs, were 60 percent more likely to have retarded children than women who did not smoke then.
*Pregnant women who smoked at least a pack of cigarettes a day were 85 percent more likely to give birth to a retarded child.
The researchers considered children retarded if their I.Q. was lower than 70 when they were 10 years old.
About 24 percent of women without mentally retarded children said they had smoked while pregnant, according to the study conducted by researchers at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and Batelle Centers for Public Health Practice and Education, both in Atlanta.
The researchers factored in elements believed to increase the chance of mental retardation, like the mother's age, economic status, education and alcohol use.
Dr. Julian Ullman, a professor of obstetrics and gynecology at Northwestern Memorial Hospital, called the study very disturbing. "There's no question it's another reason for women to stop smoking," he said.

HEADLINE: Senate Contenders in Boston Fight to a Draw in a Debate

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: BOSTON, April 9

 BODY:
Around this time of year in Massachusetts, public attention generally turns to two beloved pastimes, baseball and political campaigns. Alas, the Red Sox began the season losing five of six games on the road, and snow on Monday canceled the team's home opener in Fenway Park.
There were no such disappointments across town on Monday night in Faneuil Hall, where Senator John Kerry and Gov. William F. Weld squared off in a rousing hourlong debate of Senate candidates that revealed broad differences in style and views of government. 
 As the first in a series of scheduled encounters between the Democratic incumbent and his Republican challenger, the debate was televised live throughout the state. But the race has drawn interest well beyond Massachusetts, because both candidates have wide appeal with voters and national party leaders, and each is eager to appear as the more reasonable and moderate alternative at a time of heightened partisanship in Washington.
With more than six months before the election and recent polls showing Mr. Kerry holding only a narrow lead, neither candidate declared himself a flat-out winner of the debate. That was left to surrogates, like Paul Cellucci, the Republican Lieutenant Governor, and Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Mr. Kerry's Democratic colleague, , whose analyses suggested that they had watched different debates.
Rather, after fielding questions from reporters during the first half-hour and from each other in the livelier second, each candidate pronounced himself satisfied that he made his points.
Despite the obvious foreign policy challenges posed by China and Russia and trade with Japan, the debate focused almost entirely on domestic issues, reflecting statewide concern over a changing national economy, job insecurity and the growing disparity between haves and have-nots.
While the candidates disagreed on approaches to almost everything and many exchanges devolved into noisy charges and countercharges over the impact of tax and social proposals, the larger themes that have given each man a national profile emerged quickly: Mr. Weld as a strong proponent of a small-sized Government minimally involved in people's lives, and Mr. Kerry as a defender of maintaining Government programs for the less fortunate.
Mr. Weld took ample opportunity to trumpet his favorite campaign issues of welfare reform, lower taxes and tougher measures to fight crime -- all hallmarks of his six years in office -- and to paint Mr. Kerry, who is seeking a third term, as an entrenched Washington insider. Mr. Kerry presented himself as a champion of the people who played a major role in helping pass the 1994 crime bill and chided Mr. Weld for his spiritual kinship to Speaker Newt Gingrich, Republican of Georgia.
Their differences were especially evident when a reporter asked Mr. Weld why he thought people were poor. It gave the Governor the chance to highlight his administration's welfare policies, which are regarded as the most stringent of any state in the country.
"A whole knot of problems" causes poverty, Mr. Weld allowed, but foremost among them, he said, is "the welfare culture we have had the last 40 years in this country."
Mr. Kerry used that response to attack Mr. Weld for opposing an increase in the minimum wage and for favoring the Republicans' original proposal of $270 billion in reduced Medicare spending over seven years to finance $245 billion in tax cuts.
Later, in the evening's most poignant moment, Mr. Weld called attention to his support for the death penalty -- and Mr. Kerry's opposition -- by pointing to Ann Schavina of Springfield, Mass., whose son, Michael, a police officer, was killed in the line of duty. With Mrs. Schavina sitting in the audience, Mr. Weld asked Mr. Kerry "to tell her why the life of the man who murdered her son is worth more than the life of her son, the police officer."
The hall grew silent.
"It's not worth more," said Mr. Kerry, a decorated veteran of the Vietnam war."It's not worth anything. It's scum that ought to be thrown into jail for the rest of its life to learn day after day the pain and hell of living with the loss of freedom and the crime committed.
"But the fact is, Governor, that, yes, I have been opposed to the death penalty. I know something about killing, and I don't think a state honors life by turning around and sanctioning killing."
For Mr. Weld, who lowered the expectations of his supporters by predicting, "the debate will have a loser and it'll probably be me," the evening was at least a stylistic success. He was assertive, even forceful in defending policies and criticizing Mr. Kerry, once pounding the lectern to make a point. But Kerry supporters said Mr. Weld's volume merely helped make their candidate look more senatorial.

HEADLINE: Stocks End Mixed as Dow Drops 33.96 Points

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
The stock market turned mixed yesterday after Monday's sharp decline. The Dow Jones industrial average continued to move downward, but advancing issues outnumbered declining ones on the New York Stock Exchange.
On Monday, the Dow tumbled 88.51 points in reaction to Labor Department data that companies added 140,000 new jobs to their payrolls in March, more than had been expected. This was the second consecutive month that a robust Labor Department employment report caused a major selloff; on March 8, the average dropped 171 points, the largest percentage decline in four years. 
 The market tried to stabilize yesterday, but the Dow industrials nevertheless weakened, sinking 33.96 points, to 5,560.41. A broader indicator, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, declined 2.05 points, to 642.19.
"Early in the session, hopes ran high that the market would lift, but the rally was short-lived," said Alan Ackerman, senior vice president of Fahnestock & Company. "Uncertainties about corporate earnings, interest rates and inflation curbed optimism somewhat."
However, strength in some technology issues helped to raise the Nasdaq composite index by 3.49 points, to 1,109.15. Advancing Big Board issues exceeded decliners by 1,401 to 969. And volume inched up to 426.8 million shares, from 421.9 million shares on Monday.
This week's slump in the Dow was attributed by analysts to a resurgence in economic growth, with a related fear of inflation. Among the 30 blue-chip Dow stocks, big losses were suffered by American Express, off 1 3/8, to 47 3/8; Procter & Gamble, down 1 5/8, to 83, and United Technologies, off 1 1/2, to 110 3/8.
Mortgage companies were lower amid concerns over their profit margins. Federal National Mortgage, known as Fannie Mae, fell 1 7/8, to 31, and Federal Home Loan Mortgage, known as Freddie Mac, slipped 2 5/8, to 84 1/2.
Tobacco stocks also finished in minus territory, as traders worried about litigation prospects. Philip Morris closed at 89 3/8, down 1 1/4; RJR Nabisco ended at 29 3/4, off 3/8, and UST finished trading at 31 3/4, down 3/8.
Gold issues turned lower in line with gold prices. Newmont Mining slid 1 3/8, to 57 7/8; Echo Bay Mines dropped 1/8, to 13 7/8, and Barrick Gold gave up 3/8, to 31.
Some airline stocks were higher, with the Dow Jones transportation average adding 3.29 points, to 2,171.23. Delta Air Lines rose 3/8, to 80 1/2; Trans World Airlines gained 5/8, to 22 1/8, and Alaska Air advanced 1/2, to 29 5/8.
Oil service issues remained strong. Schlumberger closed at 86, up 1 3/4; Sonat Offshore finished at 54, up 3 3/4, and Baker Hughes ended at 29 5/8, up 1.
Paper stocks also did well. Georgia-Pacific jumped 1 1/4, to 70; Boise Cascade gained 3/8, to 41 1/4, and International Paper rose 3/4, to 39 1/4.

HEADLINE: Rehnquist Joins Fray on Rulings, Defending Judicial Independence

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 9

 BODY:
Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, as oblique as some other Federal judges have been direct in response to the recent tide of political criticism of sitting judges and their decisions, said today that the country's history demonstrated how important it was that Federal judges should never be threatened with removal because of their rulings.
Judicial independence is "one of the crown jewels of our system of government," the Chief Justice said in a speech at the law school of American University here. While judges should not be above criticism, he said, the "guiding principle of the House of Representatives and the Senate" from the earliest years has been that impeachment and removal of judges should be reserved for criminal conduct and not judicial acts. 
 The Chief Justice, who wrote a book on this theme in 1992 and has spoken frequently about judicial independence, did not refer explicitly to the current context in which attacking Federal judges has become an early theme of the Presidential election campaign.
But because the question of rulings from the bench and judicial selection have become campaign issues, the remarks of Chief Justice Rehnquist took on added resonance.
Indeed, Senator Bob Dole the presumed Republican Presidential nominee, suggested during a campaign appearance last month that a Federal District Judge in New York, Harold Baer Jr., should be impeached for a ruling that evidence in a drug case was the product of an invalid search by the New York City police in Washington Heights and could not be used in court.
President Clinton's spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, at the same time refused to rule out the possibility that the President might seek Judge Baer's resignation. The judge last week reversed his initial ruling after a new hearing.
In a highly unusual statement issued on March 28 by the chief judge of the Federal appeals court in New York, Jon O. Newman, and three of his predecessors labeled the criticism of Judge Baer an "extraordinary intimidation."
If Chief Justice Rehnquist meant to refer in his speech to these events, he did so by delicate indirection. He recounted, as he did in his 1992 book, "Grand Inquests" (William Morrow), the 1805 Senate trial of Justice Samuel Chase, who had been impeached by the House of Representatives for several rulings he made while sitting as a trial judge.
While a majority of the Senators convicted Justice Chase on one impeachment count, the vote fell short of the necessary two-thirds.
"This decision by the Senate was enormously important in securing the kind of judicial independence contemplated by Article III" of the Constitution, Chief Justice Rehnquist said in the text of his speech tonight at the centennial celebration of the Washington College of Law, the law school of American University.
He said the episode gave much-needed "assurance to Federal judges that their judicial acts -- their rulings from the bench -- would not be a basis for removal from office by impeachment and conviction. And that has been the guiding principle of the House of Representatives and the Senate from that day to this; Federal judges have been impeached and convicted -- happily, only a very few -- but it has been for criminal conduct such as tax evasion, perjury, and the like."
In his discussion of historical threats to judicial independence, the Chief Justice also evoked President Franklin D. Roosevelt's attempt to pack the Court. The plan, which the Senate rejected in 1937, was Roosevelt's effort to gain control of a hostile Supreme Court and would have permitted him to expand the Court's membership to as many as 15 Justices.
"Although Roosevelt lost that battle," the Chief Justice said, "he eventually won the war by serving three full terms as President and appointing eight of the nine members of the Court. This simply shows that there is a wrong way and a right way to go about putting a popular imprint on the judiciary."

HEADLINE: Focus Is Jobs At Expo for 50-Plus Set

BYLINE: By ELAINE LOUIE 

 BODY:
IN this era of downsizing, what do people 50 and older want most?
Jobs, say the organizers of the Fifty Plus Expo, which will take place on Sunday and Monday at the Crowne Plaza Hotel at 48th Street and Broadway. 
 While the symposium will include workshops on health, exercise, investing and even sex, 16 of the 50 seminars will be devoted to ways of figuring out new career options.
"The reality is that people 50 and older are the most vulnerable group in the employment world, the highest paid, the most experienced and the first to go when the mergers take place and the companies are being downsized," said Julie Frank, the producer of the conference. "The world, however, is a good world, if they're prepared to be creative and flexible."
Although the symposium is not a job fair, Ms. Frank said, there will be information about opportunities. "Gap Kids is looking to hire people over 50 to work in their stores," she said, "and two companies who do medical billing will be looking for people to buy their franchises, because people can do this work out of their homes."
What is clearly a growing occupation is home health care. "In anything to do with the aging population, there is projected to be growth," said Kate Wendleton, the director of the Five O'Clock Club, a national group that teaches strategies in job searches; she will also speak at the symposium. Health-care companies are expected to need salespeople, administrators and financial experts.
The key to finding a job is flexibility and preparation, Ms. Wendleton said. You should plan to spend at least two months studying your target industry as if you were in graduate school, she added.
Even people who are in their 40's and employed are not safe from downsizing, said Dr. Lydia Bronte, a gerontologist and the author of "The Longevity Factor" (HarperCollins, 1993). "If you're in your 40's, you should start making alternative plans for yourself," she said, "because if you're caught in downsizing, you have an idea of what you want to do."
Health will also be an issue at the symposium. Dr. Christine K. Cassel, the chairwoman of the department of geriatrics at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan, says she will urge people in their 80's and 90's (and, of course, younger) to swim or take brisk walks of about two miles a day, four or five times a week. "Physical activity staves off osteoporosis, improves cardiac function, lowers blood pressure and maintains postural stability," she said.
Admission to the symposium is $10 a day; $2 discount coupons are available at Duane Reade drugstores. Information: (212) 631-7547.

HEADLINE: The Korea Divide

BYLINE: By Selig S. Harrison; Selig S. Harrison is a senior associate of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
North Korea's dangerous posturing in the demilitarized zone has dramatized the need to replace the 1953 armistice, which has kept a shaky peace between the two Koreas, with a new system that reflects post-cold-war realignments.
When the pact was signed, the North was a military base for the Soviet Union and China. Now Russia and China have much closer economic and political ties with South Korea than with the North, and the North has urgently sought to normalize relations with the United States. 
 Kim Jong Il's regime has scrupulously honored its 1994 nuclear-freeze agreement with Washington, and has just agreed to discuss American concerns about its missile program next week in Berlin.
For two years, North Korea has appealed in vain for talks at Panmunjom with American generals on ways to replace the armistice with a more stable system -- one that is compatible with the improved relations envisioned in the nuclear-freeze accord. In 1995, the Pentagon did permit preliminary low-level contacts with North Korean officers in the DMZ. But pressed by Seoul, which opposes closer ties between America and the North, Washington called off the talks in September before any generals met.
Shortly after this, I met with Gen. Ri Chan Bok, the North Korean Army's representative at Panmunjom. His Government , he said, wants a two-track peacekeeping system in which a Mutual Security Commission composed of military officers from North Korea and America would operate alongside the North-South Military Commission, which was negotiated in 1992 but never instituted.
North Korea no longer insists on a peace treaty with America that excludes the South, he said, but it does believe that the armistice must be replaced and that American forces should remain in the South on their own rather than under the United Nations Command.
Explaining this significant reversal of policy on American forces, another official told me: "We must think of the impact of the withdrawal of U. S. troops on the balance of power in the region. We are particularly concerned that if U. S. troops pull out of Korea, Japan will rearm immediately."
Currently, 35,000 American troops are in the South to defend it against aggression, but the North now wants them to stabilize the entire Korean peninsula. The system that the North proposes "will help to prevent any threat to peace from either the South or North," said Kang Sok Ju, the First Deputy Foreign Minister.
America wants the North to talk with the South about replacing the armistice, even though the South did not sign it. Pyongyang is justified in arguing that Washington must participate in new peacekeeping arrangements. By the same token, Washington should insist that all military issues involving only the two Koreas must be handled by the projected North-South Military Commission.
Instead of refusing to talk with the North at the DMZ, America should put forward the terms under which it would be willing to replace the armistice, phase out the United Nations Command and set up a new system. America could insist that a trilateral coordinating body be established so that the North could not drive a wedge between Washington and Seoul. Above all, America could propose tension-reduction measures, including a three-way agreement to reduce offensive weapons along the 38th parallel.
The Clinton Administration cannot ask the Security Council to wind up the United Nations role unless the concerns that led the United Nations to intervene are addressed in meaningful arms control arrangements.

HEADLINE: Eonomic Scene;
No growth, no inflation is fine for bonds but how about people?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
A CHILLING rise in interest rates has grabbed the financial headlines in recent weeks. But for many Americans who are not shopping for a mortgage or speculating on the price of the 30-year Treasury bond, what matters are the bread and butter issues: economic growth, jobs, consumer prices. And by those criteria, the auguries still look pretty good.
How does this cheery view square with the anxious bond market? Either the market is "wrong" in the sense that it has overreacted to insubstantial data hinting at inflation ahead, or the interests of bond owners are currently at odds with those of people who earn their bread in offices, stores and factories. 
 Start with the explanation for what has been called a correction in the bond market, which has pushed up long-term yields to an eight-month high -- almost a full percentage point since January. George Perry, an economist at the Brookings Institution, argues that bond traders are responding to three factors that could signal rising inflation: the virtual collapse of prospects for deficit reduction anytime soon, the upward creep of grain and oil prices, and the rapid growth in employment in the first quarter of 1996.
With hindsight, it is hard to imagine why so many people expected a deficit deal in an election year. But it would have been asking a lot of bond traders to predict the future better than professional politicians. And it is likely that budget problems will sustain what many economists see as long-term interest rates that are well above the historical norm. Score one for the bond market.
On the other hand, inflation fears driven by food and fuel prices seem unwarranted. Commodity prices, notes Bruce Steinberg of Merrill Lynch, are indeed at an eight-year high. But commodities simply are not a large enough component for changes of this magnitude to make a big difference in the overall cost of living. Nor are rising prices buttressed by underlying constraints on capacity or rising production costs that would suggest more increases ahead.
As important, there is little evidence suggesting that higher commodity prices are being factored into the inflationary expectations of business or labor. "We've had anecdotal reports of wage pressures for the last three or four years," Mr. Steinberg says, "but no numbers showing wages rising faster than productivity."
Of course, the proximate cause of tumbling bond prices was the report of spectacular growth in jobs in February and the unexpected strength of the labor market in the March data, which were released last week. If employment continues to grow at a rate even close to the 400,000 average for these two months -- triple the actual growth of the working age population -- the Federal Reserve would undoubtedly intervene to cool the economy by raising interest rates.
But here, too, Mr. Steinberg thinks the bond market has become carried away. The meaning of the new numbers is in doubt because of problems of adjusting for seasonal changes in employment, especially in the winter. He notes that one need not look back any further than the first quarter of 1995 to find comparably strong employment statistics that coincided with very modest rates of economic growth.
At worst, then, the bond market is reacting to unanticipated strength in the economy, which will be squashed once the Fed recognizes the phenomenon and tightens credit. More likely, Mr. Perry argues, the numbers are simply confirming that the economy is bouncing back from a pause in growth that just a few months ago seemed to presage a recession.
What's missing from the instant analysis of this burp in bond prices -- indeed, what has been missing for several years in comparable events -- has been a sense of priorities. The bond market is indifferent to economic growth or employment or the distribution of income. Virtually all that matters to the pricing of Treasury securities (and other bonds that are virtually free of risk of default) is the expected rate of inflation. The best of possible worlds for bond owners is one with slow growth and rock-stable prices, which is not the best of circumstances for anyone else.
Economists and most policy makers understand this, but in recent years it has been convenient to ignore the obvious. One of the few ways anyone suffers immediate pain from big budget deficits is through lower bond prices and higher mortgage rates. Hence those who see deficit reduction as the ultimate policy challenge in a myopic political environment have welcomed the casual adoption of bond prices as an index of economic health.
The risk is that policy makers will forget that their association with bond speculators is merely a marriage of convenience. Actually, it's more than a risk: Consider the defensive tone of the Clinton Administration in announcing that 750,000 jobs have been created in the last two months.

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
New Pieces Of the Past For 2 Held In Bombing

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
Why did they do it, if they did it? Hints have been emerging since the arrests of Timothy James McVeigh and Terry Lynn Nichols in the bomb explosion that destroyed the Federal Building in Oklahoma City. Now, with the approach of the first anniversary of the worst mass murder in American history, ABC News adds new details from interviews with the accused men's family members and buddies to draw the fullest profiles that television has yet offered.
In large part, they seem to be off-the-rack case histories: Both came from poor and broken families. By society's standards and perhaps their own, both were failures. Both were drawn to conspiracy theories that attributed their hardships to nefarious and all-powerful forces. 
 "Rage and Betrayal: The Lives of Tim McVeigh and Terry Nichols" begins in childhood. Most attention is given to Mr. McVeigh. His father, Bill McVeigh, interviewed by Peter Jennings, tells of a "regular" family life, with Tim as the most enterprising of his three children. But when Tim was 16, his mother left home, a desertion that Mr. Jennings cites, a touch glibly perhaps, as a turning point: "He took to guns and what is sometimes called survivalism."
Only in the Army did the young man find success, for a time, along with a kindred spirit in the shape of Terry Nichols, whose hatred of Washington is attributed to the loss of the family farm in the 1980's. By the time he joined the Army, Mr. Jennings says, "He was already a three-time loser: as a farmer, as a salesman and as a husband." He found ideological comfort in a fringe group known as the Patriot Movement.
Somewhere along his rocky path, Mr. McVeigh discovered "The Turner Diaries," a novel about resistance to the United States Government that was becoming a bible of the far-far radical right. Mr. Jennings quotes a passage: "We drive a truck into the main freight entrance of the F.B.I. building and blow it up . . . we can wreak havoc in all the offices . . . several hundred people will be killed."
The program suggests that the killing of a White Separatist's wife and child in Ruby Ridge, Idaho, in 1992 and the storming of the Branch Davidian compound in Waco, Tex., in 1993 lighted the fuse for the Oklahoma City explosion. The buildup of rage until it became betrayal is plausible and disturbing: Mr. McVeigh and Mr. Nichols have plenty of company among Americans who have been hit by family breakdown, economic pressures and bad luck and are susceptible to the rant of talk radio and the constructions of conspiracy mongers. It only confirms the laws of probability that one or two of them should have acted out their anger and their fantasies.
 
Dateline NBC
Oklahoma City: One Year Later'
NBC, Friday night at 9
Back in his home state for the first time since the bombing, Bill Moyers talks with survivors and people who lost children and parents in the blast. Along with giving the victims their say and stirring viewer sympathies, Mr. Moyers is out to make the point that the bombing was a political act, fueled by hatemongers, against the Federal Government and all its works.
Unlike the ABC program, the evidence here consists mainly of the star's preachments and the victims' feelings. The hour becomes more of a report with the brief appearance of members of the Oklahoma Citizens Militia and, especially, two young men who have fled the violence of city life and what they see as Government corruption. But mostly it's a duet between Mr. Moyers and the good people.
In some of tomorrow night's exchanges, the interviewer might as well be interviewing himself. He asks a HUD employee, "Do you like your work?" She replies, "Yes, I do, I do." He follows up, "What about it do you like?" She replies, "I like being able to help people." He comments: "And people like you used to be known as public servants. And now you're referred to as graceless bureaucrats." Although fairly new to "Dateline," Mr. Moyers proves a quick study of the newsmagazine style.

ABC, tonight at 9:30

HEADLINE: Productivity In 1995 Was Best in 3 Years

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 10

 BODY:
Productivity in the American workplace had its best showing in three years last year but was faltering as the year ended.
Many analysts say that productivity rebounded slightly in the quarter just ended, held back by winter weather and the effects of a strike at General Motors that rippled through related industries like suppliers. 
 Robert G. Dederick, an economic consultant at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago, said big employment gains in February and March combined with continued sluggish output to keep productivity from growing faster. He cited "the impact of the weather and the G.M. strike."
Nonfarm productivity -- output per number of hours worked -- grew 1.1 percent in 1995, the largest gain since a 3.2 percent advance in 1992, the Labor Department said today.
While that was well above the previous two years, growth was less than half the annual increases in the 1950's and 1960's. Productivity increased just two-tenths of 1 percent in 1993 and five-tenths of 1 percent in 1994.
Many economists consider productivity a key element of Americans' standard of living, asserting that increased efficiency means that businesses can increase their workers' pay without having to raise prices. With a lack of productivity, businesses would be reluctant to increase prices to pay for higher wages, fearing that the added cost would price their products out of the market.
Economists argue over the cause of recent productivity gains. Some contend that the improvement results from greater efficiency as businesses reduce and restructure their work forces and invest in high technology. Others maintain that it is a result of the economic recovery and that as the business cycle levels off, productivity gains will slow.
Output rose 2.7 percent in 1995 after jumping 4 percent a year earlier, while hours worked were up 1.6 percent following a 3.4 percent advance.
But in the final three months of 1995, productivity slumped 1 percent as output dropped sharply, to a seasonally adjusted rate of six-tenths of 1 percent growth from 4.7 percent in the July-September quarter. Hours worked rose at an annualized rate of 1.6 percent, down from 2.9 percent in the third quarter.
Unit labor costs, typically two-thirds of the cost of a product, increased 2.5 percent, faster than the gains of 1.6 percent in 1994 and 2.1 percent in 1993. In the fourth quarter, they were accelerating at a 3.8 percent rate.
Hourly compensation rose seven-tenths of 1 percent during the year when adjusted for inflation, including a rate of four-tenths of a percent from October through December.
The report showed that productivity in manufacturing remained relatively strong, increasing 3.7 percent during the year compared with 4.2 percent in 1994. Factory productivity had grown 2.1 percent in 1993.

HEADLINE: Wild Pitch

BYLINE: By Roger G. Noll; Roger G. Noll is a visiting fellow at the Brookings Institution.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Even at a time when major league sports have become a cartoon of financial excess, the proposed new home for the Yankees is breathtaking in its audacity. Excluding land value, a multipurpose mausoleum on Manhattan's West Side would cost a billion dollars.
The debate has centered on two questions: Are sports facilities economically worthwhile? And should the stadium be single-purpose or multipurpose? A more fundamental question is why cities provide large subsidies to teams in the first place. 
 The Yankees have little economic effect on New York City. True, most fans would never visit the South Bronx were it not for the team. But few tourists come to New York just to see the Yankees. Thus, the Yankees generate a huge increase in economic activity within 100 yards of the Stadium, but not within the metropolitan area.
Nearly all spending at the Stadium is simply shifted from other forms of entertainment like restaurants and movies. Yes, the Yankees do draw suburbanites into the city, but many of these people would spend money in Manhattan or go to Mets games if the Yankees were not an option.
The city does make money by taxing tickets and concessions, but such revenues wouldn't come close to covering the Stadium's debt service. Even if the Jets agreed to play their home games on the West Side and the two teams combined drew four million fans a year, the city would need to collect an unrealistic $20 in taxes from each fan just to meet the mortgage payments.
 Independent studies of sports facilities invariably conclude that they provide no significant economic benefits. A sports team does increase overall income in a community slightly, but the increase never offsets the stadium's financing and operating costs. And because a team has relatively few (but very highly paid) employees, it usually causes overall employment in a city to fall because it can drive other entertainment businesses to cut back or close.
Stadiums are bad investments, which is why the teams themselves are never willing to pay for them. New York City would generate more cash by putting the money in a savings account.
Assuming that New York decides to build the stadium, a multipurpose facility would make the most financial sense -- if the Jets and Yankees would agree to share it, which is unlikely. Single-purpose stadiums are more attractive and draw more fans. And the teams want their own stadiums so they can control and profit from other events in them. The city, of course, gains nothing by letting the teams have their way.
Why do cities pour hundreds of millions into new stadiums? With intense competition for sports franchises, not even New York can keep a team without subsidizing it. New Jersey and New York have at various times fought over the Giants, Jets, Yankees and Mets. The sad thing is that the states need not be competitors: Fans could easily support a third team in both football and baseball. But each league is a monopoly, doing what monopolists do best: making the product scarce to hike up the price.
There is a far cheaper way to keep the Yankees. Bribe them. A new stadium could give the Yankees an additional $10 million in profits each year. So instead of spending $80 million annually to finance and operate a new stadium, New York could just hand the Yankees $10 million. Or, even better, the city could pay $100,000 for each game won, with a million-dollar bonus for winning the pennant.
This plan would save the city money, improve the Yankees' bottom line and benefit fans, who would be less likely to have a team that collapsed in the stretch.

HEADLINE: Toronto-Dominion to Buy Waterhouse Investor Services

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER 

 BODY:
Toronto-Dominion Bank said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Waterhouse Investor Services, which operates a chain of discount brokerage offices in the United States, in a stock-and-cash deal valued at about $525 million.
Under the proposal, holders of Waterhouse stock could choose either to receive $38 a share in cash or to exchange each Waterhouse share for $38 of Toronto-Dominion common stock. But Toronto-Dominion will not redeem more than 35 percent of Waterhouse's outstanding stock for cash, the companies said. 
 Waterhouse's stock surged after the deal was announced, gaining $3.25 to close at $36.25 on the New York Stock Exchange. On the Toronto Stock Exchange, Toronto-Dominion's shares slipped 50 cents (Canadian) to close at $23.50 .
Waterhouse Investor Services, which operates 79 branch offices in 37 states and the District of Columbia, is among the largest discount brokers in the United States. Green Investor Services, a discount brokerage chain owned by Toronto-Dominion Bank, controls more than 70 percent of discount transactions in that country.
Waterhouse and Green Line will continue to operate under their current names. Together, the two concerns will have more than one million North American customers, said W. Keith Gray, the chairman of Green Line.
Mr. Grey added that over the last few months Toronto-Dominion had been actively seeking to acquire a discount brokerage business in the United States.
"The U.S. is the world's largest economy and it is going to be a great opportunity for the growth of our discount brokerage," he said.
The companies said that current management personnel would not be affected and added they they did not anticipate any layoffs due to the merger.
Lawrence M. Waterhouse, Jr., the founder of the firm that bears his name, will continue as its chairman and chief executive, the company said.
"We believe that Green Line's proven leadership as the largest discount broker in Canada, its commitment to customer service and its state-of-the-art technology will make this a winning business combination," Mr. Waterhouse said.
The $525 million purchase price paid for Waterhouse by Toronto-Dominion represents nearly 21 times the company's earnings.
The merger will be tax-free to holders of Waterhouse stock if they choose to receive Toronto-Dominion common shares in exchange for their existing shares.
In addition, Toronto-Dominion said that it would seek a listing on the New York Stock Exchange for its common shares. The bank said it would account for the merger as a purchase transaction and said that it did not expect that it would dilute earnings either this year or the next.

HEADLINE: A Lawsuit in Japan Seeks to Ban Noisy Night Flights at U.S. Base

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 10

 BODY:
More than 3,100 Japanese who live near an American air base filed a lawsuit today against the Japanese and American Governments, demanding a ban on night flights and $30 million in damages.
The suit, while unlikely to succeed, is the first of its kind against the United States Government. It sours the atmosphere a bit in the prelude to President Clinton's state visit to Japan next week to hail the American-Japanese security partnership. 
 Those who brought the suit, who live near the Yokota base in the Tokyo suburbs, said they would also protest during Mr. Clinton's visit over noise on the base.
Still, such opposition to American bases is not expected to undermine seriously the American-Japanese summit meeting. Indeed, other recent events -- like the Chinese military exercises in the Taiwan Strait and the North Korean intrusions into the demilitarized zone -- seem to have bolstered support for the American military presence in Japan.
Mr. Clinton's visit, from Tuesday to Thursday, is not expected to focus on the trade disputes that have often divided the two countries. Instead, the summit meeting is to accentuate the positive and reaffirm mutual support for the security relationship between the two most powerful economies in the world.
In particular, the two leaders are expected to endorse efforts to make the American military bases less of a nuisance to their Japanese neighbors, particularly on the southern island of Okinawa. Opposition among Okinawans to the bases, which take up 20 percent of their island, surged after the rape of a sixth-grade Okinawan girl last fall. Three American servicemen were convicted in a Japanese court for the attack.
"We have taken the outrage in Okinawa as a signal that the United States and Japan must very seriously look at our presence on Okinawa in a way that reduces irritants," Walter F. Mondale, the American Ambassador in Tokyo, said today. Mr. Mondale said he expected "one of the most solid state visits in the history of the relationship."
While the strongest opposition to American bases has been on Okinawa, the suit filed today came from people living in the greater Tokyo area. The Yokota base is one of the most important American installations in Japan, but it is in a residential area and the neighbors complain in particular about the noise from night flights.
The plaintiffs in the suit are demanding a ban on flights between 9 P.M. and 7 A.M., as well as $30 million in damages. In the past, local residents have sued the Japanese Government for failing to protect them from the noise. In 1993 the Japanese Supreme Court ruled that they could win compensation from the Japanese Government, but it refused to order a ban on night flights because it said they arose from the United States-Japan Security Treaty and were beyond the jurisdiction of the courts.

HEADLINE: Need to Cut Costs? Order Out;
Outsourcing Saves Money, but Labor Is Frustrated

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: ASHEVILLE, N.C.

 BODY:
The anti-lock brake systems look out of place as they slide by almost silently on conveyor belts at the ITT Industries factory here. From the spotless white floors to the cool, filtered air to the young workers in white hair nets and white plastic laboratory coats, the factory seems more suited to the production of computer components than auto parts.
Far different are the cavernous buildings in Dayton, Ohio, filled with endless rows of clanking, roaring machinery, where the General Motors Corporation makes brakes for nearly all its cars and trucks. A few rusting fans hang from the exposed support beams, the only relief when temperatures soar above 100 degrees in the summer. The floors are concrete painted black, and the air smells of oil and sweat. The workers, mostly graying men in their 40's and 50's, wear greasy orange jump suits or blue jeans -- and nobody has a hairnet. 
 Across America, executives at big companies like G.M. are looking at their less efficient operations with dismay and trying to find ways to buy more parts from low-cost outside vendors like ITT. By buying more of their parts, executives can save money and keep their businesses competitive; for them, the difference between G.M.'s factories in Dayton and ITT's plant here is the difference between yesterday and tomorrow.
But for many workers, the executives' tomorrow is a frightening prospect. G.M.'s unionized employees in Dayton earn about $19 an hour, and when they get sick they can go to almost any doctor, paying no deductible and a minuscule co-payment. ITT's nonunion workers earn $9.90 an hour and choose their doctors from the lists of two health maintenance organizations.
The contrast between the two brake plants makes stark the logic that has compelled so many manufacturers to shift jobs to low-cost, outside suppliers over the last decade, as well as the uphill -- if not quixotic -- resistance from labor unions.
Because of the United Automobile Workers union's success in driving up wages and benefits at the Big Three auto makers, the savings from buying outside parts are especially large in the auto industry. Wages and fringe benefits at the average auto parts factory are only a third of what the Big Three pay their unionized workers. As a result, the parts industry has become a front line in the battle between management and labor over corporate downsizing.
But outsourcing is a prime cost-saving strategy throughout the economy, from the insurance company that replaces its security guards and cafeteria workers with outside contractors to manufacturing giants like the Boeing Company, which buys airplane parts from factories in Japan, Mexico and Xian, China, that its own employees once fabricated in the United States.
With the most to lose, labor unions have fought a largely unsuccessful rear guard action against the shifting of jobs to outside contractors. In settling a strike last year, Boeing pledged only to look for other jobs for workers displaced by foreign parts purchases and to notify its union of future plans for the purchase of outside parts.
Similarly, the 17-day strike last month at G.M.'s Dayton brake factories stemmed largely from worker objections to four G.M. contracts to buy outside brake parts. G.M. settled the strike with a pledge to hire 417 more workers in Dayton and inform the union about future plans for parts purchases; the four contracts remain in place.
Indeed, Timothy D. Leuliette, the president of ITT Industries' automotive operations, declared in a speech earlier this year that it was inevitable that auto makers would buy more parts from outside suppliers, because the public was demanding affordable cars. "Fighting to defend higher-cost jobs in an industry undergoing strategic restructuring ultimately can have little success," Mr. Leuliette said.
The U.A.W. contends that the problem lies with corporations that would rather turn to outside vendors than invest the money in their old factories.
"They're fooling themselves when they say we've got to compete with other factories that have the best techniques, that have the best manufacturing processes," said Richard Shoemaker, the U.A.W. vice president who oversees relations with G.M. "They have an obligation to put money in the plants."
The issues are seldom drawn as clearly as by comparing ITT's factory here with G.M.'s two brake plants in Dayton.
Morale is high at the ITT factory, partly because of a collegial relationship between managers and the nonunionized workers. Walk the immaculate factory floor here and the cheerfulness is unmistakable.
"I like it a lot," said Deanna Cayton, a 26-year-old worker who paused as she assembled brake valves. "The people are great, the work's not hard; it's clean, very clean."
W. Steve Dickerson, the plant manager here, dresses much like his workers, wearing a short-sleeve green polo shirt on one recent day and putting on a hairnet and white plastic laboratory coat before going on the factory floor. He knows the workers by name and talks easily with them about their families.
ITT manufactures brakes for all the Big Three auto makers. When the factory won a Ford Motor Company quality award last year, ITT spent $50,000 on a lavish party in which Mr. Dickerson and other managers dressed in tuxedos and served roast beef to the 900 workers.
Yet ITT's intentions in throwing the party were not just philanthropic. "In the next two weeks, we picked up $200,000 in productivity," Mr. Dickerson said.
Even before last month's strike, morale was terrible in Dayton. Some workers there refer to the factories as the "state prison." They labor under the watchful eye of security guards and foremen. Few workers smile or wave as Daniel E. Warrell, the factory manager, strides by in his dark blue pin stripe suit.
The floors in Dayton are filthy, with oily slime in spots. When an aide to Mr. Warrell reached down recently to pick up an oil-sodden, crushed cardboard box in an aisle, the factory manager waved him away. "That's O.K.," he said. He later apologized for his factory's dirty appearance, for which he blamed the need to bring production back to normal quickly after the strike.
Another reason is that Dayton factories do produce some mechanical parts not made in Asheville, contributing to difference in noise and dirt between the factories.
While the Dayton factories had a cookout last year, there were no parties or big staff gatherings when the strike ended. "Management had meetings," Mr. Warrell said, but relied on the foremen to talk to the assembly workers.
The sheer complexity of the union work rules agreed to by management over the years at the G.M. factories make management's own job much more difficult. Partly because the Dayton factories produce a wider range of parts, but mostly because of the work rules, the G.M. brake operations have 35 different categories of semiskilled workers, including those who work on the assembly line. There are also 16 categories of skilled workers, like electricians.
ITT has only two categories of semiskilled workers in Asheville, and skilled workers are on salary. The company buys most of its equipment from outside vendors and asks employees to change work assignments frequently, partly to keep their jobs interesting. "We never get into 'It's not my job,' " Mr. Dickerson said.
The difference in labor-management relations is particularly striking when it comes to the sharing of information.
In Dayton, one of the strikers' demands was that G.M. begin telling them more about future brake plans. But in Asheville, without strikes or union contracts, Mr. Dickerson makes monthly presentations to assembly line workers. He provided a detailed appraisal in late March of the factory's contracts and business plans for the next several years, even discussing a $650 million Ford contract that ITT did not disclose publicly until the following week.
But while the Asheville factory may offer a much more pleasant, open work environment, the pay and benefits are considerably inferior to G.M.'s. Workers in Dayton earn an average of $69,000 a year, including close to $30,000 in overtime from working six- and seven-day weeks. ITT's workers earn around $20,000 a year, with little overtime available.
Yet the workers here have few complaints about their pay. One of the reasons is a basic shift in American society: the young, married employees typically have working spouses, so they have two incomes to support their households. By contrast, many U.A.W. workers in Dayton still support their families on a single paycheck.
But the bigger reason for workers' acceptance of lower pay here is that the burden of history weighs much less heavily on Asheville, where pay scales have long been much lower than in the industrial Midwest.
The Asheville factory stands on land that used to belong to the Biltmore Estate, which surrounds the 250-room French chateau built in 1895 by George Vanderbilt as a bucolic summer retreat. ITT was the first big auto parts company to build a factory in the area, setting up operations in 1989. The main competitor then for industrial workers was a Burlington Industries textile factory that paid $7.50 an hour and closed in 1991. At $9.90 an hour, the wages at ITT seem generous.
"The pay is great," said Malina Mcasee, a 39-year-old former Burlington worker, as she used tweezers to insert a pin into each anti-lock brake passing on the assembly line. The health care benefits are also the best in the area, said Ms. Cayton, who is expecting a baby in mid-May.
The burden of history is very different at G.M.'s factories. Dayton has been a high-wage, unionized town of skilled industrial workers for generations. One of the G.M. plants bears a small historical marker noting that the Wright Brothers built some of their first commercial airplanes at the site.
In the late 1980's, G.M. was a pioneer in making anti-lock brakes, and the units turned out by the Dayton factories rely more on mechanical parts than the electronic gear at the heart of ITT's slightly less expensive but equally reliable brakes.
Now, G.M. plans to install a "clean room" production line for highly sophisticated electronic brakes inside one of the Dayton plants by 1998. And while that will not eliminate the differences between the Dayton and Asheville operations, it likely means more U.A.W. members will be wearing hairnets.
