LENGTH: 1441 words

HEADLINE: HOUSE PROUD;
The Challenge: Life in 35 Rooms

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY 

DATELINE: IRVINGTON-ON-HUDSON , N.Y.

 BODY:
ONE day this winter, Helena C. Doley was noting how her snow-covered view would turn leafy green come spring. Then she winced. Her eyes had wandered from the picturesque scenery outside the Palladian glass doors in the dining room to the wall above, and settled on a seeping white foamy mass that had stained the crimson paint on the wall.
"Honey, did you see this?" she called, stifling a screech. Her husband, Harold, entered the spacious but tenebrous dining room and took up the lament. "And we just fixed the roof," he said. 
 For the last three years, the Doleys have been restoring Villa Lewaro, the 35-room country house of Madam C. J. Walker, as she called herself, who made a fortune in the early 1900's with her hair-growing cream and other hair-care products for women of color. She was the first black woman to become a millionaire in the United States. The legend of her stellar business success and taste for opulence lives on, not least in her country home, which was named for her daughter, A'Lelia Walker Robinson.
The three-story cream-colored Renaissance revival house was begun in 1916 by Vertner Woodson Tandy, New York State's first registered black architect; it cost about $250,000 to build and was completed in 1918, just a year before Madam Walker's death at 51.
Madam Walker's legend fascinated Mr. Doley, a New Orleans stockbroker. "She was a genius," he said, "and to walk the halls that she once walked and to sleep in the room where she once slept is a feeling that is indescribable."
The Doleys and their 18-year-old son, Aaron, have had to work to carve out personal space for themselves in what amounts to a palace.
Even for a family used to grand living -- Mr. Doley is an investment banker and a former United States ambassador and executive director of African Development Bank and Fund in Abidjan, Ivory Coast -- it is not easy for three people to settle into 35 rooms.
Although they have a show-stopping dining room, whose arched ceiling is adorned with just-restored miniature erotic aquatic scenes painted on canvas, family members usually eat their meals in the kitchen, a vast room with an institutional-size oven and refrigerator. They spend much of their time in the third-floor family room, where they have a large-screen television and billiard table. When they first moved in, they had to try their luck among its eight and a half bathrooms to find enough working showers and sinks for the three of them: most of the plumbing was not operational.
They learned quickly that a house that big can be hotter than a thousand Julys in the summer and as cold as an empty church in the dead of winter. They also learned quickly that a roof leak may go undetected for weeks if the family does not frequent certain rooms.
"I don't know how long it had been since I had been in the dining room before discovering the leak," Mrs. Doley said. "What's stranger is that I may have just overlooked it for weeks. There are so many walls here."
The couple is comfortably installed in the master bedroom, for which Mrs. Doley chose seven carefully modulated shades of gray. The master bath is still equipped with a "needle" shower that was installed by Madam Walker. Surrounded by three-quarters of a circle of spray, the bather has the feeling of being in a Jacuzzi, Mr. Doley said.
"It has been an agony of love," said Mr. Doley, 49. "I'm dealing with a passion here. I knew it was going to be a difficult task, but it's been much more involved than I originally expected."
Indeed, Mr. Doley's passion for the house runs deeper than his wife's. He was the one who had coveted the mansion for more than a decade, quietly visiting its grounds as he made plans to acquire it when he was still in training to become a broker on the New York Stock Exchange.
He felt a connection with Madam Walker, a shrewd investor as well as a great political advocate who spoke out against lynchings and provided crucial financial support to the nascent National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
He finally bought the home in 1993, after bargaining for two and a half years, he said. But his wife cried in terror over the prospect of maintaining such a dwelling. And she cried again when they moved in. But she has been converted -- and a live-in butler helps with the day-to-day running of things.
Mrs. Doley, 49, a guidance counselor at the Mount Pleasant Cottage School in Pleasantville, is overseeing the interior decorating, consulting Madam Walker's great-great-granddaughter, A'Lelia Perry Bundles, as well as archives and history books for details of the original decor. Careful not to allow the home to become her raison d'etre, she said, she decorates one room at a time, which accounts for the its sparse furnishings. A wrong decorating move would be like pouring flat beer into a champagne flute.
"Part of the thing that keeps me going is seeing little projects come to fruition," she said. "That gets you ready for the next project."
In spite of its age, the house is well preserved because it has changed hands only a few times. When Madam Walker's daughter -- whose legendary parties kept the house roaring all through the 1920's -- died in 1931, she left Villa Lewaro to the N.A.A.C.P., which sold it in 1932 to a fraternal organization.
In the 1980's, a developer wanted to buy the house, level it and build condominiums. But it was saved by a 250-year-old Chinese ginkgo and a 300-year-old American beechnut, the very trees that had originally lured Madam Walker to the property: the village has an ordinance that protects trees. It is now on the National Register of Historic Places.
The next owners began the restoration effort, rebuilding the portico, recasting delicate plaster decorations missing from the ceilings and determining original colors.
When Madam Walker was building the house, she created a stir. "Impossible," residents exclaimed, according to an article in The New York Times Magazine on Nov. 4, 1917. "No woman of her race could afford such a place."
Madam Walker built the house as a showpiece, and with the help of eight servants she used it for entertaining prominent people of her day, especially the politically active. She also built it as proof of what an ambitious person could accomplish.
Born Sarah Breedlove to former slaves in 1867 in a cabin in the northern Louisiana hamlet of Delta, Madam Walker started out in hardship; both her parents had died by the time she was 7. She first married at 14 and worked as a laundress.
But as she labored over washtubs, larger questions began to haunt her, she said later -- "What are you going to do when your back gets stiff and you are old? Who is going to look after you and your little girl?"
Later, she would tell audiences fascinated by her ascent that the answer came in a dream in which a secret hair-conditioning formula was revealed. She spent years trying to realize that dream, finally successfully marketing her Wonderful Hair Grower and other products. Black women made the products an instant success. (C. J. Walker was her second husband.)
Madam Walker's operation was based in Indianapolis, but in 1912 she made her home in Harlem. Tandy designed an Adam-style town house for her on West 136th Street, complete with a beauty salon and school on the ground floor and three floors of living space. But Villa Lewaro was his greatest work.
The house in all its splendor sits right on Broadway, the main street of Irvington. The crescent-shaped, columned portico is flanked by two pavilions with Spanish tile hip roofs.
Along the fashionable summer-home strip, Madam Walker's three-story basic stucco house stood out from the other brick Tudor-style mansions of the Tiffanys, Rockefellers, Biddles and Carnegies.
"The real estate agents made her pay the 'black dollar,' meaning when they found out she was black, they charged her double what the land was worth in an effort to stop the purchase," said Mr. Doley, noting that she paid $60,000 for the land. "I think she wanted it close to the street because you had to pass this way on the way to Albany. And everyone who passed by had to see this house."
"At times you get the sense that you are living in a museum," Mr. Doley said. "The other day, someone rang the bell to ask if they could have a tour of the house. We were in the middle of dinner. I have no regrets about owning the house, but sometimes it can be very overwhelming."
Mrs. Doley added: "It's our home as well as a historic landmark. We have to find a happy medium between what is authentic for the house versus what is comfortable for us."

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds Still Receiving Big Cash Flow

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
While stock and bond markets continued to suffer a rough patch yesterday, evidence mounted that investors were not losing their appetites for stock and bond mutual funds. Far from it: A mutual fund trade group estimated that investors poured more cash into stock and bond funds in the first quarter of 1996 than in the first nine months of last year.
The Investment Company Institute, a mutual fund trade group, estimated that stock and bond funds took in a net $23 billion in March. While that was down slightly from February's total, it also supported contentions by mutual fund companies that individual investors did not flee the markets after a sharp decline in stock prices early last month. 
 "Investors have had a very minimal reaction to short-term drops in the stock market," said Mark Geist, president of Montgomery Asset Management, a fund company based in San Francisco. While the company may see cash flows slow down for a day or two in reaction to short-term trends like that seen in the last few days, Mr. Geist said, "it's really not enough to take notice of. Of course, we haven't had a long-term drop to test the resolve of investors."
Yesterday, however, stocks continued to follow bonds lower. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 74.43 points, to 5,485.98, the fourth straight decline in the market bellwether. In the last four trading sessions, the Dow industrials declined 3.6 percent, with most of the loss coming since Friday, when the Labor Department reported that for the second month, American companies added more jobs last month than analysts expected. [Page D8.]
Bond prices fell to drive the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond up to 6.94 percent from 6.83 percent -- the closest the benchmark measure of long-term interest rates has been to 7 percent since last August. Prices and yields move in opposite directions from each other. [Page D18.]
While it is too early to tell whether the most recent downturn in the market will have any effect, a newsletter that tracks mutual funds says that a record amount of money flowed into stock funds in the first week of April. In any case, the rising tide of cash into mutual funds shows no sign of weakening. Even executives at fund companies have expressed surprise over the strength of the trend, and market analysts have puzzled over the source of those waves of fresh cash.
In addition to the possibility that investors have simply started saving more, another source may stem from tax refunds, which appear to be significantly higher this year than last. The Internal Revenue Service has certified tax refunds to individuals totaling $52 billion through the end of March, a 25 percent increase from 1995's level.
The stock market's activity over the last two months, while volatile, has followed a discernible pattern. Since the beginning of February, when the Dow industrials first moved above 5,400, the benchmark has traded in a range from 5,450 to 5,700. Each time the index has approached one of those ends, it has bounced in the opposite direction, making four full round trips.
That has not troubled investors, however. Most of the mutual fund cash has been flowing to stocks lately. In March, mutual funds that invest primarily in stocks took in a net $21 billion, down slightly from $21.9 billion in February and $28.9 billion in January. The first-quarter total of $71.8 billion was more than three times the net cash inflow of last year's first quarter and more than funds took in in the first seven months of 1995.
Bond funds, meanwhile, took in a net $2 billion in March, the institute estimated, about even with February's inflows but down from January's $4.3 billion of net inflows.
Together, the estimated total inflows to stock and bond funds of $80 billion in the first quarter exceeded that of any previous quarter. The former record, of $63.6 billion, was set in the third quarter of 1993, when stock and bond funds were gathering assets at a roughly equal rate.
While the most recent estimates indicate a slight slowing of demand for mutual funds since the first of the year, that is not a surprise, analysts say. Typically, the first month of each quarter is the strongest, because companies often transfer payments to retirement programs on a quarterly basis. January is typically the biggest month of all, because of annual payments into those programs. And the first quarter is generally stronger than later quarters because individuals often make contributions to Individual Retirement Accounts during that time.
One fund tracker, however, said that cash flows in the first week of April were even higher than in March -- indeed, higher than any other week in history. Market Trim Tabs, a newsletter based in Santa Rosa, Calif., reported that in the week ended April 4, stock funds took in a record $6.2 billion, above the previous weekly record of $5.2 billion, set in the first week of January.
"The liquidity measures are still very bullish," said Kevin Kelleher, research director for the newsletter. Nor have short-term market declines, like the sharp drop in stock prices in early March, worried investors. "While flows do fall off after drops like that, the market has shown it is pretty resilient, and investors come back in."
Investment analysts have also puzzled in the last week over a report from the Federal Reserve that raises questions about whether individuals truly are putting more money than ever into the stock market. The Fed's recently released Flow of Funds report shows that in 1995, total stock market activity by all sources resulted in a net sale of corporate equities of $14.1 billion.
Households have been net sellers of corporate equities nearly every year since the mid-1950's, so the fact that their sales increased last year, to $168 billion from $138 billion the previous year, is not surprising.
But the report also shows that net purchases of corporate equities by mutual funds fell to $86 billion last year, from $107 billion in 1994 and $117 billion in 1993.
According to the data from the Investment Company Institute, net inflows of cash to equity mutual funds totaled $128 billion last year, up from $119 billion the previous year. Over the same period, equity mutual funds decreased the percentage of cash they held in their portfolios, to 7.9 percent last year from 8.5 percent in 1994.
Mr. Kelleher said that the Federal Reserve data were open to broad interpretation. For example, he said, the household category contains equity of all sorts.
"If you are an individual who owns your own grocery store and you sell it, that will show up in the report" as a sale of corporate equity, he said. But the data also show that mutual funds hold a growing portion of all corporate equities, and, as Mr. Kelleher noted, funds own mostly publicly traded stocks.
According to the Fed report, mutual funds owned 13 percent of the $8.3 trillion in corporate equities in American markets last year, up from 7 percent in 1994 and 5 percent in 1993. Over the same period, the percentage held by households has remained about even, at 51 percent, while the percentage held by private pension plans has fallen to 14 percent from 17 percent in 1994 and 22 percent the previous year.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Post Sharp Drop

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Treasury prices fell sharply yesterday on growing concerns that inflation could accelerate.
The source of the market's new-found anxiety about inflation is the Commodity Research Bureau's index of 17 commodities, which is at eight-year highs. Yesterday, the index rose 3.09 points, to 258.91, led by a surge in wheat prices. Higher energy prices have also worried investors. 
 While several spikes in the bureau's index in recent years have not been accompanied by a marked increase in inflation, market participants are concerned that the recent rise in commodity prices will ultimately be passed along by producers and retailers, leading to higher consumer prices.
"It's just a matter of time until inflation picks up a bit," said Cary Leahey, senior vice president at Lehman Government Securities.
The concern about inflation comes ahead of Government reports today on producer prices and tomorrow on consumer prices. Inflation is a bond investor's worst enemy because it erodes the returns on the investment.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 18/32 , to 887/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 6.94 percent, from 6.83 percent on Tuesday. Prices of shorter-term maturities also fell, with the yield on the two-year note rising to 6.11 percent, from 6.01 percent on Tuesday.
"The market is in the process of discounting some expected future inflationary pressures," said David Jones, vice chairman at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company.
The possibility of higher inflation has reinforced expectations that the Federal Reserve will keep monetary policy steady for a while. Some analysts expect the central bank's next move will be to increase short-term interest rates.
"I do believe that the next time they change policy it will be in the direction of restraint," Mr. Jones said.
Traders said they were disappointed with a long-awaited coupon pass by the Federal Reserve yesterday, saying the Fed had delayed its action for too long.
A coupon pass occurs when the Fed comes to the market to buy certain maturities to add cash to the banking system. While it is not a signal of any change in monetary policy, traders say, the coupon pass presents dealers with an opportunity to sell Treasury securities to a ready buyer.
"The market had so much anticipation for it that when it actually happened it was kind of a disappointment," said Waldo Best, senior economist at BZW Government Securities Inc.
The Fed bought coupons with maturities from May 15, 2003, through Feb. 15, 2026, for delivery today.
The purchases failed to ease concerns about supply as the market tries to absorb more than $30 billion in new Treasury notes. The Treasury auctioned two-year notes on Monday and five-year notes on Tuesday. And another $30.25 billion of securities are expected to be sold later this month.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Ad Takes Aim At Clinton On Tax Cut

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 10

 BODY:
Trying to mine taxpayers' misery, the Republican National Committee began assaulting President Clinton in television advertisements today for blocking a tax credit supported by the Republican-controlled Congress.
The advertisements began appearing in some of the same television markets as others, sponsored by the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, in which Republican representatives came under fire for voting to block an increase in the minimum wage. 
 Both sets of advertisements feature youngish men in flannel shirts, appearing in kitchens adorned with children's scrawled drawings. And both illustrate how legislative battles are serving this year as proxies for the Presidential one, allowing Republicans and Democrats to define their differences without putting into effect the spending restrictions that apply to advertising explicitly tied to the Presidential campaign.
In the districts in which they appear, both sets of commercials are modified to include the names of local representatives, praising or deriding them for their votes. But the Republican advertisement also names Mr. Clinton.
As in Democratic advertisements attacking the presumptive Republican nominee, Senator Bob Dole, the Republicans dispense with honorifics.
"What about the thousand-dollar tax credit for the two kids?" asks the flannel-clad man in the Republican advertisement.
"Clinton vetoed that," replies his apparent wife, a thirtyish woman with a blond ponytail. "Between the two of us, what I make goes just to support the Government."
That advertisement is appearing in 22 states, part of a campaign that the Republicans said was costing just less than $1.5 million. A second advertisement, which the Republican National Committee said was appearing in far fewer states, accuses Mr. Clinton of breaking his promise "to end welfare as we know it."
Ann F. Lewis, Mr. Clinton's deputy campaign manager, said, "If the Republican National Committee wants to frame this campaign as a campaign about economic policy, I would welcome that."
She said the tax commercial was misleading because it did not mention Republican plans to "cut Medicare, Medicaid, education and the environment" while the welfare advertisement was "factually inaccurate."
In the welfare commercial, the announcer declares that Mr. Clinton "is blocking efforts to replace welfare with work." In fact, Ms. Lewis said, Mr. Clinton has repeatedly supported such efforts.
While the Democratic National Committee has been advertising since last fall, the Republicans have not broadcast advertising since early December, allowing Republican Presidential candidates to compete in the primaries with their own advertising.
The union advertisement, which began on Tuesday and is to run through April 15, does not mention Democrats or Republicans. "Our Congressman voted to block a minimum wage increase," the flannel-clad man says, addressing the camera, "after he voted to cut Medicare and cut college loans, and to give a tax break to the rich."
But of the 21 representatives who are targeted in versions of the advertisement, only one is a Democrat, G. V. (Sonny) Montgomery of Mississippi, who has announced his retirement. Almost all the others are embattled Republican freshmen. The advertisement also dovetails with commercials broadcast for months by the Democrats, presenting Mr. Clinton as the bulwark against a Republican onslaught against programs like Medicare.

HEADLINE: Male Professors Keep 30% Lead In Pay Over Women, Study Says

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
The salary gap between female and male university professors remained constant last year, with men receiving about 30 percent more than women, said a study released yesterday by the American Association of University Professors.
Over all, salaries of full-time college and university faculty members rose 2.9 percent in 1995-96, keeping slightly ahead of the 2.5 percent rate of inflation, the study said. 
 The survey shows that pay differences have been consistent in the last 15 years. Part of the pay gap between men and women is attributed to the growing numbers of women in entry-level and junior faculty jobs. In the last six years, the association said, women have "made steady and very rapid growth" in academia, so that today women represent 32.3 percent of faculty members, up from 27.4 percent six years ago.
The gap is also attributable to a concentration of women in lower-paying departments, like education and English, the report says.
"Men disproportionately go into the hard sciences, engineering and business, which are relatively high paying," said Daniel S. Hamermesh, a professor of economics at the University of Texas at Austin who wrote the report. "Women are largely drawn to fields like history, English, languages and education, which are traditionally low paying jobs."
When women reach full professor, the gap narrows to less than 10 percent, $66,740 to $58,990.
This is the third consecutive year in which the association's annual salary survey has found modest salary gains. Salaries for professors increased 3.4 percent in 1994-95, and 3 percent the year before.
The report studied 2,230 colleges and universities, accounting for more than 90 percent of all faculty members. It said average academic salaries were $57,760 at research institutions; $47,830 at four-year institutions with master's degree programs; $42,500 at four-year liberal arts schools, and $41,640 at two-year colleges.
The average salary for all professors, from lecturer to full professor, was $50,980, with the biggest gap between full professor, at $65,440, and associate professor, at $48,310.
About 81 percent of women are in jobs leading to tenure, compared with about 92 percent of men. Of those with tenure, about 72 percent are men and 48.3 percent are women.
Raises were lowest at public institutions, where salaries over the last 10 years rose 51.4 percent. At private, independent schools, they rose 57.8 percent, and at church-affiliated institutions, 64.4 percent.

HEADLINE: New Fee Plan for Woodhull Hospital Doctors

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation has signed a new type of agreement with the doctors who work at Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center, one that demands more cost-effective treatment and pays them only for the work they actually perform.
Officials of the city hospitals agency say the agreement opens a new era in labor relations with its doctors, who are provided by medical schools or, in the case of Woodhull, an independent medical corporation. They said they hope it will be a model for affiliation contracts at the corporation's other hospitals, encouraging greater productivity in the system and saving an estimated $50 million a year. 
 "We view this as a precedent-setting negotiation, which for the first time links reimbursement with productivity and performance," said Jane Zimmerman, a spokeswoman for the hospitals corporation.
In the past, the medical schools and corporations that provide doctors to the public hospitals have received tens of millions of dollars in lump-sum payments each year and their doctors, in turn, have received set salaries, regardless of how many patients they saw. Critics of the corporation have long complained that the doctors have been lazy and unhelpful, often turning up hours late at clinics to which they were assigned.
Under the new affiliation agreement, the Woodhull Medical Group will lay off more than 10 percent of its doctors, and the doctors who remain will be paid in proportion to how many patients they treat, with the corporation setting standards for productivity. The corporation will guarantee doctors part of their current salaries for the next two years, but after that, the medical group will be paid for each patient its doctors see and each service they perform.
Doctors who do more work will be paid more, giving the medical group great incentive to pressure its members to be more productive. The Hospitals Corporation, in turn, has pledged to improve support services at the hospitals, like the time it takes to get laboratory results.
The agreement leaves the doctors at Woodhull vulnerable to losing large chunks of their paychecks if the hospital fails to run more efficiently. But many physicians at Woodhull said they felt it was a gamble they had to take, given that more than 10 percent of the city's hospitals are expected to close in the next few years, leaving doctors unemployed. The managed-care companies that are making huge inroads in the region demand more efficient medical care.
"It's given us, as a hospital and as a group, the opportunity to survive," said Dr. Gabriel Koz, president of the Woodhull Medical Group. "With managed care coming down, we were receptive to the agreement, although it was also very frightening."
The new contract took six months to negotiate and was hammered out by representatives of the hospitals corporation, the Woodhull Medical Group and the Doctors' Council, the union that represents most of Woodhull's physicians.
Corporation officials are now negotiating new affiliation contracts at 6 of H.H.C.'s 10 other hospitals: Bellevue Hospital Center, Harlem Hospital Center, Lincoln Hospital, Metropolitan Hospital Center, North Central Bronx Hospital, and Jacobi Medical Center. The city wants to turn over to private hands three other hospitals: Elmhurst Hospital Center, Queens Hospital Center and Coney Island Hospital.
It is unclear if the agreement will serve as a model at other public hospitals, which are generally staffed by the city's powerful medical schools.
Last year, doctors from the Albert Einstein College of Medicine who work at Jacobi Medical Center in the Bronx refused such a contract, saying it would be impossible to meet the H.H.C.'s productivity standards in H.H.C. clinics, where exam rooms are in short supply and patient charts are hard to find. Einstein is ending its affiliation with Jacobi when its contract expires this summer.
But as they are squeezed by cuts in Medicare and the incursion of managed care, other medical schools may well decide they need the money they get from the affiliation contracts, even on the new terms.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
After 5 Years of False Starts, Japan's Economy Is Stirring

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 10

 BODY:
This winter has lasted five years in Japan, but there is finally talk of an economic spring.
The stock market is up, corporate profits are rising, and there is plenty of cash in the banks. Perhaps more important, the long economic chill has forced corporate Japan to re-examine itself and cut costs, and so now companies may be better poised than before to compete with American and European conglomerates around the globe. 
 "Most corporations seem to have pretty much restructured themselves and are able to yield profits," said Haruo Shimada, a professor of economics at Keio University. "They are ready for another attack."
Manufacturers are once again buying equipment, adding product lines and building new plants, and corporations such as Toyota, Hitachi and NEC are scrambling to meet demand. Companies are lifting dividends again, paying more overtime, raising salaries and even widening the narrow crack in the door to new recruits.
Department stores that were virtually empty for years are doing so much better that they are opening branches across the country. Yasuo Matsushita, the governor of the central bank, the Bank of Japan, even suggested recently that given the signs of recovery, interest rates could edge up. The discount rate here is now half a percent.
And though this recovery is not so much built on American-style layoffs, most of Japan's large corporations are beginning to realize that the promise of lifetime employment is one they can no longer afford.
"The recession was the trigger for a historic transformation of Japan," said Richard A. Werner, an economist at Jardine Fleming Securities in Tokyo.
In the last quarter of 1995, Japan's economy grew at an annual rate of 3.6 percent, compared with the previous quarter. And after several years of near-zero growth, economists are forecasting growth rates of about 3 percent for 1996. Some are even putting Japan's growth rate above that of the United States and other nations of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.
To be sure, growth this year is still paltry compared with the frenzied pace decades ago, when the economy expanded nearly 10 percent annually. Nobody seems to think Japan has any chance of reliving those glory days.
Moreover, Japan has had enough false starts in the last few years to make every citizen a skeptic, and many economists say they expect the economy to slow down again next year. Depressed property prices and more than $400 billion in sour loans still impose a costly drag on the economy.
Some experts say that Japan is going to need far more serious reorganizing -- deregulation by the Government, layoffs from companies and greater reliance on technology and innovation by absolutely everybody -- before it can stage a real, lasting comeback. And if Japan continues to gloss over such problems as its aging population, the growth of imports, its cumbersome distribution network and its weak service industry, economic troubles could choke the country as it enters the next century.
But for now, the psychology of recession seems to be waning, so some consumers dare to spend again -- and that in itself is helping to lift the economy. Last month, for instance, 460 Japanese left on a three-month round-the-world cruise, after doling out up to $140,000 for the package, and they beat out hundreds of other disappointed customers, who have to wait for the 1997 cruise.
Just as the cruise passengers will spend their yen at ports all over the world, so a rebound in the Japanese economy could be a significant boon to businesses in the United States and elsewhere. Japan has the world's second-largest economy, after the United States, and it is one of America's biggest markets -- for everything from airplanes to wheat to machinery.
As Japan's economy grows, so will the Japanese appetite for American goods, and this, in turn, could help narrow the trade deficit with Japan and help lift the American economy.
Once again, foreign companies are moving to or expanding in Japan, and the economy is beginning to loosen up at the edges to accommodate change and, therefore, more growth, some economists say.
While most of the initial economic jolt is coming from a Government spending spree and corporate investment, the revampings that many Japanese companies pursued during hard times may also be paying off at last. Japanese companies have cut costs, retooled plants and moved expensive factories overseas.
Now, analysts say, profits for Japan's industries are expected to be up at least 18 percent for the 1995 fiscal year, which ended March 31, and much higher for 1996. More important, Japan must deal with a new technological challenge that could provide years of growth: catch up to the West.
"The information industry in Japan fully knows it is behind," said Jesper Koll, an economist with J. P. Morgan Securities Asia Ltd. "They recognize they are latecomers and need to catch up. And catching up to the leader is definitely one thing Japan is best at."
Japan is behind the United States in using technology, and everyone acknowledges that this is a handicap. But the situation also means that Japan can have a spurt of growth as it belatedly moves to expand the use of personal computers, electronic mail and the Internet.
Itsuji Araki, deputy general manager of executive personnel at NKK, one of Japan's largest steelmakers, used to share his job with two other managers. Every day, they would hold meetings to make decisions before writing up reports to propose to their senior executives.
Mr. Araki had to make a trip to his boss's office and get approval before he could take his written proposals all the way up the line to the president. Now, he can simultaneously send his reports to everyone, and he has taken over the job of three.
"Before, in order to give an explanation, I had to get prepared 100 percent," Mr. Araki said. "Now, I can give a rough idea first and, for the details, use E-mail. I save time waiting in the secretary's office for the bosses."
He added: "In the restroom when I meet my boss, I say, 'I put an E-mail in for you,' and he says, 'I saw that.' "
It is not clear how long this recovery may last, and many economists are forecasting slower growth for 1997. But among the signs of an incipient rebound are these:
 *The stock market, after tumbling in the early 1990's, has climbed to its highest level in more than four years, up about 50 percent from its nine-year low last July.
*Corporate profits are up sharply, with forecasts for this year pegged at 30 percent growth or more.
*Economic indicators, like growth in industrial production and construction orders, are up significantly, amid signs that the economy is being fueled by demand for goods at home, rather than demand for exports.
*Key surveys of business confidence have turned positive.
*A measure of stability can be seen in the stronger dollar, which makes Japanese goods cheaper for American buyers.
The path of the yen, which has greatly affected the fortunes of Japanese exporters, has seesawed over the last 14 months from 100 yen to the dollar, to 80 yen, and back to 107 yen, where it has settled and smoothed the way for Japanese exports.
The economic hardships, though, have been harsh on Japanese companies, and their hands have been pinned down in many ways by enormous rigidities in the economy and a culture that still makes it difficult for large corporations to dismiss employees. Yet while more change is still needed, Japanese companies have slimmed their ranks and trimmed their sails.
Take the case of Okuma Ltd., a prominent maker of sophisticated machine tools, which had 2,300 employees at the height of the economic troubles in the early 1990's.
In two years, the company's monthly order book fell to about $27 million, a quarter of peak levels, and Okuma knew it had to do something to survive. So in a move that set off debate across the nation and forced its president to resign, Okuma embarked on a ruthless revamping that resulted in the layoff of nearly a third of its work force, or 700 employees.
"Our future prospects looked very worrisome," said Masahiro Kitajima, a board member at Okuma.
Okuma started making its own parts, adding simpler, cheaper versions to its product line and broadening its variety of models to attract more sales. By reorganizing and cutting costs, it lowered its break-even point by 25 percent, reducing the level of sales it needs to cover costs and turn a profit.
The result is that after three consecutive years of losses, Okuma says it will report a profit this fiscal year of about $14 million.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Buoyant Dollar Hits Resistance And Can't Hold Higher Levels

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar climbed to its highest level in 14 months against the German mark yesterday, but retreated in late trading.
The dollar eked out a fresh 26-month high against the Japanese yen but also succumbed to selling pressure, traders said. 
 "The dollar couldn't hold those higher levels and it looks like the rally is over for now," said Jay Wertheimer, senior foreign exchange trader at Banco di Sicilia. "But the market seems to want to take the dollar higher."
A report showing that the number of unemployed Germans rose by 26,000 in March helped cement growing expectations for lower official German interest rates and fueled early dollar buying.
By contrast, the United States economy seems relatively strong, with steady interest rates that tend to enhance the appeal of dollar-based assets.
"Right now the dollar has a firm basis on the idea the U.S. economy is performing better than expected," said Chris Widness, international economist at Chase Securities.
In trading in New York late yesterday, the dollar settled at 1.4973 marks, down from 1.4982 marks on Tuesday. The dollar was also quoted at 108.40 yen, up from 108.30 yen.
A sharp drop in the British pound also helped propel the dollar as high as 1.5068 marks during the session, the highest rate since the dollar touched 1.51 marks on Feb. 16, 1995.
The pound slumped badly amid fears that the ruling Conservative Party would weaken further after a special election today. The Conservatives are expected to lose an election to fill an empty parliamentary seat representing Staffordshire in central England. A loss would cut the Conservatives' majority in the House of Commons to one.
"We're seeing a lot of pressure on the pound," said Alex Scarsini, director of foreign exchange at Barclays Group. "A lot of people are getting out of the pound and into the dollar."
In New York, the British pound was trading at $1.5125, down from $1.5205.
But the dollar was unable to continue rallying. Some traders cited the dollar's failure to break past 1.2250 Swiss francs, a key resistance point, as a reason for some selling.
The dollar remains generally buoyant, but faces some tough resistance at current levels, traders said.

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
For Giuliani, Baseball May Be a Costly Issue

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
The Mayor who likes to say "no" has whispered a tentative but unmistakable "yes" to the idea of moving Yankee Stadium to the West Side of Manhattan. And in doing so, Rudolph W. Giuliani has allowed his political opponents to feast on what may be one of the defining issues of the 1997 mayoral campaign.
With the gusto that only a true New York development brawl can provide, two of the Republican Mayor's most likely challengers have quickly and vocally moved to oppose the stadium proposal, thereby foreshadowing many of the themes likely to dominate next year's mayoral race. In a series of recent public appearances, Ruth W. Messinger and Fernando Ferrer, the Borough Presidents of Manhattan and the Bronx, have appeared positively gleeful at the opportunity to portray Mr. Giuliani as a free spender on luxury skyboxes at a time of drastic cutbacks to schools, subways, welfare and city services. 
 "It's pretty clear that this is a precursor to next year's race," said Henry A. Sheinkopf, a political consultant working for Mr. Ferrer. "It raises serious questions about what the city's priorities are, where it's important for New York City to spend its money. Potentially, it does have a lot of political capital."
The Mayor, for his part, said he would "love to have that debate" with his opponents, accusing them of the same anti-business mentality he said forced four sports franchises from the city, beginning with the Dodgers in 1957. In an interview, he specifically accused Mr. Ferrer -- who has often been critical of George M. Steinbrenner 3d, the principal owner of the Yankees -- of working first to drive the team out the Bronx and eventually out of New York City.
"I think it's a terrible issue for them," Mr. Giuliani said. "It's their philosophy that's run this city into the ground, this virulently anti-business attitude." At a news conference yesterday, he further intensified his case, saying his opponents' antipathy to business is the same philosophy that cost the city hundreds of thousands of jobs under Democratic mayors.
That argument will undoubtedly resonate with business officials, property owners on the West Side and construction unions. But in this case, the business to be saved is the New York Yankees, a team that no longer commands the city's widespread devotion.
The anger that even Yankee fans express for Mr. Steinbrenner plays directly into the hands of the challengers, producing what many political observers see as a win-win situation for them. They can oppose a new stadium as a taxpayer giveaway to a widely disliked wealthy businessman, using it to highlight the many areas in which the Mayor has cut back on spending. If Mr. Steinbrenner makes good on his threats and leaves town, he is the one most likely to be blamed by a bitter populace.
"It used to be that no politician could afford to be perceived as someone who lost the Yankees, but all that has changed over the last generation," said Jay Severin, a Republican political consultant. "The romanticism about sports franchises is gone, and the level of skepticism is now much greater than it was. If they portray this as an expensive frivolity, a priority over schools, it's a tough argument for the Mayor to win."
The election, of course, is more than a year and half away, and there has never been any shortage of criticism from Democrats of Mr. Giuliani's budget cuts. But in many ways, a new stadium provides precisely the contrast that the critics have been seeking when hammering away at those cuts, even if the stadium requires the minimal taxpayer investment predicted by the Mayor.
It is bad enough when schools are leaking and overcrowded, and the city has yet to come up with the more than $1 billion needed for repairs. But perpetual inability to fix the schools makes a much better sound bite when juxtaposed with the city's readiness to build a $1 billion new stadium.
As Mr. Ferrer said last week on the steps of City Hall, "At a time when you have schools that are crumbling, to spend $1 billion on baseball is nothing short of obscene."
Councilman Sal F. Albanese, the only declared candidate in the race so far, was out of town this week, but an aide said he, too, wants the team to remain in the Bronx.
The administration has yet to provide any figures on how the stadium would be financed, although the Mayor has confidently predicted that taxpayer subsidies could be kept to a minimum because of the increased attendance at a Manhattan ball park. The proposed stadium's critics have questioned that assumption, predicting that millions of public dollars will be required.
But even if they are wrong, the likely increase in ticket prices and parking fees also works as a populist argument. Ms. Messinger has already suggested that the move toward skyboxes and ticket surcharges would make it far more difficult for the average fan to attend a game.
At one level, both Mr. Ferrer and Ms. Messinger clearly have local constituencies to serve in opposing the move. Mr. Ferrer would like to keep the team and its economic benefits in his home borough, and Ms. Messinger would like to keep what she has called a potential traffic nightmare out of hers.
But opposing the proposal works for both undeclared candidates at deeper levels as well. For Ms. Messinger, in particular, turning the West Side stadium into the House That Ruth Blocked allows her to demonstrate that her concerns extend beyond Manhattan, the borough with which she is so completely identified. It is the Bronx, she said, that would be devastated if the Yankees move.
"This issue raises the question of whether or not the other four boroughs get the attention to their economic and neighborhood development that they deserve," she said. "If we fail to provide huge chunks of this city with those resources, we will become a city that fewer and fewer people choose to stay in."

HEADLINE: Utility Proposes Choice of Power Supplier

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER 

DATELINE: PEARL RIVER, N.Y., April 10

 BODY:
The public utility here wants to let its customers pick their own electric power supplier, just as many already do with their long-distance telephone service.
It is proposing an experiment that would involve 1,500 residents and many of the area's factories and shopping malls. The proposal, announced today, would be one of the first such experiments in the nation to introduce competition into an industry that has been dominated by territorial monopolies for almost a century. 
 The proposal, by Orange and Rockland Utilities Inc., has been endorsed by the staff ot the state's Public Service Commission, but it still must be acted on by the full five-member commission next month.
If it is approved, customers who volunteer to take part would select another utility or private power company to provide their electricity in the same way that NYNEX customers can choose among Sprint, MCI, AT&T or others for long-distance service. The electricity, though, would be transmitted over Orange and Rockland's wires and bills would continue to be paid to Orange and Rockland.
The utility, which supplies electricity to 263,200 customers in Orange and Rockland Counties as well as small enclaves in Pennsylvania and New Jersey, would lose some of its $1 billion in annual revenue. But energy analysts say that it decided to test the waters because of the inevitability of competition in the heavily regulated electric industry.
"It's more or less a forgone conclusion that the United States is heading toward deregulation of electric utilities, and the sooner anyone knows what the pitfalls are going to be the better," said Dan Scotto, a utility analyst for Bear Stearns & Company. "You'll probably see other utilities following suit."
One big goal of the three-year experiment is to see what kind of savings the plan will produce for consumers. Orange and Rockland officials pointed out that the generation of power makes up only 25 percent of the cost of electricity. Pressed to be more specific about savings, the utility's chief executive, D. Louis Peoples, said 1.5 to 2 percent would not be "out of whack."
Under the experiment, industrial customers could voluntarily designate their suppliers starting in June and residential and commercial customers could so in January. Officials of Orange and Rockland said they expected a number of suppliers and electricity brokers to solicit residential customers by telephone or advertising in local newspapers.
The competitors in this free-for-all could include other utilities that are trying to sell excess electrical power or some of the several hundred private suppliers like the United States Generating Company of Bethesda, Md., company officials said. Utilities neighboring those in New York State usually produce power at cheaper prices, and many large factories would like to be able to buy their power.
Similar limited experiments have been approved in Wisconsin and Illinois, and others are awaiting approval in New Hampshire, Michigan, California and Massachusetts. But none is yet under way.
Among residents of Rockland today, news of the plan was met with enthusiasm, but there was also skepticism, with some people expressing concern that having to choose a supplier would complicate already complicated lives.
"It's bad enough now with the phone bill, it's so confusing," said Maria Lauricella of Orangetown. "I don't think it's a good idea at all."
But Jerry Dickow, superintendent of the Rockland County Cemetery, was more receptive to the possibility that he could save some money. "At least this sounds like you're giving people a choice," he said. "Anything that generates competition has got to benefit the public."
This crack in one of the last monopolies in the American economy began with a 1992 Federal law that forced utilities to transmit power generated by independent producers and destined for distant customers.
Large industrial users began putting pressure on utilities to cut rates or let them choose their own power suppliers, sometimes threatening to leave counties or cities with high costs. In Orange and Rockland, large industrial companies have banded together into an Industrial Energy Users Association that has lobbied for lower rates with the regulatory agency. That association was part of the negotiations for a 2.3 percent reduction in Orange and Rockland rates this week that included the experiment, called Powerpick, as part of the agreement.
With the historic protection of its market crumbling, the electric industry has been drafting proposals to wade into the murky pool of competition. In New York, the one proposal that all seven of the state's utilities have agreed to would also involve competition but only at the wholesale level. Generating companies would be allowed to bid to supply power to existing utilities, but the utilities would continue to set prices for their customers.
Orange and Rockland took competition one important step further -- to the retail level. It was able to do so more readily than, say, Consolidated Edison because it already buys 40 percent of its power and can let its customers deal directly with those suppliers or others.
"We as a company believe competition is inevitable and we want to start playing in this market early," said Terry Dittrich, manager of the project for the utility.
The experiment is intended to answer a raft of questions. Would there indeed be any savings to consumers? How would costs be apportioned in such a system? Who would repay the utilities for their large investments in generating plants, equipment and overpriced power contracts? Would the system retain its reliability? If the answers after three years are positive, utility officials said, more customers would be permitted to choose their suppliers.
Mr. Scotto said the experience of other deregulated industries like telephones and airlines did not offer much hope for savings. "The empirical evidence suggests that over time competition does not necessarily produce lower rates for customers," he said.
Another concern is whether in a competitive atmosphere the interests of the smallest customers -- the poor and aged, for example -- would be protected. Currently, for example, utilities are forbidden during the winter months to shut off power to customers who cannot pay their bills.
"What happens to social and environmental policies that have been incorporated into rate-making," said Bob Johnson, executive director of the Electric Consumers Alliance, which represents low-income, elderly and minority consumer groups on utility issues.
Mr. Peoples denied that the Powerpick experiment was aimed at burnishing the company's image after a scandal in 1993 and 1994 in which top executives either pleaded guilty or were forced to resign for spending the utility's money on personal uses and illegal political donations. "Those darker days are history," he said.
Rather, the main thrust of the plan is to give consumers the feeling that they are not locked into a single power supplier. "How many times have you as a consumer said to yourself, 'Gee, I wish I had a choice in this thing,' " he said.

HEADLINE: Study Finds Smaller Pay Gap For Male and Female Doctors

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, April 10

 BODY:
The pay gap between male and female physicians is closing, a study has found.
In the study, being published on Thursday in The New England Journal of Medicine, Dr. Laurence C. Baker of Stanford University found that when differences of medical specialty, number of hours worked and practice setting are taken into account, men and women who are doctors now earn almost the same amounts. 
 "The story I'm telling supports the hypothesis that trends in medicine towards pay equality are helping, at least among young physicians," said Dr. Baker, 27, an assistant professor in economics.
Dr. Baker analyzed statistics from the 1987 and 1991 Surveys of Young Physicians, a nationwide survey of doctors under 45 years of age with two to nine years of experience. "I wanted to look at the younger physicians because they are the leading edge of change," he said. "That's where the action is."
As recently as 1987, Dr. Baker found, young men in medicine earned 7 percent more per hour than women, even after various factors like differences in specialties were taken into account. That gap was almost completely absent in the newer data.
In 1990, male physicians made $45,500 a year more than their female counterparts in mean earnings, but after adjusting for the fact that the men work an average of 11 more hours a week than the women, the $7 an hour difference that was left was almost completely because of medical specialty.
Pay discrimination seems to have lessened if male and female doctors do the same jobs, but often they still do not. Although 40 percent of first-year medical students are now women, less than 20 percent of surgical residents are women, according to the American Medical Association.
Why female physicians more often choose lower-paying specialties, like general practice and pediatrics, is a matter of debate. "This is the $64,000 question," Dr. Baker said. "It's like looking at a cross section of the population and asking why does one person choose to be a teacher and another person chooses to be a doctor. It's a tremendously personal decision."
In an accompanying editorial in the journal, Dr. Ruth L. Kirschstein of the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md., also pointed to the disparity among female and male doctors in positions of power in academic and professional societies.
"As the United States enters the 21st century," she said, "it is imperative that women physicians, who appear to have achieved equity in earnings also achieve greater prominence in academic and organized medicine. Only then will the news be entirely good."
In 1994 there were only four female deans of medical schools, according to the Association of American Medical Colleges. That same year only 24 percent of full-time medical school faculty members were women.
The good news also does not apply to all doctors. Some specialties stillshowed wage gaps. Young men in internal-medicine subspecialties and emergency medicine earned 26 percent more than women, although men in general and family practices earned 13 percent less than women. The study also showed that men with 10 or more years of experience still earn 17 percent more per hour than women.

HEADLINE: China Awards Huge Jet Order To Europeans

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, April 10

 BODY:
China's Prime Minister, Li Peng, began a visit to France today by placing an order for an estimated $1.5 billion worth of European-built passenger planes, sending a signal to the Clinton Administration that Beijing can turn to European partners if the United States becomes too intractable on human rights and trade.
The Chinese leader, making his first visit to France since presiding over the 1989 military crackdown on the democracy movement in Tiananmen Square, met with Prime Minister Alain Juppe tonight and signed a contract for 10 short-haul A320 passenger planes for China Southern Airlines from the Airbus Industrie consortium. 
 France's Foreign Minister, Herve de Charette, said the deal also obligated China to buy another 20 of the narrow-bodied A320's, but it was not clear whether this constituted a firm order or an option. Big airplane deals are often announced and reanounced, and today the Chinese confirmed an order originally made known two years ago for three larger long-haul A340 jumbo jets, also from Airbus Industrie. Details were not fully disclosed tonight.
These and earlier inroads by Airbus Industrie, a French-German-British-Spanish consortium, make it the Boeing Company's biggest competitor in China, long an almost captive market for American plane makers.
Today's Airbus order came a month after China's Trade Minister, Wu Yi, postponed a visit to the United States, where plane manufacturers had hoped for up to $4 billion in new orders.
The commercial aircraft business is one that the United States has long dominated; it supports both high-paying manufacturing jobs and advanced technology development. As such, it not only has considerable economic importance, but often assumes a high degree of political significance, as it has in the relationship between the United States and China.
Asia is the fastest-growing market for passenger aircraft, and Boeing and the other American plane manufacturer, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, have been coming under intensifying competition from Airbus.
The Chinese Government has taken advantage of the competition and has made no secret of its strategy of using aircraft orders as a carrot and a stick in dealing with the Clinton Administration. Mrs. Wu, the Trade Minister, put off her trip to the United States, and the announcement of orders, many of which had been expected to go to Boeing, after the Administration refused her a meeting with President Clinton and refused to delay its consideration of sanctions against China for allowing factories to produce pirated American video cassettes and compact disks.
One Administration official said tonight in Washington that the Airbus decision would not cause the United States to change its trade policy toward China, or drop its consideration of sanctions.
"It appears from reports that much of this involves agreements previously reached," the official said of today's order. The official added that "it would be improper to draw any conclusions one way or another" about the deal's effects on the overall relationship between China and the United States.
Cindy Smith, a Boeing spokeswoman, said: "We're disappointed in China's decision to purchase Airbus aircraft. But more importantly, the order underscores the need for the United States to move beyond the annual debate of most-favored-nation status for China and to create a long-term stable trading relationship. Boeing supports the Clinton Administration in its efforts to normalize trade between the United States and China. Establishing normal trade with China will lead to job creation and economic gain."
Ron Woodard, president of the Boeing Commercial Airplane Group, said the Airbus order was "precipitated not because of the strength of our competition or the quality of their product," Reuters reported. "Rather, it is precipitated by what I believe are ill-founded political considerations," he added.
But Mr. Li did not escape pressure on human rights in Paris.
French newspapers greeted his arrival with satirical cartoons, and protesters denounced the visit as a sign of European willingness to sacrifice principle for profit. A small rally near the Eiffel Tower demanded that China release political prisoners and end what demonstrators called "the oppression of Tibet."
For security reasons, the French police kept a tight lid on the Chinese delegation's movements. The Chinese Prime Minister originally intended to go on to the Netherlands and Luxembourg this weekend, but canceled those visits, saying he was short of time. A visit he made to Germany two years ago was marked by many protests.
Mr. Li's visit to France also produced a three-year wheat deal, a $460 million French-financed expansion of a car factory in Wuhan that produces Citroen cars for the Chinese market and a $50 million gas-liquefaction plant for Shanghai. An agreement was also reached giving French ships unrestricted access to Chinese ports.
But the results amounted to far less than the $10 billion or so in trade deals that the French had hoped for after agreeing two years ago to stop selling arms to Taiwan, which China regards as a renegade province.
Taiwan bought 60 Mirage jet fighters worth about $2.6 billion from France in 1992, on top of a $4.8 billion purchase of 16 naval frigates the previous year, and Beijing responded by banning Chinese orders from France.
But now a new, conservative administration under President Jacques Chirac is eager to establish France as a potential supplier of modern technology to China, and one less squeamish than the United States about doing business with countries that do not live up to Western standards on human rights.
The French deny a double standard, but are glad to have the business.
"Will we sacrifice human rights for trade?" asked Foreign Minister de Charette before Mr. Li's visit began. "That's out of the question." But Jean-Pierre Desgeorges, president of a French-Chinese industrial trade group, said he did not plan to raise the question of human rights during the visit at all. "I'm a businessman," he said.
Still, French officials said the signing of the plane deal tonight was delayed for two hours by a disagreement over Mr. Juppe's plan to bring up human rights during his dinner speech. In the end, Mr. Juppe did not touch on the subject, The Associated Press reported, but the two sides refused to exchange toasts.
For some French intellectuals, however, Mr. Li's presence spoke for itself.
"Mr. Li recovers his lost honor today," an essay in Tuesday's issue of Le Monde said. "But do those who govern us realize they are sacrificing theirs, and ours as well?"
Le Monde said the essay was written by "several senior officials who have filled posts in Asia," but published under a pseudonym.
About 50 supporters of Amnesty International stretched a white banner across the Champs-Elysees reading: "Li Peng ignores human rights. We don't." French policemen quickly removed it, and barred demonstrators from approaching the Chinese Embassy on Avenue Georges V.
With unemployment in France at 11.8 percent, and in Germany at 10.8 percent, both countries have been outdoing each other in soliciting job-generating trade orders from Asia's largest market. It is especially important for the aircraft industry, which President Chirac regards as crucial for maintaining European technological competitiveness with the United States in world trade. Mr. Chirac planned to have lunch with Mr. Li on Thursday.
Jacques Rummelhardt, the Foreign Ministry spokesman, said, "France, as the world's fourth-largest exporter, doesn't have the position in China that it should have."
On Saturday Mr. Li is to visit the plant near Toulouse where the Airbus planes are made. Airbus Industrie received more orders for new planes than Boeing did in 1994, but last year secured only 106 orders, worth $7 billion, compared with Boeing's 346 orders, worth $31 billion.
French Foreign Ministry officials said negotiations were continuing on a possible purchase of 28 electric locomotives from the Alsthom group, an aluminum plant and other projects before Mr. Li returns to China on Saturday.

HEADLINE: U.S. Sees Higher Gasoline Demand, and Prices

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
The demand for gasoline, already soaring, is expected to set records this summer, sending prices higher, a Government agency predicted yesterday.
Prices rose in the last month on strong demand and unusually tight supplies; because of the long run of cold weather, refiners kept producing heating oil and kerosene rather than gasoline. 
 Some of the demand for gasoline reflects greater consumption from faster driving, as speed limits have been raised to 65 miles an hour on major highways in most states. Beyond that, customers are continuing to buy sport utility vehicles, which are less fuel-efficient, often in preference to cars and station wagons.
The Energy Information Administration, a unit of the United States Department of Energy, predicted yesterday that the demand for gasoline would increase 2.1 percent, to more than 8 million barrels a day, this summer. In the agency's terminology, the peak driving season of summer is considered half a year, the second and third quarters.
"U.S. gasoline demand has never averaged above 8 million barrels per day in a calendar quarter, so this summer's demand may be a watershed," the agency said.
And it added, "This year's demand increase is not a transitory phenomenon but is a reflection of two long-term factors: the relentless impact on travel demand of increased population and income, and the end of the era of perennial increases in average highway fuel efficiency."
This view underlines a debate under way in the industry: whether the increased use of sport utility vehicles has fundamentally changed demand, so that old yardsticks no longer apply.
The agency predicted that prices at the pump could average as high as $1.31 a gallon this summer if supplies continued to be tight and prices of crude oil remained high. Early this month, industry experts said, the price of regular fuel averaged $1.16 a gallon, and a year before that, $1.07.
At $1.31, retail prices would be the highest since the Persian Gulf war period early in 1991.
But if crude oil prices declined from current levels, as many analysts expect, the prices at the pump would increase less, to $1.23 on average during the summer, the agency said.
Though there is a surging demand and a greater reliance on imported gasoline, some energy experts doubt there will be a shortage, saying that refiners will produce more to add to supplies.
"There's not going to be a shortage," said John H. Lichtblau of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, an industry consulting group. "There could be some price spikes."
Mr. Lichtblau said the current surge in gasoline prices was caused by higher crude oil prices and very low gasoline inventories.
Higher prices, though, have done little to discourage driving, with many motorists paying little attention to price and not bothering to comparison-shop. In some areas, it has become common for gas stations near each other to have as much as a 10-cent difference in price. Gasoline price wars are becoming rare.
Even with the higher prices expected this summer, gasoline, when adjusted for inflation and omitting taxes, costs less than in the 1960's.
Mike Morrissey, a spokesman of the American Automobile Association, said that the price increases expected this summer were "not enough to make you change your travel plans."
"It's not a major financial burden to keep the tank full," he said.
Mr. Morrissey added that an auto club study recently sought to determine how more it cost to drive a sport utility vehicle in terms of gasoline and oil. It found that a new Ford Taurus GL cost 5.9 cents a mile to drive, while a new Chevrolet Blazer, a sport utility vehicle, cost 6.8 cents a mile.
That kind of difference, he said, was not great enough to make people pause in buying sport utility vehicles -- a category that now makes up about 40 percent of new vehicle sales.
With that popularity, fuel economy has, after years of improvement, leveled off -- the memories of the gasoline lines of 1970's oil embargoes having faded.
Even though some experts worry that there could be another oil-supply crisis as a result of political instability in Saudi Arabia, they have remained voices in the wilderness as consumption has continued to grow.
The Energy Information Administration predicted that imports of crude oil could reach record levels this year of 50 percent.
At the wholesale level, gasoline for May delivery is now selling near 73 cents a gallon, the highest since May 1991.

HEADLINE: Florida Farm a Labor Battleground

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: QUINCY, Fla., April 10

 BODY:
Daniel Martinez figured he would join the lunchtime demonstration for higher wages and better working conditions, and be back on the job within the hour. Instead, his employer dismissed him and had him arrested for trespassing.
The 32-year-old Mr. Martinez was among 84 mushroom pickers discharged because of that demonstration, held last month at Quincy Farms, a mushroom grower here about 30 miles northwest of Tallahassee that the United Farm Workers union has been trying to persuade to bargain for a union contract. As part of the U.F.W.'s efforts to win recognition, it has called a boycott of the company's Prime-label mushrooms, which are sold throughout the Southeast. 
 The U.F.W.'s drive here coincides with a new priority by the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations to increase union membership among low-paid workers, particularly in the South. Quincy Farms, with 615 workers, is the largest private employer in one of Florida's poorest counties, Gadsden.
The pickers here, almost all of them immigrants from Mexico and El Salvador, say that although they want better pay and benefits -- their average weekly wage, they say, ranges from $180 to $270 -- of greater concern are job safety and security, and what one after another describe as the "disrespect" encountered daily.
"I want them to pay attention to us," said Mr. Martinez, a Quincy Farms employee for the last four years who supports a wife and two young sons and who, like the other dismissed pickers, is looking to get his job back once union representation is won. "Right now we don't get any respect from the company. They scream at you. If you protest, they take you to the office" like a child.
Many workers complain that any disagreement with a supervisor invariably leads to threats of dismissal. Harvesters must climb five feet or higher to reach mushrooms that are grown indoors in trays stacked one above another, and falls, they say, are common. But those who require medical attention must sign papers accepting responsibility for the accident before treatment is offered, the workers say, and often the company doctor does not take the injury seriously and sends the worker back to the job.
When one group of workers asked for a raise last October, union organizers here say, a supervisor used rough language to turn them down. Other workers then staged a five-hour job halt in protest, and that led to higher pay for packers, irrigators and all other workers except the pickers, who instead settled for modifications in their work to help prevent accidents.
Company officials did not return telephone calls seeking interviews, but in advertisements and letters published by local newspapers they contend that they have been responsive to employee concerns by holding regular meetings and providing protective gear like back-support belts. They say the company offers a 401(k) retirement plan, major medical coverage and competitive wages.
The president of Quincy Farms, Rick Lazzarini, does not describe the shutting out of the workers who attended the lunchtime demonstration on March 14 as a dismissal. He says that he instead considers them to be on strike, although he has not explained his rationale, and that the two dozen workers who were arrested at the demonstration had ignored repeated warnings to move the protest off company property.
Quincy Farms officials also say the labor dispute is the work of "a few outside agitators." But some here attribute it to the growing expectations of the workers, Hispanic immigrants who have been in the United States long enough to become permanent residents, to purchase not only trailer homes but also satellite dishes that enable them to receive Spanish-language television, and to be increasingly vocal about their treatment.
"Their legal status has given them self-confidence," said the Rev. Richard Castillo, pastor of St. Thomas the Apostle Church, which is trying to mediate the dispute. "A lot of them know enough English to know what should be happening, and what shouldn't be happening."
The U.F.W., which has nine organizers here from Texas, California and New York and has set up headquarters at a Roman Catholic center in the nearby town of Greensboro, says that more than half of Quincy Farms's employees have signed authorization cards supporting representation by the union. Many cars in town now carry bumper stickers reading "Union, si." "
Beyond recognition, the union wants Quincy Farms to drop trespassing charges against those arrested and to reinstate those dismissed. But already the company has replaced half of the discharged workers.
The U.F.W. faces other hurdles as well. For one thing, farm workers are exempt from provisions of the National Labor Relations Act that enable other workers to petition for Government-supervised elections that determine whether their workplaces will be unionized. For another, Florida is a right-to-work state, giving employees of unionized companies the option to stay out of the union. None of the estimated 300,000 seasonal farm workers in the state are currently covered by a union contract.
"I suspect that if the firm hunkers down and is adamant in not allowing them to organize or signing a union contract, that's exactly what would happen, and it would survive," said Prof. Barry Hirsh of Florida State University, who specializes in labor economics.
As the weeks go by without word from the company, some of the discharged pickers have found temporary jobs in local nurseries, while others search for work in either construction or the area's tomato fields. They also take turns picketing outside Quincy Farms but are limited under the terms of a court injunction to 16 pickets at a time, at least 50 yards away from the entrance.
The strategy now is to build support for the boycott, a tool that has proved successful for the U.F.W. in the past. But so far local groceries are still carrying Prime mushrooms in their produce sections, and many of the workers, especially those supporting families, have no idea whether they will be able to meet next month's bills.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

China Gives Airbus Order, In a Slap at Washington
China placed a $1.5 billion order for passenger planes from Airbus Industrie, sending a warning signal to Washington that it can turn to Europe if the United States becomes intractable on human rights and trade. The Chinese ordered 10 short-haul A320 planes from the four-country European consortium, and may buy another 20.
The sale makes Airbus Boeing's biggest competitor in China, which has long relied on American plane makers. [Page A1.]
 
Dow Drops for 4th Day
Blue-chip stocks fell for the fourth consecutive session, hurt by a rise in interest rates. The Dow Jones average plummeted 74.43 points, to 5,485.98, and so far this week, has lost almost 200 points, or 3.5 percent. [D8.]

Prodigy is laying off 115 of its 680 employees. Analysts said the cutbacks were needed as the struggling company focuses on the Internet and attempts a management buyout. After five years, Japan's recession may be lifting at last. The stock market is up, and corporate profits are rising. The recovery could prove to be a false start, but for now, consumers are daring to spend again. [A1.]

Studies of the safety of cellular phones have found no increase in death rates among users, researchers said. [A17.]
