HEADLINE: Healing Quebec

 BODY:
Quebec voted last October by the thinnest of margins to remain a part of Canada. But the emotional campaign and close result left Canada's second-most-populous province bitterly polarized. Six months later a new Quebec Premier, Lucien Bouchard, is trying to heal the divisions. Though a committed separatist, Mr. Bouchard has made reconciliation and recovery his primary concerns. This shift is a welcome development, for Quebec, for Canada and for the United States.
Quebec separatists have long contended that their nationalism was not limited to the French-descended majority. But large numbers of English-Canadians, immigrants and Cree Indians feared they would be unwelcome in an independent Quebec; 83 percent of Quebecers grew up speaking French, 10 percent speaking English and 7 percent speaking other languages. 
 In the October referendum, 60 percent of the French-speakers voted for separation, while some 95 percent of the non-French-speakers voted against. These figures provoked an angry and offensive Election Night outburst from Jacques Parizeau, then Quebec's Premier, who blamed "money and the ethnic vote" for the defeat of his separatist cause. Mr. Parizeau was forced to resign.
He was succeeded by Mr. Bouchard, an engaging and effective politician who had been a Conservative cabinet minister in the 1980's. Converted to separatism, Mr. Bouchard waged a passionate but civil campaign for the "yes" side in the referendum and was chiefly responsible for the separatists' near-success. That earned him considerable credit in the French-speaking community, and he has begun to put it to good use.
Without sacrificing the ultimate aim of separatism, Mr. Bouchard has announced that no new referendum will be held before the next provincial election, which could be more than three years off. Yet another vote on separation so soon after the last would only be destructive. Mr. Bouchard sensibly declares that regenerating Quebec's ailing economy must come before any new status vote.
Mr. Bouchard has also mixed his calls for a separate Quebec with pleas for continued formal association with Canada, leaving some maneuvering room for a future constitutional accord. Quebec has legitimate constitutional grievances, and Canada's Prime Minister, Jean Chretien, has promised to address them in the near future.
Most important , Mr. Bouchard has grasped the need to reassure and rebuild trust among non-French-speaking Quebecers.
Healing is just what Quebec needs. Over the years, a revitalized French-speaking community has done much to end its second-class economic status within the province. French-speaking business owners and executives are now far more plentiful and powerful than before. Yet the skills and energies of English-Canadians and immigrants also make an important contribution to the provincial economy. Unless the alienation and concerns of these minority groups are addressed, they could move elsewhere, damaging business confidence and diminishing Quebec's cultural vibrancy.
Quebec needs a breather, and Mr. Bouchard seems determined to provide one. Quebec and Canada will be the better for it, and America will benefit by facing a less turbulent Canadian province across the border.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
MUSICLAND POSTPONES PUBLIC OFFERING FOR UNIT

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The Musicland Stores Corporation postponed the planned initial public offering of its Suncoast Motion Picture Company unit yesterday and said it would take a $35 million pretax restructuring charge in the first quarter. Musicland, the nation's largest seller of prerecorded music and videos, also said its banks had agreed to provide more financial flexibility in return for an increase of half a percentage point in the interest rate on its debt. The company said it had decided to put off selling a 30 percent stake in Suncoast because it believed that the unit was worth more than the market wanted to pay. Musicland, which is based in Minneapolis, had said in January that it hoped to sell 3 million of Suncoast's 10 million shares to the public at about $15 a share.

HEADLINE: TV WEEKEND;
On the Chicano Awakening

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
"Chicano!," a four-hour tribute to the Mexican-American civil rights movement, begins in the 1960's with the campaign for the return of lands in New Mexico that leaders like Reies Lopez Tijerina claimed had been guaranteed to Chicanos after the Mexican-American War. His Alianza movement, participants recall, fostered an ethnic solidarity that soon broadened into demands for economic justice and political power.
Allied to other minorities and to protesters against the Vietnam War, the Mexican-American Crusade for Justice, led by Rodolfo (Corky) Gonzales, sparked demonstrations for antipoverty causes and community control as it strove to build an independent political movement in the Southwest. 
 The producers' sympathy for the efforts of a beaten-down people to assert themselves is, unfortunately, not matched by the production, which is more dutiful than inspired, more celebratory than inquiring. Still, it does draw attention to a significant piece of the history of the 1960's.
At its most vivid, the opening hour brings back high or low moments, like Tijerina's June 1967 attack on a New Mexico courthouse, which earned him a jail sentence, and the big 1970 anti-Vietnam War rally in Los Angeles that erupted into violence. The police called it a Chicano riot; the pictures used here suggest that it was a police riot.
The second hour, "The Struggle in the Fields," covers the best known, hardest fought and most successful of Chicano movements, the migrant-worker campaign led by Cesar Chavez. The exposure of the conditions under which crop pickers labored and Chavez's spirit of nonviolence stirred sympathy across America. The combination of a prolonged strike, a consumer grape boycott and the efforts of politicians like Robert F. Kennedy brought the farm workers' union its first labor contracts and new laws that improved conditions for the long-exploited workers.
In something of an anticlimax, next week's two hours are given to a 1968 conflict over the schools in East Los Angeles and the creation in 1970 of La Raza Unida as a third political party.
 
CHICANO!
History of the Mexican-American Civil Rights Movement
PBS, tonight at 9 and April 19 at 9 P.M.
(Channel 13 in New York)
 
Sylvia Morales, Susan Racho, Mylene Moreno and Robert Cozens, producers; Jesus Salvador Trevino and Joyce Campbell, co-executive producers; Jose Luis Ruiz, executive producer; narrated by Henry Cisneros. Produced by the National Latino Communications Center and Galan Productions in association with KCET/Los Angeles. Hector Galan, series producer.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains on Outlook for Rise In U.S. Rates and Fall in Bonn's

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against most leading currencies yesterday, bolstered by expectations that United States interest rates would remain steady, while German rates would fall.
With the United States economy showing signs of strength, currency traders and analysts expect the Federal Reserve will keep short-term interest rates steady and may even raise rates later this year. At the same time, the Bundesbank is expected to cut German rates later this quarter to spur Germany's stagnant economy. 
 Higher interest rates bolster a currency by making its assets more attractive.
"The dollar's extremely strong against the Europeans," said Malcolm Gilroy, a portfolio manager at Laketon Investment Management in Toronto. "The U.S. economy is quite clearly strengthening. The exact opposite is true in Europe."
For the second consecutive day, the dollar touched a 26-month high against the Japanese yen, rising as high as 108.90 yen, its highest level since Feb. 9, 1994, when it reached 109 yen. The dollar also neared a 14-month high against the German mark, rising as high as 1.5047 marks.
"Everyone is jumping on the higher-dollar bandwagon," said Richard Vullo, manager of currency sales at Bayerische Hypotheken und Wechsel Bank.
But in trading in New York, the dollar gave up some of its gains. The dollar settled at 108.41 yen, up from 108.40 on Wednesday. The dollar was also quoted at 1.5020 marks, up from 1.4973. The British pound fell to $1.5115 from $1.5125.
The Bank of France lowered an important interest rate yesterday, and some analysts expect the Bundesbank to follow suit in the coming months. Comments by several Bundesbank officials fed speculation of a rate cut.
In an interview yesterday with The Financial Times, the president of the Bundesbank, Hans Tietmeyer, pledged to "assess carefully" the potential for cuts.
In addition, the Bundesbank's chief economist, Otmar Issing, dismissed concerns about a recent surge in money-supply growth. Mr. Issing said Germany ran no risk of a stronger inflation rate.
The yen continued to suffer yesterday from Japanese investors sending money overseas to escape Japan's low interest rates, traders said. Japanese 10-year Government bonds yield 3.31 percent, compared with 6.66 percent for United States Treasury 10-year bonds.

HEADLINE: Clinton Adviser Rules Out Taking Commerce Post

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 11

 BODY:
Thomas F. McLarty 3d, a top White House adviser, has withdrawn as a possible replacement for Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown, leaving a wide-open field.
Clinton Administration officials said today that Mr. Clinton was in a hurry to replace Mr. Brown, who died along with 34 others on April 3 in a plane crash in Croatia. They said the President could settle on a choice as early as this week. 
 "He will find a replacement for Secretary Brown and do so rather swiftly," said Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary.
Mr. McCurry also suggested that Mr. McLarty had told the President that he wanted to remain as White House counselor, an ambiguous but influential position he took in 1994 after being bumped as White House chief of staff.
An official close to Mr. McLarty, speaking on the condition of anonymity, confirmed that Mr. McLarty, a former business executive in Arkansas, had passed on the chance to replace Mr. Brown because he wanted to be involved in Mr. Clinton's re-election campaign.
Other aides said Mr. McLarty also feared a bruising battle with Republicans, although the official close to Mr. McLarty denied that.
Senator Larry Pressler, the South Dakota Republican who heads the Commerce Committee, said today that he had a high opinion of Mr. McLarty and did not expect a fight over any potential Clinton nominee.
Mr. Pressler also praised Stuart E. Eizenstat, the chief domestic policy adviser under President Jimmy Carter, who is well liked by Mr. Clinton, but an Administration official said it did not appear that Mr. Eizenstat would get the job.
Mr. Clinton is apparently interested in someone else, a person whom the official would not identify.
With the White House keeping quiet about filling the post, Congressional and economic-community officials circulated names of prospects, including John Young, former head of Hewlett-Packard; Mary Goode, the Acting Commerce Secretary; George Fisher, chief executive of Eastman Kodak, who spoke at Mr. Brown's funeral, and John Scully of Apple Computer Inc.
Officials say Mr. Clinton is interested in finding an official from a high-tech industry.
Laura D'Andrea Tyson of the National Economic Council and Phil Lader, the director of the Small Business Administration, have been mentioned in news reports as prospects, but aides said Mr. Clinton was not considering them.
Another question facing the President is whether Republicans will block his nominee as part of their effort to eliminate the Commerce Department. The plane crash that ended Mr. Brown's life also ended his campaign to save the department. Congressional Republicans promise to scrutinize the nominee, but they say Mr. Clinton will get a chance to put his person in place for the debate over the department's future.
A bill to dismantle the department had been scheduled for a vote on April 29. It may now be delayed until June out of respect to Mr. Brown, Republican officials said.

HEADLINE: Even Before Deregulation, Cable Rates Are on the Rise

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER and GERALDINE FABRIKANT 

 BODY:
For cable-television subscribers across the country, 1996 is starting to look a lot like 1986.
After a lull in recent years, cable rates are spiking up again -- more sharply than at any time since Congress deregulated the industry in the 1980's. In mailboxes from New York City to Norfolk, Va., and Seattle to Sacramento, Calif., cable subscribers have received the unwelcome news that their monthly bills are going up anywhere from 5 percent to 20 percent. 
 By June, when Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable operator, puts into effect its across-the-board rate increase of 13 percent, most of America's 63 million cable subscribers will be paying up to $3.50 more a month to watch CNN, MTV and the other channels that are part of basic cable service.
Cable operators said the increases were a necessary adjustment to the stringent rate cuts that the Government imposed on them in 1993, after a consumer backlash that prompted Congress to reregulate the industry. But critics said the industry was now seizing on loopholes in these rules to resume its practice of hefty rate increases.
"This is deja vu," said Gene Kimmelman, the co-director of Consumers Union, a lobbying group in Washington that has been critical of the cable industry. "These rate increases rank with the largest that occurred after Congress first deregulated cable in 1984."
What makes this wave of increases remarkable is that it comes even before cable rates are to be deregulated yet again. Under the communications law passed earlier this year, all Government controls on cable prices are to be removed -- but not until 1999, as the result of a compromise between Republican and Democratic lawmakers.
The compromise assumed that by the end of the century, the industry would have vigorous enough competition from satellite television or telephone companies to prevent cable rates from soaring.
Until then, in theory, the Federal Communications Commission is supposed to keep a tight rein on cable rates, allowing increases only for inflation and programming costs. In practice, though, the current rules give cable operators leeway to pass along higher costs to customers.
So far, the rate increases have not ignited a nationwide consumer revolt like the one that prompted the Government to roll back rates in 1993. But complaints are starting to pile up in local government offices in cities like Sacramento, Portland, Ore., and Suffolk, Va.
And some industry experts said the increases could erode whatever consumer good will the cable industry garnered from 1993 through last year, when rates rose moderately and even declined in some markets.
"Twice now, the Government has allowed big rate increases and each time, the public image of the cable industry has gotten clobbered," said Paul Kagan, a leading cable-industry analyst.
But now, unlike in the 1980's, consumers may have little recourse to mushrooming cable rates. With Congress having passed an intricate bill that strips away most regulations from telecommunications companies of all sorts, even lawmakers who harshly criticized cable rates will have scant leverage to rein them in. Few in Washington can envision anyone upsetting the law's delicate balance of industry interests simply to punish the cable companies.
Proponents of deregulation argue that the competition unleashed by the bill will curb cable rates. But satellite broadcasters still reach barely 2 million customers -- compared with the 63 million served by cable. And most of the regional Bell companies are scaling back their plans to break into television.
Indeed, some analysts said the industry was pushing its rates now primarily to capitalize on its monopoly position. "They still have a window," said Dennis Leibowitz, a cable analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "They are doing it now because later competition will make it harder."
Almost all the big cable operators have carried out -- or announced -- rate increases since January. In New York City, Time Warner raised its rates 10.4 percent. The typical monthly bill for Manhattan subscribers rose $2.85, to $30.18 from $27.33, according to Richard Aurelio, the president of Time Warner Cable's New York City system.
Until now, Mr. Aurelio said, the company had never raised its rates by more than $1 in a single stroke. The reason the increase is so much higher this time, he said, is because it covered a longer period of time than previous increases.
Historically, cable companies estimated cost increases and inflation every quarter, and passed along those costs to customers in the following quarter. Now, though, the companies are projecting their cost increases for the entire coming year and figuring them into the current monthly bill.
The F.C.C. rules that make this possible grew out of prolonged period of tinkering after the commission temporarily froze rates in 1993. In 1994, the F.C.C. allowed companies to raise rates if they added new channels, and in January it permitted them to begin raising rates to account for the growing cost of their existing channels.
Because the F.C.C. took several months to devise the new rules, the new round of increases encompass the period from July 1995 to January 1997. So, in effect, the industry is taking a year and a half worth of rate increases in one shot.
Tele-Communications is using that rationale to justify its 13 percent average rate increase, or $3.03 a month, to $25.34 from $22.31. The company is putting through even larger increases in certain markets, where the cost of maintaining its cable networks is unusually high.In Denver, for example, its rates are going up 20 percent, while in Seattle and Portland, rates are going up between 15 percent and 18 percent.
"They're betting that this very aggressive increase will pass muster at the F.C.C.," said David Olsen, the director of cable communications for Portland. "As one local government, we'll do everything we can to make our opinions heard."
Given that the rate increases are legal, it is not clear what Mr. Olsen and other officials can do.
Still, the grass-roots protests are making cable executives nervous -- even prompting some to label each other as rate-mongers.
"Jerry Levin bragged to me about how large their increases were," said John C. Malone, the chief executive of Tele-Communications, referring to Gerald M. Levin, the chairman of Time Warner.
A spokesman for Time Warner said Mr. Levin was traveling and unavailable for comment.
In New York City, Time Warner has tried to take the edge off the increase by offering a full year of service at the old rates, if customers paid in advance for the coming year. The company even threw in one free month of service. Mr. Aurelio said that 5.6 percent of Time Warner's 1.1 million New York City subscribers had responded to the offer.
Other cable executives defended the increases on competitive grounds: The industry needs huge amounts of capital to upgrade its networks to carry the crystal-clear digital images and exotic interactive programs that they say consumers will demand in a few years.
"I really get offended by the criticism because we need the capital desperately," said Marc B. Nathanson, the chairman of Falcon Cable TV, a medium-size operator, with 1.1 million subscribers.
Falcon recently announced it would raise its average monthly bill by $1.14, from $22 to $23.14. Although that ranks as one of the industry's more modest increases, it has prompted fierce complaints in some of Falcon's service areas, including Suffolk, Va., a suburb of Norfolk where Falcon has 16,000 customers.
"I no longer subscribe to Falcon because we get Mickey Mouse service and exorbitant rates," said Richard R. Harris, a council member who signed up for DirecTV, a satellite broadcasting service owned by Hughes Communications, a unit of the General Motors Corporation.
Reed E. Hundt, the chairman of the F.C.C. and the architect of the new rate regulations, acknowledged that this latest round of increases could alienate the very consumers that the telecommunications legislation was supposed to protect.
"Everybody thought Congress, cable and consumers had cut a deal," Mr. Hundt said. "I sure hope the compromise is not unraveling."

HEADLINE: About Real Estate;
Rental Apartments Try A Comeback in Suburbs

BYLINE: By MARY MCALEER VIZARD 

 BODY:
In suburban markets, developers who say they are responding to a lag in condominium and cooperative sales are increasingly turning to rentals. They say they are doing so in order to keep building and to serve a growing number of people who are unwilling or unable to commit to a purchase.
After the conversion craze of the 1980's, rental housing has been in growing demand in the suburbs. In Westchester County, for example, there was a 20 percent decline in rentals from 1980 to 1990, during which time 5,000 rental apartments disappeared. 
 The rentals being built today, however, do not fit the traditional image of tall, flat-roofed, brick buildings with no amenities. Instead, today's suburban rentals are more often low-rise garden apartment complexes with swimming pools and parking garages, perks normally associated with condominiums.
In Westchester County there are now about 10 rental projects being built or in the planning stages. Developers maintain that a change in attitude on the part of communities has allowed for the spurt of construction.
"Communities have gotten more sophisticated about the need for housing populations within the areas where they work," said Robert Weinberg, chairman of the Robert Martin Company, a developer and property owner based in Elmsford. "They're more inclined to work with the developer now to come up with a project that benefits everyone."
In one of its corporate parks, called Talleyrand, in Tarrytown, Robert Martin plans to break ground this summer on a rental complex of 300 one- and two-bedroom apartments, some with dens. They are expected to rent for $800 to $1,400 a month.
The complex will be colonial-style, with buildings "two to three stories high," said Jerome Rockhill, vice president for design and development. "And there'll be a parking garage underneath."
The housing will share the park with two existing office buildings and a T.G.I.F. restaurant. Robert Martin retains the right to build one additional office building.
The company is also planning another project that could have 600 to 700 units in the town of Greenburgh, "We're in negotiations now with the community to work out the number of units and determine the impacts on traffic and services," Mr. Weinberg said.
Both rental projects are designed to "serve an income bracket that's now caught in the middle," Mr. Weinberg said. "People who make $45,000 to $65,000 a year have too much money to qualify for a subsidy, but not enough for a down payment on a town house or condo."
The emergence of rentals is also a response, developers say, to the feeling of job insecurity that is so widespread today. "Every day we're hearing about people laid off somewhere," said Michael Seidner, a principal with Continental Properties of Edison, N.J. "People don't feel confident enough in their jobs to make the commitment to buy a house or condo now."
Mr. Seidner's company is now building two rental projects in Edison and planning a third. One is called Village Court, a 14-building complex with 248 apartments of one and two bedrooms, renting for $800 to $900. It is about two-thirds completed, Mr. Seidner said.
The other, Talmadge Village Estates, is now in the beginning stages of construction, and will offer one- and three-bedroom apartments and feature a parking garage. "It's very unusual to find a three-bedroom rental apartment in a complex with a parking garage," Mr. Seidner said.
Developers predict that some of the vacant office and factory space in many suburbs could one day be converted into rentals. In January, Scarsdale Associates of Manhattan, asked the Westchester village of Tuckahoe for permission to build 160 luxury apartments and a 70,000-square-foot supermarket in a former Revlon factory that has been vacant for over a decade.
There has been community opposition to the plan, based on the number of units and size of the supermarket, "but there's no objection to the fact that they're rentals," Mayor Philip White said.
One-bedroom rents in the village now start at $1,100 and go to $1,500 for two bedrooms, said Philly Scoca, owner of Village Realty. "I know I can't afford that," Ms. Scoca said. "They can get those rents now because demand far outstrips supply."
Rentals make economic sense for communities, according to Mr. Weinberg, because "they attract mostly two-career couples, singles and some older people."

HEADLINE: Developer Buys the Rights to Build a Times Square Tower

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
A Manhattan developer has acquired the right to construct a large office tower at the northeast corner of 42d Street and Broadway in Times Square, taking over part of a vast development proposal that has been stalled for 15 years.
The developer, Douglas Durst, has agreed to buy the rights to the site from a group headed by the Prudential Insurance Company of America. If Mr. Durst's plan succeeds -- and it is subject to approval by both the city and state, which is by no means assured -- his project would be the first new privately financed office building since 1992 in Manhattan, where an office glut has discouraged builders. 
 It would also break a logjam in the big development scheme for what New Yorkers once proudly described as the Crossroads of the World, an intersection that had grown tawdry and blighted since the 1950's but now shows signs of a renaissance in entertainment and shopping.
Prudential and its partner, George Klein, a large Manhattan builder, said they had agreed to Mr. Durst's terms in February, but no one involved in the deal would disclose how much Mr. Durst would pay. He has since submitted outlines of his plan to the city and state.
The site stretches from 42d Street to 43d Street, including the boarded-up hulk of the former Nathan's Famous restaurant, long a Times Square institution. In addition to the parcel controlled by Prudential, Mr. Durst would include adjacent property he owns, expanding the base of the proposed building by about 30 percent.
"The timing of this decision is based on what we see as the strength of the office market," he said in an interview, adding that he intended to build his office tower even if no large tenant is immediately found.
The Prudential group was selected in 1981 to develop four huge office towers on the south end of Times Square. It won the promise of long-term tax breaks from city and state officials, who hoped that the office buildings would lead a rebirth in the area.
But the plan provoked a torrent of lawsuits, and protests by civic groups upset at the huge scale of the proposed towers, which they said would overwhelm the congested intersection.
While the project was blocked by litigation, other developers began building at the north end of Times Square during the late 1980's, creating an office glut and postponing the Prudential plan.
Over the last two years, the Disney Company and other investors have moved in, investing heavily to renovate 42d Street theaters and open splashy new stores, sowing the seeds of renewal that were to have come from Prudential's towers.
Mr. Durst's plan contains an added twist because he and his company, the Durst Organization, had been among the most outspoken critics of the tax breaks offered to the Prudential group, saying they favored one builder over other property owners.
But now, Mr. Durst said, the time has come to build, and he intends to claim 35 percent of the Prudential group's long-term tax breaks, which apply to his building site.
Mr. Durst's plan comes when the office vacancy rate in midtown Manhattan has been shrinking, to 12 percent at the end of last year from a high of 17 percent in 1990, according to Cushman & Wakefield, a brokerage. He said he expected an increase in demand by 1999, the earliest his tower could be completed.
Top economic development officials for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki said they would like to see Mr. Durst's plan succeed. The city and state must agree to the transfer of tax breaks that had been pledged to Prudential, and to the design and size of Mr. Durst's building.
But John S. Dyson, the Deputy Mayor for finance and economic development, said he would insist that Mr. Durst have a commitment to his building by at least one large tenant as a form of insurance that it be built quickly. "As a business deal, we are not there yet," Mr. Dyson said.
State officials may hold greater sway over the plan, since the state, through its condemnation powers, has already acquired the land under Prudential's building sites, as well as several other parcels along 42d Street.
"I feel comfortable this deal will go ahead," said Charles Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation. He said the agency planned a public hearing on Mr. Durst's plan for May 6. But like Mr. Dyson, he said some assurance that an anchor tenant has signed would be required by the state.
Mr. Durst, while saying he would be confident enough in his building's prospects even without an immediate commitment from a large tenant, said he was aggressively seeking one and might have a commitment within weeks.
But he denied speculation that Conde Nast, the publishing company, was interested in the site for a headquarters. "I've had discussions with them, but they did not go anywhere," Mr. Durst said.
Mr. Durst declined to say how large his tower would be, saying that that is being negotiated. But someone close to the discussions who insisted on anonymity said Mr. Durst wanted about the same square footage as Prudential had proposed, though the building would not be as tall because it would be on a larger site. Prudential's plan was for a 58-story building.
If Mr. Durst does not try to exceed the floor area that Prudential wanted, he seems likely to avoid some of the opposition the greeted the Prudential group in the 1980's.
The buildings at the other three Prudential sites -- at the southeast corner of 42d Street and Broadway, the southwest corner of 42d Street and Seventh Avenue and the northwest corner of 42d Street and Seventh Avenue -- are undergoing renovation at street level to accommodate 19 new stores, including gift shops and delicatessens, which are to open by the end of the year.
The work is being performed by the Prudential group as part of an interim agreement with the city and state two years ago that enables it to put off construction of its office towers until office demand picks up.
But with Mr. Durst planning his tower, the Prudential group may push forward its plan to build, said Michelle Demilly, a spokeswoman.
"Development on one site will certainly spur development on the other three," she said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Close Mostly Higher

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Treasury prices closed slightly higher yesterday after a report on producer prices eased worries among some market participants that inflation could accelerate.
In the corporate bond market, Donald J. Trump and affiliates sold $1.2 billion of 10-year junk notes -- or 9 percent more than planned -- to help finance the merger of the Trump Plaza and Trump Taj Mahal casinos in Atlantic City. 
 The Labor Department reported yesterday that the Producer Price Index rose five-tenths of 1 percent in March, while the so-called core index, which excludes food and energy price rises, edged up a slim one-tenth of 1 percent. Producer prices are the prices that manufacturers and farmers charge for the products they sell to retailers, distributors or other buyers.
The core figure indicated that the recent jump in commodity prices was not yet being passed along by wholesalers to retailers, analysts said, which calmed some investors.
"The market very quickly focused in on the fact that core prices are not rising at any level," said Christopher Low of HSBC Markets Inc.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond swung during the session and ended up 4/32 at 884/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, slipped to 6.93 percent, from 6.94 percent on Wednesday.
Although the producer price data were roughly in line with expectations, analysts said the market's jitters over inflation in the medium-term were not past.
The Producer Price Index "convinced the market that at least for one month things are still going O.K.," Mr. Low said. "But people are still worried."
One source of concern, analysts said, was another rise in the Commodity Research Bureau index of 17 commodities to a fresh eight-year high. The index rose 1.75 points, to 260.66 points.
Investors will be watching another inflation report today, the Government's release of the Consumer Price Index and the retail sales reports for March.
Bond prices were also bolstered by remarks from a Federal Reserve Board governor, Janet Yellen. In a speech she said she saw no significant impact on inflation from wage pressures.
Analysts have been worried about a possible minimum wage increase, which could put more money into people's pockets, fuel consumer demand and spark inflation.
Traders said the Fed's two coupon passes yesterday, although not bold, also underpinned Treasury prices.
"The Fed was not a very aggressive buyer of securities," said Patrick Dimick of CS First Boston.
In the first intervention, the central bank bought coupons maturing Oct. 15, 1996, to Sept. 30, 1998, for settlement on April 15. Later, the Fed purchased coupons maturing from Oct. 15, 1998, to Feb. 15, 2003, for delivery on Monday.
A coupon pass occurs when the Fed comes to the market to buy certain maturities to add cash to the banking system. While it is not a signal of any change in monetary policy, the coupon pass presents dealers with an opportunity to sell Treasuries to a ready buyer.
Analysts said they expect the market to remain in narrow ranges over the next few days with yields around 7 percent.
"I think 7 percent bonds are probably going to be viewed as reasonable value, 7 percent makes sense given where inflation is," said James Glassman, senior economist at Chase Securities Inc.
In trading in corporate bonds, Trump Atlantic City Associates' 10-year first mortgage notes, callable after five years, were priced at par to yield 11.25 percent, a quarter percentage point above the yields previously estimated.
But investor demand was strong and the size of the offering was increased yesterday to $1.2 billion from $1.1 billion. Originally, the deal had been decreased slightly, from $1.18 billion to $1.1 billion.
Mr. Trump will use the proceeds of the offering to merge the Taj Mahal in which he owns a 50 percent stake -- into Trump Hotels, which operates the Trump Plaza and a still-to-open riverboat gaming operation in Indiana. The merger, approved by shareholders and bondholders yesterday, is expected to close Wednesday.

HEADLINE: U.S. Enlists Rich Nations in Move to End Business Bribes

BYLINE: By MARLISE SIMONS 

DATELINE: PARIS, April 11

 BODY:
Under intense pressure from the United States, the world's richest nations today took an important step to fight corruption in international business dealings by agreeing that bribes paid to foreign officials, often listed as commissions or fees, should no longer be tax deductible.
The United States, which is the only major nation that has laws barring its companies from paying bribes abroad, has long argued that Americans are often at a disadvantage in bidding for major contracts around the world. 
 But rather than weaken its own rules, a move some American business executives wanted, Washington has enlisted its main rivals and others to join an anti-bribery campaign.
Today's decision by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, a club of industrial countries, commits its 26 members to rewrite tax rules that have effectively encouraged the bribery of foreign officials by making such payoffs tax deductible.
"This is a sea change, a very important step in breaking the international chain of corruption," said David Aaron, the American representative at the organization. "It takes governments out of the business of subsidizing corruption by giving tax breaks for bribery.
"It may sound ludicrous to declare a bribe as a tax deduction, but that is simply a measure of how ingrained this habit was."
While all the O.E.C.D. countries have laws against domestic corruption, most of these rules do not apply to what their executives do abroad.
On the contrary, most industrialized countries allow businesses to deduct payoffs and kickbacks, commonly described as commissions or fees or promotional costs, from their taxable income as a legitimate expense.
Business executives and diplomats from several European countries said they believed that in countries with strong tax systems, the proposed changes should have an effect on business practices because large payments to officials will not be deductible.
But some said that given the stiff competition for what are often multibillion-dollar contracts in construction, armaments, telecommunications and pharmaceuticals, entrepreneurs may try to find loopholes.
They noted that some American companies, barred from paying graft, have hired middlemen to handle such matters, and that some regularly woo prospective clients by inviting them on junkets to the United States that include gambling stops at Las Vegas or Atlantic City or visits to Disney World.
A number of American companies do not need to disclose foreign payments if they are involved in "national security" work.
In most cases -- but not in the United States, Britain and Canada -- payments to foreign officials have been tax deductible as long as the recipient is identified by name. Laws are most lax in Belgium, Luxembourg and Greece, which have not even required the recipient's name.
In each country, Governments are expected to propose legislation tightening tax laws, which will be subject to parliamentary approval.
The group gave the member countries no deadline for revising their tax codes, but it ordered a watchdog committee to monitor the changes with instructions to report back within a year.
The O.E.C.D. does not have the power to make its agreements legally binding; it works through peer pressure, and its decisions amount to strong commitments by the members.
American diplomats said they hoped the next step would be to make payoffs to foreign officials a crime, as they are under the United States Foreign Corrupt Practises Act of 1977.
The Council for International Business in New York, one of many American groups that has lobbied against bribery as an unfair business practice, applauded the move.
"We are very pleased that the O.E.C.D. has gone much further and much faster than we anticipated," said Sheila O'Neil, a council official, noting that when talks began in 1994 "there wasn't much of a consensus."
Insiders said negotiations had been difficult, with countries with powerful ministries in charge of commerce or exports, like Germany, Japan and France, at first arguing that they could not put obstacles in the way of exporters. But they said the issue gained momentum in recent months as big bribery scandals have come to light affecting many governments. "We think everyone has begun to see the huge social and economic and political consequences of bribery," Ms. O'Neil said.
American diplomats who have worked on the anti-bribery issue said they felt vindicated as the 26 Governments approved today's anti-bribery move by consensus.
"We were considered naive Americans for pushing this issue," Mr. Aaron said. "Now many others recognize there is a serious problem."
Since 1977 several dozen American companies have been charged with violating the anti-bribery law, but no chief executive has been convicted.
Today's decision is part of a broad crusade by the Clinton Administration, which has said that bribery used by America's rivals represents a real if invisible form of trade barrier. It has said bribery inhibits American exports and cost Americans jobs, all the more so in the present rush toward the globalization of business, with opportunities growing rapidly in Eastern Europe and Asia. Large American companies, including General Electric and Boeing, have openly complained that they have difficulty competing for contracts with European rivals who are free to use bribes.
In March the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, calling bribery an unfair tariff, said, "Last year, from April 1994 to May 1995, the U.S. Government learned of almost 100 cases in which foreign bribes undercut U.S. firms' ability to win contracts valued at $45 billion."
He added that the Administration's goal was "to level the playing field and make the rules fair by eliminating his pernicious practice."
The Clinton Administration is not alone. Several West European governments have said that they are in favor of addressing the issues of bribes and extortion in future loan and aid agreements and have begun debating at the O.E.C.D. the question of how to police development aid.
Two weeks ago the International Chamber of Commerce, based in Paris and with members from more than 130 countries, published new rules on how to handle extortion and bribery.
"We are definitely noticing a change in attitude," said Karen Hussmann, an official of Transparency International, a Berlin-based group that fights corruption. "Many governments and companies are becoming sensitized to the devastating impact of corruption."
On March 29 the United States was successful in its campaign to have the Organization of American States adopt an Inter-American Convention Against Corruption.
Next, the Clinton Administration has said, it wants to put corporate bribery on the agenda of the ministerial meeting of the World Trade Organization in Singapore later this year.

HEADLINE: BOXING;
No Title Fight Is Complete Without Palm Trees

BYLINE: By GERALD ESKENAZI 

DATELINE: ST. MAARTEN, Netherlands Antilles, April 11

 BODY:
Pernell Whitaker, bored with yet another opponent he says he has never seen fight, will put his welterweight title at risk Friday night in this unlikely setting.
Unlike Whitaker, the island is attempting a comeback after a hurricane roared through here for more than a day last September and left only a third of the hotel rooms still usable. 
 So the commissioner of boxing, Jacinth Bryan Labega -- "My husband used to be a fighter; we love the sport." -- is cheerleading a championship doubleheader that she hopes will not only bring back the fight game but also the tourists.
Whitaker will earn $2.5 million, thanks to some French promoters and Home Box Office, for his fight against the unbeaten Wilfredo Rivera.
But one wonders after six world titles in four weight classes and an 11-year career at the top, whether he is in the position to be toppled at the age of 32. How long can he keep saying that he has no interest in fighting, that he doesn't watch his opponents and that he needs extra-special incentive to be motivated?
For this fight, he brought his wife and four children and what seems to be all the kids on the block he grew up with.
Rivera, with a 23-0-1 record, is the World Boxing Council's No. 1 challenger. Teddy Atlas, who once trained him, describes Rivera as "careful and cautious, a very good technician who is not going to let Pernell sucker him."
Whitaker, an outstanding defensive fighter, has also drawn many of his opponents out of their game plan with his maddening moves, which include ducking and crouching so that his knees almost touch the mat.
The semifinal, also a welterweight championship, kicks off the HBO telecast at 9:30 P.M. It features Ike Quartey, who holds the World Boxing Association title, against Vince Phillips, a onetime New Yorker.
It is possible that if Whitaker and Quartey win, they will meet to unify the title -- sort of. Felix Trinidad, another outstanding performer, is the International Boxing Federation welterweight ruler.
Phillips graduated from Taft High School in the Bronx and attended Pensacola (Fla.) Junior College. He was a baseball pitcher as well.
"But they cut me because they said I didn't have a 90-mile-an-hour fastball," he said.
"Now he's got a 90-mile-an-hour right hand," said one of his handlers, Akbar Muhammad.
Phillips has a 33-1 record with 22 knockouts. Quartey, from Ghana, is 31-1 with 27 knockouts.
Whitaker has been training with the same unorthodox moves that have enabled him to post a 37-1-1 record since becoming an Olympic champion at Los Angeles 12 years ago. But he has seemed uninterested these last weeks, becoming animated only when discussing his unofficial crown as the world's best pound-for-pound fighter -- a shaky crown, at that, with the supermiddleweight champion Roy Jones Jr. beating up opponents.
Whitaker arrived around midnight on Tuesday after having a long day punctuated by a snow-interrupted flight from Newark. The temperature will be in the high 70's by fight time.
To keep the Caribbean look for its television audience, HBO stationed its main camera on the side of the ring overlooking the azure water. The background seemed a little bare, though, so palm trees were brought in from another part of the island and planted in the distance.
No one in the audience should have trouble seeing the fighters. The action will take place in a sort of courtyard at a gambling casino-hotel. There will be only 1,000 people in attendance -- and 700 of them have been invited free, from the United States, Europe and South America, because they are high-stakes gamblers. It cost more than $11,000 to ship the ring by container from New Jersey. It has been set up over the fountain in the courtyard.
St. Maarten is about a 30-minute flight east of Puerto Rico. It is a small place, with only about 80,000 residents.
Theo Heyliger, whose business card reads "Commissioner in charge of tourism, economic affairs, public transportation, energy affairs and harbor," is hoping that the fight card will demonstrate that the island is recovering.

HEADLINE: J. P. Morgan Earnings Rise; First Union Shows Decline

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
J. P. Morgan & Company said yesterday that earnings rose 72 percent in the first quarter as trading profits surged.
Bank of New York also reported a strong gain. Earnings at First Union, however, fell, reflecting costs related to its acquisition of First Fidelity of Newark. 
 J. P. Morgan, the nation's fifth-biggest banking company, said net income rose to $439 million, or $2.13 a share, from $255 million, or $1.27, in the quarter a year earlier.
Analysts had expected the company, which offers commercial and investment banking services, to earn about $1.71 a share, based on a survey of 15 analysts by IBES International Inc.
But shares of J. P. Morgan fell $1.875, to $77.125, on concerns that profits from trading would decline. Trading revenue more than doubled to $758 million in the quarter -- almost twice as high as analysts expected.
"People may be questioning whether that level of trading gains is sustainable, which it's probably not," said Robert Maneri, an analyst with Society Asset Management.
Still, the stock decline came amid a general selloff in banking issues prompted by concerns that this year's rise in interest rates could slow loan growth and shrink lending margins.
J. P. Morgan, based in New York, is one of the biggest traders in the world. It had an explosive quarter, recording $602 million in trading revenue, compared with $303 million a year ago.
Keefe, Bruyette & Woods raised its earnings estimate for 1996 to $7.50 a share from $7 after the earnings were announced, and Merrill Lynch & Company said it expected to raise its estimate as well.
First Union, based in Charlotte, N.C., reported earnings of $242.9 million, or 85 cents a share, down from $349.8 million, or $1.19 a share, in the quarter a year earlier. The recent quarter included $181 million in charges for costs of the acquisition of First Fidelity, which it completed in January.
But operating profits rose to $424 million, or $1.50 a share, from net income of $349.8 million, or $1.19, a year earlier.
"The $1.50 pretty much proves that they're going to have no trouble in hitting the $6.30 that they've projected for the year," said Richard Bove, an analyst with Raymond James & Associates.
Shares of First Union rose 75 cents yesterday, to $58.25.
The Bank of New York Company said first-quarter earnings rose 14 percent on increased lending and higher revenue in the company's securities-processing business.
Earnings rose to $243 million, or $1.16 a share, from $213 million, or $1.12, a year ago. The results exceeded analysts' expectations of $1.14 a share, based on a survey of 19 analysts by IBES.
"Fee-based income is doing very well across the board," said Thomas Hanley, an analyst with UBS Securities Inc.
The banking company said net interest income rose to $517 million from $502 million because of increased lending.
Bank of New York shares fell 87.5 cents, to $48.

HEADLINE: Experts Say Stadium Plan Would Cut Yankees' Take

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
Ticket sales, luxury suites and other revenue will not raise enough cash to pay for the $1 billion West Side stadium envisioned by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani without cutting deeply into the profits of the Yankees or any other sports tenant, experts familiar with the financing of stadiums in other cities said.
That fact, the experts said, suggests that the plan Mr. Giuliani has endorsed as the most fiscally sound way to keep the Yankees from leaving New York City with minimal cost to taxpayers, may be impracticable. 
 "It is undoable," said John Moag Jr., chairman of the Maryland Stadium Authority, which financed Oriole Park at Camden Yards in Baltimore and has lured the former Cleveland Browns to play in an adjacent football stadium.
"It's hard to think of the funding sources to get that high," said Mitchell Zietz, senior management consultant at Public Financial Management, a Philadelphia-based consulting firm.
At least $90 million a year would be needed to pay off the state bonds that would finance construction of the stadium, which would be the most expensive ever built by far. That would almost equal the $107 million combined annual debt payments for eight recently built or planned stadiums in Denver, Baltimore, Cleveland, Nashville, Arlington, Tex., and Cincinnati.
Raising the $90 million through the sale of tickets, luxury boxes and beer would require crowds of at least 40,000 for Yankee games, 66,500 for football games (if a team is found), and the sale of between 120 and 220 luxury suites, costing up to $175,000 each, according to a study done for New York City, the state and the Yankees. And it would require that the city and state get enormous percentages of that revenue from the teams, including a significant portion of the Yankees' profits.
The debt would also have to be covered by revenue from other events anticipated by Mr. Giuliani, like conventions, Super Bowls and the N.C.A.A. basketball Final Four.
A 70,000 seat multipurpose stadium with a retractable dome, Mr. Giuliani said yesterday, would give the city "an asset that it does not presently have, that cities far smaller than New York now have, and that allow them to outbid us, and to beat us, in terms of being able to bring conventions to their city."
But the Yankees, with 81 dates a year, are for now the only permanent tenant in sight. The Jets have a lease in New Jersey through 2008. And crucial to the final decision will be how much of the Yankees' lucrative cash flow George M. Steinbrenner 3d, the team's principal owner, would be willing to surrender.
Mr. Steinbrenner, who is dissatisfied with the money-making potential of Yankee Stadium, would be expected to bear some of the financing burden, but it may be excessive to expect him to dedicate more than a small share of his revenue to the debt, especially without a football cotenant on the horizon.
The Mayor may ask Mr. Steinbrenner to concede all or some money from areas like beverage-pouring rights, luxury suites, stadium-naming fees and personal seat licenses, which are one-time fees for the right to buy season tickets.
"Look, this is all pie in the sky," said former Mayor Edward I. Koch. "George Steinbrenner is yanking Rudy Giuliani's chain. He won't give up a nickel that he thinks he can get, from parking to frankfurters to boxes. He won't give up a French sou, let alone an American dollar."
At $1 billion, the two-sport, retractable dome stadium envisioned by the Mayor next to the Hudson River between 30th and 33d streets would cost four times what the San Francisco Giants are raising without government aid for a privately financed ballpark in the city's China Basin area. And the cost is nearly twice what the multipurpose Skydome in Toronto cost several years ago.
The steep price boggles many in the stadium business. But Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum, the architectural firm that studied the site on the West Side of Manhattan, said the cost is necessary because a $103 million concrete platform must be built over the rail yards on the site; numerous highway, road and mass transit improvements are necessary, and the cost of doing business in New York City is astronomical.
The $388 million cost of the two-sport stadium structure alone is equaled by various infrastructure costs and provisions for cost overruns and inflation.
"The costs are based on historic precedent," said Tim Delorm, the architect who was in charge of the study.
Mayor Giuliani, who had dinner Tuesday with Mr. Steinbrenner, has begun to pinpoint stadium revenue sources that could finance the debt, said people familiar with the process.
Mr. Giuliani said Wednesday: "We had a very interesting conversation," which included discussions about the West Side and Yankee Stadium, "and the things the Yankees are going to have to do to make a decision and the things that the city has to focus on, even beyond the Yankees, for the best interests of the city."
He said the next step was to take a "very, very close look" at financing.
"And there are different ways to do it," he said, adding that he would like to resolve the situation by the end of the year.
A financial analysis of the West Side site by KPMG Peat Marwick, the accounting firm, found that a dual purpose stadium would generate revenue of $199 million, while a baseball-only facility would produce $129.6 million.
According to Financial World magazine, the Yankees generated $32.5 million in gross revenue from gate receipts and other stadium sources, including luxury boxes, in the strike-shortened 1994 season. Figures from Financial World and the Parks Department place the 1995 gross revenue estimate at $45 million. The numbers exclude the Yankees' estimated $45 million cable television rights payment.
For the state and city to try to finance $90 million in debt payments from a multipurpose stadium, it would require nearly half of the stadium's $199 million revenue estimated by Peat Marwick. To finance the debt from a baseball-only stadium would take two-thirds of the estimated $129 million in revenue.
"For an owner to give up a lot of money, it means cutting into the value of his team," said Michael Ozanian, deputy editor of Financial World.
The Peat Marwick analysis has buoyed Mr. Giuliani, who has touted the dual-purpose stadium with a retractable dome and artificial turf as the easiest option to finance. The revenue, he said, "would be off the charts."
"It's something the city of New York will appreciate 20 to 30 years from now," the Mayor said yesterday.
Peat Marwick's findings, which sports-financing experts say may be unrealistic, include these:
*An average of 40,750 people would pay an average of $15.46 for tickets to watch Yankee games, and 66,500 would pay an average of $34.56 for tickets to watch football, providing revenue of $74.2 million. The estimated attendance for baseball would be 67 percent above the Yankees' average of 24,293 during last year's shortened season.
*One hundred twenty luxury suites for baseball would sell out at $150,000 each, and 220 suites for football, the sports with a greater demand for suites, would sell out at $175,000 apiece, providing revenue of $38.5 million.
*Eight thousand cushy club seats for baseball would sell for $3,500 each and 16,000 for football would sell for $3,000 each, providing revenue that could reach $76 million.
"That assumption is so excessive as not to be reachable," said Marc Ganis, president of Sportscorp Ltd., a Chicago-based consulting firm. "A $3,500 premium for a baseball club seats -- where baseball club seats have not done all that well -- is excessive. And 8,000 is a lot when you consider that 25,000 is a great number for a team's total season ticket base."
If Mr. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki pursue the West Side option without enough financing from stadium revenue, they would have to consider using other sources of money that are common to such projects, including sales taxes, taxing tickets for sports and other entertainment events, taxes on alcohol, wine, cigarettes, hotel rooms and car rentals, or a special sports lottery.
Some of the taxes would be politically untenable; the city sales tax of 8 1/2 percent is already high, the hotel tax was recently reduced from an onerous level to make the city more competitive, and any increase in "sin taxes" would be protested by the liquor, beer and tobacco lobbies.
A lottery directing all of its proceeds into a stadium fund would require special legislation, said Rick Grenell, a spokesman for the New York State Lottery. "Right now, all our profits have to go into education," he said.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Sales of U.S. Autos Up 50% in Japan Since Trade Accord

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 11

 BODY:
Ten months after the United States reached a high-stakes accord with Japan over automobile trade, President Clinton is set to announce that sales of American cars in the Japanese market have surged 50 percent and that Japanese auto makers have begun buying far larger quantities of American parts.
Mr. Clinton will make a formal announcement of the figures in the White House on Friday, Administation officials said today. The announcement will come two days before Mr. Clinton departs on his second state visit to Japan, and just as the Ford Motor Company moves to tighten its control of the Mazda Motor Corporation of Japan. [Page D1.] 
 While the President's claims of success in an area that has stymied his predecessors for 20 years are clearly tinged with politics -- Senator Bob Dole, his Republican opponent in November, is already talking about stricter enforcement of trade accords -- the numbers are promising enough for Mr. Clinton to make a case that his brinksmanship with Tokyo is beginning to pay off.
Asked why the President will be personally appearing to talk about mufflers, roof racks and auto repair, the White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, told reporters today: "We've got bragging rights, so we'll claim them. Is that straightforward enough?"
According to officials familiar with the plans for the Friday presentation, Mr. Clinton will announce that since the accord was reached in June, the Japanese Government has certified 730 automotive garages that are independent of Toyota, Nissan and the other major Japanese auto manufacturers, freeing the garages to carry American-made replacement parts, from shock absorbers to power-steering systems. Until now, such repairs could only be made by Government-certified garages that were tied to the Japanese auto industry.
Moreover, sales of American cars in Japan, which were running at about 10,000 a month before the accord, jumped to about 15,000 a month in the last quarter of 1995.
Even some of the makers of auto parts who were skeptical of the value of the accord struck in late June now say they believe that a change in attitudes has begun to set in.
"It is a remarkable shift," said Robert E. Cole, a vice president of Kaiser Aluminum and chairman of a committee that advises the Government on automotive trade. "In some cases we have seen the numbers really jump. But more importantly, we're seeing sincere interest in what we have to offer. That rarely happened before."
The auto accord was negotiated in Geneva between Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, and Ryutaro Hashimoto, who is now Japan's Prime Minister. It was the biggest of the 20 agreements that have been struck with Japan since Mr. Clinton's last trip to Tokyo, in July 1993, and the one on which the Administration bargained hardest. The American side threatened to ban the import of Japanese luxury cars if Japan refused to accede to the American demands.
In the end, as in all trade negotiations, the Administration got considerably less than it had originally demanded. Mr. Hashimoto, for example, fought off efforts to force the Japanese auto makers to buy far more American parts for their Japanese factories, though the accord called for big increases in the use of American-made parts in Japanese "transplant" factories in the United States.
And Japan refused to agree to any specific purchasing targets; instead, Mr. Kantor was given nonbinding, sometimes vague, estimates by Japanese auto makers of their plans to import parts over the next several years; the United States then translated those estimates into more specific numbers.
But with two notable exceptions, the agreement has already resulted in significantly more progress than Mr. Kantor, the President's campaign manager in 1992, had expected last summer. Toyota has announced that by 1998, three-quarters of the vehicles it sells in the United States will be made in the United States. The Japanese Government has followed through on virtually all of its commitments to streamline regulations that American companies complained were intended to aid the home team, especially rules that limited the sale of foreign-made replacement parts, a $60 billion market in Japan.
But resistance continues in some areas, including the creation of more dealerships in Japan for American autos. Last June, Mr. Kantor said that he expected 200 new dealers by the end of the first year of the accord; in fact, agreements that have been struck so far would create only 30. And increases in sales of American parts to Toyota, Nissan and Honda, Japan's big three, have only been modest, though there is often a lag of three years between the time that a new part is "designed in" to a new model and the time those shipments begin to show up in trade statistics.
Still, the United States Transportation Department reported recently that the North American content of Japanese-made cars this year is up 14 percent, compared with 1995 models. Cars made by Japanese companies in the United States average more than 50 percent American content this year for the first time, a statistic that allows Mr. Clinton to make the campaign statement that he has succeeded in creating jobs for American workers.
The question that economists and statisticians cannot answer convincingly is how much of this change would have happened anyway. The strength of the yen in the first half of the 1990's created a constant incentive for Japanese manufacturers to buy more imports; they were only constrained by the fear of a social backlash if they began to lay off Japanese workers in large numbers.
"You could argue that the big change came in 1992, when the Big Three chief executives came to Japan with President Bush and were so embarrassed back at home," said J. Michael Farren, a top Commerce Department official at the time. "When they came back, they began to invest in Japan seriously."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Wall Street Begins to Fear Market May Continue Slide
After five days of declines, Wall Street's spirits are being dampened by a nasty suspicion that the stock market may not always rise. Worries about inflation are probably the chief culprit. Commodity prices are hitting new highs, and bond yields are climbing quite close to 7 percent. Market Place. [Page A1.]
 
Most stocks fell again, with the S. & P. 500 stock index off 2.32 points, to 631.18, and the Nasdaq composite down 8.14, to 1,097.14. But the Dow industrials eked out a gain of 1.09 points, to 5,487.07. [D7.]
 
Inflation Jitters Surface
Inflation jitters grew despite a Government report that a jump in producer prices in March was confined to energy and food. Contributing to the uneasiness were rising prices for oil, grains and metals. [D3.]
 
American Cars Selling in Japan
Sales of American cars in Japan have surged 50 percent, and Japanese auto makers are lifting purchases of American parts, 10 months after Washington and Tokyo reached a high-stakes accord over the automotive trade, Administration officials said. [A1.]
 
A $1.2 Billion Broadcasting Deal
The Sinclair Broadcast Group of Baltimore agreed to buy River City Broadcasting of St. Louis for $1.2 billion. The deal, made possible be the recent overhaul of telecommunications laws, will form the nation's seventh-largest television holding company. [D4.]
 
China and France in Jet Deal
China and France signed a preliminary agreement to study joint development of a 100-seat jet. Boeing and McDonnell Douglas have also been seeking to team up with the Chinese to build a new plane. [D2.]
 
J. P. Morgan Profits Jump 72%
J. P. Morgan benefited from surging trading profits in the first quarter. Bank of New York also had a strong gain, but First Union's profits fell, reflecting an acquisition. [D6.]
 
Kmart Plans Integrity Pledge
Kmart plans to require all employees and vendors to sign an "integrity pledge" related to gifts and kickbacks. [D2.]
 
Retail Sales Up on Easter Buying
Retails sales rose 4.23 percent in March, according to Goldman Sachs, but analysts cautioned that much of the gain was buying for Easter, and that April sales could lag. [D3.]
 
News on the Web, for a Fee
Time Warner plans to begin charging a monthly fee for a personalized news delivery system on the World Wide Web. It would let users of Compuserve gain access to the service without charge. [D6.]
 
O.E.C.D. in Anti-Bribery Stance
Under pressure from the United States, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, representing the world's richest nations, agreed that bribes paid to foreign officials, often listed as commissions or fees, should no longer be tax-deductible. [A10.]
 
A New Tower for Times Square?

Subject to city and state approval, he would take over part of a vast development proposal that has been stalled for 15 years. Terms were not disclosed. [B1.]

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Time of Testing In Love Affair With Wall St.

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
While the rest of New York enjoyed a beautiful spring day, it was drizzling yesterday on Wall Street, where spirits are being dampened by the nasty suspicion that maybe, just maybe, the stock market will not continue to go up forever.
Such a suggestion has almost become heresy this year as the market has soared, aided by low interest rates and a flood of money from average Americans, many of them investing for their retirements. These often inexperienced investors have been told that every decline is just a chance to pick up a bargain. And until now, that has been right. 
 Most stock prices have been falling since last Thursday. And while blue-chip stocks managed to eke out a gain yesterday -- the Dow Jones industrial average rose 1.09 points, to 5,487.07 -- it capped the worst five trading days for the market in two years. For the first time in a long time, the stock market is not immediately bouncing back from bad days and bad news.
The immediate culprit is probably worries about inflation; commodity prices are hitting highs, and bond yields are climbing awfully close to 7 percent. "Until last week confidence was very high that inflation was not a problem, rising interest rates are not a problem, the Fed is not a problem," said Michael Metz, the chief strategist at Oppenheimer & Company. "Now the whole story is gone, and it was the only justification for a market that otherwise looks extremely overvalued."
Which leaves the stock market relying on Russ Roach.
Mr. Roach is not a market guru; he is a state legislator in Oklahoma who found a great way to increase the size of his campaign war chest -- by investing a big chunk of it in the stock market. In fact, he concentrated his bet on just one stock and scored big with a gain of more than 60 percent in just 11 months.
From the floor of the House of Representatives in Oklahoma City, Mr. Roach, a Tulsa Democrat, said he was quite an experienced investor -- he owns about seven stocks and six mutual funds -- and that he did not rely on a hot tip to put his money in the Williams Companies, a local pipeline concern. It was, he said, "a very safe investment."
Such serene confidence in the stock market, the almost complete lack of fear, seems to characterize investing in the 90's. It is part of the phenomenon of billions of dollars flooding into stock mutual funds -- as much in the first three months of this year as in all of 1994 -- and Congress seriously proposing that Social Security money be invested in stocks.
Indeed, it may be a kind of New Age Ebullience. It used to be that the stock market madness that signaled trouble was symbolized by guys guzzling champagne and throwing big bills out the windows of Rolls-Royces; today, market mania may be characterized by retirees-to-be confidently shoveling their cash into stocks, believing that over the long run, whatever that may be, the market will rise.
So far, the weak market does not seem to have soured average investors, at least those who buy mutual funds. At Charles Schwab & Company, a discount brokerage concern, investors sold slightly more stocks than they bought in the month through April 10 -- $2.18 billion versus $2.22 billion. But they bought more stock mutual funds, for $1.25 billion, than they sold, for $800 million.
Whether the new love affair of Americans for equities is a good sign or not depends on the point of view of the analysts -- and, probably, their ages. It used to be that when individual investors got interested in the stock market, the professionals pulled back, because they believed ordinary people buy at the top.
But today, the huge inflows into stocks via mutual funds are widely considered to be a prime impetus behind the rising market, the idea being that demographic demand for equities pushes up prices. As more Americans have to make their own decisions about investing their pensions, they have been inundated with studies showing that stocks are always the best investments in the long run.
"That has been true for the last 15 years, so why not believe it?" asked Robert J. Farrell, senior investment adviser at Merrill Lynch. "Except that one day it won't be true, because the market goes from one extreme to another."
Eventually, he said, returns are not going to match the average investor's expectations, and when that happens, the consequences could be severe. "I'm afraid people are going to be disappointed."
Old market hands like Barton M. Biggs, chairman of Morgan Stanley Asset Management, like to point out that no market goes up forever. "It wasn't so long ago that the conventional wisdom was commercial real estate was the way to get rich," he wrote recently, "and you couldn't go wrong buying your home with a big mortgage since prices only went up."
Over the next few years, he has predicted, stocks will return only 4 percent a year, far less than the 14 percent they have averaged in the last five years.
The bull market has been going on at least since 1987 and by most measures since 1982. The value that the stock market puts on America's blue-chip companies, as measured by the Dow industrial index, has doubled since 1991.
None of this means that the stock market is necessarily going to crumble next week or next month or even next year. It has not paid investors to be cautious, much less bearish, in a very long time.
And many seasoned investors, like Lazlo Birinyi, who runs his own research firm in Connecticut, remain bullish. "Though with a small b," he said, adding that he expects the Dow to bounce around between 5,400 and 5,700 this year, which does not leave much room for further gains. Yesterday, the Dow was down 203 points from its high of 5,690 on April 3. According to his figures, the last time the Dow suffered such a steep drop was in March 1994, when the Dow tumbled almost 243 points in a week.
But Mr. Metz of Oppenheimer points out that even pension investors are not forced to keep their money in the stock market. "In the dark age, this money used to go into Guaranteed investment contracts, bond funds and balanced funds," he said.
And it may well do so again if interest rates continue to rise. Right now, the yield on 30-year Treasury bonds is 6.93 percent. A 7 percent bond yield is "neutral territory" for stocks, but 7.5 percent is "bearish at this price level," said Eric H. Sorensen, the head of global quantitative research for Salomon Brothers.

HEADLINE: Mixed Signs In Producer Price Index

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 11

 BODY:
Inflation jitters grew today despite a report that a sizable increase in producer prices in March was confined largely to energy and food.
Contributing to the uneasiness was another rise in the price of oil, as well as increases for grains and metals. There was also a bigger drop than expected in first-time claims for unemployment insurance in the week ended last Saturday. 
 Summing up the mixed evidence, which caused a brief deterioration of the bond market, analysts said reassuring figures for last month did little to offset current price surges.
"Some people think inflation's on the way, even if they didn't get it in this report" from the Labor Department, said Edward F. McKelvey, senior economist at Goldman, Sachs. He pointed to sharp rises in grain futures prices and another peak for the price index compiled by the Commodity Research Bureau.
The prices paid to producers of finished goods rose five-tenths of 1 percent last month, according to the department's Bureau of Labor Statistics, more than reversing February's two-tenths of 1 percent decline.
But when the volatile energy and food components are put aside, the so-called core Producer Price Index edged up just one-tenth of 1 percent, the fourth consecutive month without significant change.
"Without food and energy, it's clearly and plainly obvious that inflation is well behaved," said Paul A. McCulley, chief economist for UBS Securities in New York.
He added that while food and energy were important items in the economy, it was by no means clear that Federal Reserve policy makers would worry even if these prices rose sharply for some time. Such a rise may just mean that wholesalers or other middlemen have to absorb the extra costs if competition does not permit passing them along.
"The question is, does it put pressure on somebody's margin?" Mr. McCulley said.
Other evidence that inflation remains subdued, at least through March, was a lack of price pressure at earlier stages of production. Core intermediate goods like a bolt of cloth edged down two-tenths of 1 percent last month. With their sixth consecutive decline, they are now below the level of March 1995.
And raw materials other than food and energy fell 1.8 percent last month, continuing a string of declines that began last July, interrupted only by a flat reading in January.
"Inflation fears are probably exaggerated," said Lynn Reaser, a California economist who heads the American Bankers Association's advisory council. She described the bond market as now "plagued by negative sentiment" about inflation, in sharp contrast to the "euphoria" that she said marked much of 1995.
The price of finished energy goods jumped 2.4 percent last month, the department's report showed, with gasoline up 7.1 percent and home heating oil soaring 10.5 percent. Residential natural gas rose 1.4 percent.
Food, a lesser factor, rose six-tenths of 1 percent as vegetables leaped 43.1 percent after a 5.1 percent February decline. Beef and veal prices, however, fell 5.1 percent.
Among intermediate goods, which advanced two-tenths of 1 percent over all, hot rolled steel bars and other durables used in manufacturing fell two-tenths of 1 percent after a February decline of eight-tenths.
An 8.5 percent surge in crude petroleum was a big contributor to a 1.6 percent rise in raw materials.

HEADLINE: Art in Review

BYLINE: By Pepe Karmel 

 BODY:

Meyer Vaisman
303 Gallery
89 Greene Street
SoHo
Through April 20
 I' December 1994, Meyer Vaisman, a Venezuelan artist living in New York, was chosen to represent Venezuela in the 1995 Venice Biennale. But when members of the selection committee saw the installation he intended to exhibit -- a cinder-block shanty enclosing an elegant, wood-paneled dressing room -- the invitation was hastily withdrawn. 
 Mr. Vaisman's installation, titled "Green on the Outside, Red on the Inside," is now on view at 303 Gallery. The cinder-block exterior is unlikely to shock anyone who has ever seen bricked-up tenements in New York City. On the contrary, New Yorkers are more likely to be fascinated by the "modern," 60's-style paneling of the interior, which has by now acquired a distinct retro charm. It comes, in fact, from Mr. Vaisman's childhood residence. The four apertures revealing the interior are framed by casts of human hip bones, as if the implied return to childhood were also a voyage up the birth canal and back into the womb.
The exhibition also includes several pieces in which black beans are displayed on top of cinder blocks, sometimes by themselves, sometimes heaped inside articles of clothing. It appears that these particular beans wer' planted and grown in the formal gardens of the Serralves Foundation, in Portugal, while "Green on the Outside, Red on the Inside" was being exhibited there.
A sympathetic viewer might interpret them as a comment on the trans-Atlantic economy of the colonial era, with its harvest of wealth for the few and mere subsistence for the many. Visually, alas, they remain unimpressive. PEPE KARMEL
