HEADLINE: Ford Is Getting Tighter Control Of Its Partner, Mazda Motor

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Friday, April 12

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company agreed today to invest nearly $500 million in the Mazda Motor Corporation in a deal that makes Ford the first American company to take effective control of a Japanese car maker.
Ford, which has held a 25 percent stake in Mazda since 1979, will raise its interest to 33.4 percent, the two companies said today. Ford will buy 52 billion yen, or about $480 million, worth of newly issued Mazda stock. 
 A longtime Ford official, Henry Wallace, who is now at Mazda, will become the president of Mazda on June 27. He is Scottish, which would make him one of the few foreigners ever to run a large Japanese corporation. Ford also said there would be "a modest increase in the number of Ford personnel nominated to Mazda management positions."
Yoshihiro Wada, who is Mazda's president now and and will take the largely ceremonial post of chairman this summer, said Ford and Mazda would work together more closely "while still maintaining each company's separate identity."
The additional investment in Mazda represents in part a defensive effort by Ford to protect the value of its 25 percent stake in the struggling auto maker. Ford also wants to strengthen its position in the rapidly growing East Asian car market.
All of the world's biggest car makers are looking to East Asia for their strongest growth in the coming decade. John F. Smith Jr., chairman and chief executive of the General Motors Corporation, set a goal in January of capturing 10 percent of that market by the end of 2005.
Ford's board approved the deal on Thursday, and Mazda's board gave its assent today in Japan.
Today's deal marks an extraordinary reversal in the fortunes of American and Japanese auto makers. The five-year recession in Japan has crippled that country's car producers, as plunging sales have ruined their profit margins and deprived the weaker ones like Mazda of the money to develop new models.
At the same time, the strong American economy and vigorous sales have left the American companies in their best financial condition in many years. Detroit has also benefited from the growing popularity of sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks, two categories in which Japanese auto makers have had trouble coming up with popular designs.
But the American auto makers' prosperity is now threatened by the steady strengthening in currency markets of the dollar against the yen, which has made Japanese cars more competitive in the American market. Ford has been the most worried about the dollar's rise, and today's investment resembles the original Ford purchase of a stake in Mazda, also motivated by worries about Japanese competition. The share of the American market held by Japanese car makers leapt 2 percentage points, to 24.7 percent, in March from March 1995.
[In Tokyo, Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry welcomed the deal as good for the world economy.]
Mr. Wallace was the president of Ford of Venezuela when he was named in 1993 to become the executive vice president of Mazda, a title he has held ever since.
During the 1980's, Ford often looked to Mazda for help in designing more attractive cars and improving the efficiency of its manufacturing operations. But as Mazda has run into trouble, its management has been increasingly taking its cues from its bankers and Ford. Ford officials have closely overseen many spending decisions at Mazda since Mr. Wallace's arrival there.
Mazda's troubles stem partly from a weak network of dealers in Japan and partly from its over-investment in new factories and car models in Japan just before the recession. With the exception of the area around its base in Hiroshima, Mazda has struggled to hold a large enough share of the Japanese market to be profitable. Lacking money to invest in new designs, Mazda has become increasingly dependent on Ford technology.
Mazda has also had trouble in the United States. Even the company's Miata sports coupe -- so much a fad in 1990 that people offered up to $10,000 over the retail price for slightly used models -- has faded in popularity in the last two years.
Mazda ranks seventh in the United States in sales of cars and light trucks, and its market share here has been shrinking. The company sold 62,209 vehicles in the first quarter of this year, down 17.4 percent from that period of 1995.
By comparison, Ford sold 948,769 cars and trucks in the first quarter this year, down seven-tenths of 1 percent from the 1995 quarter.
Wall Street analysts praised the move, saying Mazda needed the money and could prove a good investment for Ford. After years of losses, the company may have broken even for the year ended on March 31 and could start turning a profit in the coming months, they said.
"It makes sense for Ford to put more money in the company," said Ronald A. Glantz, an analyst at Dean Witter in San Francisco. "It is tempting to say it is throwing good money after bad, but it is not" because of Mazda's potential.
Today's Mazda deal could also indirectly help Ford in its efforts to capture a big share of the large and fast-growing Indonesian market. Mazda owns a big stake in Kia, a Korean auto maker that has been unusually successful in Indonesia. Ford also owns a small stake in Kia, and today's closer alliance with Mazda is likely to increase its influence.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
From Swamp to Brawny Big City

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI

 BODY:

CITY OF THE CENTURY
The Epic of Chicago and the Making of America
By Donald L. Miller
Illustrated. 704 pages. Simon & Schuster. $35.
Carl Sandburg called it the "City of the Big Shoulders." Dreiser dubbed it "a new world" in the making, and William Archer described it as a place that "embraces in its unimaginable amplitude every extreme of splendor and squalor," a place where paradise is just around the corner from hell. It's the city that never goes to bed, the Florence of the West, the "Marseilles of our Mediterranean," a city of stockyards and skyscrapers, boosters and businessmen, reporters and reformers, criminals and con men, the city, in Mark Twain's words, "where they are always rubbing a lamp and fetching up the genii, and contriving and achieving new impossibilities." 
 In his new book, "City of the Century," the historian Donald L. Miller conjures up 19th-century Chicago, tracing its remarkable seven-decade metamorphosis from swamp-ridden trading post to quintessential modern city. Mr. Miller, who teaches history at Lafayette College in Easton, Pa., is the author of a 1989 book on the scholar Lewis Mumford, and "City of the Century" -- with its wide-angled look at cultural, social and environmental themes -- owes a considerable debt to Mumford's approach to urban history. It also appears to draw heavily on earlier books like "Nature's Metropolis: Chicago and the Great West," by William Cronon, and the many biographies of Louis Sullivan. Once again, we are treated to an examination of the geographical and economic forces that helped propel Chicago to prominence. Once again, we are given an appreciation of the architectural innovations that were made on its streets.
Yet if "City of the Century" breaks little new ground, it still provides a wonderfully readable account of Chicago's early history, "from the first recorded discovery of the site by a missionary and an explorer in the service of France" to the Columbian Exposition of 1893, which marked the culmination of "a civic awakening unparalleled in the history of American cities." Mr. Miller draws freely from impressions of the city set down by novelists like Dreiser, Norris and Sinclair, not to mention a host of lesser-known writers and travelers, and he uses them to give the reader a sense of what it must have been like to live in the Windy City during its formative years.
From time to time, Mr. Miller interrupts his colorful narrative to step back and frame for the reader, a la Mumford, the larger dynamics at work in the growth of Chicago. He underscores the important role that technology played in the city's coming of age: how the railroads, carrying lumber and coal and meat, made the city a vital hub for commerce, and how those railroads came to define the city's relationship with its suburbs. He shows how the invention of the reaping machine led to the domestication of the surrounding countryside, and how the invention of the elevator made the skyscraper a viable solution to expensive urban real estate.
For the most part, however, Mr. Miller tells the story of Chicago through the lives of the larger-than-life hustlers, visionaries, eccentrics, entrepreneurs and pols who built the city upon a wind-swept prairie marsh, and turned it into a colossus of privatism and public works, capitalist ambition and reformist zeal.
There's William Butler Ogden, the city's first Mayor, who envisioned great things for this collection of wood shanties and unpaved roads. There are the meat kings Gustavus Franklin Swift and Philip Danforth Armour, who built empires out of cattle and hogs; and the super-merchants Marshall Field, Aaron Montgomery Ward and Richard Warren Sears, who helped invent America's consumer culture and happily supplied its voracious needs.
Like the city itself, some of the biggest players in Chicago's history were odd hybrid creatures, mercenaries endowed with a vision, dreamers motivated by cupidity and power. The "Cable Czar" of Chicago, Charles Tyson Yerkes, was an ex-convict who won a reputation as the city's "most vilified public figure" for his shameless manipulation of stocks and bonds; he was also the man responsible for fashioning one of the world's greatest urban transportation systems.
Carter Henry Harrison, the city's five-time Mayor, maintained close ties with the head of the city's vice empire and blatantly played the game of patronage politics; he was also a wildly popular leader, whose support of labor earned him the respect of the poor and whose commitment to urban growth won him the backing of business. "He personified in himself," a Chicago paper said of Harrison, "all the restlessness, the energy, the ability, and the ambition which have built the World's Fair city into the greatest metropolis in the Nation."
One of the things that insured Chicago's continued rise, of course, was its amazing resilie'ce, its citizens' refusal to submit to the adversities of nature (swamps, mud, extremes of heat and cold, pollution, disease) or the fickleness of the economy. Indeed, the great fire of 1871, which virtually wiped out the town, became an intrinsic part of its mythology. Within two decades, Chicago had been entirely rebuilt, boasting the country's busiest and most modern downtown and more than a dozen of the tallest buildings ever constructed.
As Mr. Miller writes, "Chicagoans were convinced they had survived a 'iblical test, a terrible but purifying act that had cleared the way for a vast regeneration that would transform their ruined city into the master metropolis of America."

HEADLINE: Minimum-Wage Raise Still Causes Job Loss

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In a 1987 editorial, "Don't Raise the Minimum Wage," you reasoned that "a higher minimum wage would probably price many working poor people out of jobs, since they could not demonstrate the productivity necessary to justify the higher wage." 
 Now your April 5 editorial proclaims, "Boost the Minimum Wage." Your reversal is perplexing because your 1987 job-loss argument remains economically valid today.
Research from Boston University and the University of Wisconsin demonstrates that after a minimum-wage increase, welfare mothers and other low-skilled adults are displaced from the work force by middle-class teen-agers who are lured to jobs by the higher wage.
A more thoughtful policy uses minimum-wage jobs as training for more highly paid positions. Census Bureau data support this policy: People earning the minimum wage a year ago are now paid an average of $6.08 an hour, an increase of $1.83, or twice the President's proposed increase to $5.15. With a higher minimum wage, many of these individuals would have never had the opportunity to join the work force.
 
THOMAS K. DILWORTH
Director of Operations
Employment Policies Institute
Washington, April 9, 1996

HEADLINE: Treasury Prices Surge as Inflation Fear Ebbs

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices staged their biggest rally in nearly 10 months yesterday after economic reports suggested the economy was growing at a pace too slow to cause inflation to accelerate.
"Today's reports reassured people that inflation is still under control," said Jim Fields, who manages $3 billion at Wright Investors' Service in Bridgeport, Conn. "Long-term we're fairly bullish. We could see a 6.3 percent 30-year bond yield by the end of year." 
 Monthly surveys on retail sales, consumer confidence and manufacturing eased concern that inflation would accelerate later this year and buttressed the view that this year's rout may be ending, traders said.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 118/32 , to 8927/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 6.79 percent, from 6.93 percent on Thursday.
The gains were somewhat exaggerated because some traders had bet that the economic data would not lift prices, by selling securities short, traders said.
In a short sale, traders borrow securities and sell them on the bet that prices will fall. If prices fall, traders buy back the bonds at lower prices and pocket the difference. If bonds rise, as they did yesterday, traders may be forced to buy securities or face mounting losses.
"The news was as expected; it wasn't a big surprise," said Steven Saslow, executive managing director at HSBC Securities in New York. "What was a surprise was the price move."
Yesterday's economic reports generally heartened the market.
The Government said consumer prices rose four-tenths of 1 percent last month, more than a gain of three-tenths of 1 percent that analysts had expected. But without the volatile categories of food and energy, the index rose three-tenths of 1 percent, in line with forecasts.
"Manufacturers are having difficulty passing along higher prices," said Joseph Bench, who manages $1.5 billion of bonds for Capstone Asset Management in White Plains. "That's the kind of thing that will help the market overcome its inflation concern."
And a report from the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta showed that more Southeastern manufacturers were paying their suppliers lower prices as manufacturing activity in the region continued to contract.
A University of Michigan survey of consumer sentiment suggested consumers were less upbeat about their economic prospects. The index fell to 90.8 this month from 93.7 in March, traders said. The survey is released only to subscribers.
The market's concerns about inflation were also somewhat allayed by an article in The Wall Street Journal yesterday about Federal Reserve policy. The article, quoting unidentified sources, said Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Fed, believed concern that the economy was growing too quickly was overblown and that he was unlikely to support raising rates anytime soon.
Falling commodity prices also helped ease worries. Crude oil for May delivery tumbled $1.09, to $24.25 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The Commodity Research Bureau's index fell 0.49 point, to 260.17.
Also, some foreign investors bought Treasury bonds because they offered higher yields than European securities, traders said.
United States 10-year debt now yields 23 basis points more than the 6.43 percent yield on 10-year German bonds, compared with 4 basis points less than the German 10-year bond a week ago. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
In the corporate bond market, notes of Trump Atlantic City Associates were actively traded, showing strong investor demand. The notes were issued on Thursday to help finance the merger of the Trump Plaza and Trump Taj Mahal casinos in Atlantic City.
The first-mortgage notes, which were priced at par to yield 11.25 percent, were quoted at a price of 102 yesterday afternoon.

HEADLINE: Make Brooklyn a World-Class Seaport

BYLINE: By Jerrold Nadler and Michael R. Long; Jerrold Nadler, a Democrat, is a Congressman whose district includes part of Brooklyn. Michael R. Long, a Brooklynite, is chairman of New York's Conservative Party.

 BODY:
The Port of New York and New Jersey has a lemon on its hands. Millions of cubic yards of riverborne mud contaminated by toxins are clogging New York Harbor's channels and docks. Some large ships cannot enter fully loaded and must put part of their cargo on barges first.
Solving this problem is not simple. For years, the Army Corps of Engineers routinely dredged the mud and dumped it in the Atlantic six miles east of the Jersey Shore. That is now against Federal law because the mud harms marine life. 
 Some vessels are going elsewhere, and the seaport's dominance on the East Coast -- and 180,000 jobs -- are at risk.
One proposed alternative is to deposit the silt in Brooklyn in so-called borrow pits -- holes that are dug under the water and capped with clean fill. But this approach is unworkable, because strong currents would eventually erode the caps.
There is a better solution. Engineers call it near-shore disposal. The silt could be deposited behind concrete dikes between existing piers on Brooklyn's partly defunct commercial waterfront. This fill could be used for a major new container port and a park and soccer field for the Sunset Park neighborhood. The port would greatly help restore New York's economy.
New York City became a commercial and financial giant because of its port. But in the 1960's, the Port Authority built on cheap New Jersey land what is now the region's main container port, largely replacing New York's. New Jersey's port is situated at the end of the narrow, treacherous, hard to navigate Kill Van Kull; that port's problems have progressively worsened as ships have gotten bigger.
Shippers are beginning to imitate the airlines by consolidating their operations into hub and feeder systems. A 1995 Port Authority study concluded that eventually the East Coast will have only one such hub (for the largest ships) served by many smaller feeder ports.
Transforming New Jersey's port into a hub would require deepening the Kill Van Kull by blasting through miles of solid rock -- an enormous expense. But the Port Authority warns that if this project isn't undertaken, the region could lose up to 40 percent of its current traffic.
Building the hub in Brooklyn, partly on the new fill, would be far cheaper. The port could be 50 feet deep -- the minimum needed -- since rock is not encountered until 65 feet beneath the water's surface in most places. New Jersey's port could still handle the smaller ships.
Thousands of maritime jobs would be created, warehousing and manufacturing would follow. In addition, the new revenues could finance the recreation sites in Brooklyn.
The near-shore use of silt would be environmentally sound. While the water-soluble toxins harm fish, the low concentrations in the landfill would not hurt people.
Gov. George Pataki has asked Michael Finnegan, his counsel, to cooperate with New Jersey officials to find a solution to the problem. Near-shore disposal for Brooklyn should be high on Mr. Finnegan's agenda.

GRAPHIC: Drawing.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 33; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1501 words

HEADLINE: A Mall by Any Other NameCan Good Vibes Sell Elvis Busts and Cuban Food?

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

DATELINE: COSTA MESA, Calif.

 BODY:
Shaheen Sadeghi owns a shopping strip here, where he makes a sweet living providing space to hip stores that cater to shoppers in their 20's.
But he is not really in the retail business, Mr. Sadeghi insists. He prefers to call himself a "conceptualist," responsible for controlling the strip's "vibe." 
 Mr. Sadeghi has put together an increasingly successful shopping center, known as The Lab, full of cutting-edge tenants, served up in an atmosphere designed to lure in a generation disenchanted with the cookie-cutter look and feel of just about every suburban mall in the country.
Don't look for Starbucks Coffee here. There will be no softer side of Sears. Mrs. Fields, that ultimate cookie hawker? Woefully out of touch. Those ubiquitous shops selling leather pants, shimmery first-date shirts or dangling earrings, two for $5? No way.
Instead, there are more than a dozen stores offering surf wear, authentic plastic Jesus statues, and college-radio CD's, all enclosed by broken walls, ripped-up carpet and a do-it-yourself community garden.
And above all, Mr. Sadeghi says, don't call The Lab a mall. No, it's an "anti-mall."
And that's the genius behind Mr. Sadeghi's approach. For by aiming at a special age group and marketing to that group's perceived set of esthetic and spending values, he has managed to tap into the most popular form of specialty retailing around today without appearing to do so.
"They call themselves the anti-mall, but that is just really very clever marketing," said Mark J. Schoifet, a spokesman for the International Council of Shopping Centers in New York. "It has been very important for malls to differentiate themselves, and niche marketing is becoming more and more important in the shopping center business."
Starting with just a handful of stores, Mr. Sadeghi opened his anti-mall three years ago in a former military night goggle factory. It is in the heart of conservative Orange County, just down the road from the South Coast Plaza, an archetype of the luxury shopping center.
The anchor, Urban Outfitters, offers the disaffected uniform of Generation X -- T-shirts meant to be worn a size too small, bowling bags-cum-evening bags, black sunglasses. Tower Records set up a store offering mostly "alternative" music. (Translation: if the band you are looking for can be found in a magazine pull-out card for a record club, you're in the wrong place.)
Now, there are 16 tenants, with more to come. In addition to the better-known Urban Outfitters and Tower, they have more obscure names like Spanish Fly, where jaded shoppers can find ultra-camp plastic Elvis busts and religious-kitsch items, and The Closet, which offers clothing for surfing, skating and snow boarding. There's a comic book store and several small apparel shops. The coffee bar is not a chain, and the restaurant is Cuban.
The anti-mall disdains chrome, skylights and food courts, preferring instead to maintain the warehouse look with exposed steel rods sticking out from the walls and lots of cement. The space is further embellished with paintings and drawings by local artists and ready-made objects, giving it the slightly risque feel of a squatter den.
"We are approaching this from a very purified point of view," said Mr. Sadeghi, 41, whose background is in designing clothing and surf wear, and who says he started The Lab when he realized that there was money to be made in alternatives to the standard shopping mall. He combined his undergraduate degree in business, his studies at the Pratt Institute and work on Seventh Avenue to make it happen. "We like it to have that personal feel," he added. "It's not like a typical mall where everything is real cold and you don't know who owns it."
One wall is covered with odds and ends ranging from oil paintings to antique kitchen equipment, and in the center is an open space called The Living Room, where the kind of furniture found at a garage sale has been set up for shoppers to sit and sip their fruit whips by the light of lamps fashioned from old carburetor filters.
The juxtaposition of a nearby fancy hair salon close to the wall covered with poems and old potato peelers leaves one with the impression that Marcel Duchamp had been enlisted to fix up a Neiman Marcus.
"I just love this building," Mr. Sadeghi said. "It gives us authenticity, because it is so honest. We just don't have that many old buildings around here." (The building dates from the 1950's.)
With its carefully honed rough edges, The Lab is probably best understood not so much as the antithesis of conventional retailing today but as a quintessential example of the latest trends in marketing.
First there is its size. At 40,000 square feet, The Lab fits in with the rise of smaller malls, the fastest-growing segment of the industry. Then, there is its demographic vision. In this age of retail downsizing, retailers are increasingly aiming at specific age and socio-economic groups. Finally, the entertainment angle pulls it all together -- rooms to hang out in, live music concerts, interactive offerings like the garden where shoppers are encouraged to plant seeds so they have a stake in coming back to see how they do.
"Its focus on entertainment is the way the whole industry is going," said John Konarski, the vice president of the National Council of Shopping Centers. "At Bal Harbour, they have entertainment groups, too, only it is string quartets. The music and retail space here simply reflects the age and interest that they are going for."
The Lab doesn't always hit its target of 18- to 30-year-olds, though. Indeed, the anti-mall's mix of hip stores and Cuban food appears to attract a host of teen-agers and a lot of baby boomers tinged with nostalgia for their own lost youth. Middle-aged shoppers in Hillary headbands cruise the strip avidly.
Diane Vanderlip, a 48-year-old psychotherapist, said she was thrilled the other day to find an outfit at half price at the CP Shades store here that she spotted earlier for $185 at Nordstrom's. And the faux-60's atmosphere made it all the better. "I think it is great here," she said. "I feel like I've stepped into a time warp."
Jarond Gibbs, 21, was less enthused. "They have a really good selection of records," Mr. Gibbs said between sips of a hot drink at the Gypsy Den, the coffee house. "But everything else here is kind of stupid. It seems to me like kids come here to be cool and away from their conservative parents."
Which is fine, in Mr. Sadeghi's estimation. Indeed, in today's harsher economic climate, a lot more young people are willing to spend $20 on a plastic Jesus lamp than they are to splurge for a pricey Versace raincoat over at South Coast Plaza.
The formula seems to be working, even if it hasn't been perfected.
Mr. Sadeghi said sales average about $450 a square foot annually, up from about $250 a square foot when it first opened, which would place it well above most successful strip malls. He collects about $2.50 a square foot for rent, which rivals some Los Angeles prices on trendy Robertson Boulevard. Urban Outfitters' manager, Karen Stradinger, said the store here is "about in the middle" in terms of the sales volume in its 20-odd stores nationwide. The stores range from about 12,000 square feet to 2,000 square feet
Still, the small stores have experienced a high turnover rate -- about three stores a year are replaced. "When we first opened, beads were hot," Mr. Sadeghi said. "Now, it's cigars. We need to turn the excitement of the center. We need to keep introducing new products. We don't give them an option."
But The Lab also risks finding itself a victim of its own success. "Whenever you niche market, you narrow your audience," Mr. Konarski said. "You have to make sure not to narrow it down too far."
Indeed, for all Mr. Sadeghi's obsession with his own sense of "authenticity," young adults today are no more unified in their shopping habits than they are in their voting records or their eating patterns.
Plenty of people in their 20's are just as happy with a skirt or tie from Nordstrom's as they are with a fuzzy crop top from Urban Outfitters, which may explain why 43 percent of the anti-mall's shoppers, according to marketing surveys, also frequent South Coast Plaza, the uber-mall down the road.
Further, there is not much within miles of the anti-mall that supports its groovy retail thesis. Down the street is a Wahoo's Fish Taco restaurant, a gas station and a McDonald's. Little in this sunny, affluent area surrounded by highways suggests that the East Village of Southern California is in the making.
But don't tell that to Mr. Sadeghi, who has harnessed practically the last embodiment of anti-capitalism to his own vision of hip capitalism. "The whole Cuba thing is really happening right now," Mr. Sadeghi said, standing in the doorway of Havana, The Lab's sit-down restaurant. "There is something really good about Cuba. It is the only place that is really vibrant."

HEADLINE: New York City Can't Afford This Tax

BYLINE: By Rebecca Johnson; Rebecca Johnson is a contributing editor for Vogue and Mademoiselle.

 BODY:
Every three months, I make out a check to New York City for, well, never mind the exact number -- suffice to say it's 4 percent of my quarterly earnings.
If you get a paycheck, an annual Christmas party and will send off your annual check to the Internal Revenue Service on Monday, you probably have no idea what I'm talking about. But if you are self-employed and a full- or part-time New York City resident you, too, probably pay 4 percent on top of the taxes everyone else pays. It is called the unincorporated business tax, and it is especially harmful in a city that depends on its freelance writers and artists. 
 Taxes do more than create revenue -- they are also instruments of social engineering. A deduction for mortgage interest encourages people to buy homes, thus boosting the economy. Sin taxes on cigarettes and alcohol discourage us from indulging our vices. Cars pollute and create potholes -- thus New York's whopping 14.5 percent sales tax on parking garage fees. Those punitive taxes make sense in a society where smoking, drinking and driving are considered wasteful or bad (especially if done in unison). Freelancing, however, is not a bad thing.
In fact, freelancers are exactly the kinds of people New York should encourage to live here. They are the dancers, actors, writers and musicians who forego the security of a real job, with its perks of health insurance and pension fund, for the freedom to create. They are what helps make New York hum, and it's the hum that attracts the tourists who in turn spend lots of money on the local economy.
A 1994 study by the Manhattan Borough President's office found that New York's share of the national magazine publishing workforce declined by nearly 10 percent between 1977 and 1990 and recommended overhauling the unincorporated business tax.
It's not as if freelancers use more city services than employees. The 10 feet I travel from my bedroom to my office is not covered by a subsidized rail system, so why am I taxed twice?
Very wealthy writers, of course, don't pay the additional tax. They make enough to benefit from the tax breaks of incorporating. Every year, I ask my accountant why I don't incorporate and he gently tells me I don't make enough money to make it worthwhile.
Many politicians have said they want to change the law. In 1994, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani promised relief, but the city's need for revenue took precedence and in the end he only gave a minor tax credit for the purchase and service costs of office equipment. Maybe if I belonged to a strong union, it could bully lawmakers into making significant changes, but I'm a union of one and no politician frets over the freelancer vote.
To be fair, it's not just New York City that penalizes us. So does the Federal tax code. Employers pay half of Social Security and Medicare taxes for their workers, while the self-employed pay the entire 15.3 percent of earnings out of their own pocket. Benefits like health insurance and paid vacations are usually estimated to be as valuable as 30 percent to 40 percent of salary. Those self-employed people who can even afford health insurance can deduct only 25 percent of their premiums.
It's not that I'd rather work for a big company. I'm 30 years old, born at the tail end of the baby boom. My generation read "Death of a Salesman" in high school: I've never expected a company to take care of me. When the company I used to work for referred to us employees as "part of the family," it made my skin crawl. A company is not a family. It's a business. I'm sympathetic to downsized middle-aged managers, but I can't relate to them. Their expectations seem quaint and old-fashioned.
As more people are laid off, many are forced to go into business for themselves. Federal and local tax codes should changed in response to the ways the workplace has changed. These days, the corner office may well be the home office.

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Rise Slightly; Consumer Prices Up 0.4%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 12

 BODY:
Retail sales eked out a small gain in March as inflation edged higher, Government figures showed today, indicating that a rebound seen earlier this year may be moderating.
The reports calmed financial markets nervous about higher interest rates by suggesting to many investors that the pace of economic growth was not fast enough to reignite accelerating inflation. 
 Bond prices rose, pushing the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond down to 6.79 percent today from 6.93 percent on Thursday. Prices and yields move in opposite directions. Encouraged by bonds, stocks also posted strong gains.
While the data showed a rise in the Consumer Price Index of four-tenths of 1 percent -- higher than expected -- the core, or underlying, rate that excludes food and energy rose three-tenths of 1 percent, matching the market's expectations. The core rate is regarded as a better indication of inflation pressures over the short run than the index as a whole. The rise in the overall index lifted the three-month compound annual rate to 4 percent.
Retail sales, meanwhile, were reported by the Commerce Department to have edged up a scant one-tenth of 1 percent in March. But analysts also pointed to a huge upward revision in February sales, to a 1.9 percent surge instead of the eight-tenths of 1 percent gain that was first estimated. And the figures ran counter to many reports from auto makers and retailers showing strong gains for the month.
The upshot was further consternation among economists.
"Given all the problems the Commerce Department has had in dealing with -- and seasonally adjusting for -- the Government shutdowns, the blizzard and an early Easter, it is still unclear how strong the consumer rebound really is," said Veronika White, an economist with the First Union Bank in Philadelphia.
A separate Commerce Department report today showed that factory and trade inventories edged up one-tenth of 1 percent in February while the inventory-sales ratio -- the length of time it would take to deplete stocks at the current pace -- eased to 1.4 months.
And the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta reported that its index of business activity in its district was in negative territory for the eighth straight month while both prices-paid and prices-received indexes hit record lows.
"The economy's bouncing back from very anemic growth but it's only to 2 percent-type growth," or well within the Federal Reserve's comfort range, contended Mickey D. Levy, economist for Nationsbank Capital Markets in New York. And the latest inflation figures, including yesterday's report covering producers, "suggest it's not a problem yet," Mr. Levy added.
Retail sales last month edged up to $203 billion, mainly reflecting 1.9 percent spurts in receipts for gasoline service stations and for merchants selling furniture and other items for the home.
Service station results were swelled by higher prices as well by increasing numbers of sport utility and other poor-mileage vehicles on the road, analysts said.
Sales were also up by three-tenths of 1 percent at drugstores and by one-tenth of 1 percent at food stores and at restaurants and bars.
But these gains were almost entirely offset by declines of 1.7 percent for merchants selling building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes; five-tenths of 1 percent at automotive dealers, 1.6 percent at clothing stores and three-tenths of 1 percent at department stores and others selling general merchandise.
The large upward revision for February embraced every category except gasoline service stations, where an unchanged reading became a modest decline.
Among the consumer price components, grocery-store foods, which were unchanged in each of the preceding two months, jumped nine-tenths of 1 percent, with a 6 percent surge for fresh fruits and vegetables accounting for much of the increase.
Transportation prices advanced seven-tenths of 1 percent, with motor fuels climbing 3.6 percent to account for 90 percent of the increase. Used cars, a category that has become so volatile that the Federal Reserve Bank of New York proposes that the department use retail transaction prices instead of wholesale auction prices, climbed eight-tenths of 1 percent in March.
Higher transportation costs also reflected a 4 percent rise in intracity fares that helped to more than offset a 1.9 percent decline in airline fares.
Clothing, another erratic category, climbed six-tenths of 1 percent after a decline of nine-tenths of 1 percent in February.
Among the handful of metropolitan areas for which March inflation figures were published today, prices rose five-tenths of 1 percent in New York and Philadelphia and seven-tenths of 1 percent in Chicago and Los Angeles, the report also showed.
New York prices were up 3.5 percent over the latest 12 months compared with 2.8 percent for the country at large.

HEADLINE: Commerce and Diplomacy

 BODY:
Mickey Kantor, President Clinton's choice to succeed Ronald Brown as Commerce Secretary, can be expected to keep American overseas business interests in the forefront of Washington's foreign policy agenda.
The Administration's increased emphasis on trade and investment, championed so energetically by Mr. Brown, clearly makes sense in an era when cold war military rivalry has given way to peaceful international economic competition. But commercialism has costs, and the challenge for Mr. Kantor and Mr. Clinton will be to keep them in mind as the Administration fine-tunes its foreign policy in this election year. Defending human rights, curbing the spread of nuclear weapons and protecting other American diplomatic and military interests must not be subordinated to the pursuit of commercial contracts. 
 Mr. Kantor should shift smoothly to Commerce from his post as United States Trade Representative, where he has effectively defended American trading interests. While he sometimes got less than he advertised in his negotiations with Japan, and on occasion we disagreed with his confrontational tactics, he made the trade office a powerful advocate for American business. Like Mr. Brown, Mr. Kantor has longstanding ties with Mr. Clinton, extensive business and political connections and a knack for making things happen.
As more of a negotiator and dealmaker than salesman, Mr. Kantor may be less inclined than Mr. Brown was to lead delegations of American businessmen in visits to promising foreign markets. American commercial interests were clearly advanced by Mr. Brown's 15 major sales trips abroad. These focused on what the Commerce Department designated as "Big Emerging Markets" -- poor but developing countries like China, India and Indonesia where the idea was to lock up deals for American companies to build aircraft, energy systems and telecommunications networks.
A bit less salesmanship would not be a bad idea. When Mr. Brown brought a delegation of 25 high-powered American executives to India last year, serious American concerns about India's secret nuclear weapons program and its sweeping military repression in Kashmir were neglected as billions of dollars in new contracts were signed. Last fall, with China's human rights situation deteriorating and tensions rising rapidly in the Taiwan Strait, the Commerce Secretary was in Beijing pressing some $20 billion in new aircraft, energy and communications contracts on China's President, Jiang Zemin.
In other areas, like Northern Ireland, the Middle East, South Africa and on that ill-fated final journey to the Balkans, business promotion efforts can usefully support Administration efforts to reinforce diplomacy with economic reconstruction.
It is generally a good idea for the United States Government to put its power and influence to work to help open access to foreign markets and give American business the same kind of help winning contracts that European and Japanese companies get from their governments. Export orders can create high-paying jobs at home, and contracts for overseas production can strengthen American companies against their foreign competitors.
But this commercial diplomacy also creates powerful constituencies for overlooking human rights abuses and winking at dangerous weapons programs. Promoting economic prosperity abroad may be the most effective long-term strategy for encouraging political liberalization and international peace. But in the short run, as the actions of countries like China plainly demonstrate, human rights and peaceful behavior could sometimes benefit from diplomatic and economic pressure.
Commercial diplomacy best serves the United States when it is incorporated into a broader foreign policy framework. That should be Mr. Kantor's goal.

HEADLINE: Mayor Woos Civic Leaders on Stadium Plan

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
Even as he insists that no decision has been made on a proposal to build a new stadium for the New York Yankees on the West Side of Manhattan, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has begun a campaign to rally the city's business leaders behind the idea.
The effort has come as the Mayor acknowledged for the first time yesterday that the city and state might have to come up with significant amounts to pay for roads, mass transit and other improvements around a new stadium. 
 With political opposition to a proposed stadium emerging, the Mayor has turned for support to business executives, particularly real estate developers, who share Mr. Giuliani's belief that the project could generate new economic activity and who, in some cases, stand to benefit.
"He's definitely discussed it with people in the community," Jerry I. Speyer of Tishman Speyer Properties, one the city's largest developers, said in an interview yesterday. "Judging from my peers in the business community, they're right behind the Mayor and the Governor."
In news conferences all week and on his weekly radio program yesterday, Mr. Giuliani has been pressing his case for building a new home for the Yankees, always careful not to rule out the possibility of remodeling or rebuilding Yankee Stadium in the South Bronx. On radio, he even interviewed the president of the American League, Gene Budig, about the benefits of new stadiums to teams and cities.
A new, multi-use stadium could be the city's largest public works project outside of City Water Tunnel No. 3, the $5.5 billion project to increase the capacity of the city's water supply.
As important allies for any major public development, the business leaders could lend added political weight to Mr. Giuliani's arguments that a new stadium could benefit the city economically, even if it means the Yankees would leave their home in the Bronx after 73 years.
Ever since the consulting firm of Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum recommended that the city and state build the Yankees a new home on the West Side of midtown Manhattan, at a cost of $800 million to $1 billion, Mr. Giuliani has said the project could be financed with little taxpayer money, from revenues generated by increased attendance, luxury boxes, concessions and other amenities. Yesterday, however, he estimated that the city might have to spend $20 million to $40 million in such improvements, although the consultant's report estimated the total cost of improvements would be much higher.
"Our objective here is to hold the taxpayer cost down to a bare minimum," he said in his program on WABC-AM radio, "and then if there is a taxpayer cost, have if not all of it, the vast majority of it invested in infrastructure improvements."
Real estate developers would have strong interests in any project that could revive a neighborhood, near the Jacob Javits Convention Center, that has not seen significant development in recent years.
The area also includes several businesses that could flourish with a new stadium to anchor redevelopment, including the ferry service operated by New York Waterway and the Chelsea Piers, the newly developed sports and entertainment center on the Hudson River between 17th and 23d streets. The heads of both companies, Arthur E. Imperatore and Tom A. Bernstein, respectively, expressed support for a stadium yesterday.
"What comes to my mind is what comes to everyone's mind: Camden Yards," said Mr. Bernstein, who is also a part owner of the Texas Rangers, referring to the new park built for the Baltimore Orioles. "It was a huge spur for everything around it."
Charles Gargano, the State Commissioner of Economic Development, who is heading the state's involvement in the stadium issue, said yesterday that he too had approached business leaders about the plans. "If we don't get them involved," he said, "this will never get done."

HEADLINE: Labor Deals Major's Tories A New Blow In Local Vote

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM 

DATELINE: LONDON, April 12

 BODY:
Trimming the Conservative Party majority to a single seat, the Labor Party scored an unexpectedly large victory in a parliamentary election on Thursday, snatching a seat in the Staffordshire South-East local election.
With 60 percent of the vote, the Labor candidate, Brian Jenkins, 53, swept into a seat long held by the Conservatives. 
 While the Conservative defeat had been widely expected, the dimension of it took politicians here by surprise. The Conservative candidate, Jimmy James, got only 22 percent of the vote, with candidates from 10 other parties sharing the rest, the final count showed.
Prime Minister John Major, whose Conservatives have slipped a long way from the 21-seat edge they won four years ago, is certain to feel increased pressure to call for general elections sooner rather than later, especially with the Labor Party hinting at a vote of confidence in Parliament. A general election must be held by May 1997.
The Labor Party leader, Tony Blair, who is visiting the United States, vowed today to seize any chance to topple the Government.
"Of course, if an opportunity presents itself to remove this Government, then it's not merely an opportunity, it is our duty as the opposition to try and remove them," Mr. Blair said in Washington, where he met President Clinton.
The wide margin of Labor's victory adds another setback to a seemingly unbroken string of political troubles for the Tories, ranging from the Government's handling of the mad cow disease to the party's plummeting popularity. Opinion polls show Conservatives trailing Labor by 30 points, with little relief in sight.
The dimension of disappointment with Mr. Major's Government was evident during a visit on Thursday to Tamworth, a prosperous town of 60,000 in Staffordshire.
This community, about 200 miles north of London, is one of the fastest-growing in the country, with unemployment estimated at only 5 percent, significantly below the national average of 8 to 9 percent.
The parliamentary seat here has been held for years by the Conservative whip, Sir David Lightbown. If anything, Tamworth was considered one place where the "feel good" factor brought on by low unemployment and steady growth was supposed to play in favor of Mr. Major's conservative policies.
Instead a score of people interviewed at random indicated they were ready for change.
"This used to be a conservative town, but I don't think we are popular any longer," said Leslie Tucker, a 48-year-old farmer who was running as a candidate for the ultra-conservative Churchill Party. "I'll be happy if I get 1,000 votes today."
As it happened, Mr. Tucker got only 123 votes. A candidate running for something called the Official Monster Raving Loony Party, which believes in "the opposite of all the other parties," got 506.
"They started to lose their ways, the Tories," said Gordon Charlesworth, 68, a retired mine worker, who stressed his long support for the Conservatives, but made up his mind to vote for Labor. "They have been in power too long. Personally I think they have lost their way on health, crime, taxes -- just about everything.
The defeat was even more painful to the Tories because it came after an intensive monthlong campaign that saw a score of Cabinet ministers and ministers of state going to Staffordshire to lobby for a victory.
It was the 35th consecutive Tory defeat in by-elections since 1989. During those years two Conservative members of Parliament defected to Labor and seven others died. Any further deaths or defections would render Mr. Major's Government a minority one, which might allow it to continue to govern in alliance with others, but would make it far more vulnerable politically.

HEADLINE: Man in the News: Franklin Delano Raines;
Moving From Big Money to Politics

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 12

 BODY:
When Franklin D. Raines was asked by the Boeing Company to join its board last year, he answered that it would be a great honor -- and that by the way, he had a personal connection to the giant aircraft company: his mother had worked for years cleaning its offices in Seattle.
In a career that has already come a long way -- from a working-class family to a Rhodes Scholarship, a post in the Carter Administration and a lucrative career on Wall Street -- Mr. Raines took another big step today, agreeing to become President Clinton's budget chief. It is a job that puts him at the very center of Washington politics and makes him one of two black Cabinet-level officials in the Clinton Administration. 
 Indeed, he had come so far that President Clinton could not resist a dig at him. Alluding to the fact that Mr. Raines would be giving up a huge salary in the business world to take the $148,400-a-year job as Director of the Office of Management and Budget, Mr. Clinton said he would be joining "other successful people who came into this Administration to help save the middle class and when they leave they'll be part of it."
As vice chairman of Fannie Mae, the giant mortgage company, Mr. Raines earned $2.25 million last year.
As budget chief, the 47-year-old Mr. Raines may have to wait for a second Clinton Administration, if there is one, to make much of a mark. Mr. Clinton has already set his broad budget policy, having made a commitment to balance the budget in seven years.
The Administration and Congress are still trying to reach agreement on the current year's budget, but if any deal is to be struck, it will probably be soon. And the Administration has already unveiled its budget for next year, even if it stands no chance of being adopted by the Republican-controlled Congress.
But if his job lasts beyond next January, Mr. Raines is likely to find himself at the center of the process of making the tough choices that the President's broad commitment to balancing the budget entails. And he could find himself a point man in the political rough and tumble as the Administration and Congress fight over what should be cut to try to bring spending in line with revenue.
Mr. Raines served on Mr. Clinton's transition team after the 1992 election and has long been thought to be in line for an Administration job.
He said today that he was looking forward to working with Congress and on "this issue of now that there's an agreement on balancing the budget, what values will that budget embody?"
"That's the most important fiscal issue that's facing the country now," Mr. Raines said, "and I'm happy to be able to have a part in it."
Franklin Delano Raines was born on Jan. 14, 1949, in Seattle, where he said he was instilled with a work ethic and, as his parents' choice of name for him might suggest, a belief that Government could be a powerful source of change and improvement for people.
'It's something I was taught throughout my life, to be something important," Mr. Raines said at the White House ceremony where his appointment was announced today. "You don't grow up with the initials F.D.R. without having some appreciation of the role, and the positive role, that Government can play in the lives of people throughout this nation and throughout the world."
After graduating from high school in Seattle, Mr. Raines attended Harvard College, where he received a B.A. in government. He then spent a year as a Rhodes Scholar at Oxford University in England in 1971 -- three years after Mr. Clinton was a Rhodes Scholar there -- before returning to Harvard Law School, from which he graduated in 1974.
After working for two years as a lawyer in Seattle, he was appointed by President Jimmy Carter to be associate director of economics and government in the Office of Management and Budget. After President Carter's defeat by Ronald Reagan in 1980, Mr. Raines went to Wall Street, working in the municipal finance division of Lazard Freres & Company, the investment firm.
He left Lazard in 1991 to become vice chairman of Fannie Mae, a private company created by the Government to help the housing market by packaging and selling home mortgages to investors.
Friends and associates said Mr. Raines has a deep understanding of the role of financial markets in setting economic policy, and in particular of the need to soothe the bond market's fears of inflation -- and thus keeping long-term interest rates down -- by achieving a balanced budget.

HEADLINE: Trade Representative Picked As New Commerce Secretary

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 12

 BODY:
Moving swiftly to fill a Cabinet vacancy created by the death of Ronald H. Brown, President Clinton today appointed one of his most loyal political strategists, Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, to fill out Mr. Brown's term as Commerce Secretary.
"We need to send a clear signal to the rest of America and to the world that we don't intend to miss a beat," Mr. Clinton said this afternoon in the East Room, where he turned what would normally be a little-noted review of American automobile sales in Japan into an election-year promotion of his trade policies. "We've got a strategy. We've got a team. It's working, and we're going forward with it." 
 For the last three years Mr. Kantor, who was Mr. Clinton's campaign chief in 1992, has seized headlines and raised tempers around the world as the combative, short-tempered battering ram of American foreign policy, using extraordinary pressure tactics to force Europe, Japan, Mexico and China to open their markets. Several weeks before the crash that took the life of Mr. Brown and 32 other Americans, he portrayed himself as Mr. Brown's colleague and polar opposite.
"I punch open the holes and Ron runs through them," Mr. Kantor said.
The move to the Commerce Department is a lateral one for Mr. Kantor, who already has the rank of a Cabinet member. But for Mr. Clinton, it keeps one of his canniest campaign strategists at the center of economic policy-making and in a position focused on creating jobs.
In addition, Mr. Kantor is a member of the inner circle, helping to plot the re-election effort at the White House. Mr. Kantor's appointment was an unusually emotional event at the White House today, where the mood has been somber since Mr. Brown's death nine days ago. Mr. Clinton embraced Mr. Kantor in a prolonged bear hug after announcing his appointment.
"As you might imagine," Mr. Clinton noted today, "this has been a profoundly moving and difficult week for all of us in our political family."
Mr. Kantor seems bound to exercise remote control over the trade representative's office. His deputy there, Charlene Barshefsky, will take over as acting trade representative, the President said, when she returns this weekend from China, which appears headed toward a showdown with the United States over trade and the spread of nuclear weapons.
At the same ceremony, Mr. Clinton appointed Franklin D. Raines, vice chairman of the Federal National Mortgage Association, to succeed Alice Rivlin as the director of the Office of Management and Budget, the key White House post in forming Federal spending policy.
Mr. Raines, who will become the second black member of the Cabinet -- the other is Energy Secretary Hazel O'Leary -- was a staff member in the budget office in the Carter Administration. He is leaving a job that pays $2.25 million to take one that pays about a 20th of that amount, in an Administration at such odds with Congress that it has operated with no budget since September.
Mr. Kantor's name will be submitted to the Senate for confirmation, but that is only a formality. Mr. Brown was killed while Congress was out of session, allowing Mr. Clinton to make a "recess appointment" that requires no Senate approval until the end of this session of Congress, early next year and after the Presidential election. The White House said Mr. Kantor would be serving as Commerce Secretary by the time Mr. Clinton leaves on Sunday for his state visit to Japan.
Today, Mr. Clinton's presumptive opponent, Senator Bob Dole, said he expected no opposition to Mr. Kantor. "He probably will be widely supported on the Republican side," Mr. Dole said in Texas, where he was campaigning. "I've worked with him, found him to be very fair and a good person."
But Mr. Dole also used the moment to attack Mr. Clinton and Mr. Kantor for celebrating the early results of the Administration's automobile agreement with Japan, a chief accomplishment of Mr. Kantor at the trade representative's office.
"President Clinton's declaration of victory on automobile trade with Japan is sad and unfortunate," he said, arguing that the U.S. "still has less than 1 percent of the Japanese market, while Japan has over 25 percent of the U.S. market."
As in all things related to trade, the veracity of Mr. Dole's figures depend on how you measure: While he counted cars made by the three major American automakers and sold in Japan -- which numbered about 58,000 last year -- he did not include cars produced by Japanese makers on American soil and shipped to Japan. That total was 84,763, bringing the total American share of the market to 2 percent, as against 0.5 percent in 1992, the last year of the Bush Administration.
The move across Pennsylvania Avenue to the Commerce Department will be a big one for Mr. Kantor: Currently he runs one of the smallest agencies in Washington, with fewer than 150 employees; on Monday he will take over one of the larger ones, with more than 38,000.
His biggest task will be to keep it from being dismantled, a battle with the Republican Congress that Mr. Brown waged for most of the last year. Many in the department feared that if Mr. Clinton appointed a Washington outsider to the Commerce post the department would be a sitting duck for Republican budget cutters. But Mr. Kantor is a wily player on Capitol Hill.
Today, Mr. Clinton made a strong argument for the centrality of the department's role. "I am determined that we will continue on the work that Ron Brown was engaged in the last day of his life," he said.
The main part of that work, or at least the part for which Mr. Brown has been remembered in the last week -- involves taking American business on the road, from Beijing to Belfast. Mr. Kantor will need little introduction to that work: He has traveled the world in the last three years butting heads with trade ministers. "I thought we ought to give him the chance to be a good cop for a change," Mr. Clinton said today.
Mr. Kantor, by all accounts, did not seek the job he was given today. He seemed content to work on the campaign from the trade representative's office in the Winder Building, where Lincoln used to come to read reports from Civil War battlefields, and that now has become the command center for trade battles around the world. But he said today, "I have never turned down anything this President has asked me to do."

HEADLINE: 55-Nation Conference on Fund-Raising for Bosnia Is Split Over the Serbs

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, April 12

 BODY:
Representatives of 55 countries began a two-day meeting today intended to raise $1.2 billion more in foreign economic aid for Bosnia and Herzegovina this year. American and European officials disagreed about whether the discredited Bosnian Serb leadership should get any of the money yet.
The Bosnian Serbs, who control 49 percent of the country's territory, refused to attend the conference because the organizers insisted that they sit as part of one delegation representing Bosnia's separate but loosely integrated Muslim-Croatian Federation and the Serbian entity. 
 "We have the intention of extending a hand to everyone, including the Serbs," Carl Bildt, the international civilian coordinator for Bosnia, said today. "We have seats reserved for them, and everyone can see that we are not closing the door to them. Their own leaders are closing the door on them."
But American officials at the conference said that none of the $200 million in United States economic aid pledged to Bosnia this year was intended for Serb-controlled areas.
Using the Serbian name for the Bosnian Serbs' republic, William D. Montgomery, President Clinton's special adviser for Bosnian civilian programs, said: "People don't want to help indicted war criminals stay in power. That's the dilemma on loans to the Republika Srpska."
The Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, has been indicted by an international tribunal for purported war crimes and will be barred from running in elections expected to take place in early September. Mr. Bildt said Dr. Karadzic had personally ordered the Serbian delegates to stay away from the conference.
The World Bank estimates that $5.1 billion will be needed over the next three to four years to help peace take hold in Bosnia, about $3.7 billion in the Muslim-Croatian Federation and $1.4 billion in the Serbian entity.
In December, representatives of 50 countries and 27 organizations raised nearly $600 million for 1996. Most of the same organizations have gathered here now to try to bring the 1996 aid total to $1.8 billion in hopes of getting at least some of Bosnia's shattered economy moving again before 60,000 NATO peacekeepers pull out at the end of the year.
American officials here said today that the United States was not contemplating an increase in the $200 million it has pledged so far, part of a three-year commitment of $600 million for economic reconstruction.
Instead, they argued, the United States should get credit for the contributions it is making in other ways -- an additional $350 million this year to help refugees, provide food supplies, train and run an international police force, organize elections and maintain a peacekeeping operation in the Croatian province of Eastern Slavonia.

HEADLINE: Observer;
Down And Out

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER 

 BODY:
The upmounting volume of outsourcing in ongoing downsizing circles has Mr. Barton V. fuming. "Where do they get these words?" he asks, referring to "outsourcing" in a letter I have culled from the incoming mail.
Fromculling incoming mail often rewards the fromculler with pathetic glimpses of those who want to hold back the future, or backhold the upcoming, as a fluent user of modern English would almost certainly say. 
 Mr. V. is clearly one of these would-be backholders. He suspects the existence of a secret euphemism factory to which captains of industry resort when they require new ways of downplaying the negative with silly words like "outsourcing."
This is surely paranoid nonsense. American English has always had a genius for gilding the nasty fact. It is a skill that comes naturally to every American with something to sell, which is to say virtually every citizen with a patriotic love of the marketplace.
In undertaker's lingo, for example, people are not permitted to die. They must pass away. This reduces a completely unnerving experience to absurdity by suggesting it is rather like a football maneuver.
It is perfectly natural that American industry should try to make us believe that farming out their jobs to cultures where labor is cheap is nothing more than outsourcing. Does anything sound duller than "outsourcing"?
If you sat for 40 days and 40 nights in a lonely room trying to guess what an outsourcing might be, what are the chances you would see a great tycoon firing the local work force to take advantage of cheap labor in other towns and countries?
No wonder American industry talks of outsourcings and downsizings. If these spades were called spades, fiendish incendiaries might re-ignite the flames of Grandfather Marx against capital's inhuman readiness to maximize profits by squeezing labor, and so forth.
American industry now employs public-relations wizards and psychologists expert in fooling enough of the people all of the time to invent claptrap words like "downsizing" and "outsourcing." Or at least expert enough to persuade their bosses to use such words without rolling on the floor in laughter.
By turning bad economic news into pussycat phenomena like downsizing and outsourcing, American business manages to upplay the positive. The American passion for the preposition, with its numbing effect on the brain, makes downplaying the negative and upplaying the positive easier than it should be.
How? For one thing, by discouraging us, when we hear "downsizing" and "outsourcing," from saying: "Hold it right there, pal. When you say 'downsizing' and 'outsourcing' to me, smile, unless you say it in plain English, the mother tongue, words of one syllable."
How, we might ask these utterers of gobbledygook, does outsourcing differ from insourcing? Is it possible to have upsourcing and downsourcing? Why is industry forever downsizing but never upsizing? What about upsidedownsizing? Rightside upsizing?
Insideoutsourcing?
Yes, we know what the happy consequences of all this preposition alized sizing and sourcing will be one of these days. It will be prosperity for all.
That sweet-smelling, ever-loving prosperity for all is upcoming, coming our way, coming at us, coming to us. Not just upcoming, but atcoming and tocoming. If you are in a pickle, it is incoming. If out in the cruel storm, it is outcoming.
For those at the bottom of the economic ladder, it is downcoming, and when it has downcome all the way and touched these lowly wretches, they will be upgoing.
If you are constantly in and out of the house, in and out of the hospital, work, jail, it will be inandoutcoming. Are your days spent going back and forth, to and from the employment office looking unsuccessfully for a job ? Do not despair. It will be backandforthcoming as well as toandfromcoming.
Ah, that great atcoming, tocoming, upcoming, downcoming, incoming prosperity to be produced by downsizing and outsourcing! Despite what the old song says, it will not be coming round the mountain when it comes. It will be roundcoming whatever obstacle it must circumnavigate.
What's more, after it arrives it will be ongoing.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Liberian Civilian Hostages Are Trapped in Mortar Attack

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: MONROVIA, Liberia, April 12

 BODY:
Several thousand Liberians held hostage in a barracks here by one of the country's warring militias came under mortar attack today by another faction for the second day. While the fighting continued, a United States evacuation effort focused on pulling out stranded Americans and other foreigners from isolated hiding places here.
Diplomats said they had no way of verifying the number of people trapped in the camp. At the American Embassy a mile and a half away, loud thuds from the shelling could be heard. 
 The attacks occurred late this morning at the Barclay Training Center, a sprawling camp near the center of town that belonged to the former Liberian Army.
Forces of the former rebel leader, Charles Taylor, lobbed mortar shells into the compound, killing several people and wounding many others.
Moussa Ismael, a 46-year-old Lebanese merchant who was rescued from the camp but had to leave his wife and three children behind in captivity, said: "It is better for me to die with my children. I don't care about my money or my property, but please, God, spare their lives."
In an interview with the BBC, Mr. Taylor denied that he had bombed the Barclay Center, but said his men were determined to capture it.
"This is a responsible government, and everything will be done to allow humanitarian agencies to do their work," said Mr. Taylor, who is now a deputy chairman of the bitterly split Council of State. His words provoked hisses from a large crowd of refugees gathered around a short-wave radio at the headquarters of the West African peacekeeping force here.
Refugees who escaped from the camp said hostages had been pulled into the training center by fighters of the Krahn ethnic group who are loyal to D. Roosevelt Johnson, a renegade Government minister.
[Gen. George Joulwan, the NATO commander in Europe and the American general with jurisdiction over West Africa, has ordered the sending of a Marine amphibious group from the Mediterranean to the Liberian coast, a Pentagon official said Friday in Washington.
[Lieut. J. G. Walker, a Navy spokesman, said the group would probably consist of the Guam, a helicopter carrier; the Trenton, an amphibious transport ship, and the Portland, a dock landing ship. The ships were in the Mediterranean on Thursday. He also said two other ships were being sent: the Connolly, a destroyer, and the Big Horn, an oiler.
[The ships will carry 2,000 marines and about 1,500 sailors, Lieutenant Walker said.]
Liberia's seven-year-old civil war exploded anew last Saturday after Mr. Taylor and other Council of State members stepped up efforts to arrest Mr. Johnson on murder charges.
The fighting that ensued has pitted thousands of Krahn against the combined forces of Al Haji G. V. Kromah and Mr. Taylor, whose 1989 invasion of Liberia from the Ivory Coast set off a war that killed well over 150,000.
Neither the local or international authorities have estimated casualty figures from the ferocious combat.
United Nations officials were forced out of their compound in the Mamba Point area of the capital today and were marched by Mr. Taylor's fighters to the American Embassy, where they joined hundreds of others.
Paul Koulen, deputy director of the United Nations development program here, said that in just the short walk to the embassy, he had seen numerous bodies strewn in the streets, some of them with their hands tied behind their backs.
From the air, smoldering fires could be seen above the city and long lines of people wandering the streets in search of food and water. While United States Air Force gunners scanned the ground below, shots were fired in the vicinity of a United States military helicopter that ferried a few foreign journalists from neighboring Sierra Leone, forcing a hasty takeoff.
The United States Ambassador to Liberia, William Milam, said that more than 1,000 people, mostly foreigners, have been evacuated from the country in recent days, and that more were turning up all the time.
"People keep running to us for refuge because we're the only refuge in town, except Ecomog," Mr. Milam said, referring to the West African peacekeepers. "Ecomog has been here for five years and is pretty well known, but the United States has been involved here for 150 years and has always been looked to for stability."
Liberia was founded in 1822 by freed American slaves and has traditionally maintained close ties with the United States.
For many families in Monrovia, life over the last few days, spent in isolated neighborhoods with little news and no prospect of safe movement, has been a harrowing experience.
"We haven't slept since this began," said Dr. Wilhemina Jallah, an American woman of Liberian origin. She and her husband had gathered their five children, aged 6 months to 17 years, in just a few seconds after a radio call came from the American Embassy telling them to show up within 10 minutes at a rendezvous point.
"We were lucky that we could afford a $600 Motorola radio, which is what kept us in touch," she said. It was purchased after the family went through a previous evacuation during fighting in 1990.
In fact, many people here faced wrenching decisions about whether to leave the country at all. Many Liberian parents of children who were born in the United States, and who are hence American citizens, learned that only one guardian would be allowed to travel with American children.
"Most of the people who are in that situation have decided to stay behind all together," said Sorsor Jallah, an engineer who, along with his wife, said he had to console many other Liberians who were unwilling to split their families.
Diplomats said today that there was little sign that the Liberian conflict was moving toward resolution, despite reports of a truce coming out of the talks with a high-level delegation of officials from Ghana, which is representing the Economic Community of West African States.
"Everyone says the other has to make the first move," Ambassador Milam said of the warlords, some of whom he has spoken with over the last two days. "It is extremely frustrating to watch things just continue along this way."
Complicating the situation further, telephone service in Monrovia was cut today as workers who have not eaten for several days abandoned their headquarters. At the American diplomatic compound, food and water needed for the large numbers of people taking refuge on the grounds are running low.
At an embassy annex, an open field not far from the diplomatic compound, as many as 20,000 Liberians remained huddled, exposed to the elements and without basic provisions for the sixth day.
Because of the shortages and increasing insecurity, American officials said they would fly as many helicopter sorties into Monrovia as possible tonight to remove 200 to 300 people awaiting evacuation. As of today, there were 200 to 300 Americans whose whereabouts were known and others who were scattered throughout town. There were also 350 people outside the embassy trying to get in.
Groping for an explanation of the crisis, many Liberians said the war would not end until only one warlord was left standing, or when a foreign force deploys here in large enough numbers to begin a disarmament.
"They say that this whole thing began with an attempt to arrest Johnson, but everyone here knows that that was just a pretext by the warlords to bring their contest into the city," said Ben Asante, one of the refugees here. "Now there are dead bodies everywhere, and a humanitarian crisis is looming. No, it has already begun, and this country appears more than ever to be finished."

HEADLINE: State Dept. Budget Is Vetoed; Clinton Protests Planned Cuts

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 12

 BODY:
Complaining that the Republican-led Congress was trying to undermine the White House's foreign policy authority, President Clinton today vetoed a $13 billion State Department authorization bill that would have required substantial spending cuts and would have forced Washington to give more political support to Taiwan.
"This legislation contains many unacceptable provisions that would undercut U.S. leadership abroad and damage our ability to assure the future security and prosperity of the American people," Mr. Clinton said in his veto message to Congress. 
 "It would also restrict Presidential authority needed to conduct foreign affairs and to control state secrets, thereby raising serious constitutional concerns."
The veto sets up another major election-year fight between Mr. Clinton and Congressional Republicans, who are already locked in political battles over the 1996 budget, a seven-year plan to balance the Federal budget and tax cuts.
The Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, the all but certain Republican Presidential nominee, said, "Vetoing the bill shows that, for President Clinton, the era of big government is alive and well."
The House and the Senate passed the bill last month, but both vote margins were well shy of the two-thirds majorities needed to overturn a veto. The White House and Republicans will have to work out a deal when Congress returns on Monday from a two-week recess.
The bill would authorize $6.5 billion in each of the next two years for the State Department and other foreign policy agencies. That annual number would be $500 million less than the 1995 spending level, which was $7 billion, but the bill preserved annual aid to Israel at about $1.5 billion and to Egypt at just over $1 billion. The bill also authorized $426 million to fight the international drug war and $435 million for the Peace Corps.
Led by Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina, the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Republicans pushed to merge the Agency for International Development, the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency and the United States Information Agency into the State Department.
But in a bow to the White House, which was rejected by the Administration, Congressional Republicans inserted a provision that would allow the President to protect two of the three agencies from elimination.
Mr. Clinton called the spending levels unacceptable, saying they would "adversely affect the operation of overseas posts of the foreign affairs agencies and weaken critical U.S. efforts to promote arms control and nonproliferation, reform international organizations and peacekeeping, streamline public diplomacy and implement sustainable development activities."
Administration officials found a section on relations with Taiwan even more onerous, saying it would further strain relations with China.
The bill would revive the 1979 Taiwan Relations Act, under which Washington guaranteed Taiwan the sale of defensive weapons; such a move would supersede the 1982 Shanghai Communique, under which the Reagan Administration promised China to gradually reduce weapons sales to Taiwan.
President Clinton said such a move would threaten "one of the cornerstones" of his China policy.
The Republican lawmakers also included a provision that called for President Lee Teng-Hui of Taiwan to be invited to the United States for a visit "with all appropriate courtesies." Last year, under Republican pressure, Mr. Clinton granted a visa to President Lee for a private visit, an action that incensed China.
The Administration had at least a dozen smaller but no less nettlesome problems with the bill, including a section urging the President not to visit China until there had been a "marked improvement" in human rights in China and Tibet.
