HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Adds to a Week of Gains As a Firm U.S. Economy Is Seen

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the German mark and Swiss franc, helped by perceptions that the United States economy remains strong relative to its European rivals.
Economic data released yesterday failed to alter the view of many currency traders that the United States was growing fast enough to keep the Federal Reserve from cutting interest rates. Most European economies, by contrast, are so sluggish that central banks there may be forced to lower rates soon to encourage growth. 
 The dollar rose to an 8-month high against the Swiss franc, and reached a 14-month high against the German mark for the second time in three days. It also set another 26-month high against the yen in Asian trading, before giving back its gains.
"This has been an impressive move for the dollar," said John de Beer, a portfolio manager at Loomis Sayles & Company in Boston, who oversees the firm's $2 billion in international bonds.
In trading in New York late yesterday, the dollar settled at 1.5035 marks, up from 1.5020 marks on Thursday and at 1.2260 Swiss francs, up from 1.2210 Swiss francs. The dollar was also quoted at 108.55 yen, up from 108.41 yen. The British pound was trading at $1.5140, up from $1.5115.
The gains came at the end of a strong week for the dollar, which has climbed 2.5 percent against the Swiss franc, 1.3 percent against the mark and eight-tenths of 1 percent against the yen since last weekend.
While there have been recent signs of growth in the United States economy, the economies of Germany and Switzerland have, by contrast, appeared sluggish.
The president of the German central bank, Hans Tietmeyer, told a group of Swiss and German business executives in Zurich yesterday that the German central bank would consider cutting rates in "coming weeks and months." But that would happen only "in the proper environment," he said.
Those remarks and similar recent comments by central bank officials have bolstered investors' hopes for a cut in German rates that would buoy the dollar.
"We can count on further easing in Germany," said John Trammell, international fund manager at the A. Gary Shilling Company, an investment firm.

HEADLINE: Top Editor Will Leave Magazine

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES 

 BODY:
Andrew Sullivan, the editor of The New Republic, announced yesterday that he would step down from his post at the end of May.
Mr. Sullivan, who has edited the magazine since October 1991, said that he wanted to concentrate on writing, and that he had signed a contract with Alfred A. Knopf to deliver a book on friendship. He will continue to write for the magazine as a senior editor. 
 "This will be my 250th issue next week," Mr. Sullivan said. "I've done it longer, continuously, than either of my predecessors, and it just seemed right. I think you should stop talking before they start looking at their watches."
Mr. Sullivan said he was infected with the virus that causes AIDS but was not stepping down for health reasons. "I am not quitting because I am sick," he said. "I am quitting because I am healthy. I'm very early on in the disease, and I intend to survive it."
He added: "Inevitably, you view the world in a very different way when something like this happens. You don't want to tread water."
Martin Peretz, the editor in chief and chairman of the magazine, said that he had made no move to pick a successor yet. "There are a couple of obvious candidates in-house, although I won't say who they are, and I suspect there will be some volunteers from the outside," he said.
When Mr. Sullivan was named to succeed Hendrik Hertzberg as editor of the magazine, a journal of politics and the arts, the choice represented not only a generational shift but also a cultural one. Only 28 at the time, Mr. Sullivan was British, a practicing Roman Catholic and openly homosexual. Politically, he was a Thatcherite conservative, with a genuine enthusiasm for American culture. A graduate of Oxford University, he holds a master's degree in public administration and a doctorate in political science from Harvard University.
Under Mr. Sullivan, The New Republic devoted more attention to popular culture, religion and gay issues while continuing to cover American politics, foreign affairs and economics. During the 1992 Presidential campaign, the magazine was an early and persistent champion of Bill Clinton, whom it celebrated in one early cover article as "The Anointed." The honeymoon ended soon after Mr. Clinton was elected.
Mr. Sullivan said: "I wanted to expand the variety of subjects and to develop more the magazine's argumentative and tempestuous self. I wanted to stir it up." He compared the magazine to a dinner party made up of cantankerous guests.
Critics of the magazine complained that the Sullivan era of diversity and his oft-proclaimed "post-ideological" point of view made the magazine blurry and confused. Admirers praised him for infusing new blood while preserving the magazine's reputation for being independent-minded.
"Andrew gave it a more consciously hip tone, but he was very good at keeping the serious side of the magazine serious," said Michael Kelly, the Washington editor of The New Yorker and a former contributor to The New Republic. "He kept the magazine intellectually honest, tough minded and free of cant."
Mr. Sullivan said that part of his mission had been to bring in younger writers. "I looked around the table at an editorial meeting the other day and the average age was around 30," he said. One of those younger writers was Ruth Shalit, whose reporting has repeatedly been attacked as inaccurate and on a few occasions as containing plagiarized material. Ms. Shalit is on a leave of absence from the magazine.
Mr. Sullivan wrote often on sexual politics and gay issues, and he argued strongly in favor of gay marriage and against the Catholic Church's doctrine on homosexuality. He developed his views at greater length in "Virtually Normal: An Argument About Homosexuality," which was published last year by Knopf.
Mr. Sullivan's unusual blending of political conservatism and social liberalism made him an unpredictable voice on homosexual issues, however. He brought down on his head the wrath of many gay critics after he criticized the practice of outing, or identifying by name actors, politicians and other public figures who were keeping their homosexuality secret.
During Mr. Sullivan's tenure, the circulation of the magazine increased from 96,000 to 100,000 and advertising revenues rose 76 percent. The New Republic won National Magazine Awards in reporting and general excellence in 1992. Adweek magazine named Mr. Sullivan editor of the year for 1996.
"He brought us new readers by focusing on certain kinds of cultural issues," Mr. Peretz said. "He probably lost us some readers who thought those interests compromised our authority as a guide to how you think politically."

HEADLINE: Ford, in Mazda Investment, Is Revered as Well as Feared

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company's decision to take effective control of the Mazda Motor Corporation represents a judgment that the ailing Japanese car maker, with its sales falling, can no longer make it by itself in an increasingly global and combative auto industry, executives and analysts said yesterday.
"They are a small company and today's world is getting very competitive," Wayne Booker, executive vice president of Ford, said at a news conference in Dearborn, Mich. 
 But in Japan, the effective takeover of a leading company in a core industry by an American company was greeted with some of the same sense of letdown and concern with which many Americans initially viewed the Sony Corporation's purchase of a Hollywood studio.
A decade ago, American auto makers were struggling to emulate the Japanese. But now, Henry D.G. Wallace, a longtime Ford executive who cannot speak Japanese, will become the new president of Mazda. Most big Japanese companies do not have a single foreigner on their boards and a foreign president is virtually unprecedented.
Only a few weeks ago, one Mazda manager insisted that Mr. Wallace, who is Scottish, would never become president because it would mean a loss of face and morale within Mazda. Mr. Wallace, who was dispatched from Ford in 1993 to be an executive vice president at Mazda, was already effectively in control of the company, he said.
Under the agreement announced yesterday, Ford will give Mazda a much-needed capital injection of 52 billion yen, or about $480 million. That will increase Ford's stake in Mazda from the roughly 25 percent it has held since 1979 to 33.4 percent, a level that gives it effective control under Japanese law.
Ford will pay 363 yen for each of the newly issued Mazda shares, well below Mazda's closing price of 465 yen on Thursday; Mazda's shares did not trade yesterday on the Tokyo Stock Exchange.
Ford's new stake in Mazda is not completely unprecedented. The General Motors Corporation owns an even larger 37 percent of Tokyo-based Isuzu Motors Ltd. G.M. has also stationed its executives at the Japanese truck manufacturer in posts as high as executive vice president. But G.M. never tried to exercise the hands-on control that Ford has with Mazda.
Workers at Mazda and people in Hiroshima, where the company is based and is a mainstay of the economy, had mixed feelings. Some hoped Ford would revive Mazda, while others worried that American management would end the practice of lifetime employment.
"That's what the young workers are talking about -- tomorrow you will be fired," one young manager in Hiroshima said. "This kind of joke has been going around since the announcement."
But Mr. Booker of Ford said yesterday that he did not anticipate any major cuts in Mazda's employment.
In Tokyo, Mr. Wallace said at a news conference that his priority was "first and foremost to establish and maintain a very strong corporate identity for Mazda worldwide." Mr. Wallace -- who has insisted that he is an employee of Mazda, not Ford -- said the image of a company is not based upon "who the shareholders are and who the component makers are."
Ford is now expected to integrate Mazda more fully into its global operations. For instance, Ford can turn to Mazda for product design, especially for the fast-growing Asian market.
"They are very nimble," Mr. Booker said. "They can develop products very quickly. They have a good knowledge of what Asian customers want."
He said Ford would "quite likely" sell its own cars through Mazda dealers in Japan, where American auto makers have faced difficulties in signing up dealers.
To get any value out of Mazda, however, Ford had to save it, analysts said. "It wouldn't have gone bankrupt, but it would have just gotten smaller," said Saul Rubin of SBC Warburg in Tokyo. "With Ford behind it, I think it can regain its competitiveness."
To some extent, Mazda is already on the mend. Even though the company posted net losses totaling 80 billion yen, or roughly $800 million, in the fiscal years 1993 and 1994, Mazda expects to have reached the break-even point in its fiscal year that ended last month.
But that improvement comes mainly from severe cost-cutting, not better sales. The company slashed investment in new plants and equipment in 1995 to less than 20 percent of its level in 1992.
"They cannot continue to reduce investment forever," said Chikao Masuzawa, an analyst at Salomon Brothers in Tokyo. "They have to refurbish their factories at some time."
Meanwhile, Mazda's production of vehicles in Japan plunged 21 percent in 1995 from a year earlier, as both its domestic sales and exports dropped sharply. From 1990 to 1995, sales by Mazda in Japan fell 40 percent and its exports 48 percent. In the United States, its sales in the first quarter of this year are down 17.4 percent from the corresponding period last year.
The recent problems of Mazda stem from its vast expansion in models and dealers during the Japanese boom of the late 1980's. When the economy slumped, Mazda was left with excess capacity and costs. Mazda has relatively limited production outside of Japan, making it more vulnerable than many of its Japanese competitors to the adverse effects of a stronger yen.

HEADLINE: New Jersey Offers Yankees Stadium Plans

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

DATELINE: TRENTON, April 12

 BODY:
The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority has given the New York Yankees' principal owner, George M. Steinbrenner 3d, plans for a stadium in New Jersey to house the team after the lease for its current home in the Bronx expires in 2002, according to officials of the state and the Yankees organization.
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said this week that she did not know the details of talks between the state and the Yankees. But other senior state officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the state had offered Mr. Steinbrenner a number of "concepts" for an old-fashioned baseball-only stadium that would hold 50,000 to 55,000 people. 
 Although Mrs. Whitman said the plans were not a formal proposal, the team's executive vice president, David W. Sussman, said New Jersey officials "presented a specific plan" late last year. "The only one from the Yankees who has the authority to discuss it is George Steinbrenner," Mr. Sussman said. "George has been dealing directly and exclusively with the people in New Jersey."
But Mr. Steinbrenner is refusing to comment on his discussions with New Jersey officials. He did not return telephone calls to his office over the last two days.
The New Jersey proposal is part of a delicate, four-way dance involving Mr. Steinbrenner, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Bronx political leaders and officials in New Jersey. Mr. Steinbrenner has made it clear that he is dissatisfied with the team's 73-year-old home in the Bronx and that he would welcome proposals for a new stadium either in New Jersey or elsewhere in New York City.
Until now, neither New Jersey officials nor the Mayor have wanted to be the first to suggest that the team should leave the Bronx.
But in recent weeks, Mayor Giuliani has become much more aggressive in promoting the idea that a new stadium be built on the West Side of Manhattan. In the last few days he has begun a campaign to rally business leaders behind the West Side plan. [Page 26.]
Meanwhile, New Jersey officials quietly gave their plan to Mr. Steinbrenner, all the while continuing to profess in public that nothing official had been offered.
During the Yankees' home opener this week, Mr. Steinbrenner was joined in his executive suite at the stadium by the chief executive of New Jersey's Sports Authority, Robert E. Mulcahy 3d; the authority's chairman, Michael D. Francis, and is past chairman, Jon F. Hanson.
"I have no comment on talks," Mr. Mulcahy said when asked if the group discussed the possibility of the Yankees moving to New Jersey. As for the state's proposal, he said, "There is no hard and fast plan." That night, Mr. Steinbrenner went to Gracie Mansion for a private talk with the Mayor.
The conceptual plans that New Jersey presented to the Yankees include three or four sites in northern New Jersey, officials familiar with the plans said. The cost would be about $400 million to $500 million, depending on the specific plan. The price would vary largely due to environmental factors, since some of the proposed sites have significant wetlands and potential traffic problems that would have to be addressed.
Although New Jersey has not undertaken the significant cost analysis that New York City recently completed, the estimated costs are about 50 percent less than the estimates for New York City's plan to build a giant dual-purpose sports stadium on Manhattan's West Side.
The Meadowlands complex in East Rutherford is already home to two professional football teams that once were based in New York, and New Jersey baseball fans have longed for a team for years. In 1987, when state proponents of baseball tried to attract a team by getting the authority to build a stadium near the Meadowlands, voters rejected a $185 million taxpayer bond that would have financed construction. Since Governor Whitman came into office over two years ago, she has insisted that the state would not use tax dollars to build a stadium.
"We have always had an interest in bringing baseball to New Jersey," Mr. Mulcahy said. "But we have to do it within the confines of Governor Whitman's parameters." State officials have since said they could still issue bonds for a new stadium and pay them off with a percentage of ticket sales and other receipts.
Surveys have shown that an estimated 60 percent of the Yankees' attendance comes from New Jersey and Westchester County. And while the team has never had more than 2.7 million fans a season during its 73 years at Yankee Stadium, New Jersey officials project that a site in the Meadowlands, for example, could boost attendance to 3 million a year.
Officials close to Mr. Steinbrenner noted that the team owner might be patronizing the New Jersey officials only to gain leverage in his talks with New York City. But as one of Mr. Steinbrenner's close friends, who would only speak on condition of anonymity, said: "I know him well enough to know that's not what he's doing. I think he wants to get a new ballpark, period."
Mr. Giuliani, on the other hand, is publicly using the threat of a Yankee exodus to New Jersey to create a sense of urgency and convince New Yorkers of the merits of his own stadium plan. A senior official in the mayor's office said he had not seen any proposals from New Jersey.
Mr. Steinbrenner has told New Jersey officials that he prefers the type of natural grass, open-air stadium that they are proposing over New York's plan, which calls for a multi-purpose, domed stadium with artificial turf.
The New York proposal might be the city's last hope for saving the team, since Mr. Steinbrenner has rejected all offers by New York for improvements to the current Yankee Stadium. And the $1 billion West Side site envisioned by Mr. Giuliani is considered by many stadium finance experts to be far too costly to work economically -- for either the city or Mr. Steinbrenner.
New Jersey officials said that Mr. Steinbrenner might be allowing New York to make its best effort, and should that fail he would then be able to make it clear to the public that New York City's space and economic constraints have left him with no other choice than to move the team out of the city.
Mrs. Whitman, who ultimately must approve any formal proposal from the Sports Authority, said she does not want to become part of a bidding war, allowing the state to be used as a negotiating tool for Mr. Steinbrenner.
By not making what she called a "formal proposal," even though the sports authority has given Mr. Steinbrenner conceptual plans, the governor may be trying to have things both ways.
When asked about the stadium plans during a news conference on Thursday, her comments underscored her administration's approach on the matter. "We're not going to get in a bidding war with someone else," Mrs. Whitman said. "It doesn't help to have New York to spend more to keep the Yankees where they are." Then, she added, "If the Yankees are interested in moving, the sports authority has put a proposal out."

HEADLINE: Spring Tonic in a Surge of Income Tax Refunds

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
An early surge in income tax refunds is giving Americans billions of extra dollars to spend this spring, which helps to explain the revival in the economy now in progress.
The tax refunds, $52.1 billion through the end of March, are turning out to be a shot in the arm for the economy; indeed, the latest of several temporary shots in the arm that may well make the second quarter, just getting started, the strongest period of growth this year. "The refunds are definitely showing up as car down payments," Wynn Van Bussman, an economist at the Chrysler Corporation, said, "and that is stimulating sales." 
 The tax refunds, along with several other special effects, could lift economic growth in the second quarter to an annual rate of 3 percent or so, according to some forecasters, including those at the President's Council of Economic Advisers. But as these booster shots wear off by mid-summer, economic growth will probably scale back, closer to a 2 percent rate.
"The odds of a spurt in activity later this year are not that high," said Joel Prakken, a partner at Lawrence H. Meyer & Associates, an economic consulting firm in St. Louis.
The boosters come from several sources. Apart from the tax refunds, warmer weather has removed an obstacle to the shopping and construction that snowstorms and floods had postponed in the first quarter. Auto manufacturers raised production quotas for April to make up for lost days during the General Motors strike last month. And the drop in interest rates that lasted through 1995, bringing down mortgage and auto loan rates, is still helping the economy, economists say, with many Americans making purchases on credit before borrowing gets too costly again. Interest rates began to creep back up in January.
The surge in tax refunds became evident in data made available by the Internal Revenue Service this week. During March, the number of refund checks authorized by the I.R.S. rose to 41.6 billion from 17 billion on March 1, and the total amount of those checks jumped to $52.1 billion from $24.2 billion at the end of February. The dollar total represented a rise of 25 percent compared with the first three months of last year, when tax refunds were delayed.
But even discounting for last year's delays, the refunds are up by more than 10 percent, or roughly double the normal rise of 5 or 6 percent a year. "Unequivocally, more tax refunds are flowing into the economy than is normal," said William Dudley, director of economic research at Goldman, Sachs & Company.
Through March, the average refund check was $1,252, up 16.4 percent from last year's first-quarter average of $1,076. The increase was larger than in any previous first quarter in this decade, but I.R.S. and Treasury Department officials said the average would taper off as more refunds were issued.
The jump in refunds reflects, in part, unusual delays last year, when the I.R.S. held up checks to screen returns for fraud in claiming money under the earned-income tax credit. The returns were also checked for inaccurate Social Security numbers. "Most of the people caught in the Social Security screen have been careful not to repeat that mistake this year," said Steven Pyrek, an I.R.S. spokesman.
But the higher refunds also reflect a rise in payments that the working poor receive under the earned-income tax credit, the revenue service said. By law, the maximum credit rose to $3,110 last year from $2,528 in 1994, and last year's money is going out now through tax refund checks. Many wealthy taxpayers, who were hit with higher tax rates starting in 1993, may also have withheld from last year's paychecks more than they actually owed in taxes, prompted to do so by stiffer penalties for failing to withhold enough.
Still, by December, I.R.S. officials said, tax refunds should be more in line with what happened in 1995, when they totaled $93.4 billion, sent out to 79.3 million taxpayers in checks averaging $1,178.

GRAPHIC: Graphs: "Lifting the Economy?" shows Federal income tax refunds as of March 31, since 1991. (Source: Internal Revenue Service)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
DOCUMENTS FILED WITH S.E.C. FOR REFINANCING

 BODY:
Apple Computer, struggling to avoid a financial crisis, announced one step yesterday that would give it additional breathing room. The company said that it had filed documents with the Securities and Exchange Commission reporting that it had successfully extended and refinanced $400 million of short-term loans to its subsidiaries in Japan and the Netherlands. The debt included a $187 million note, due in March, and a $203 million note that was due this month. The computer maker, based in Cupertino, Calif., said that it had extended the loans with new maturity rates ranging from June 28, 1996, to Sept. 29, 1996.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 33; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Mickey Kantor Is Named To Head Commerce Agency
President Clinton named Mickey Kantor, who has been the trade representative, to succeed Ronald H. Brown as Commerce Secretary. Mr. Kantor, shown at left, used extraordinary pressure tactics to force Europe, Japan, Mexico and China to open their markets, a style much different from Mr. Brown's.
Mr. Kantor seems bound to exercise remote control over the trade representative's office, where his deputy, Charlene Barshefsky, will take over. Mr. Clinton also named Franklin D. Raines, a Fannie Mae executive, to head the Office of Management and Budget. [Page 1.]
 
Retail Sales Inch Higher
Retail sales eked out a small gain in March and inflation edged higher, Government figures showed. The reports calmed financial markets nervous about higher interest rates. The Consumer Price Index rose four-tenths of 1 percent, but its underlying rate rose three-tenths of 1 percent, matching the market's expectations. Retail sales edged up a scant one-tenth of 1 percent in March. [34.]
 
Mazda Takeover Seen as a Rescue
Ford's decision to take effective control of Mazda represents a judgment that the ailing Japanese car maker can no longer succeed on its own, analysts said. In Japan, the takeover and naming of a Western executive to head the company was met with a sense of letdown. Most Japanese companies, even the most global ones, do not have a single foreigner on their boards, and a foreign president is virtually unprecedented. [35.]
 
Anne Klein Ends Designer Unit
Anne Klein & Company, one of the first American design houses run by a woman that has achieved world-class respectability, plans to end its designer collection division. It has suffered through several seasons of savage reviews and poor sales, and has not been profitable since 1989, according to its parent company, Takihyo of Japan. Anne Klein's lower-end lines will remain in stores. [34.]
 
Editor Steps Down at New Republic
Andrew Sullivan, the editor of The New Republic, plans to step down at the end of May to concentrate on writing. He has just signed a contract with Alfred A. Knopf to deliver a book on friendship, and will continue to write for the magazine as a senior editor. [35.]
 
Stocks Recover Some Ground
Stocks broke out of a weeklong slump to end sharply higher for the day, as a rally in the bond market eased worries about higher interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 45.52 points, to 5,532.59, and that rise was held back by I.B.M., which fell 6, to 111 1/2. For the week, the Dow fell 2.6 percent. [37.]
 
In the bond market, the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond tumbled to 6.79 percent from 6.93 percent, as investors became less troubled by signs of inflation. [43.]
 
Wheat Surges Again
Wheat futures prices continued to surge as forecasts for a hot, dry summer prompted panicked buying from companies anxious to secure supplies. One wheat analyst said, "What we're seeing is constant buying and virtually no selling." [36.]
 
Profit Skids at Texas Instruments
Profits dropped 29 percent at Texas Instruments, hurt by falling prices for memory chips. The results were far below expectations. [45.]
 
Dollar Up Smartly
The dollar rose to an 8-month high against the Swiss franc and a 14-month high against the German mark. Currency traders said the United States is growing fast enough to keep the Federal Reserve from cutting interest rates, whereas European economies are so sluggish that central banks there may lower rates to spur growth. [36.]
 
New Jersey Offers Yankees a Plan
New Jersey has approached George Steinbrenner with plans for an old-fashioned baseball-only stadium that would hold 50,000 to 55,000 people. The cost would be $400 million to $500 million, about half the projected cost of the plan for a dual-purpose stadium proposed by New York City. [23.]

CORRECTION-DATE: April 26, 1996, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An entry in the Business Digest on April 13, referring to an article about Anne Klein & Company's decision to end the designer collection division, misidentified the owner of Anne Klein. It is Takihyo Inc., a privately held company based in the United States, not the Takihyo Company, a publicly traded Japanese company; the two companies are not affiliated.

HEADLINE: Vietnam: Oct. 22, 1967;
Where Johnson Ends and McNamara Begins

BYLINE: By Neil Sheehan 

 BODY:
In Robert S. McNamara there has been a unique meeting of a man and his times. In a period of vast social and technological change, with vast domestic and international problems arising from this change, Robert S. McNamara is the managerial type par excellence. He has mastered the technique of the statistical approach, the careful analysis of the available options, the ability to qualify the disparate elements of a complex situation. He also has arrived at a time when the United States is at the height of its power, with crisis after crisis flowing through the operations room of the White House. For two Presidents, eager to make today's multitude of decisions and go on to tomorrow's, McNamara has provided the ready answers.
Yet his managerial prowess alone is not what has made McNamara such an accomplished servant of princes. Other men have shown this quality and it has not brought them the power McNamara wields. He has another quality which has been equally important in his relations with two Presidents. It is his absolute loyalty to his superior. . . . 
 "Why does the President hold McNamara in such high regard?" a member of the Joint Chiefs of Staff was recently asked. "Because McNamara will be hatchet man for the President on anything the President wants," was the unhesitating reply. "If the President told McNamara to call a press conference and announce that I'd gone berserk this morning and jumped out a window, he might argue, but he'd do it without batting an eye," the officer said, "even though he knew I'd died of a heart attack from overwork." . . .
As the day unfolds between appointments, he slowly works his way through the stacks of documents. By 7:30 or 8 P.M., as the Secretary leaves for home in his black Cadillac limousine, General Pershing would admire the cleanliness of the desk.
Mrs. McNamara says he leaves his work behind him. "He is not a worrier," she said. "Once he makes a decision, it is done and it no longer bothers him." . . .
For his part, McNamara has helped the President to hold the line against the really drastic escalation of the bombing which the generals and their political friends are seeking. For the generals want much more than a few important bridges and airfields. They want to conduct an unrelenting campaign of strategic air interdiction against North Vietnam. They want to demolish or otherwise completely neutralize all of the port facilities at Haiphong, to bomb the air defense command and control centers in the populated areas of Hanoi and Haiphong, to destroy the hydroelectric dams and locks in the Red River delta and cause widespread flooding and crop damage and to make virtually unrestricted attacks on the rail lines and highways close to the Chinese frontier. All of these objectives are still denied them.
McNamara was not, however, arguing for an end to the bombing as the doves desire. A restricted air campaign, with periodic suspensions, has its place in his strategy. His stand against an escalation of the bombing arises as much from his present conviction that the war will be decided on the ground in the South as it does from his lack of faith in the efficacy of air power.
What the doves also forget is that McNamara's managerial skills have made the war much more palatable to the public than it might otherwise have been. McNamara, in fact, removed some of the inhibitions the President might have experienced in undertaking it. He placed a 467,000-man expeditionary corps in South Vietnam for Johnson without the political repercussions of mobilization and, by frequently calculating war production needs with dangerous narrowness, has eased the inflationary impact on the American economy.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: WOMEN: Sept. 10, 1967;
An Interview with a Cheerful First Lady

 BODY:
When did you meet the President?
When I was at the university . . . He asked me for a date at breakfast the next morning -- and breakfast turned out to be also about a four-hour drive out into the country in which we discussed everything about each other.
Was it love at first sight?
Not on my part. It was keen interest and excitement. When I say we discussed everything, I mean he told me a great deal about his job -- he was at that time secretary to Congressman [Richard M.] Kleberg from Corpus Christi -- and about his interests and his family. Then he asked me if I would drive with him to meet his mother and father.
On the first date?
Yes. . . .
Now, in Texas terms you really lived in much more sumptuous surroundings than the Johnson family did. How did this strike you at first?
Well, there was nothing in my background that would have taught me to seek the same kind of economic level I had. One rather turned one's back on aiming toward that, because there was always the thought that with hard work and ability you could arrive at just about anywhere you wanted. My father had come up from no economic background to a very solid one, and as for my husband's family, his father had been a rancher, farmer and legislator. . . . And his fortunes had risen and fallen with the depressions and with the slope of the years, and at the time I met Lyndon they were of quite modest means. That to me was obvious and no barrier.

HEADLINE: 1990's: Dec. 1, 1991;
Grady's Gift

BYLINE: By Howell Raines 

 BODY:
GRADY SHOWED UP ONE DAY at our house at 1409 Fifth Avenue West in Birmingham, and by and by she changed the way I saw the world. I was 7 when she came to iron and clean and cook for $18 a week, and she stayed for seven years. . . .
Gradystein Williams Hutchinson (or Grady, as she was called in my family and hers) and I are two people who grew up in the 50's in that vanished world, two people who lived mundane, inconsequential lives while Martin Luther King Jr. and Police Commissioner T. Eugene (Bull) Connor prepared for their epic struggle. For years, Grady and I lived in my memory as child and adult. But now I realize that we were both children -- one white and very young, one black and adolescent; one privileged, one poor. The connection between these two children and their city was this: Grady saw to it that although I was to live in Birmingham for the first 28 years of my life, Birmingham would not live in me. . . . 
 "I always wanted to be more than I was," she says. "I thought if I was given the chance I could be more than I was ever allowed to be." . . .
Among black people in the South, Grady is part of a generation who saw their best chances burned away by the last fiery breaths of segregation. It is difficult for young people of either race today to understand the openness and simplicity of the injustice that was done to this dwindling generation. When you stripped away the Constitutional falderal from Wallace's message, it was this: He was telling Grady's mother, a working parent who paid property, sales and income taxes in Alabama for more than 40 years, that her child could not attend the institutions supported by those taxes.
Even to those of us who lived there, it seems surreal that such a systematic denial of opportunity could have existed for so long. I have encountered the same disbelief in the grown-up children of white sharecroppers when they looked at pictures of the plantations on which they and their families had lived in economic bondage.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (92%); 

STATE: ALABAMA, USA (92%); 

CITY: BIRMINGHAM, AL, USA (92%); 

GEOGRAPHIC: BIRMINGHAM (ALA); UNITED STATES (92%); ALABAMA, USA (92%); BIRMINGHAM, AL, USA (92%);

HEADLINE: Race and Rights: Feb. 11, 1968;
Memoirs of a 'Cold Warrior'

BYLINE: By Irving Kristol 

 BODY:
I find it more than a little odd that I -- and others like me -- should be denounced as an "obsessive" anti-Communist and an "incorrigible cold warrior." But, then, I must admit that I find many things odd about the new radicalism in American intellectual and literary circles. I am confused by middle-aged radicals who insist, in one and the same breath, that the present distribution of income is horribly inequitable and that you can't live decently in New York on less than $50,000 a year. I am bewildered by a highbrow left-wing magazine which proudly advertises that it is "cliquish" and "snobbish." I don't comprehend the merger that seems to have taken place between the literary left and cafe society, or the calm assumption that writers are and ought to be "celebrities." 
 There is still a sense, I suppose, in which I can fairly be called a "cold warrior." What I mean is: I believe in individual liberty and representative democracy; I prefer a modified form of capitalism to any other proposed economic system; I am certain Castro is no good model for Latin-American progress; I consider Maoism as detestable as Fascism and not easily distinguishable from it; I do not see that the underdeveloped countries of "the third world" represent any kind of wave of the future, and Che Guevara is not my idea of Robin Hood. But this is a new and different kind of cold war, in another time, for the most part in other places, and involving different ideologies. Looking back on the cold war of the 1950's against Stalinism, I can at moments feel positively nostalgic for the relatively forthright way it posed unambiguous moral issues. No amount of "revisionist" rewriting will affect my view of these moral properties. It was, by every canon I recognize, a just war, and I am pleased to have had a small part in it.

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Disabled Access To Inns at Issue

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE 

 BODY:
DAYS INNS OF AMERICA and the Justice Department are going to court over the Americans With Disabilities Act, signed by President Bush almost six years ago.
The law bars discrimination in many areas -- employment, access to telephones and other communications equipment, rail travel, bus travel, public attractions and public accommodation. Accommodation is the issue in this fight: the Justice Department says that the Days Inn company is not requiring motels bearing its name to meet requirements on safety and access. The corporation says it only franchises Days Inns and thus is not responsible, although it supports fully the letter and spirit of the law. 
 The law said that existing hotels were to eliminate barriers by Jan. 26, 1992 "if readily achievable." Hotels making alterations were required to see that altered areas met the rules on access and safety for the disabled: wheelchair users, the blind, the deaf or other people with an impairment that affects a major life activity. The most recent phase of enforcement covers hotels opened since Jan. 26, 1993. The Days Inn case is the first suit by the Government affecting new construction. The law requires, among other things, that public areas and a specific number of rooms -- depending on the size of the hotel -- be accessible by wheelchair, that a hotel have alarms, telephones and safety devices that are useful to the deaf or the blind, bathroom fixtures that can be used by people who are unable to stand unassisted, and clothes rods and curtain-closing devices that can be reached from a sitting position.
Five new Days Inns -- in Willows, Calif.; Champaign, Ill.; Evansville, Ind.; Hazard, Ky.; and Wall, S.D. -- were identified in the five Government suits filed on Feb. 8. The suits also name the motels' individual architects and general contractors as well as Days Inns of America Inc. and its parent company, HFS Inc. (formerly Hospitality Franchise Systems), which also owns Howard Johnson International, Ramada Franchise Systems, Park Inns International, Super 8 Motels and Villager Franchise Systems, on the ground that they participated in the design and construction of the five motels. The motels must respond to the case this month.
The Government brought the suit, according to John L. Wodatch, chief of the disability-rights section of the Justice Department, after investigating 28 new Days Inns in 17 states over 18 months and finding that all failed to comply with the law. Twenty-three of the motels are negotiating with the department for a resolution; the five others are those named in the suits, and some of them are still negotiating.
HFS denies that it is involved, pointing out that the wording of the law refers to "owners, operators, lessors and lessees" and not franchisers. On Feb. 1, a week before the Justice Department went into Federal court in the five states, the company filed an opposing suit in Federal court in a Texas circuit asking for a ruling that HFS had no responsibility for individual Days Inns' compliance with the law. Jeanne Murphy, vice president and corporation counsel for HFS, said that the company selected the Texas court partly because a previous suit brought there against a franchiser under the disabilities act was dismissed. The Supreme Court would not hear an appeal.
Ms. Murphy said that her company licenses the Days Inn brand name and provides reservation, marketing and other services to franchise holders for a fee. It does not own, operate, lease, manage, design or construct any Days Inn properties. The company's franchise agreement requires that individual motels obey all state and local laws as well as all Federal laws.
When a motel violates a rule in a jurisdiction, she continued, HFS notifies the owners that they are in default under the franchise and that some remedy is required. This would be the case, she said, if a court found any of the five motels in violation of the disabilities act. But officers of the company do not go uninvited to the individual properties, nor do they speak for the owners.
 
 
 
Clients Complained

Mr. Wodatch, describing how the five cases ended up in court, said that the department began its investigation of Days Inns in June 1994 because of a few dozen travelers' complaints, which he said outnumbered the complaints about other chains. Days Inn is the biggest economy chain in the country, with more than 155,000 rooms in 1,700 motels in 49 states.
Mr. Wodatch said that the department was suing HFS on the general grounds that it is an act of discrimination to fail to design and construct places that do not accommodate everyone.
"New construction is the easiest part," he said. "We want them to take a look when they build and then they won't have to worry." A bathroom doorway to accommodate a wheelchair, for example, would need a clear width of 32 inches. This is a no-cost item in the design stage, he said, but widening a doorway in cinderblock construction is another matter.
The department cited all five Days Inns as failing to provide a full range of options, among other problems. "Many travelers with disabilities travel with a companion or caretaker, and need to have two beds," the department said in each case. "While the hotel has guest rooms with two beds, all of the guest rooms designated for use by individuals with disabilities have only one bed."
 
 
 
Between Heavyweights

Four of the five motels charged gave minimal or no response to questions from The Times. The Days Inn in Wall, S.D., is owned by Richard and Karla Hauk, who referred questions to their lawyer, Kim Ruckdaschel-Haley of Lindquist & Vennum in Minneapolis. She described the case as one in which "small businesspeople are casualties of a battle between two heavyweights, the Justice Department and Days Inn."
"The Hauks constructed their hotel in accordance with Days Inn standards," she continued, "had their building plans reviewed and approved by Days Inn prior to construction, and obtained Days Inn approval before opening." She reported that Mr. Hauk said: "We believe in making buildings accessible to the disabled and we thought that we had done just that. Our expectations were that Days Inn, when it set forth standards for the building we could construct and approved of our building, was watching out for whether our hotel was in compliance with Federal laws."
The Hauks were trying to work out modifications with the Justice Department that may cost well into six figures, the lawyer said.
Mr. Hauk said, again through his lawyer: "We feel betrayed and abandoned by both Days Inn, which so far has washed its hands of the matter, and the Justice Department, which seems to be using us to prove a point."
Days Inn will be giving preliminary answers in the courts this month. People with disabilities who wish to make complaints about accommodations may send them to the Department of Justice, Disability Rights Section, Room 7129, 10th and Constitution Avenue, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20530.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Dollar Outlook Brighter After Last Year's Slide

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

 BODY:
WITH the possible exception of the weather, no single variable in planning for international travel is more subject to uncertainty than the value of the dollar. Just consider last year. The dollar was hitting new lows against its Japanese, German and French counterparts in the spring, and it seemed unclear when the slide would end.
Then, in the middle of the summer, the dollar started surging in value, in part because the economic outlook for the United States brightened relative to other big countries. A hotel room in Paris that would have cost $200 a night on July 28, when the dollar bought 4.8 francs, would have cost $188 a night six weeks later, when the exchange rate was 5.1 francs. The difference might not seem like much, but over a seven-night stay, it adds up to $84, hardly pocket change even in a city as expensive as Paris. 
 Of course, movements in the dollar are not always directly translated into changes in travel costs. Currency values are only one of myriad factors that affect air fares, if they affect them at all. Package tours often hold their advertised prices steady even when the dollar is bouncing up or down.
But a strong trend in one direction or another unquestionably filters through to travelers in big ways and small -- and over the past several years the dollar has gyrated substantially against many major currencies.
In the last decade the dollar has lost considerable value almost everywhere. After its tumble early last year, though, it has been strengthening, as the American economy has remained stable. According to the Thomas Cook Group, the world's largest owner of foreign exchange outlets, the dollar had increased 5 percent on average against the major European countries in the 12 months to the end of March. Among the biggest changes was the rebound of the dollar against the Japanese yen. The dollar was worth 83 yen last April; at the end of March it was at 106, a gain of 27 percent. During the same period, the dollar rose in value from 6.79 Mexican pesos to 7.55, a gain of 11 percent.
The question now is what to expect for the rest of this year.
It is a tricky question, given that currency values are subject to a host of economic, political and financial market factors that are hard to anticipate. But, like many analysts, Jim Dibe, the vice president for currency trading at Thomas Cook, said the outlook for the dollar is generally good.
"Overall, the scenario is very supportive of the dollar," he said. "There is low inflation, a fairly good economic outlook and politically not as much uncertainty as a while ago. Therefore most people expect the dollar to continue to gain strength, but not a lot of strength."
Mr. Dibe said his company has projected that over the next year the dollar's value should rise from 5.05 French francs to 5.35; from 1.48 German marks to 1.55, and from 106 Japanese yen to 112. The projections, he said, also call for the American currency to gain against the Mexican, British and Italian.
Mr. Dibe asserted that travelers should not make too much of currency fluctuations. Not only are they unpredictable, but they also rarely if ever make an inexpensive country an expensive one, or vice versa.
"If the value of the dollar goes up 20 percent, Japan and Switzerland are still real expensive," he said. "If an American goes to Mexico, it's a good value, irrespective of what the dollar does."
Moreover, he said, the economies of many countries are "dollarized," especially in the former Soviet bloc and to some extent in Latin America and Israel. That means many prices, especially for tourists, are set officially or unofficially in dollars and do not necessarily move with exchange rates.
"For American travelers going to those countries, the value of the dollar doesn't mean anything," he said.

HEADLINE: FRUGAL TRAVELER;
Deco and Deals In Miami's South Beach

BYLINE: By SUSAN SPANO 

 BODY:
RECENTLY I started reading mystery novels set in and around Miami by such writers as Elmore Leonard, Carl Hiaasen and Edna Buchanan -- page-turners full of fecund moons and firearms, Palm Beach palaces and shabby hotels, sad-sack victims and charismatic thugs. I found myself yearning to visit. So in February, I bought a round-trip ticket to Miami on Tower Airlines for $168 and flew south.
It was Elmore Leonard who led me to showy, balmy South Beach, which sits across Biscayne Bay from downtown Miami. In "Stick," Ernest Stickley Jr., a k a Stick, fresh out of prison, rents a room at the Bon-Aire Hotel in South Beach for the admirable rate of $33 a night. I couldn't find a listing for the Bon-Aire in the 1996 Miami Visitors Guide (which I ordered from the Greater Miami Convention and Visitors Bureau), so I booked rooms in three other South Beach hotels: the Dorchester on Collins Avenue at $75 for one night, the Surfcomber, also on Collins, for two nights at $75 each and the Park Washington on Washington Avenue for one night at $69. Stick feels curtailed by his lack of wheels, so I reserved an economy Dodge Neon at the airport office of Dollar Rent-a-Car for $22 a day. 
 Picking up the car and finding my way onto the elevated freeways was no problem at all, because Miami has posted sunburst signs that help visitors find tourist areas like the beaches and Coconut Grove and avoid dangerous neighborhoods near downtown. On the way to South Beach, I made a stop downtown at the Greater Miami Convention and Visitors Bureau on Brickell Avenue, swept across Biscayne Bay on the MacArthur Causeway, passing cruise ships lined up at the Port of Miami, and then stopped again at the Miami Beach Chamber of Commerce on Meridian Avenue.
Both detours proved beneficial, since they allowed me to collect a "Florida Traveler Lodging Guide," containing a coupon that trimmed the cost of my room at the Surfcomber to $49. I also picked up the "Miami Perfectly Seasoned Savings Booklet," providing two-for-one entrances to a number of Miami tourist sights, like Vizcaya Museum and Gardens and the Bass Museum of Art in South Beach; traveling alone, all I had to do to get the discounts was team up with the person behind me in line at ticket offices.
On Collins Avenue, South Beach's main thoroughfare, the first thing I saw was a Rollerblader in a tiny gold lame bikini; when I leaned out the window to take her picture, she posed -- apparently a basic instinct in the town that has become a backdrop for fashion, movie and television shoots, a showplace for trendy interior design, drag shows, nightclubs and one of Miami's prime attractions (not even counting the big, sandy beach). In fact, the assertively hip community has taken to calling itself SoBe, but this is just the most recent incarnation of a place that has seen it all, and shows it.
Before about 1900 South Beach was a mangrove swamp with alligators as its primary residents, along with a few settlers, who eventually learned that tourists were a better cash crop than coconuts. The first causeway over the bay was completed in 1913, just as hotels started to rise (though never too high). The first architectural wave was in the Mediterranean Revival style of the day, with arches, twisted columns and tile roofs, and the second, after the great hurricane of 1926, was in the International Style, or Art Deco, as we now call it. So frenzied was the pace of construction that by 1936 two new hotels were opening every week, sporting bright color schemes, ribbons of neon lights, eyebrowed windows, ziggurat-crested facades and the occasional porthole. The place was a veritable Busby Berkeley set, but by about 1960 the action in Miami Beach had moved north, leaving low-income South Beach retirees to play pinochle in the shade while the neighborhood devolved into a crime-ridden slum.
Parts of the neighborhood are still seedy; many Art Deco landmarks are boarded up, homeless people sleep on the beach, and in the early morning drunks stumble out of all-night bars on Collins and Washington Avenues. But in the last 20 years or so, many more of the 800 Art Deco buildings in South Beach's one-square-mile historic district have received such lavish and inventive renovations that I suspect they look better than new. By the time the sun strikes their pink, green, yellow and sea-blue facades, pretty people with matching mastiffs come out, followed by tourists speaking Spanish, German and French, drawn not only by the style and sunshine but also by the neighborhood's edginess. The predilection of European and South American tourists for South Beach has influenced the area in subtle and surprising ways -- there are no washcloths in some hotel bathrooms, restaurants often include a service charge on the bill, and topless sunbathing is accepted on the beach.
I stood in line to check into the 94-room Dorchester Hotel behind a French family with two very excited teen-agers. The L-shaped building from 1939 had a well-kept swimming pool, and my third-floor room was comfortably large, with a double bed, rattan chair, television and 30's-style tiled bath. Dingy carpets and an old, ill-equipped kitchenette suggested bygone down-at-the-heel days. Still, the moderately priced Dorchester was in much better condition than some of the budget hotels I checked along Collins Avenue -- Bon-Aire sorts of places with carefully painted Art Deco fronts yielding to threadbare lobbies and depressing $45 rooms where I could imagine Stick playing solitaire.
Happily, the Surfcomber, across the street and a half-block away from the Dorchester, with a seahorse on the white, pink and turquoise facade, was a big step up from these. It is on the beach side of Collins Avenue (and near a good Cuban restaurant called El Viajante, serving a full breakfast and jolting cafe con leche for about $4), its pool lined with cabanas. In the busy lobby I sometimes passed German tour groups getting a lecture from their guide. My third-floor room suited me fine, with two double beds, a sliver of an ocean view and generic motel-style furnishings. But, of course, it was the price I liked the most.
Traveling frugally has turned me into something of an accommodations maven, which is why I would have been perfectly content to do nothing besides cruise hotels in South Beach. They come in every stripe, from the eye-popping Delano (winter rates $200 to $600, $8 for a Kettel One vodka martini at the bar), with a lobby and porte-cochere draped in diaphanous white curtains two stories high, to the Streamline Moderne Marlin (rates $200 to $325), the interior decorated in a style called "island funk," to the pleasant little Brigham Gardens Guesthouse (winter rates $75 to $105), which makes a cameo appearance behind Michelle Pfeiffer in the movie "Up Close and Personal."
Luckily, on my last night in South Beach I got to stay in a hotel with at least a modest sense of style: the Park Washington, in a blocklong enclave of Art Deco hotels run by the same company, all with secretive gardens and a small pool in front, each surrounded by a scalloped concrete wall. The white Park Washington is trimmed in neon green and red, with bird-of-paradise flowers in the cool lime lobby, and two floors of small rooms that make a virtue of 40's-style assembly-line bedroom sets. My room had a double bed, television, refrigerator, canary yellow walls and another pleasing tiled bath.
The hotel is across the street from the chrome-sided 11th Street Diner, where I had an excellent cheeseburger and iced hazelnut decaf for about $8, and the Washington Storage building, erected in 1927 as an off-season repository for rich snowbirds' furs and jewels. Last fall it reopened as a museum devoted to the decorative arts called the Wolfsonian Foundation (admission $7, including an audio tour). There I took in an exhibition featuring modern objets d'art including an elaborate Queen Victoria Diamond Jubilee casket made at the Della Robbia Pottery studio in England during the heyday of the Arts and Crafts Movement and a streamlined Hobart meat slicer (model 410, from 1941) that looks more like sculpture than home appliance.
SUCH lustrous objects have clearly inspired contemporary Florida designers and artists, whose works can be admired (but not easily afforded) in shops like South Beach Style, galleries like the South Florida Art Center and chic restaurants like Yuca that line Lincoln Road, once the Fifth Avenue of Miami Beach. On a sunny afternoon I strolled Lincoln Road, at the north side of the neighborhood, stopping for a take-away lunch of tabouli, grilled vegetable and tomato-and-mozzarella salads (for about $7) at Lyon Freres et Compagnie, before moving on see an exhibit of costumes from Fellini films at the nearby Bass Museum of Art (admission $7). Giulietta Masina's plain gray cape from "La Strada," Marcello Mastroianni's tuxedo from "Ginger and Fred," and the black silk minidress Anita Ekberg wore in "La Dolce Vita" were all there. But when dusk falls on Ocean Drive along the beach, the stylish restaurants openand the preprandial parade begins, museum exhibits pale; South Beach is a Fellini film come to life.
A trendy Ocean Drive restaurant enticed me for dinner one night, but I had more satisfying and economical meals at a colorful Haitian place called Tap Tap on Fifth Street (shrimp in coconut sauce with rice and beans for $12) and at the restaurant on the ground floor of the Impala Hotel on Collins Avenue. Sitting on the front porch there, I ordered a glass of pinot grigio, garlicky sauteed spinach, and eggplant parmesan (for about $25), watching searchlights circle in the night sky.
During the day, sunshine and temperatures in the high 80's never failed, so of course I went to the beach, walking the mobbed sandy strip between Fifth and 15th Streets, running on the boardwalk that stretches into the slower-paced high-rise district north of 21st and eventually putting down a towel far from the crowd at the North Shore Open Space Park between 79th and 87th Streets in northern Miami Beach.
A tour on a bike obtained from South Beach Skate and Bike Rental in Lummus Park, with a lunch stop at Joe's Take Away and Coffee Bar near the channel that separates Miami Beach from Fisher Island (where huge, delicious fried soft-shell crab sandwiches cost $6.25), further deepened my tan -- as did a two-hour round-trip ride (for $12) from the western end of Lincoln Road on one of the water taxis that scoot around the islets in Biscayne Bay.
At Villa Vizcaya just south of downtown (admission is $10), I watched a film crew shoot a commercial featuring a Cadillac parked at the bayfront entrance of the lavishly decorated, 34-room Italian Renaissance-style mansion built in 1916. Later I drove 40 miles southwest of Miami to walk the half-mile long Anhinga Trail in Everglades National Park. There I saw alligators, snakes and great blue herons, striking, exotic creatures all -- but no more so than some I'd seen in South Beach.
 
The bottom line in South Beach
I spent an average of $107 a day while in the Miami area, with $61 going to accommodations.
I flew to Miami in February for $168 round trip on Tower Air, (718) 553-8500 or, outside New York, (800) 348-6937; the ticket was valid for one year from the date of departure and changes were allowed with no penalty (though if fares go up you may be charged the difference).
My economy-class Dodge Neon from Dollar Rent-a-Car, (800) 327-7607, cost $23.39 a day (though a 5 percent American Automobile Association discount brought that down to $22.22). You might not want to rent a car if you stay in South Beach, where parking is a problem (meters charge 25 cents for 30 minutes).
Super Shuttle vans, (305) 871-2000, take visitors between Miami International Airport and South Beach hotels for about $10 a ride.
The water taxi, (305) 467-6677, makes 15 stops in downtown Miami, one on Fisher Island and two on Miami Beach (for stops outside downtown, reservations are required); one-way fare starting from Miami Beach is $7, round trip $12, and an all-day pass $15.

It has 30 rooms for $69 to $89 in the winter (Nov. 15 to April 30), and $39 to $69 in the off-season; rates include morning coffee and sweet rolls served in the lobby. Next door is a metered parking lot; two blocks away is a municipal lot with parking for $6 a day.

HEADLINE: In Hiring Aliens, Companies Face Hurdles

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
WHEN Colin Service Systems in White Plains was recently fined $1.5 million, the largest amount ever imposed by the Immigration and Naturalization Service for hiring illegal aliens, the whole subject of immigration, legal and illegal, hit close to home.
Founded in Westchester in 1913, Colin employs 4,000 workers who supply cleaning services to many large companies in Westchester and to hundreds of other businesses in eight states. Colin denied that it knowingly employed illegal aliens. H. Lawrence Colin, president and chief executive officer, said that most of the violations were the result of unintentional mistakes in completing complex paperwork. 
 Difficulties in complying with requirements of the immigration system extend to all businesses large and small.
Westchester companies, especially those with international business, that rely on hiring highly skilled legal immigrants, are also struggling with the arcane and ponderous regulations that pertain to obtaining visas for foreign employees, said Joseph DeGiuseppe Jr., a partner in the White Plains law firm of Bleakley Platt & Schmidt. "Few topics stir as much emotion and controversy as restricting immigration," Mr. DeGiuseppe said, "but bowing down to pressure from special interest groups, Congress is unable to come to terms with the issue."
Adding that legal immigration is crucial to the economy of the United States, Mr. DeGiuseppe said, "specially for those engaged in international business, the need for legal immigration has increased, not decreased."
In his practice, Mr. DeGiuseppe focuses on immigration, labor and employment law. His work with businesses requires him to deal with the complex rules and regulations surrounding the entry of legal immigrant workers to the United States.
"Multinational companies often have to transfer foreign executives to the U.S. on very short notice for various reasons," Mr. DeGiuseppe said. "When a U.S. appliance manufacturer, for instance, a company then known as Hamilton Beach bought Glen Dimplex, a British manufacturer of small appliances, Hamilton Beach wanted to integrate the key executives from the British company in a corporate transfer from England to the U.S."
But first, Mr. DeGiuseppe said, the executives needed working visas, which fall into two categories. "The L-1 is for executives and managers, and the H-1-B is for professionals such as scientists and engineers," he explained, saying that quotas and regulations for legal immigrants coming into the United States are among the most restrictive in the world. "One rule requires that the applicant has to have at least one year of prior experience with the foreign company in the same job before a visa is granted."
Under the current system, international businesses are hampered by their inability to move executives around as needed.
"Just recently, an international transportation company with operations in Westchester bought a British shipping company and wanted to bring a systems analyst, a key executive who helped design the program and was familiar with it, to the U.S. to help the American company integrate the British system with theirs," Mr. DeGiuseppe said. They needed him on board immediately after they bought the company."
Mr. DeGiuseppe said that it was not to be. Why? Because the key British executive did not fit in either the L-1 or the H-1-B category. "Immigration laws today impose so many artificial restrictions that that particular executive could get only a temporary visa, which meant he had to commute between Westchester and London every 60 or 90 days," Mr. DeGiuseppe said.
Unless Congress comes to terms with immigration reform, it will continue to hinder the ability of American businesses to compete globally, Mr. DeGiuseppe argued.
"What will happen, it will become virtually impossible to run an international business from the United States," he said. "The net result? Companies may be forced to move their headquarters out of the country with a loss of jobs and business, which I don't think anybody wants."
As for the argument that American jobs are saved by restricting immigration, Mr. DeGiuseppe disagrees. "The reality is that when highly skilled technical workers are needed we don't have them because we are not training enough of our own. High-technology companies need a skilled work force if they are to survive and prosper, and they are not finding it domestically."
Other countries, like Britain, Canada, Australia and India, and the British colony Hong Kong are producing the best trained high-tech people in the world, Mr. DeGiuseppe said. "Frankly, without the ability to get these workers from abroad, many U.S. companies would be forced to move to other countries," he said. That is the untold story of immigration, Mr. DeGiuseppe said.
"It is not simply a matter of protecting American workers from losing unskilled jobs to illegal aliens that should obsess us," he said. "Rather it's a case of giving U.S. companies who need high-tech employees an immigration policy that is flexible enough for them to continue to do business at home."
Citing the experience of another one of his clients, a high-technology company, Mr. DeGiuseppe said: "They needed computer analysts on staff so they took all the steps companies normally take to find employees. They placed ads in newspapers and journals. They contacted employment agencies. They spent months on it, but in the end they did not get one application from an American citizen."
Yet, immigration is still viewed by most Americans in emotional terms. "They see hordes of illegal aliens cross the Mexican border in the dead of night to steal factory jobs from Americans," Mr. DeGiuseppe said. "And the truth is that the issue of illegal immigration impacts on every corporation and business in the U.S. Every employer has to verify the legality of every employee he hires, which means businesses have the unfair burden of documenting employment eligibility without being able to verify the authenticity of the employee's I.D."
One small, family-owned business in White Plains thought it was doing everything right, Mr. DeGiuseppe said, but a mistake on the forms, cost the business $7,000 in fines, and some of their employees were arrested.
The problem is compounded by the fact that documents are frequently forged or counterfeited.
"What we really need is an employee-verification system that works," Mr. DeGiuseppe said. "A three-year pilot program, a voluntary telephone procedure, is now under way in some states; New York is one of them."
Mr. Colin endorses the idea of a national computerized registry "to give employers a valuable new tool for compliance." He added: "Simplifying and streamlining the verification process would allow us to focus on what we do best: cleaning and maintaining buildings."
Explaining that the registry would incorporate information from the Social Security Administration and the Immigration and Naturalization Service, Mr. Colin said: "Then employers could check that the Social Security number provided by the applicant was valid and had been issued to someone authorized to work in this country.
"It's a simpler, more fraud-resistant system, one that would reduce the time, the resources and the paperwork that businesses are now spending time on complying with immigration laws. All an employer would have to do is ask workers one question, 'What is your Social Security number?' "

HEADLINE: Cold War Heroes

BYLINE: By Elaine Sciolino; Elaine Sciolino has covered foreign policy for The New York Times since 1987.

 BODY:

ON THE BRINK
The Dramatic, Behind-the-Scenes Saga of the Reagan Era and the Men and Women Who Won the Cold War.
By Jay Winik.
Illustrated. 672 pp. New York:
Simon & Schuster. $30.
With the cold war over and Ronald Reagan in the twilight of his life has come a neoconservative nostalgia that attempts to rejigger history to fit ideology. According to this view, the Berlin wall fell and the Soviet bloc collapsed because of one man, Mr. Reagan, and his single-minded battle against the Soviet "evil empire." His military buildup and ideological zeal, it is said, forced the Soviets to abandon their expansionism abroad and repression at home and pushed their economy to the breaking point. 
 The social, political and economic forces that caused the corrosion of the Communist system from within are conveniently ignored. So is the fact that the end of the cold war caught most so-called foreign policy experts -- particularly the zealous anti-Soviet conservatives -- by surprise. And so is Mikhail Gorbachev, the Soviet leader whose deep antipathy to nuclear weapons was matched only by Mr. Reagan's, and who accepted the inevitability of German reunification and the demise of the Soviet system.
Jay Winik, a senior scholar at the University of Maryland's School of Public Affairs and a true believer in what has come to be known as the Reagan victory school, has added an unconventional twist to the debate. In "On the Brink," he has focused on four Reagan lieutenants -- all of them renegade Democrats -- who he claims "won" the cold war: Jeane Kirkpatrick, the outspoken chief American representative at the United Nations; Richard Perle, an Assistant Secretary of Defense who fought against arms control agreements; Elliott Abrams, the Assistant Secretary of State for inter-American affairs who championed the cause of the anti-Communist rebels in Nicaragua; and Max Kampelman, the arms control specialist who led negotiations with the Soviets on nuclear and space arms. Secretary of State George P. Shultz, Secretary of Defense Caspar Weinberger, even Mr. Reagan himself play only bit parts, wandering in and out of the narrative with very little to do.
Everything that went before and after the Reagan Administration, Mr. Winik suggests, was accommodation and weakness. The Nixon, Ford and Carter Administrations took the United States to "the brink" of possible nuclear war; the Bush Administration shut out the "counterestablishment" that the four functionaries represented, and they had to sit on the sidelines and watch the forces of history that they had unleashed.
This book does not attempt to offer a coherent, chronological account of the final years of the cold war from a Reaganesque point of view. Rather, it is a chatty -- often disjointed -- collection of stories that attempt to lionize the four former officials as nothing less than great and passionate American heroes.
"They took over at a fearful time when the globe was mercilessly divided between East and West, frequently hovering at the brink, and Soviet power, not democracy, was on the rise," Mr. Winik writes. "In the end, they preserved the West from totalitarianism and aggression and quite literally ushered in a new world, restoring the possibility of freedom and dignity throughout the globe."
"On the Brink" serves, for example, as an apologia for Mr. Abrams. He is described as having been a "na<arrow up>ve and foolish" victim -- certainly not a liar -- when he misled Congress by denying any operational Government involvement in the illegal supplying of the contras and any foreign governmental involvement in providing money to them. The reader is told that he pleaded guilty to two misdemeanor counts of withholding information from Congress not because he was guilty but because the strain was too much for him, his wife, Rachel, and their children. "The legal fees would certainly bankrupt him," Mr. Winik writes. "For his own sanity, and for the health of his family, he had to put an end to it all. In one emotionally charged October day, he and Rachel decided that they had cried and fought too long. Enough, he thought."
The reader also learns a lot about the cooking and eating habits of Reagan Administration bureaucrats, particularly Mr. Perle. To wit, the opening of Chapter 27: "It was a moment Richard Perle savored, the vegetables and dinner ingredients spread out before him in a tantalizing array: crunchy watercress, squeaky leaves of radicchio, slightly chilled mche, a small but delicate goat cheese off to the side. From the sink rose the earthy smells of freshly rinsed lettuce, and all around him lay other intricate ingredients that would become engulfed in the clamor and fray of a busy kitchen, gearing up for a dinner that was only an hour away."
The British served "thick red ham, creamy mousses, cheeses and exotic French pts" at one annual meeting of NATO's nuclear planning group that Mr. Perle attended. "There was also an assortment of salad greens, a concession to the Americans, who seemed to like their vegetables raw."
The reader learns that Dr. Kirkpatrick drinks tea every morning; that Andrei Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister, ate "a hearty breakfast" and drank "a cup of thick black coffee" before meeting in the Crimean resort town of Yalta with George McGovern in 1984; that Mr. Abrams nursed the flu with tea and toast; that Mr. Perle brought "kosher salamis, cheese and crackers, canned pt, rich chocolate brownies" to the summit conference in Reykjavik, Iceland, in 1986; that Les Aspin, the Democratic Congressman from Wisconsin, "was munching reflexively on salted potato chips" while watching the results of the summit meeting on television. It's foreign policy as a picnic.
Kitchen metaphors even make their way into Mr. Winik's analysis. The Middle East, for example, is described as "a pot of water chronically on the verge of boil, always ready to spill over with seething steam."
The book will certainly be devoured by those who believe that the four functionaries have been unfairly criticized by Congress and the news media and deserve to be treated better by history. But readers who want the recipes will be disappointed.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review
