HEADLINE: One Pilot Program's Concerted Effort

BYLINE: By RICHARD WEIZEL 

 BODY:
ISRAEL CRUZ of Bridgeport said one of the saddest days of his life occurred last year when his now 17-year-old daughter Alisha left school before earning her high school diploma.
But Alisha, who dropped out after becoming a parent, is back in school. And so is her 41-year-old father, as a parent volunteer in a new three-city anti-truancy program at the James Curiale School that is being hailed as a model for the state and even the nation. 
 "It was completely devastating to me when my daughter stopped going to school because I grew up in one of the worst streets in the South Bronx, and the only thing that kept me out of trouble was going to school," said Mr. Cruz. "I had to get involved in this program because after convincing Alisha to go back I felt it was important to help other kids too."
After being implemented last year as a pilot program at the Longfellow School in Bridgeport, in the city's West End, the new program helped attendance rise to more than 94 percent from 88 percent, the best of all 38 schools in the state's second-largest city, school officials said.
"If we were able to make it work at Longfellow, believe me, they can make it work anywhere in the world," said the school's principal, Jetti Tisdale. She said 90 percent of her pupils come from homes whose single parents are now making a real effort to get their children to school every day.
"We had a day in which it snowed throughout the morning, which in the past would have meant a large absentee rate," said Ms. Tisdale. "But this time we had only 15 kids out of school. That means the program is working. These kids now want to go to school."
The program, which stresses strong parental and community involvement to reach out to chronic truants in kindergarten through fifth grade, will involve Bridgeport, Stamford and Norwalk over the next 18 months.
The Regency Truancy Prevention Project, supported by a $50,000 grant by the Fairfield County Community Foundation and administered by Action for Bridgeport Community Development, has been launched at a time when Gov. John G. Rowland has become increasing impatient with the state's dropout rates and its 10.4 percent truancy rate.
During his recent State of the State Address, Mr. Rowland proposed cutting off welfare benefits to parents who keep their children out of school.
But educators feel punitive measures can only go so far to cure a problem with a multitude of causes including:
* Single-parent households where parents are not aware their children are skipping school.
* Families that keep their children out of school to do errands and babysit for younger children while the parent works.
* A quick economic fix like drug dealing that students may see as the only way to escape poverty.
* Poor self-esteem; pupils avoiding school out of fear they cannot do the work.
School officials hope their new program will help turn things around by addressing these and other issues.
At the heart of the program are trained teams of school staff and volunteer parents who keep tabs on chronic truants and follow up with phone calls, home visits and positive reinforcement to get students to return to school.
Having other students cheer and congratulate those returning to the classroom, as well as encouraging parents and their children to attend extracurricular events like basketball games are all part of the positive reinforcement efforts.
"We'll do whatever it takes to get them back in school and keep them there," said Mr. Cruz, who does his volunteer work at the James Curiale Elementary School in Bridgeport, the city's second school to take part in the effort. "We'll call them every day, we'll talk to the students and their parents, and somehow get the message across how important it is to go to school every day."
That was the message Mr. Cruz successfully delivered recently to his own daughter.
"I just hope I can help other kids in the same situation not to make that mistake that my daughter almost made," said Mr. Cruz, whose 14-year-old son Carlos attends Curiale School and wants to run for class president.
Esther Williams-Montambo, the school's home-school coordinator, said there are many reasons why it is important to keep youngsters in school, including safety.
"A few years ago a little girl was murdered in Bridgeport during the time she was supposed to be in school," Ms. Williams-Montambo said. "We don't want to see that to ever happen again, and this program is one of the ways to prevent that."
Michael Hanna, principal of the Curiale School, said: "We're hoping for the same kinds of results that they had at Longfellow and I expect that will happen because of the heavy influence of committed parents participating here."
School officials, aiming to convince students that their best hope is to stay in school, are trying to get the message across that chronic truancy in the early grades can have a negative impact throughout life.
"Attendance problems are usually a very good predictor of academic problems later on and dropping out," said James A. Connelly, Superintendent of Schools in Bridgeport.
A 1992 study in Bridgeport by Dr. Catherine Oleksiw for Bridgeport Future Initiatives concluded that "habits formed in the early grades affected students in high school." "Unfortunately, many parents and students in urban schools are so caught up in issues surrounding day-to-day survival that they do not consider school attendance a top priority."
But Mr. Connelly says he is encouraged by the already-demonstrated success of the new program.
"This is the kind of program that has already shown very promising results in one of our previously poorly attended schools and there's no reason it can't work throughout the school system," he said. "It's a terrific model that works."
Truancy experts agree.
"This program has worked and will work as long as there is strong parental involvement -- that's really the key," said Matt George, director of student support service for the city of Bridgeport.
"What this program does so impressively is organize the parents and coordinate an active participation among parents, teachers and other educators," said Mr. George.
Charles Norman, acting president and chief executive officer of the Norwalk-based Fairfield County Community Foundation, which is supporting the program, with a nearly $50,000 grant, said the project is the most exciting anti-truancy effort he has ever seen. "A program that promotes close ties among young students, school personnel, parents and members of the community" to reduce unexcused absences, he said, is "very compelling."

HEADLINE: Keeping Children Off the Streets

BYLINE: By JULIE MILLER 

 BODY:
THE supervisor of the New Haven Police Department's juvenile services, Lieut. Douglas MacDonald, placed his hands on the shoulders of a 12-year-old boy standing in front of him. The boy, just under 4 feet tall and weighing about 50 pounds, fixed his eyes on the floor and said nothing. He had just been arrested for car theft, and this was not the first time.
"Believe it or not, his feet can reach the pedals," Lieutenant MacDonald said after turning the boy over to another police officer. "I asked him why he wasn't in school, and he said he had a doctor's appointment. He didn't go the day before because he overslept. His mother told me that if her son got into trouble, he was on his own. When a parent has that response, we can predict the kid won't show up in school. He'll develop a street life and meet up again and again with the criminal justice system." 
 But Lieutenant MacDonald hasn't given up on the boy. New Haven, like other cities in the state, is finding new ways of helping children who are dropping out of school and heading for a lifetime of crime. The police department and schools in New Haven are collaborating with community agencies on several projects aimed at getting truant students off the streets and back into school. They are concentrating their efforts for the first time on the elementary schools, where children begin the habit of skipping school.
"Working with very young children is the way to go. We have to create habits rather than retrain kids later on," said Steven Lindner, who conducts a dropout prevention program in the New Haven schools.
Although there are no statistics on the extent of truancy in the state, the problem is becoming urgent as daytime crime among juveniles increases, according to Mr. Lindner said. "To get kids off the street and get rid of daytime crime, we need to make sure they complete school," he said.
Fueling the concern about truancy is a shortage of job opportunities, given the bad economic climate in the state, said Reginald Mayo, the School Superintendent in New Haven. "I think it's obvious that if young people don't have an education, they will be lost," he said. "Factory jobs are not out there to absorb dropouts."
Under state law, a child must attend school until age 16. Truancy refers to a child between 7 and 16 who has 4 unexcused absences in a month or 10 in a school year. Habitual truancy occurs when a child has 20 or more unexcused absences in a school year. The law requires schools to investigate such cases, and if the child continues to miss school, the case must be referred to juvenile court. A juvenile probation officer meets with the child and his or her parents and investigates the case.
The probation officer may handle certain offenses informally, depending on the seriousness of the allegation, the child's history and the attitude of the parents. The probation officer may decide to dismiss the case, refer the child and family to a social service agency or ask the court to intervene.
In New Haven, a pilot anti-truancy program started last year was expanded this year to include all the city's schools. Teams made up of truancy officers and police detectives travel through New Haven's neighborhoods every day and round up students who should be in school. The teams picked up more than 500 children in kindergarten through 12th grade during the first two months of the current school year, Mr. Lindner said.
A truancy court recently established in the city handles the cases of students in fifth through eighth grade with 10 or more unexcused absences. The court is composed of students from the New Haven area and a lawyer from the corporation counsel's office. A high school student and a law student serve as the child's mentors. The child is required to attend a hearing, to which parents are invited, and the parents and mentors draw up a contract meant to insure that the child attends school. The mentors follow the student's progress in meeting the terms of the contract.
A mentor is the most important influence in a child's decision to stay in school, Mr. Lindner said. Several organizations in New Haven, including the police and fire departments, provide mentors. "We want to extend a student's family so that truancy is not just a court issue," Mr. Lindner said. "The majority of kids who drop out say there was no one who cared about them and no one to talk to."
Children have learned how to skip school by the time they reach fourth or fifth grade. "When I stayed home, I would replace the answering machine tape with a new one. I would take the phone off the hook, or I wouldn't answer it, because I didn't know if it was my Mom or the school. I was 12," said Verdell Grace, a ninth grader at Hillhouse High School in New Haven.
The boy, who is 16, said his school years have been marked by conflicts with classmates, difficulties with his studies and suspensions and that his anger toward his father, whom he hasn't seen since he was 6 years old, makes it hard for him to concentrate in class. "Every time I hear about him, I get upset," he said. "I hear what the teacher is saying, but my mind is somewhere else."
It was in fourth grade, Verdell said, that "My attitude started kicking in. I would go to school upset. Somebody would say something to me, and I would flip. I needed someone to talk to, someone who would look out for me and make sure I didn't get into trouble."
By the time he reached seventh grade, he started staying home. But his mother, who works as a nurse, insisted that he finish high school. She called a truant officer, Robert Turner, this year after she became concerned that her son was skipping school. Mr. Turner has helped smooth out the mother-son relationship and arranged a summer job for Mr. Grace as a caddy.
After high school Verdell would like to be a carpenter; in the meantime, he's looking for a job after school and on weekends. He also takes classes in martial arts and plays African drums in a group that performs at local festivals.
Although he was recently suspended for a week for fighting with a classmate, Verdell does plan to finish high school. "They say if you're 16, you don't have to go to school," he said. "But I have no choice; my mother keeps me going. I'm so used to going now, it's simple."
New Haven is encouraging children to stay in school in other ways. A middle school sports program started this year allows students to participate only if they attend school and receive an hour of tutoring daily. Third graders take part in classroom exercises that teach them to think twice before staying home from school. Children with perfect attendance are rewarded with free tickets to New Haven Ravens baseball games.
In the West End section of Bridgeport, a two-year truancy prevention project was started in 1993 at Longfellow School that includes pre-kindergarten through eighth grade. The project focused on children with 40 to 50 absences in the first four months of school, said Judith Watson, a social psychologist and consultant with Action for Bridgeport Community Development, the agency that funded the project.
A truancy team checked the school's absentee report every morning and visited the homes of youngsters who were habitually absent.
"We discovered that that kind of attention to the children and their families was effective in keeping those kids in school," Ms. Watson said. At the end of the project, Longfellow School had the best attendance rate in the city. The program is continuing this year with volunteers.
Tracking down truant children is not the only factor in keeping them in school. Longstanding habits and attitudes must be changed, said Jettie Tisdale, principal of Longfellow School. Ms. Tisdale added that parents create the biggest problem. "We have a breakfast program that can serve 300 kids. But I get less than 60," she said. "The parents won't get up in the morning and get their kids out to school."
A home-school coordinator, hired by the school, conducts classes for parents in child care, Ms. Tisdale said. "Some you'll save and some you won't," she said. "If one parent sees another getting the kids to school on time, she will do it, too. It's like building a house with a good foundation. These are habits you need when you have a job. You have to go to work on time, or you won't keep that job."

HEADLINE: Dentist-Anesthesiologists Are Pushing for Formal Recognition

BYLINE: By JOAN SWIRSKY 

 BODY:
IT was not front-line combat as a marine in the Vietnam War that undid Michael Arms. Nor the time he was mugged and stabbed in the Bronx.
Rather Mr. Arms, director of the North Shore Animal League in Port Washington, said: "Nothing is as traumatic for me as going to the dentist. I'm one of those phobic people who wouldn't even go for a checkup, because even the sound of the drill or a shot of novocain is enough to keep me away." 
 But a few years ago Mr. Arms learned from a friend that he could receive general anesthesia in a dentist's office. "Now," he said, "when I walk in I have no fear. And when I walk out, I'm in a good mood."
That does not surprise Dr. Ralph Epstein, a dentist-anesthesiologist in Great Neck. "There is a clear need for general anesthesia in dentists' offices," Dr. Epstein said. "But most people don't know it exists."
Dr. Epstein is one of 98 dentist-anesthesiologists -- Long Island has nine -- who have received board certification through the American Dental Board of Anesthesiology. He and his colleagues have studied the administration of general anesthesia in two- and three-year postdoctoral programs.
Their offices are equipped to intubate, or place protective airways in the windpipes, and to administer intravenous, inhalation and intramuscular anesthesia.
In contrast, oral surgeons receive four months of anesthesia training in a typical four-year program.
In 1993 the American Society of Dental Anesthesiologists asked its parent body, the American Dental Association, to recognize its speciality. The major impediment to approval has been an A.D.A directive that the anesthesiologists prove the "need and demand" for their services.
Dr. Epstein said that assertion was bogus and that there was a latent demand for the services that he and his colleagues offer. "People who acquired cell phones and fax machines over the last few years didn't demonstrate their need for better communication by picketing in the streets," he said. "They heard by word of mouth that something better was out there. It's the same with dental anesthesia. The need is there, but people don't know it exists. So how can they ask for it?
"A vast number of people are not getting the dental care they need, because they are terrified of the drill, of pain and of what they imagine will be the worst experience of their lives. I thought the A.D.A. would applaud this effort. Instead they told us it wasn't necessary."
At a meeting in Washington last month the anesthesiologists' group instituted a board of diplomates that, in effect, confers specialist status on its members.
The associate executive director for education for the American Association of Oral-Maxillofacial Surgeons, Randi V. Andresen, said all the criteria for specialist eligibility had not been fulfilled.
"There are nurse-anesthetists and medical anesthesiologists," Ms. Andresen said. "So there's no need for more people administering anesthesia. Unless dentists also do general dentistry, as well as anesthesia, the need for this service is simply not there. There's no way for itinerant anesthesiologists who travel to different dentist offices to know if these facilities have the ability to handle emergencies. The patient has the right to know this. This is a matter of safety."
Dr. Epstein said premiums for dental-liability insurance for dentist-anesthesiologists country had increased in the last 10 years.
The anesthesiologists want to advertise themselves as specialists. For several years the Federal Trade Commission has been reviewing their complaints about "the restriction of truthful, nondeceptive advertising," said Sally Maxwell, a senior lawyer in the competition bureau at the commission. "A similar complaint against the American Medical Association was adjudicated in the 70's," Ms. Maxwell said. That case had several appeals before the United States Supreme Court upheld the complaint. Since we're the health-care division of the F.T.C. we learn about these issues through professional journals and people who write and call us with grievances."
The commission has not set a date for a hearing.
In 1972 and 1988 the F.T.C. said that the A.D.A. rules that prohibit the self-designation of specialty status were "not reasonable" and issued an order to stop the "restricting, impeding or advising against the advertising of dental-care services."
The general counsel for the A.D.A., Peter M. Sfikas, said the ruling had dissenters. "We subscribe to the dissenting opinions," Mr. Sfikas said.
The A.D.A. recognizes eight specialist categories, oral and maxillofacial surgery, orthodontics, dentofacial orthodontics, oral pathology, endodontics, pediatric dentistry, prosthodontics and dental public health.
Dr. Epstein said the two-year hospital and university training programs were threatened. He added that the Health Care Financing Administration reimbursement policy required that a specialty in dentistry be accredited by the Commission on Dental Accreditation.
"But this is the very body that refuses to accredit us," he said. "It was clear to us during out lengthy appeal process that politics and economics were driving the A.D.A.'s judgment. Every one of the A.D.A.'s numerous committees approved of recognizing us. But ultimately intense competition from the 6,000-member organization that represents oral-maxillofacial surgeons prevailed."
Many specialists, including oral surgeons, seek friendly relationships with dentist-anesthesiologists, Dr. Epstein said, adding, "But this camaraderie has unfortunately been eclipsed by the kind of market forces that are increasingly defining how medicine is practiced."
"There is absolutely no competition involved," Ms. Andresen said. "There aren't that many dentist-anesthesiologists in the country to even raise that issue."
Two consumers, Danusia Pawska and her husband, Elliot Cohen, said the competition issue was alive. After having driven from their home in Old Greenwich, Conn., to Dr. Epstein's office for anesthesia for their son Anson, 6, who is learning disabled and asthmatic, Ms. Pawska said, "The patient should come first, not some group that is protesting a possible loss of income."
After her son had initially been evaluated in Connecticut, she recounted, she was told that he would have to enter a hospital for his dental work, at a cost of $2,500. "When I asked them if Anson could have the same procedure in an office, they told me no," Ms. Pawska said. She scheduled him for admission, "weeks in advance, which was the only time they had space for him," and he developed an abscess.
Ms. Pawska consulted a dentist in New York City who referred the case to Dr. Epstein and his wife, Dr. Mary George, a pediatric dentist. Anson's two-hour removal, under general anesthesia, proceeded uneventfully.
"I stayed with him in the recovery room and was there when he woke up," Ms. Pawska said. "It's a shame so few of these specialists exist and that people can't have their children's needs taken care of all in one office. It was worth the trip, and I'll always make it. Here I know that my son's special needs will be understood, and that's worth everything."
To some on Long Island the dispute has personal consequences, too. When Steven Frome took an autistic son, Joshua, to Dr. Epstein, he said, "it was the first time in my son's 17 years that he was able to tolerate dental care."
"The hospital environment was so unfamiliar and anxiety producing," Mr. Frome, executive vice president of the Parker Jewish Geriatric Institute in New Hyde Park, said, said, "that it would take five or six people to hold Joshua down just to start the IV. But the dentist office is familiar and friendly, and he doesn't mind going at all.
"I understand health care from the payers' perspective. In a dentist's office you are not paying the hospital's overhead fee."
Dentist-anesthesiologists say they can halve hospital "facility fees," or up to $2,000. Because insurance companies often do not cover dental work, that represents a sizable savings for patients who, Dr. Epstein said, might never seek care "until it's too late."
But Ms. Andresen said costs increased when dentist-anesthesiologists were present. "People have to pay two people to treat them," she said, "not only the dentist doing the work, but the one giving anesthesia."
Unlike most dentists, who routinely use local anesthesia dentist-anesthesiologists use a technique that for physicians requires a three-year residency, with the last year in a specialty like cardiac care.
Dentist-anesthesiologists are certified in advanced cardiac life support. Like hospitals, their offices are equipped with emergency equipment and recovery rooms. While traveling, they take along their emergency equipment and supplies.
"Too often," Dr. Epstein said of the autistic, the retarded and other people who have special problems, "these patients don't receive dental work until end-stage conditions exist. Years, even decades, go by, and small problems become unnecessarily large."

HEADLINE: Lilco Under Fire for Warnings on Rate Increases

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
OFFICIALS and private groups are attacking statements by Lilco that an immediate cut in electric rates could undermine its finances and force higher rates next year.
In arguments to the Public Service Commission this month, the Long Island Power Authority and Nassau and Suffolk Counties depicted Lilco and its shareholders as immensely enriched by the 1989 agreement that closed the Shoreham nuclear power plant. The critics said despite statements that it would cooperate in efforts to lower rates the Long Island Lighting Company continued to pursue policies to thwart cuts. 
 The authority and counties argue that the rate cutting that the P.S.C. is considering would have few or no adverse effects on Lilco finances. The steps include an immediate refund to customers of $81 million paid by Suffolk County for excess assessments of Shoreham.
The power authority called on the P.S.C. to reduce rates $154.9 million, or 6.5 percent. Of that 4.5 percent would be a one-time deal from the $81 million refund and $25.9 million from other sources. The remaining 2 percent would come from adjustments in how fuel savings are passed along to customers.
Describing Lilco as financially sound, the authority said the utility's higher-than-average debt, rather than signifying financial weakness, reflected a decision to pay high dividends instead of reducing debt.
In another indication of pressure to revise the 1989 agreement, the authority asked the commission to examine rate of return on the $4.4 billion that Lilco is allowed to recover for Shoreham.
"The P.S.C. should consider whether Lilco's rate of return should be allowed to continue when over two-thirds of its rate base consists of paper assets, which have no operational risk, maintenance costs or capital expenditures," said the acting executive director of the authority, Anastasia Song. The authority is negotiating separately with Lilco on a plan backed by Gov. George E. Pataki to disband the utility and cut electric rates by 12 percent. Under the plan the authority would sell tax-exempt bonds to buy the Lilco transmission and distribution systems. The generators and gas business would be sold to separate companies.
The 12 percent rate reduction, much of it from refinancing Lilco debt through bonds, would be in addition to the 6.5 reduction that the authority seeks. A ruling on the reductions is apparently weeks away.
The discussions result from a P.S.C. order in February that required Lilco to show why it should not immediately refund the $81 million payment and the $25.9 million in excess revenues and make other adjustments. In a response last month Lilco said that the money should be used to reduce a $380 million deferred debt that customers owe for Shoreham. The utility also warned that any sign that support for the 1989 agreement was weakening would alarm investors, harm Lilco financially and create a need for higher rates.
The agreement, between Lilco and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and endorsed by the P.S.C., promised the recovery of the Shoreham costs and included so-called rate moderation and other measures to ease or defer rate increases to pay for the plant.
Suffolk now says Lilco badgers the commission to reaffirm the 1989 pact on the company's terms. The county said Lilco had made numerous references to "the 1989 agreement's goal of returning Lilco's credit rating to investment grade," but made "no mention at all of Lilco's successful and deliberate efforts to keep itself teetering on the brink of junk-bond status, thereby holding its ratepayers and the commission hostage to its scheme of high prices for its ratepayers and generous dividends for its shareholders."
"For six years the commission has complied with the 1989 agreement, and Long Island has paid the price," the county said. "Lilco pursued a corporate strategy of aggressively paying out dividends when more responsible management would have paid down debt. Only by putting itself squarely in harm's way could Lilco hope to persuade the P.S.C. that without the P.S.C.'s unwavering support of Lilco's agenda it will perish."
The county hired a financial expert on the power industry, Charles M. Studness, who said, "The dominant feature of Lilco's financial position is its extremely strong cash flow." Mr. Studness noted that Lilco expected to generate $1.96 billion in cash from 1996 to 2000 after capital expenditures and paying dividends to holders of preferred shares. He said the utility intended to pay $1.09 billion of that "discretionary cash flow" to shareholders in dividends and to use $870 million to retire debt.
The high debt would be lower "if Lilco had pursued a conservative dividend policy," Mr. Studness said, adding that the utility borrowed $667 million from 1989 to 1993 to pay dividends.
"Lilco's strong cash flow and untapped opportunities to increase efficiency provide a basis for substantial reduction of Lilco's electric rates," the consultant said.
An economic model projected a "meaningful reduction in electric rates" of 5 percent would create 2,500 jobs, Mr. Studness said, and a "moderate reduction" of 10 percent would create 5,000 jobs. A 50 percent reducting, taking the Lilco rates down to the national average, would create 25,000 jobs, he estimated.
Lilco rates are the highest in the continental United States.
A reduction is "in the public interest and can be effectuated without Lilco suffering any financial or operational harm," Nassau said in its brief. "Lilco's pleadings to the contrary are nothing more than attempts to obfuscate the fact that Lilco continues to ignore the repeated cries for deserved rate relief for its customers in favor of maintaining a high level of profits and dividends for its investors."
Nassau said speedy payment of the debt was not warranted because the utility industry was experiencing increased competition. The restructuring of the industry is "on our doorstep," the county said, suggesting that another P.S.C. proceeding might result in lowering of the Shoreham recovery total.
"It is this uncertainty that the financial markets have and will continue to evaluate," the county said.
"A P.S.C. decision to provide much needed rate relief to Lilco's customers," the brief continued, "should not affect the financial markets."
In an attack on the 1989 pact the county said Lilco had "entered into what turned out to be a disastrously expensive and failed nuclear-plant investment" and then won an agreement with the Cuomo administration that charged customers for its errors and rewarded shareholders.
A consultant for Nassau, James D. Cotton of the Columbia Group Inc. in Ridgefield, Conn., said that the county had steadfastly demanded the $81 million tax refund be used to lower rates and that the P.S.C. could decide how to allocate the money.
What the commission decides may determine what it does with a potentially even larger tax refund Suffolk that faces in another case. Lilco is seeking up to $500 million for excess assessments of Shoreham in more recent years in a suit before Justice Thomas M. Stark of State Supreme Court in Riverhead.
Other groups joined in urging the P.S.C. to cut rates now. "The P.S.C. should take this opportunity to spark a revival of Long Island's economy by beginning to restore electricity prices to more reasonable levels," said Robert Ceisler, executive director of the Citizens Utility Board, a consumer group in Albany.
The Association for a Better Long Island asked to "end Lilco's practicing of using the decommissioned Shoreham atomic plant as a basis for charging customers for power." The builders' group said Mr. Pataki had "put into place a Public Service Commission board that is not a tool of the utilities."
"There now needs to be an alliance that can confront the legions of Lilco lawyers who seek to deny any opportunity at rate reduction," the president of the business group, Jan Berman, said.

HEADLINE: Whalers In Need of a Few (More) Good Fans

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH 

 BODY:
THE Mayor of Hartford, Michael P. Peters, says that if the Whalers decide to leave his city, "I'll be the guy lying down in front of the moving trucks."
Given the Whalers' endangered species status in the state's capital, Mr. Peters could get run over -- and soon, at that. For if a last-ditch campaign to keep the team in Hartford fails, the owner of the Whalers may very well decide next month to end the team's 21-year stay in Connecticut. 
 That would would not only cost the state its only major league sports team but also deprive the Hartford Civic Center of its primary tenant -- a devastating thought for the restaurants, bars and other small businesses in the immediate environs that count on games to generate business.
Unless the Whalers can sell close to 11,000 season tickets and lease most of 45 sky boxes in the Civic Center by May 1, yesterday afternoon's game against the Boston Bruins may have been the Whalers' last in Hartford. And tonight's final season game against the Buffalo Sabres in Buffalo could be Hartford's swan song in the National Hockey League.
Peter Karamanos, a Detroit businessman who owns the Whalers, concedes that those goals will be extremely difficult to achieve, considering that only 5,800 season tickets were sold this season and only 27 sky boxes leased, at season prices of $62,000 to $72,000.
Making it even more difficult, perhaps, was the team's decision to raise ticket prices for next season, if there is a next season in Hartford, by an average of about $6 a game on the day that the ticket drive began, April 1.
"If the ticket drive falls on its face, we could leave," said Mr. Karamanos. "You can't say you want a major league team and average 10,000 fans a game."
Mr. Karamanos would probably have no trouble relocating. Cleveland, San Antonio, Nashville and Portland, Ore., are among the big-market cities that have been trying to lure an N.H.L. team.
Under a 1994 agreement with the Connecticut Development Authority, a quasi-public body, Mr. Karamanos is free to take the Whalers elsewhere following the 1997-98 season if the team has lost $30 million by then.
But Mr. Karamanos, who has owned the Whalers for only two seasons, says that he has already lost $31 million on the team.
"I think that in light of our losses that the state would give us permission to leave," Mr. Karamanos said. "When you've lost as much money as we have, you have to look around and ask what we're doing here."
A lot of people have been wondering about that ever since the Whalers, then in the old World Hockey Association, moved from Boston to Hartford during the 1974-75 season, lured in large measure by the brand new Hartford Civic Center.
For one thing, Hartford, unlike New Haven (which has had minor league hockey teams on and off since 1936), had no hockey tradition. For another, the team has never been a success, either on the ice or at the box office. It has had only three winning seasons and scored its box-office high, of just 14,574 fans per game, in 1987-88.
Indeed, most of the state's hockey fans back either the New York Rangers or the Boston Bruins, depending on where they live. Even those involved in the campaign to Save the Whale(rs) concede that at least 90 percent of Whaler fans live in Hartford County or very near.
"And the team can't survive as just a Hartford team," said Lou Beer, the team's consultant for business affairs, who, like Mr. Karamanos lives in the Detroit area but of late has been spending most of his time in Hartford. "But developing an affinity between the Whalers and the rest of the state is a four- to five-year process, and we don't have that much time. So we have to jumpstart the process."
In an effort to do so, Gov. John G. Rowland and Lieut. Gov. M. Jodi Rell invited corporate leaders in the state to a meeting on April 2. About 50 people attended, but only one large corporation from the southern part of the state, U.S. Surgical (based in Norwalk), sent a representative.
Last Friday, the Capitol Regional Council of Governments invited town officials and civic leaders from 29 Hartford area municipalities to discuss ways to insure that the Whalers remain in Hartford.
With the slogan "The Puck Stops Here," a Kansas City marketing firm is coordinating the ticket-selling drive, trying to get Connecticut corporations into a "marketing partnership" with the Whalers, said Mitch Wheeler, president of the firm, Marketing Associates International Inc. Losing the Whalers would relegate Hartford and Connecticut to "minor league status," he said, as well as hurting economic and community growth.
The Hartford Courant, which has been conducting a "Whale Watch" on game attendance, has gone even further, saying editorially that "the loss of the team would unquestionably be devastating to the region's economy and self-esteem."
William H. Russell, a chairman (with Michael E. Waller, the publisher of The Courant) of a task force set up by the Hartford Downtown Council, says "The Whalers are critical to the city's renaissance."
And Tony Caruso, the executive director of the Downtown Council, said it was estimated that the Whalers have been responsible for generating about $100 million annually in business for the Hartford area.
"The team is also one of the best recruiting tools we have for the city, particularly for young executives companies are trying to lure here," Mr. Caruso said.
But some people have questioned whether it has been in the state's interest to invest millions of dollars in a team that attracts scant statewide support. And some recent studies have indicated that economic benefits from a major league sports team are marginal at best, despite supporters' arguments.
The idea that a major league team enhances a city's morale has caused some black civic leaders in Hartford to point out that in a city dominated by blacks and Hispanics it is rare to see a nonwhite face at a Whalers' game. Further, it is pointed out, hockey is rarely played by black or Hispanic youngsters.
Both Mr. Karamanos and James Rutherford, a former N.H.L. goalkeeper who is the team's president and general manager, praised the administrations of Gov. Lowell P. Weicker and of Governor Rowland for trying to insure that the Whalers remain in Connecticut.
To that end, the state has allocated millions of dollars in grants and loans to prop up the franchise, along with buying the team from the previous owner, Richard Gordon, a Hartford developer, and then, through the Connecticut Development Authority, selling it to Mr. Karamanos. "The state has done everything they could," Mr. Karamanos said.
As for the city, the club's ownership has been unhappy for years over a policy that precludes the team from sharing in parking and concession revenues, which most N.H.L. teams do. So Mayor Peters has suggested that parking lot and garage owners near the the Civic Center contribute a share of their profits -- say, $1 a car -- to the team. But that may not strike a responsive chord, given that the Whalers' player payroll has quadrupled from $5 million in 1988-89 to $20.5 million this season.
Neither, perhaps, will comments by Whaler officials that, should the team remain in Hartford, a new arena would be needed to provide more sky boxes -- a thought the owners now seem to backing away from. "That has to be part of our longterm thinking," said Mr. Beer. "But it's ludicrous to think about a new arena when we can't fill the one we now have."
Mr. Rutherford agreed. "A new arena would be something to consider 8 or 10 years down the road," he said, adding that the Whalers' share of receipts amounts to about $300,000 a game compared with as much as $800,000 for some other N.H.L. clubs.
At this stage, Whalers' officials say, corporate support and a broadening base of fan support are the keys to staying in Hartford.
"We can't expect much more from the state," Mr. Rutherford said. "But pretty soon, we're going to have to sit down and see if it makes sense to stay in Hartford."

LENGTH: 1215 words

HEADLINE: Make Big Hollywood $$ in the Comfort of Your Home

BYLINE: By VERNE G. KOPYTOFF 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
IN Hollywood's jargon, Susan Gardner's home was discovered. A film scout scouring the neighborhood for the ideal crime scene knocked on her door and asked if she wanted to transform her home into a stage set and reap a few thousand dollars for the bother.
Since then, Ms. Gardner's suburban estate, 20 miles northwest of Los Angeles in Westlake Village, has been immortalized on screen. She and her husband, Doug, and daughter, Katie, patiently endure a slalom course of light stands and the inevitable scuffed walls caused by careless filming. But the fees can approach $1,500 a day. 
 "A film person just walked up to the door and said we had the perfect foyer for their show's murder," Ms. Gardner said. "This is the easiest money you can possibly make next to winning the lottery."
Ms. Gardner is among hundreds of homeowners in the Los Angeles area who are prospering thanks to the production industry's growing desire to use genuine rather than studio-manufactured settings for films.
According to the Entertainment Industry Development Corporation, the office that oversees filming in Los Angeles County, the number of shooting days in county streets and homes last year grew by nearly 25 percent to 33,500. The growth is driven in part by network newcomers like United Paramount and the flourishing independent and straight-to-video market.
It is often cheaper for a studio to rent a private home than to build a stage set. So production companies recruit the properties of people like Paula Iny, who owns a "Miami Vice"-like mansion in Encino, just north of Los Angeles.
Recently, Ms. Iny's home was being used as a backdrop for the low-budget thriller, "The Dentist," starring the former "L.A. Law" star Corbin Bernsen as a love-spurned professional turned maniac.
Workers cleared Ms. Iny's living room of all its furnishings, boxed away breakables and transformed the space for the camera into an office with a faux marble desk. Around it, they packed the paraphernalia of Hollywood production equipment for Mr. Bernsen's next scene.
Ms. Iny stood guard lest a crew member scratch the entry-hall floor with heavy equipment or perhaps stain the swimming pool with stage blood during the on-camera murder.
"I like to stay here for the peace of mind," Ms. Iny said, as studio assistants swung a camera crane in her dining room just above a fragile glass banister. "Sometimes I think I should leave, and that way when I come back everything will be in its place."
MS. INY, who lives with her husband, Benjamin, and their two children, says she shows the house to prospective studio renters at a moment's notice and signs the necessary documents that spell out the rooms to be used, hours of filming and the fee.
So far, the Iny home has starred in such productions as the television series "Beverly Hills 90210," the film "Ghost in the Machine," and in music videos by the singer formerly known as Prince and the rapper Ice Cube.
A contract with a major studio film is the Oscar of homeowner paychecks, followed by television series, commercials and B-grade movies. The reward of up to $4,000 a day varies with home size, production budget and number of crew members.
That profit can nearly double if free home improvements are lavished on the property. Lucy M. Edwards of Pasadena, Calif., 12 miles northeast of Los Angeles, said her Victorian mansion, which was growing dowdy with age, has now been nearly restored to its former grandeur by decor-conscious film makers working to make the furnishings suited the script.
"When Debbie Allen was producer of 'Polly' with Phylicia Rashad, I had gold carpeting here that I hated," Ms. Edwards said. "They put in a dusty rose colored carpet that's just lovely. The film 'Jo Jo Dancer' put up wallpaper worth $7,000 in the front room. And I think the TV series 'Gangster Chronicles' papered the bedroom."
Before choosing a film site, production companies generally sift through the thousands of properties listed through local film commissions and private location services (which earn a 20 to 40 percent finder's fee). Some houses can languish in obscurity while others enjoy a near-blockbuster status.
The quaint Victorian is perhaps more often than not a fictional character's home of choice. And unless a show is location-specific like a Western or surfing film, the scripts call strictly for Americana.
"Producers want the back-East look," said Jean Ferguson, owner of Ferguson's Location Library, one of the largest private location services in the country. "Palm trees are usually too Southern California. They want a house that looks like Anywhere U.S.A."
Perhaps the ultimate test of a home's star potential is square-footage. Owners might consider their living room to be spacious, but many forget that it must accommodate dozens of camera assistants plus equipment. Not surprisingly, big bathrooms are always in demand, as was Ms. Iny's, which has a whirlpool bath and fireplace.
Homeowners say studios generally keep their promises to return a home to how they found it. This often requires touching up walls with paint and shampooing soiled carpets. Though homeowners may be satisfied with the arrangement, some of their neighbors frequently bemoan it once the assault of equipment trucks and film crews begin.
IT sometimes takes artful persuasion and perhaps sheer bribery for a production crew to get permission for night shots from affected residents, a necessity in some towns.
If charm does not work, location managers may try the more material appeal of fruit baskets, block party barbecues and, on rare occasions, pocket money.
"If all-night filming is going to be a disruption, I can put people in a hotel," said Gary deGalla, a film location manager. "If I am establishing a full-time location for, say, nine days, I might host a neighborhood get-together and bring sandwiches and soda so that the filming experience is not all negative."
If a show is a success, homeowners can expect an onslaught of gawking tourists like those who mill outside the Los Angeles area home used for the exterior shots in the television series "The Brady Bunch." The addresses of some residences used in filming are publicized in tour guides and for years afterward their sidewalks fill with bus tour cinephiles.
Many cities welcome the economic infusion of glitter. One study by the Nevada Motion Picture Division of the Commission on Economic Development showed that a production could pump nearly $100,000 a day into a community through catering, wages and tourism.
For example, thousands of people drive for hours across Iowa to toss a ball and buy souvenirs where Kevin Costner carved a baseball diamond in a cornfield in "Field of Dreams."
James Cleary, a Los Angeles accountant, says the best thing about welcoming the entertainment industry to his home is that the first 14 days of rental a year are exempt from Federal income taxes. And that alone makes his life of packing and unpacking his home to a studio schedule worth the trouble.
"When I make $4,000 from a production in a week, it's like making $8,000 from my day job because I don't have to pay any taxes," Mr. Cleary said. "And I think that I can stand a little inconvenience for that. It's a wonderful way to make fast cash."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Doug and Susan Gardner with daughter, Katie, left, in Westlake Village home. Their foyer witnessed a "murder." Encino mansion of Paula and Benjamin Iny, above, was a thriller backdrop. (Photographs by Marissa Roth for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
INVESTING WITH: Robert W. Bissell

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY MIDDLETON 

 BODY:
WHEN stock investors look for safety, they flock to companies that are paying high dividends. For whatever the ups and downs of the stock market, these holdings produce a steady stream of income.
 The comparable investment in mutual funds is the equity-income category. Its funds invest in just such high-yielding stocks. With volatility increasing and talk persistent about how long it has been since a 10 percent decline in the broad stock market, these funds make sense for the conservative.
Among the strong performers in the category is the Stagecoach Diversified Income Fund, which was in the top 25 percent in the first two months of 1996. Robert W. Bissell, 48, chief equity investment officer for Wells Fargo Bank in Los Angeles, has been manager of the fund, now at more than $100 million in assets, since its inception in November 1992. He manages $1.5 billion, including private accounts, in the same style. 
 He aims for a combination of decent yields,now 3.44 percent annually at Stagecoach Diversified Income, and capital growth. Typical of his fund and other equity-income funds are blue-chip stocks. He characterized his investment style as buying companies with strong fundamentals when "investor expectations are low" -- in other words, value investing. But another thread runs through much of his portfolio: a belief in management. A couple of his biggest holdings are companies run by former Wells Fargo executives.
 Mr. Bissell puts a third of the portfolio in his 10 favorite stocks, including Ford Motor, Bankers Trust New York, ARCO and I.B.M., and puts the balance in 40 to 50 other issues.
A longtime holding is Household International, the consumer finance company in Prospect Heights, Ill. From time to time, the shares of Household International rally, and Mr. Bissell trims his holdings to prevent his position from going over 5 percent of the fund's assets. "That's an internal collar we use, for diversification purposes, and it's the only time we sell this company," he said. "It represents everything we believe in."
Generally, the fund holds a stock until the price rises to what Mr. Bissell considers fair value, a more compelling opportunity arises or something causes him to reconsider his investment.
Last year, the fund sold its stake in PNC Holdings after that bank company acquired Midlantic Bank of New Jersey. The acquisition was made with stock, which Mr. Bissell thought would dilute earnings about 10 percent in the first year. The fund realized an average gain of $5 a share, or 21 percent, on its one-year investment in PNC, the manager said.
His buy-and-hold strategy results in little turnover, about 40 percent annually of the portfolio, and it often means that Mr. Bissell invests cash coming into the fund in long-held positions.
 
 
A Leaner Lender
 Stagecoach began buying Household International in fall 1994, when William Aldinger, the former vice chairman of Wells Fargo, became Household's chief executive. "We knew Bill very well, and that's what created our interest," Mr. Bissell said.
Mr. Aldinger cut Household's annual expenses from nearly 60 cents on each dollar of operating revenue to 54 cents in 1995, and Mr. Bissell expects a decline to 45 cents by 1998. Household, which issues the General Motors credit card, has built up a cash reserve to help withstand a possible increase in write-offs, something industry analysts are concerned about as consumer debt and late payments rise. Household's reserve is equal to 5.4 percent of card receivables, compared with an average of 1.9 percent at other specialty-card issuers, Mr. Bissell said.
He expects profits to reach $5.10 a share this year, up from $4.30 in 1995. Over the next two to three years, he said, earnings could grow 20 percent. The fund paid an average of $36 each for its Household shares, and although the stock is trading at nearly twice that amount, the manager still considers them a value. "Our target price on this stock is $130 within two years," he said.
 
Problem? No, Opportunity
 Bankers Trust New York also has new management, in the wake of a derivatives debacle last year that led to client lawsuits and a tumbling stock price. "What the market sees as a problem," he said, "we see as a buying opportunity."
The new chief executive, Frank Newman, is a former Under Secretary of the Treasury with banking experience at Bank of America and Wells Fargo. "We think Frank is the right person to restore balance and reputation to Bankers Trust," Mr. Bissell said.
Stagecoach bought its stake last fall, when Mr. Newman was hired, at an average cost of $67. Bankers Trust's profits plunged last year to $2.03 a share, sharply less than the $4 dividend, and the fear of a cut in the payout hangs over the stock. Mr. Bissell, however, expects earnings to rebound this year to $6.75 a share, an aggressive target.
Along with playing down of derivatives, Mr. Newman reduced the company's reliance on trading for its own account. The trading made earnings volatile, which Wall Street doesn't like.
 
A Better Idea?
 The last auto maker to revamp, Ford Motor is poised to be the first in performance in the last years of this decade, Mr. Bissell said.
The company has announced plans under the rubric Ford 2000 to move to an international from a regional operational structure, reducing the number of vehicle platforms, the underlying structures, to 16 from 24, and cutting expenses 20 percent to 30 percent. Another element is a reduction in capital spending, "which frees up a lot of cash for either a higher dividend or share repurchases," Mr. Bissell said.
A frequent trader of Ford's stock, Mr. Bissell began building his most recent position about a year ago at an average cost of $27 a share. The stock is now trading in the mid-$30's, but he values it at about $40. He expects earnings, $3.58 a share last year, to edge up to $5 in 1997, a considerably more optimistic view than the consensus on Wall Street. "We really see the 1997-99 time frame as when the earnings increases will be the most significant," Mr. Bissell said.
The recent downturn in the market did not frighten Mr. Bissell, who has about 5 percent of his portfolio in cash. "It's not a surprise to see bonds back up to 7 percent, but the reason for that weakness isn't inflation; it's the outlook for a better economy, and that should help our companies, Ford in particular," he said.

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Hot Heads On Hairdresser Lane

BYLINE: By LENA WILLIAMS 

 BODY:
STROLL along Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn, anytime, any day of the week, and in the hubbub of commerce you'll find people getting their hair permed, weaved, braided, blow-dried, curled, wrapped or set.
When it comes to black American coiffures, Flatbush Avenue is the hairstyling mecca. On the avenue, styles are done with outrageous flair that tend more toward five-inch beehives than pixie cuts, and the women who wear them want to turn heads. 
 The street is a kaleidoscopic zone of tiny hair salons and beauty supply stores. There are stores selling hair, human and synthetic, and stores selling hair-care products. There are hair consultants, hairstylists and hair doctors. The section of Flatbush between Winthrop Street and Parkside Avenue alone boasts eight salons and two beauty supply stores.
Hard data on Flatbush's hair industry are elusive. Neither the National Association of Black Hair Stylists nor the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce had figures. But several people in the area, among them stylists, shop owners and street chroniclers, say the trend dates back 10 years or longer and directly coincides with demographic changes.
"It's become known as 'Hairdresser Lane,' " said Fadare Bashiri Imhotep, owner of Shear Perfection at 941 Flatbush, a 4,000-square-foot, two-story shop that's more hair-care mall than salon. "I've been in the area for the last 10 to 12 years and in the last 5 years, the black hairstyling business has mushroomed beyond comparison."
The boom can be traced, in part, to a wave of immigrant entrepreneurs. Much in the way Koreans gained an economic foothold through greengroceries and nail salons, scores of West Indian immigrants are building an empire of their own in hair, attracted by the relatively low rents of Flatbush Avenue and by its cachet as a hairstyling center.
Doll Lakhan Gibbs, a native of Trinidad, once worked as a sales clerk in the beauty supply store she owns, which now bears her given name. The previous owner, an Italian-American, knew the trade but had lost touch with his market, she said.
"The area had changed demographically," said Ms. Lakhan Gibbs,"and what was once an area that was 80 percent white became 80 percent black and Caribbean. The store was still carrying products for white hair. When I bought it 20 years ago, I started stocking products blacks needed for their hair."
In a textbook case of supply meeting demand, Ms. Lakhan Gibbs opened Doll's Beauty Supply at 700 Flatbush and, 10 years later, Doll's Unisex Salon at 716 Flatbush. Following in her footsteps was Yasmeen Bibi, a Trinidadian who had worked as a stylist at Doll's. Two months ago, Ms. Bibi opened Satisfaction Guaranteed, a unisex salon, across the street from her old boss. "There's room enough for all of us," said Ms. Bibi. "The clients are here."
Indeed.
A recent Thursday afternoon was a typical hair day on the avenue. Salons were crowded with men and women whose hair was in various stages of preparation, from those paying $10 for a basic haircut to those paying $100 for braids and weaves. Clair Wharwood, a stylist at Shear Perfection, estimated that 150 clients would be styled that day and 200 each on Friday and Saturday.
"Some Saturdays I don't leave here until 2 A.M. Sunday morning," Ms. Wharwood said with a smile and a shrug. "A lot of our customers work in the service jobs like nursing, so they may not leave work until 8 P.M., and we try to accommodate their schedules."
The salons seldom advertise, relying instead on word-of-mouth or fliers. The results justify the methods.
The shops have a steady stream of customers visiting from the West Indies and other countries to see relatives in the city. They stop by to get the latest American hairstyles. Once, a woman flew in from Harare, Zimbabwe, to have her hair done and buy hair-care products.
Kauleen Sandford of London, who was having her hair styled at Doll's, heard about Hairdresser Lane from her cousins in Queens. "There are some good stylists in London," Ms. Sandford said, "but I wanted to have my hair styled here, and my cousin said the avenue had some nice shops and the prices are reasonable."
The success of the industry has not gone unnoticed. Koreans are now moving into the vast black hair business, especially in the area of hair supply. And black salons that have closed in Manhattan often resurface on Flatbush Avenue.
Dr. Joseph Mosely, a trichologist and hair consultant with offices on nearby Nostrand Avenue, said the steady growth in hair care in Brooklyn could be traced in part to the nature of the business.
"It's easy to get into with little money or education," said Dr. Mosely, who started his business in 1950. "I've watched the industry grow and it's not a new phenomenon. The area has a clientele with a deep interest in hair -- immigrants who want to keep up with the American scene."
But hairdressers along the avenue note that there is a downside to that interest. They say they have noticed an increase in clients coming in for weaves because their hair had been damaged by chemicals.And Dr. Mosely says that the growth in the black hair business is directly related to a rise in his own business. "With all of the weaving and attachment and chemical processing of the hair," he said, "we're seeing more and more problems related to damaged hair."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Kauleen Sandford, in from London to visit relatives, made sure her itinerary included a stop at Doll's Hair Salon on Flatbush Avenue. Marie Geocelyne Pierre was the stylist. (Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times)
 
Chart: "HAIRSTYLES: The Scoop on the Scrunch"
The scrunch is one of the most popular black hairstyles to emerge from Flatbush Avenue.
Method -- The hair is finger-combed into deep marcel waves and teased to heights of one to three inches. Extensions ef human or synthetic hair are often added for a full-bodied look. With enough gel and holding spray -- and if the hair is not washed -- the style can last two to three weeks.
Effect -- Retro movie star glamour with an attitude.
Cost -- $35 to $50.

HEADLINE: GARDENING;
A Time to Ponder Amid Shoots and Buds

BYLINE: By JOAN LEE FAUST

 BODY:
APRIL is the month of new beginnings, when the landscape starts to come alive. The earliest bulbs have bloomed; others are up, waiting their turn. Buds on the maple trees, elms and oaks are getting fatter, ready to burst. In some places there are even patches of new grass.
It is a time of anticipation, but it should also be a time of patience. The landscape has been through a long, hard winter when there were many stresses from ice, snow and wind. Ground water damage from dissolved road salt may not show up for several months in browned leaves and stunted growth. 
 Although the outdoors beckons with scads of chores to be done, and there is a yearning to end that cabin fever and rush out to be doing them, it is wise to proceed slowly. Hasty tamping with the soft and soggy ground could mean deep trouble in future weeks.
This spring's wealth of ground moisture is ideal for mending root systems that were parched by the prolonged drought last summer. Many plants, particularly the shallow-rooted trees and shrubs, will be strengthened by the abundant water.
But heavy feet or garden carts can spoil the healing effect. Some of the places to be particularly cautious are in flower borders and in the vegetable patches. Underneath many shoots and tips are pushing up from root systems. They do this with remarkable agility. One day the ground seems bare; the next, there are the new shoots. Interfering with this activity is definitely not a good idea. Some plants, including hostas and platycodon, are so slow to stir, they sometimes seem lost to winter forever. But they too are busy, preparing to poke through.
Heavy footwork in a vegetable garden might be just as serious. All that hard work done last fall to turn over the ground and let it lie fallow for winter snow, freezes, thaws and spring rains must not be ruined now by excess trampling.
In fact, some early birds that had the forethought to prepare their ground last fall have already planted their pea crop, which needs cool weather to germinate and grow. That well-known reminder to plant peas on St. Patrick's Day is a worthy ditty to be heeded.
This is also a season to be cautious about the use of garden chemicals, particularly those grabbed indiscriminately as soon as a browned stem or chewed leaf appears. More to the point these days is less use of garden chemicals and more use of down-to-earth practicality.
More and more professionals are embracing I.P.M. (integrated pest management). It is not just a phase of do-good for the earth philosophy, but an effective and economic method of controlling a wide range of garden pests.
As reported in a recent publication of the Agricultural Research Service, the United States Department of Agriculture initiated an I.P.M. program at the National Arboretum in Washington, D.C. At the arboretum, often referred to as the nation's garden, gardeners decided to change their habits and stopped spraying the grounds routinely.
Instead, the arboretum adopted the I.P.M. program in 1992. The total volume of pesticides used dropped by about three-fourths and the report is that the plants are doing better. This is no small gathering of plants either, as the 444 acres support more than 640 new plant varieties as well as old-line stock.
Rather than use massive doses of spray, the arboretum has spot-sprayed -- that is, targeted a specific problem with a specific spray to stop a specific insect. This solution has resulted in a two-thirds reduction in total pesticide costs. Unwritten savings include less risk to the spray handlers and lower expenses for safety equipment.
The I.P.M. program at the National Arboretum has been coordinated by Scott Aker, staff horticulturist. He has found that being an advocate for I.P.M. caused marked changes in human behavior.
"People have to get away from the idea of reaching for a spray can the minute they see one bug on a plant," he said. "They have to realize, for one thing, there may be another bug lurking nearby waiting to eat the first bug. A spray could kill both bugs, or deprive the harmless predatory bug of a meal."
As dull as it may sound, labels on bottles, bags and cans are important reading for anyone who works with plants or tries to control the insects that may feed upon them. Labels reflect years of testing and are written for the user's protection and information. Labels are essential to the correct use of any product.
And there are many more sources of information available. Gardeners need not be afraid to ask questions. It is much better to seek and find out rather than guess at a solution.
When a problem does seem to present itself, the major part of the answer is correct identification. What might be assumed to be a termite, for example, could actually be just a sowbug that could be swept away and forgotten.

SECTION: Section 13LI; Page 14; Column 3; Long Island Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 807 words

HEADLINE: GARDENING;
A Time to Ponder Amid Shoots and Buds

BYLINE: By JOAN LEE FAUST

 BODY:
APRIL is the month of new beginnings, when the landscape starts to come alive. The earliest bulbs have bloomed; others are up, waiting their turn. Buds on the maple trees, elms and oaks are getting fatter, ready to burst. In some places there are even patches of new grass.
It is a time of anticipation, but it should also be a time of patience. The landscape has been through a long, hard winter when there were many stresses from ice, snow and wind. Ground water damage from dissolved road salt may not show up for several months in browned leaves and stunted growth. 
 Although the outdoors beckons with scads of chores to be done, and there is a yearning to end that cabin fever and rush out to be doing them, it is wise to proceed slowly. Hasty tamping with the soft and soggy ground could mean deep trouble in future weeks.
This spring's wealth of ground moisture is ideal for mending root systems that were parched by the prolonged drought last summer. Many plants, particularly the shallow-rooted trees and shrubs, will be strengthened by the abundant water.
But heavy feet or garden carts can spoil the healing effect. Some of the places to be particularly cautious are in flower borders and in the vegetable patches. Underneath many shoots and tips are pushing up from root systems. They do this with remarkable agility. One day the ground seems bare; the next, there are the new shoots. Interfering with this activity is definitely not a good idea. Some plants, including hostas and platycodon, are so slow to stir, they sometimes seem lost to winter forever. But they too are busy, preparing to poke through.
Heavy footwork in a vegetable garden might be just as serious. All that hard work done last fall to turn over the ground and let it lie fallow for winter snow, freezes, thaws and spring rains must not be ruined now by excess trampling.
In fact, some early birds that had the forethought to prepare their ground last fall have already planted their pea crop, which needs cool weather to germinate and grow. That well-known reminder to plant peas on St. Patrick's Day is a worthy ditty to be heeded.
This is also a season to be cautious about the use of garden chemicals, particularly those grabbed indiscriminately as soon as a browned stem or chewed leaf appears. More to the point these days is less use of garden chemicals and more use of down-to-earth practicality.
More and more professionals are embracing I.P.M. (integrated pest management). It is not just a phase of do-good for the earth philosophy, but an effective and economic method of controlling a wide range of garden pests.
As reported in a recent publication of the Agricultural Research Service, the United States Department of Agriculture initiated an I.P.M. program at the National Arboretum in Washington, D.C. At the arboretum, often referred to as the nation's garden, gardeners decided to change their habits and stopped spraying the grounds routinely.
Instead, the arboretum adopted the I.P.M. program in 1992. The total volume of pesticides used dropped by about three-fourths and the report is that the plants are doing better. This is no small gathering of plants either, as the 444 acres support more than 640 new plant varieties as well as old-line stock.
Rather than use massive doses of spray, the arboretum has spot-sprayed -- that is, targeted a specific problem with a specific spray to stop a specific insect. This solution has resulted in a two-thirds reduction in total pesticide costs. Unwritten savings include less risk to the spray handlers and lower expenses for safety equipment.
The I.P.M. program at the National Arboretum has been coordinated by Scott Aker, staff horticulturist. He has found that being an advocate for I.P.M. caused marked changes in human behavior.
"People have to get away from the idea of reaching for a spray can the minute they see one bug on a plant," he said. "They have to realize, for one thing, there may be another bug lurking nearby waiting to eat the first bug. A spray could kill both bugs, or deprive the harmless predatory bug of a meal."
As dull as it may sound, labels on bottles, bags and cans are important reading for anyone who works with plants or tries to control the insects that may feed upon them. Labels reflect years of testing and are written for the user's protection and information. Labels are essential to the correct use of any product.
And there are many more sources of information available. Gardeners need not be afraid to ask questions. It is much better to seek and find out rather than guess at a solution.
When a problem does seem to present itself, the major part of the answer is correct identification. What might be assumed to be a termite, for example, could actually be just a sowbug that could be swept away and forgotten.

HEADLINE: GARDENING;
A Time to Ponder Amid Shoots and Buds

BYLINE: By JOAN LEE FAUST 

 BODY:

HEADLINE: Port Can't Be Held Hostage To Environmental Demands

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Consumers and industries can be grateful for the recent high-profile news coverage of the crisis posed by the buildup of silt in New York Harbor. Unfortunately, much of this discussion is coming late in the game and is laced with unrealistic proposals that can only delay urgently needed solutions. 
 The Port of New York and New Jersey is choking on natural silt deposits from the Hudson, Passaic and Hackensack Rivers because of the failure to find a cost-effective way to remove tainted sediments. Unrealistic environmental demands have raised the costs of disposal so high that they threaten to overwhelm the port's ability to maintain its channels and berths.
The port is an irreplaceable economic asset, creating more than 150,000 jobs both directly and indirectly. Without it, many of those jobs would be lost. Many more truck trips would be needed to move goods into and out of the region, further choking roadways, driving up the cost of goods, worsening environmental and health problems and impairing the region's economic competitiveness.
The solution cannot be found by going back to the future. In a letter to the editor on March 21, Representative Jerrold Nadler of Manhattan argues that that much of the container activity at Ports Newark and Elizabeth should be shifted to Brooklyn. But a modern container port needs large upland space for staging, easy movement of cargo to other modes of transportation, and nearby warehouse and industrial parks for storage and processing. In this region, such amenities are simply not available anywhere but New Jersey.
The Port of New York and New Jersey stands poised to become far and away the most important port on the Atlantic Coast. But unless a realistic, cost-effective solution to the dredging crisis is found soon, the ebb and flow of nature will dictate economic decisions that will forever remake the quality of life and prosperity of the region -- for the worse.
 
J. WILLIAM VAN DYKE
Chairman, North Jersey Transportation Planning Authority
Newark

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
Need Tax Help? So Do the Experts in Washington

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
IT is estimated that about half the Americans who file Form 1040 income-tax returns do the work themselves, spending an average of 12 hours trying to understand the complex laws of the tax system. Many of these 59 million taxpayers will be stuck inside today, trying to complete their returns before tomorrow's filing deadline.
If that isn't frustrating enough, here is a much smaller number to ponder: Of the almost five dozen Senators and Representatives who write the nation's tax laws, only six said they did their own taxes. Most of the rest don't deal with the prose they helped to inspire, instructions like: "Subtract line 8 from line 7. If zero or less, skip lines 10 through 13, enter zero on line 14 below, and go to line 15." Instead, they hire professionals to figure out what it all means. 
 Of the 37 members of the House Ways and Means Committee, where tax legislation begins, only four said they prepared their own taxes. On the other side of the Capitol, only 2 of the 19 members of the Senate Finance Committee, which drafts tax bills, said they did their own returns.
President Clinton can't do his return because his assets are in a blind trust. That is not the case for the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, Margaret Milner Richardson, who hires a professional, and she is a tax lawyer. Why doesn't she prepare her own?
"It's just the time" it takes away from her work, said Steve Pyrek, a spokesman for the I.R.S.
Senator Bob Dole, who has locked up the Republican Presidential nomination, doesn't do his return, although his campaign office declined to explain why. But another leading Republican, Representative Bill Archer of Texas, boasts that he is "the first Ways and Means chairman to do his own taxes." He said it was important for senior officials to prepare their own returns because it helps them "understand what Americans must go through."
"If we required members of Congress to do their own tax returns," he said, "I really do think we would have a very different tax code."
So what has Mr. Archer gleaned from hunkering down with his tax returns for about 16 hours year after year? He concludes that the current system should be dumped. He said a tax on spending would make more sense because defining taxable income is too complex and, more important, the Internal Revenue Service intrudes too deeply into people's financial affairs.
Of the other committee members, 30 said they hired professionals and three declined comment or did not respond to requests for information. The only members who followed their chairman in completing their own returns were Bill Thomas, Republican of California, and two Democrats, Andrew Jacobs Jr. of Indiana and William J. Coyne of Pennsylvania.
On the Senate Finance Committee, only John H. Chafee of Rhode Island and Don Nickles of Oklahoma, both Republicans, said they prepared their own taxes.
Republican sponsors of the leading flat-tax proposal are divided on the subject. Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader, does his own return. But his co-sponsor, Senator Richard C. Shelby of Alabama, hires the work out.
And what about the chief staff members for the committees? Phillip Moseley, the Republican chief of staff for the Ways and Means Committee, and his Democratic counterpart, Janice Mays, do their own taxes. Lindy L. Paull, the chief counsel of the Senate Finance Committee, and Mark Patterson, the Democrats' chief counsel, also said they prepared their returns.
Kenneth J. Kies, chief of staff for the Joint Committee on Taxation, which analyzes and drafts tax proposals for the House and Senate, said he always did his own taxes.
"I think any tax lawyer who doesn't do their own return ought to be embarrassed," he said. "Secondly, it is the best way to keep informed every year just how we have changed the system and how it is working."
He assumes that the 55 economists and tax lawyers on the committee staff all do their own taxes. Joking, he said, "I would consider firing them if they didn't."
At the I.R.S., the deputy commissioner, Michael P. Dolan, does his own returns. So does the chief of taxpayer compliance, James E. Donelson, and Frank Keith, the senior I.R.S. spokesman.
But the I.R.S. chief counsel, Stuart L. Brown, gets professional help with his return, as does Dave Mader, the chief of management and administration.
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, a former co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs, has his fortune in a blind trust. Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers said his wife, Victoria, a tax lawyer, prepared their return with his help. "Our return is considerably less complicated now that I am in Government," said Mr. Summers, a former chief economist for the World Bank.
Leslie B. Samuels, the Assistant Treasury Secretary for tax policy, prepared his own returns when he was a tax lawyer but has used a professional tax preparer since taking office, said Calvin Mitchell, a Treasury Department spokesman.
How about some of the people who want the tax laws to be changed?
Jack Kemp, the former Congressman and chairman of the National Commission on Economic Growth and Tax Reform, a private organization that promotes the flat tax, gets assistance, an aide said.
The authors of "The Flat Tax," a book recommending a flat tax rate on business and individuals, both prepare their own taxes. The writers, Robert E. Hall and Alvin Rabushka, senior fellows of the Hoover Institution at Stanford University, both use tax preparation software.
Robert S. McIntrye, the director of Citizens for Tax Justice, an organization that believes the tax system favors the rich, and J. D. Foster, executive director of the conservative Tax Foundation, do their own taxes. Indeed, both men created spreadsheet programs to help. "If I couldn't do my own taxes," Mr. McIntrye said, "I shouldn't be speaking about taxes."
