HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER EAST SIDE;
Fight to Regain School Board Voice

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
For 8 of the 20 candidates running for Community School Board 2, there is a missionary fervor: winning representation for the Upper East Side on the board.
But the eight candidates living on the Upper East Side, or with children in the neighborhood's schools, face an uphill struggle for the May 7 election. Nineteen candidates, plus a write-in, are running for nine seats in the sprawling district, Manhattan's most racially diverse. 
 About 5,650 students, about a quarter of the district's children, are in schools above 57th Street or on Roosevelt Island. But the Upper East Side typically turns out only 1,000 or so voters for a board election, which in 1989 attracted 12,000 votes districtwide.
Still, the complex proportional representation system of voting usually insures that one or two Upper East Siders are elected to the nine-member board. But in the last election, in 1993, the Upper East Side turned out the same 1,000 or so votes in an election that attracted 51,000 votes, as gay-rights advocates and their allies fought back conservatives endorsed by the Christian Coalition. Upper East Siders are likely to have a better chance this time around.
Four Upper East Side candidates have children in district schools. Douglas H. Robinson, a Citibank computer programmer, is gay and has two adopted sons. He lives in Washington Heights but has one son at Public School 6 on East 81st Street. Renee Ward, an accountant, has one of her two daughters at P.S. 6. Both Mr. Robinson and Ms. Ward emphasize greater parental control over the district's budget, maintenance of buildings and teacher accountability.
Patricia Sliwak-Grinberg, a housewife, has four children, two of whom attend P.S. 183. Although District 2 has no jurisdiction over high schools, Ms. Grinberg has been pressing for an academic high school on the East Side.
Essie D. Owens, an educational consultant who lives on Roosevelt Island, has her 10-year-old son at P.S. 217. Like Mr. Robinson, who is also black, Ms. Owens wants to boost minority representation on the board.
Mr. Robinson, Ms. Sliwak-Grinberg and Ms. Owens are on the Alliance for Better Community Schools slate, which tends to support the Superintendent, Anthony J. Alvarado, a former city schools chancellor.
Four candidates do not have children in the district. George Spitz, a retired state auditor, has gained a reputation as a gadfly. Robert S. Kelley, a securities analyst and a write-in candidate, also plans to attack wasteful spending. Adolfo Carpio, a computer programmer, wants to encourage more parents to volunteer at their schools. John C. Sovak, an unemployed waiter, said he wanted to apply "modern management science" to the board. ANTHONY RAMIREZ

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
Buy Britain! Sell Sweden! Hold Hong Kong!

BYLINE: By DOREEN HEMLOCK 

 BODY:
WANT to bet on a recovering economy in another country? Think Germany will soon cut interest rates and drive up that country's stock market? Some new investments make it particularly easy to speculate on just such matters.
The American and the New York stock exchanges recently introduced stock index products for several countries. The issues, which trade like stocks, let investors buy the bulk of a foreign market in one fell swoop, in much the same way as a Standard & Poor's 500 index fund allows one to own most of the United States market. 
 "This is the simplest and most convenient way for most Americans to invest abroad," said Jim Rogers, the author of "Investment Biker" and a financial adviser. "You can tell your broker, 'Instead of buying me I.B.M., buy me Germany or Australia.' "
Not that it was impossible to buy a fund specializing in these areas before. But the choices were mostly closed-end funds, which issue a fixed number of shares and often trade at a discount or a premium to their underlying stock prices. Most closed-end country funds do not track an index but are actively managed, meaning they are run by stock pickers who aim to do better than the broad market.
Along with closed-end funds, some open-end mutual funds specialize in specific countries, but most of those are also actively managed. Open-end funds are priced once a day and can be bought or sold at their net asset values. Among the biggest managers of these funds is Wright Investors' Service, in Bridgeport, Conn., which has nine actively managed open-end country funds. "Our objective is to outperform," said Peter Donovan, chairman of Wright, adding that investors will choose based on performance. "If the index outperforms, they'll buy that."
 Index funds aim to replicate the performance of the broad market by buying all the shares in a stock index and then keeping their expenses low. Only a few foreign funds, including the Vanguard International Equity Index European, now use indexing. Given how Americans have flocked to the concept of index investing at home, the new country index investments -- really a cross between open-end and closed-end funds -- are likely to attract a fair share of fans.
 World Equity Benchmark Shares, or WEBS, made their debut in March on the American Stock Exchange, and come in 17 varieties, each based on a different Morgan Stanley Capital International index. Country Baskets Index Funds, listed on the New York Stock Exchange, come in nine versions, including one for the United States, and are based on Financial Times/Standard & Poor's AWI indexes. Most of the countries covered have relatively large, stable stock markets. You won't find Turkey or Israel in either group -- at least not yet.
"This is the first time you can easily buy an index fund for most of these countries," said Gregg Wolper, who specializes in closed-end funds at Morningstar Inc., the fund tracking firm in Chicago. "Whether that's good or not remains to be seen. It's very possible you could do just as good or better with a closed-end fund."
The biggest impact could well be on the closed-end fund market, which has been in the doldrums, with only a handful of new issues in the last year.
"Since the WEBS and country baskets started, discounts on some closed-end funds have widened," said Thomas Herzfeld, who specializes in closed-end fund investing and is president of an advisory firm bearing his name in Miami. The discount on the Germany Fund has increased to 18 percent from 11 percent in January, he said, and the discount on the Scudder New Europe Fund, which has holdings in France, Germany and the Netherlands, has grown to 20 percent from 10 percent at the beginning of the year.
 "The result is that closed-end funds are currently cheap," Mr. Herzfeld said, "compared to WEBS and country baskets." Investors could reap a nice profit if the price of the closed-end funds moved closer to their underlying values and perhaps a windfall if the funds ever decided to convert to open-end status, issuing new shares.
As an example, look at the Germany fund, a closed-end fund, and the new indexed Germany products. The portfolios are similar. "If the discount narrows, you'll make a lot more money buying the closed-end Germany Fund," said Mr. Wolper of Morningstar. There is no guarantee, however, that a discount will disappear over time.
Some investors have long treated closed-end country funds as something akin to a broad market basket. That's not always the case. Even portfolios with similar holdings may have weighted the stocks differently. At the end of January, the Mexico index for WEBS consisted of 41 stocks, with Telefonos de Mexico at 28.2 percent. The Wright-Equifund Mexico, by contrast, had just 5.5 percent in Telmex at the end of March.
The choice between actively managed funds and index funds is a basic one for investors. Index funds have proved particularly useful for buying large-company stocks in the very efficient stock market in the United States. The markets overseas may not be as efficient because of different accounting rules and difficulties in getting access to information.
For these reasons and others -- like a desire to buy a fund that hedges against currency risk or one that moves into cash in times of political uncertainty -- many investors are willing to pay more for actively managed funds. Average annual expenses on international stock funds are 1.8 percent of assets, versus about 1 percent for WEBS and country baskets. Other costs to consider are brokerage commissions, which apply to WEBS, country baskets and closed-end funds, and sales charges, levied on many international mutual funds.
"The indexes are a low-cost alternative," said George Murnaghan, vice president of Rowe-Price Fleming International, which runs $23 billion in actively managed international funds for T. Rowe Price. "But an investor may not want to have exposure to certain things in an index. They may want to skew their portfolio away from certain companies, like banks in Japan."
Financial advisers generally urge small investors to start with a foreign fund that invests in many nations.
"The single worst investment you can make is in a single-country fund, especially in emerging markets, which are highly volatile and high risk," said Frank A. Fernandez, chief executive of Global Emerging Market Advisors L.P., of New York, a specialist in diversified funds. "And the toughest investment decision to make is 'top down' by country. It's easier to pick individual stocks in individual markets than to follow the political, economic and cultural events that can affect a single-country market."
STILL, some people want to speculate -- at least with a small part of a portfolio -- with a single-country fund.
And large investors may find the products particularly appealing. Money managers and fund companies may buy the country baskets and WEBS for their mutual fund portfolios. One appeal for anyone investing at least $450,000 is the possibility of getting out of WEBS or country baskets by taking the underlying stocks instead of cash. Such redemptions, granted at the issuer's discretion, allow investors to time their gains and losses on specific stocks.
Sophisticated investors many also use the index products for arbitrage, taking advantage of temporary discrepancies in markets. For example, they could sell the index fund short -- a bet that its price will fall -- during New York trading hours and then buy the underlying shares abroad when that market opens if the price indeed falls. They would pocket the difference as a profit. Country baskets can already be sold short when the price is going down; WEBS are seeking authorization to do so. Shorting is rarely possible with funds.
"I think the new indexes will make the markets more efficient," said Gary Evans, senior strategist for fixed income in emerging markets at Lehman Brothers.
Investors in foreign countries may clamor for the new products as well. "You can't buy index funds in most countries of the world," said Mr. Rogers, the investment adviser, "so I suspect these funds also will be a way for foreigners to invest in their own markets."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CARROLL GARDENS;
Housing May Replace Barren Lot

BYLINE: By SOMINI SENGUPTA 

 BODY:
On the eastern edge of Brooklyn, in what was once a part of Jamaica Bay and then a city dump for construction debris, a developer is proposing to erect a new neighborhood, including the largest housing development to be built in Brooklyn in the last 20 years.
Along with local churches, Grenadier Realty, a subsidiary of the company that built the huge Starrett City apartment complex in East New York in the early 70's, has proposed to construct more than 1,300 single- and two-family homes as well as a 200 units of apartments for the elderly. The development, Gateway Estates, would have two schools, several parks and a shopping center on a tract bounded by Flatlands Avenue, Fountain Avenue, the Belt Parkway and Hendrix Creek. 
 The city would spend $25 million to build roads, electrical and sewer lines and the other items required for the 227-acre lot and nearly $75 million to subsidize the construction of the homes. Total cost for the development, part of a city urban renewal plan, is estimated at more than $500 million, city housing officials said.
"This is a wonderful site," said Robert C. Rosenberg, senior vice president of Starrett Corporation, Grenadier's parent company. "A vast number of housing units can be built without displacing anyone. There is no controversy here."
Backers of the project, including Borough President Howard Golden, who has already allocated $3.75 million to the proposed development, have argued that it will bring homeowners to a trash-littered lot on the far edge of Brooklyn and generate more than 2,000 jobs. The proposed complex is the largest in Brooklyn since Starrett City, with nearly 6,000 apartments opened in 1974 several blocks to the west, Mr. Golden said.
But at a city Planning Commission hearing this week, environmental groups voiced their opposition to the project. They argued for the preservation of open space that birdwatchers and hikers now use and expressed concerns about methane gas beneath the lot. According to the environmental impact statement, methane has seeped into the soil from years of dumping.
Richard Cogen, a lawyer for the Audubon Society, said that accumulated methane gas can explode. Mr. Rosenberg said the methane would be dissipated during construction and that the houses would be built without basements, to prevent the gas from collecting under the homes. He said the paved roads and clean soil would also protect against the other contaminants lingering underground.
The Planning Commission is to vote on the project on May 6. If it is then approved by the City Council, construction is to begin this fall and is estimated to take about five years.
Under the proposed development, the Starrett Corporation would build 840 two-family homes restricted to families with income of between $35,000 and $70,000 a year. Another 500 single-family homes for families making $21,000 to $65,000 a year will be built by East Brooklyn Congregations, developers of 2,200 row houses in East New York and Brownsville under its Nehemiah Homes project.
The Starrett Corporation has also agreed to build an elementary school for 900 to 1,200 students and an intermediate school for 900. The company proposes to lease the schools to the Board of Education once they are completed. The proposed community would also have a large park around its periphery and three smaller neighborhood parks. SOMINI SENGUPTA

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
On-Line Trading Takes Off

BYLINE: By MARCIA VICKERS 

 BODY:
CALL your broker! For clients of discount brokerage houses, that phrase may become as old-fashioned as button your shoes.
Since January of last year, the number of discount brokerage companies that provide on-line trading has almost doubled, from 12 to 22, the American Association of Individual Investors says. The firms include large organizations like Quick & Reilly and Fidelity Brokerage Services and smaller concerns like Accutrade and Pacific Brokerage Services. 
 Investors are flocking to sign up. The number of on-line accounts has jumped to 624,000 this year from 412,000 in 1995, Forrester Research of Cambridge, Mass., estimates. Forrester predicts that 1.3 million accounts will be on line within three years.
Most auspicious of all, beginning in May Charles Schwab & Company, the nation's largest discount broker, will allow investors to trade through its Internet site. This move by Schwab, which already offers on-line trading through Street Smart and e.Schwab, its proprietary software, may help prompt more such offerings among discounters.
"Schwab's reach, in terms of sheer size and the impact it has in the brokerage business, makes this quite significant," said Guy Moszkowski, a securities industry analyst in New York. "Look for more discount brokerages to follow suit."
Investors have three ways to trade on line. The most popular is through a discounter's special software, like Schwab's Street Smart or Fidelity's On-Line Xpress. Some discounters can be reached through on-line services like Compuserve and America Online or through generic modem software like Procomm and Crosstalk. And, as with Schwab's venture, investors can also hook up with some brokerage firms via the Internet. (But don't look for full-service brokers, who offer personalized advice as well as order-taking, to offer any of these methods. So far, only discount and deep-discount brokerage firms have ventured into the area.)
All the on-line discounters execute stock trades and offer their services around the clock. They also provide clients with information about their accounts and offer real-time or delayed stock-price quotations, in some cases for an extra fee.
But the scope and terms of the services vary in other ways. While Fidelity Brokerage Services offers trades in stocks, bonds, mutual funds and options, for instance, smaller companies may handle just stocks and perhaps one other type of security. Most on-line discounters will execute standard buy-or-sell trades and limit orders, in which the investor sets a floor or ceiling for the trade price. And many will execute more exotic transactions like short-selling, in which an investor borrows shares on a bet that a stock's price will decline. Some also execute "versus purchase" orders, through which an investor can specify which lots are being sold to limit tax liability.
Generally, the fees that computerized discounters charge on line are comparable to those for conventional trading. But there are some divergences.
One involves discounts for on-line trading, which is generally cheaper than transactions requiring human brokers. The American Association of Individual Investors says seven on-line brokers offer commission discounts for on-line trading. Aufhauser & Company, Schwab, Jack White, Muriel Siebert and Quick & Reilly offer 10 percent reductions from regular fees. Max Ule offers 20 percent discounts and Freedom Investments has discounts from 10 percent up, depending on the size of the trade.
But on-line traders may encounter special costs. Investors who use Schwab's Street Smart software must pay $38 for it, for example, while Fidelity's On-Line Xpress costs $49.95. Then there are the costs of the on-line computer services. And, just as they do in their off-line businesses, some discounters attach miscellaneous fees to client transactions. E*Trade, for example, charges 27 cents a minute to give clients on-line access to the company.
In choosing on-line brokerage companies, an investor should keep an eye on services, said Andre Scheluchin, managing editor at Mercer Inc., a research firm in New York that tracks the discount-broker industry. If you want research and real-time stock quotes, for instance, look for a firm that provides them at a discount or at no cost.
But be wary about going on line to trade, said John Markese, president of the individual investors association. While many people think that technology somehow makes them better decision makers, he said, the new tools merely get information to them faster. Technology does not make the information better, or investors wiser.

HEADLINE: "So What Will You Have, Hon?"

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD 

 BODY:
AT the Hilltop Diner, 164-02 Union Turnpike in Fresh Meadows, Queens, you can find a man who for five years now has eaten two meals a day there, seven days a week. You can find out why The Lunch Bunch became The Big Three. You can find out why it's better for management if someone has a few Cokes rather than a swordfish steak. You can find out what it means to order a Greek salad "Deborah's way."
Go to the Hilltop and see life unvarnished, unexpurgated, in need of a cheeseburger deluxe, extra fries. See a menu, ablaze with possibilities, lengthier than a novella. See waitresses with irremovable smiles say, "So what will you have, hon?" See people order a piece of chocolate layer cake and get a towering thing that contains a day's output from a good-sized sugar refinery. You wonder why more dentists don't open next door to diners. 
 Small fleecy clouds were drifting across the city. Union Turnpike was aswarm with honking cars this Monday, and every so often one glided into the Hilltop, open 24 hours a day, every day. Here came a guy with a tumbling shag of red hair carrying an astrology chart and a small telescope. A man and a woman with hurry-up looks. A young guy with a buzzed-up haircut. A woman with a rambunctious child who whined: "I'm not eating. I'm not eating one crumb."
There was, as always, a low murmur going through the place, and the periodic clattering of plates being cleared. This is the small, consoling music of the diner. Smiling, John Morfogen, a co-owner, greeted the arrivals and, radiating sincerity, shunted them to booths. Mr. Morfogen moves constantly, with calm purpose. He listens to a lot of conversations, but since he has heard the same ones for years, he does not listen too closely.
The first diners were actual railroad dining cars plucked off their tracks, but modern diners often look more like space shuttles. The Hilltop is like that -- gleaming, low-slung gray granite with a neon-lighted flat roof.
The diner's animating thesis involves an emotional communion people have with the sterile environment and the sovereign good will. Go there any time and humanity in musing good spirits awaits. Someone in the skewers of a dilemma will often turn first to his succoring waitress. If a repeater fails to appear on schedule, the waitresses call around. Jerry Schnitzer, a social studies teacher who takes breakfast at the Hilltop every morning at 6:45, didn't arrive until 11 one day (waylaid by a doctor's appointment), and the whole staff panicked.
The business benefaction of a diner is that it permits a ceaseless cycle of eating. Diners don't have three meals a day; they have something like 10. They have early-bird dinners, after-the-club snacks, before-movies this, between-classes that, unexpected-rumble-in-my-stomach this. A New York Jets linebacker lumbered in once and had a six-egg omelette, went to an appointment and returned an hour later for an encore six-egg omelette.
"You'd need a henhouse to feed that man," a waitress concluded.

THE GREEK CONNECTION
Both John Morfogen, 61, and Angelo Trombettas, 65, who jointly own the diner, are Greeks, which is to be expected. There is some unwritten stricture that diners must be owned by Greeks. Many of the Greeks who came to this country plowed right into food; it was an easy-entry business. Others mimicked them. Before long, there was scarcely a diner around that didn't feature a Greek salad and chicken souvlaki.
Before the two Hilltop partners became partners, they were total strangers. Mr. Trombettas was born in Chefallonia, Greece, and came to America when he was 21. He began scrubbing dishes in a Pittsburgh restaurant, and eventually owned his own restaurant there. After 20 years, business slackened. In 1988, he sold the place, moved to New York and bought the Hilltop with two partners. A year later, one partner wanted to sell out (the second subsequently took ill and also sold his interest), and John Morfogen happened along.
Mr. Morfogen was born in Anavriti, Greece, and came to Brooklyn with his family when he was 12. Over the years, he worked as a busboy, waiter, cook. Starting in 1954, with his two brothers, he ran the Chelsea Chop and Steak House in Manhattan, following that with other steak and seafood restaurants. The tablecloth business started to contract, and he sold the establishments over a period of years. Through the restaurant grapevine, he got wind of the Hilltop.
The Hilltop dated to 1948, and had been on the decline. Competition had intruded in the form of a Roy Rogers, a fish 'n chips, a pancake house, a pizza place. The new owners renovated the diner. And they went the way of other diners, distancing the Hilltop from the heartlandish, greasy-spoon image by upgrading the menu. Everything but lobster tails, shrimp and french fries is now fresh, and there are plenty of health food and vegetarian offerings. On the menu are dishes like "agnolotti with shrimp and scallops" and "osso buccho of lamb shank Milanese." As always, though, there is the requisite rotating display of artery-clogging desserts just inside the entrance, slowly twirling several trillion calories in a tight circle before your eyes.
"Years ago, the diner catered to the truck driver, the single elderly person," Mr. Morfogen said. "Everything was a cheeseburger and a milkshake. It was a tradition to sit at the counter. Now most people come in with someone else and they eat everything. We had 16 counter seats and I cut back to 7, turning the space into booths for two. We are oriented toward the businessman breakfast special and the family dinner. Listen, 'diner' is a powerful word. It has survived fast food, health food. Nothing stops the diner."

THE REGULARS
It was cool and almost quiet. Throughout the diner sat people in all the attitudes of relaxation. One of the gnostic truths about diners is that they attract authentic characters, people groping for a new center to their lives. For instance, sit down in that booth for two near the kitchen and introduce yourself to Malcolm Heyman.
Mr. Heyman is a sturdily built man of 64 with a high domed forehead and a rubbery look to his face. Regular as a metronome, he shows up at 5:45 each morning to get a take-out breakfast that he delivers to his wife. Then he returns and takes his breakfast alone. He skips lunch to work out at the gym. Each evening at 4:30 he acquires a take-out dinner for his wife, then reappears for his own dinner. He has adhered to this concise regimen 365 days a year for five years.
He spoke with a steadfast smile and a sententious manner. To underscore his points, he stabbed the air with his right index finger. He said his wife eats at home in solitude because she can endure no stress. "She's been through a hectic five years," he explained. "She had two sisters die of cancer. Then our only child had to be placed in a residential center. And I broke down with post-traumatic stress disorder and she's battling cancer."
His twisting account of his own breakdown involves his working at Creedmoor Psychiatric Center, teaching hardcore psychiatric patients how to turn castoff wood from the Steinway piano factory into table lamps. It involves a disturbed man living on the streets near Creedmoor coming at Mr. Heyman with a 2-by-4 and tossing rocks at him from behind bushes. The police caught him but Mr. Heyman said he was traumatized by the episodes. Then, he said, supervisors harassed him. He said he wasn't getting his phone messages and mail. His nerves went.
Now he receives workers' compensation. He is often depressed. If he is stationary for long, he said, he falls asleep. So he stays ambulatory. He said he walks for four hours a day. To occupy himself, he collects cans. The proceeds are bet on the stock market. Nickels from Coke cans are plowed into Coca-Cola stock. Pepsi money goes into Pepsi. Money from Master Choice cans (the A.& P. house brand) buys A.& P. stock. Money he finds on the streets he puts into shares of Service Corporation International and Charles Schwab. He said his portfolio hovers around $5,600.
His roast turkey dinner was delivered, and he dug in.
"I like this place," he said, taking a brief, angling look around the diner. "I like a lot of life. There's a lot of life here."

THE BURGERS AND MORE
Nothing is more astounding about diners than the density of their menus. There are 379 items on the Hilltop menu. The most popular choices, forgetting coffee and Coke, are hamburgers, chicken and eggs (omelette is the favored style). The least-ordered selection is meatloaf. Days can lapse without a taker.
Each day, the diner goes through 360 eggs, 250 hamburgers, 40 loaves of bread, 25 pounds of coffee, 3,000 napkins (many are wasted), 180 Cokes. Pastries and cakes are made fresh on the premises. They are sold for two days. The third day, they go to a soup kitchen.
Mr. Morfogen explained diner economics: "The method of pricing I learned is, you take the food cost and then add on double that to get the menu price. So if something costs me $3.25, I charge $10 for it. Overall, you shoot for 10 percent net profit."
Within those broad rules are certain exceptions. Some foods won't bear such markup. Others can handle much more. A Coke gets marked up 10 times its cost. Ditto for anything made of flour, like a pancake. Seafood, with its high cost, can only be doubled. "Coffee you can mark up at least 10 times," Mr. Morfogen said. "The problem is the refills are free. If someone is a heavy coffee drinker, it's costing me."

THE WAITRESS AS V.I.P.
Slow time. Huge thunderheads were coming this way, roiling the sky. Outside the kitchen doors, some waitresses were talking among themselves about diner sociology.
Angela Cestaro, the chirpy head waitress, on why so many patrons request a specific waitress: "People don't like to repeat everything over and over. A regular waitress gets to know if someone takes his coffee light or without sugar. They want their eggs without butter. They want their bagel scooped out. We don't know people by names. We know them by what they eat. The guy with the toasted bagel and two soft-boiled eggs. The woman with the spinach salad without the bagel. You are what you eat here."
"You can make a customer for life by remembering that he doesn't want a pickle," said Barbara McGowan, who has been serving diner food for 13 years.
A case in point is Deborah Fromberg, who, in her words, is "allergic to, like every food on the planet." When she orders, she tells her usual waitress, Lucy Wagner, "I'll have it my way." She knows that Deborah's way means, say, Greek salad with no achovies, no scallions, no onions, no tomatoes and a few extra grape leaves to compensate for what's left out.
Diner waitresses hear the wearisome catalogue of life's encroachments. "In a diner, people want you to speak to them," Ms. Cestaro said. "They want conversation. They want to draw you into their lives. You have to be a psychiatrist, a priest, a mother-in-law. You listen to every story. There is an elderly guy here who was in this morning and he says he wants to kill himself. I say, 'What do you want to do that for? Life is good.' He's in love. The woman doesn't love him. He's 75."
Ms. McGowan had a story: "There was this Russian man and an Indian man. They'd come in here every night for weeks and sit in a booth in the back. Each of them would have steak and several Heinekens. Then they didn't come in for a while. I read in the magazine that the Russian guy was this big Russian spy and had been arrested. Scary. And they were good eaters."
Donald Manes, the Queens borough president who killed himself after becoming implicated in a bribery scandal, used to eat at the diner with regularity. He was in the Hilltop the day he took his life. Detectives later interviewed the staff about his meal.
"He had a fruit cup," Ms. Cestaro said. "Always something light, because he was watching his weight. Even on that last day."

THE BIG THREE
Lunch time. The place was pulsing with customers, their minds fixed on burgers deluxe and club sandwiches. The sizzle of bacon was audible. Steam puffed from the coffee urns. The cooks were bug-eyed, concentrating like clerics as they rhythmically churned out the platters.
Tensions between the waitresses and cooks get dicey when business picks up. A spirit of we're-all-in-this-together can rapidly deteriorate to acid sarcasm. The current waitresses and cooks get along tolerably. A decade ago, the kitchen staff was haughty -- and physically demonstrative. They would hurl things. Ms. Cestaro was struck by two raw eggs. "And I didn't do anything," she said. "But the cook said he couldn't throw them at the head waitress, so he threw them at me."
Only 11:30 and Ms. Cestaro already had a table of 12 teachers. Separate checks.
"You haven't experienced life until you've heard teachers order," Ms. Cestaro said. "They're not like anyone else. Very particular. Very diet-conscious. Very money-conscious. They get a lot out of a waitress."
For instance, the man at the head of the table. He has his coffee not in a china cup but in a cardboard container. He takes skim milk in a glass, and as soon as the glass is set down on the table, he covers it with a napkin. He eats only with plastic forks and spoons. He wants his coleslaw drained. His toast has to be rye and burnt. He insists his habits are not whimsy. He said he once had an infectious disease; now he is scrupulous about what he ingests.
The orders of the teachers in, the requests emerged unbidden.
"Do you have any milk?"
"Little more coffee here."
"I'm waiting on a Diet Coke."
"I need more bread, honey."
The fastidious man at the head of the table had ordered a spinach egg-white omelette, an extra large order of well-done home fries and burnt rye toast. He attacked it with plastic fork and knife.
Two minutes elapsed. Ms. Cestaro was summoned.
"The toast isn't burnt enough," the man declared, "and could I have some more fries?"
Enough with the teachers. Best now to slip into the next-to-last booth along the window and listen to the Big Three. The Big Three have been the Big Three only for a year, having derived from The Lunch Bunch.
They were all women who worked at nearby Queens General Hospital, where they first met in the cafeteria. The food not to their liking, they sought out an alternative and, 15 years ago, seized on the Hilltop. There were 14 at first. They came every day. A reservation sign would go on their table: "The Lunch Bunch."
Retirements and deaths thinned their ranks. Last year they were eight. Now they are three. The contraction has necessitated new nomenclature: "The Big Three." They are Elaine Brown in administration, Sherry Schoenfeld in purchasing and Yetta Maletzky in pathology.
The Big Three seem synecdochic of the diner as a whole: faithful lemmings who have found some hard-to-describe tranquillity here.
Their meals are slight. "We're always dieting," Ms. Brown said. "I have a muffin or a fruit cup. Cottage cheese and jello is a big favorite."
The patter is constant. "We cover the world," Ms. Maletzky said.
"Sometimes the other tables will get concerned," Ms. Brown said. "We do get a little risque. We talk about movies, about politics, about our friends now that they're not here."
Ms. Maletzky said, "Yeah, when you leave, we'll talk about you."
"A big topic is our husbands," Ms. Schoenfeld said. "They're always portrayed in an unfavorable light."
Several years ago, the diner was shuttered for a couple of months after a grease fire. The Lunch Bunch glumly trooped to Roy Rogers. "Oh, remember that?" Ms. Brown said. "It was horrible. Without a doubt, that was one of the worst times in my entire life."

THE SUPPLY GUY
It was now nearly five in the afternoon, a Tuesday. Seymour Gabaeff, the sales representative for Sysco, had merchandise to sell. Hilltop buys from about 15 suppliers. Much of the food comes from Sysco, the largest food supplier to the food services industry. It offers 26,000 different items.
"Someone called the other day and wanted a garden hose," Mr. Gabaeff said. "We had it. They needed it to wash down their garbage cans. We carry sinks. We have lightbulbs."
"O.K., Seymour, how about taking some business," Mr. Morfogen said.
Mr. Gabaeff got out a clipboard and carefully opened up his laptop computer. "I love diners," he said, "because they buy a lot. They have big menus. They're always open. Diners are great."
Mr. Morfogen: "Shrimp. What's your price?"
Mr. Gabaeff: "It's $8.74, same as last time."
"O.K., 50 pounds. Smoked mozarella, half a case. Please don't disappoint me on the smoked mozarella."
"I won't."
"One case of toothpicks for the club sandwiches."
"You want the bigger ones? They're the most popular."
"Yeah."
Mr. Morfogen brought over his Delicatessen Paper and said it was too small: "I can't even wrap an English muffin in it. I can't work with this."
"I have bigger."
"O.K., give me a case. Same price?"
"You're a headache. How can I give you bigger and charge the same price? I tell you, diners give too big a muffin. The portions are too big. People have to carry the stuff home. And I wish some diner would have the guts to make a smaller menu."

'A LOT OF STOMACHS'
Ten-minute break. The uncrowded pre-dinner staticness. John Morfogen sat down and polished off a turkey burger. Out of the corner of his eye, he spied a wad of gum stuck against the outside of the window. He summoned a busboy to remove it.
"This business is difficult because we're dealing with your stomach," he said. "People are very fussy with what they put in their stomach. In a diner, you see a lot of stomachs. So you better know what you're doing."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 4; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1126 words

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
If Wall St. Zigs, Find Markets That Zag

BYLINE: By KEN BROWN 

 BODY:
WITH the American stock market becoming more and more skittish, many investors may look abroad for safety. For while overseas investments are often seen as chancy and lucrative, they can also help to lower risk, like any other method of diversifying a portfolio.
The trick is to focus on whether the foreign market tracks the performance of Wall Street; if it does, investing there may not add to an investor's safety. But if the foreign market is only loosely related to the American market -- a relationship called "low correlation" -- an investment there can reduce a portfolio's risk. If American stocks fall, the idea goes, the out-of-sync overseas markets may not go down as far, or may not fall at all. 
 In a new study of such correlations, Smith Barney confirmed one primary and unsurprising pattern of this strategy. Comparing different countries with the United States during two five-year periods, 1986 to 1990 and 1991 to 1995, the researchers found that many developed countries were closely correlated to the American market and many emerging markets were not. With 1.0 indicating the highest possible correlation, for instance, Britain had a 0.60 correlation with the United States market from 1991 to 1995, while Thailand scored just 0.20.
Indeed, some emerging countries, like Peru, Turkey and Venezuela, actually have slightly negative correlations to the United States. That means that when the American market is down, theirs is up.
"There are some markets that move in their own step, no matter what has been going on in the United States," said Leila B. Heckman, the author of the study and Smith Barney's managing director of global asset allocation.
But the Smith Barney study also documented some exceptions to the rule. It identified several countries that although developed, had low correlations with the United States. Despite the close economic links between the two nations, for example, Japan had just a 0.20 correlation to the United States from 1991 to 1995. Italy, Austria and Denmark also had low correlations. In fact, Italy has shown just a 0.07 correlation with the United States in the last five years, the study said.
For investors who want to reduce their reliance on the American market but worry about investing in risky emerging countries, these four nations might provide a safer alternative.
But don't overdo it. The best way to lower a portfolio's risk is to invest in the emerging markets, which over all have the lowest correlation with the market in the United States, said George Foot, a partner with Newgate Management Associates.
"The broad brush of the low correlation is not in the developing markets, it's in the emerging markets," Mr. Foot said.
But, the study found, there are a few emerging nations that have high correlations with the United States. These include countries like Argentina and Hong Kong, with currencies pegged to the dollar. For investors looking to lower the risks of domestic exposure, these countries should be avoided.
But investors should know that the correlation tactic has always had a defect: In bad times, the linkages among markets get stronger. When the American market crashed in October 1987, for example, markets fell around the globe. Markets also move more closely together during periods of international crisis, like the Persian Gulf war, and during recessions, like the one in the early 1990's.
In other words, just when American investors may be looking for markets that are only loosely related to theirs, the markets of the world draw closer together.
For that reason, the Smith Barney study also looks at correlations during worrisome economic times -- specifically, when monetary conditions in the United States are getting tighter. That focus is particularly timely today, with interest rates continuing to rise. In fact, Smith Barney's "monetary pressure" index, which measures short- and long-term rates, turned negative on April 5 for the first time since January 1995. This may indicate that the monetary environment is turning adverse, Ms. Heckman said. In 1987, the index turned negative in April and did not turn positive until November, a month after the crash.
In this part of the study, Smith Barney looked at all those periods, from 1986 through 1995, when monetary policy was tightening in the United States. Then the researchers figured out the correlations of other countries to the American market during those periods. The idea: if investors look for countries that have low correlations in such adverse times, they may be able to avoid that perennial defect of the correlation strategy.
And, as it turns out, there are a good number of both developed and emerging markets that have had low correlations with the United States during times of monetary tightening. That is true even if one looks only at the countries that show low correlations at other times as well. Among them: the developed countries of Austria, Italy and Japan had correlations of 0.42, 0.40 and 0.36, respectively, during times of tight money. And among emerging countries, Colombia had a correlation of 0.04 and Taiwan had one of 0.45.
Of course, an investor must also evaluate the foreign market to see if it appears sound, whatever its correlation might be. If an investor has the jitters over the recent tensions between China and Taiwan, for example, he or she might want to skip putting assets into either.
Investing in an emerging market will not necessarily lower risk, said R. Sheldon Johnson, a managing director for equities at Morgan Stanley. Indeed, "an individual country on its own may give you higher risk," he said.
Over all, how would the correlation strategy translate into a real portfolio? The answer will vary from investor to investor. But generally, "to be well-positioned and well-diversified, an investor would have 10 to 20 percent of his portfolio outside the United States, and have emerging market exposure, especially in those emerging markets that are not closely tied to the dollar, and have some exposure to Japan," Ms. Heckman said.
Some experts quarrel with the "top down" direction of the correlation tactic, though. While some analysts say investors should pick their countries and then choose good companies within them, these experts say that good companies will thrive anywhere, even in a country with an unimpressive economy.
Ms. Heckman believes countries matter most, especially in emerging nations, where the biggest companies make up such large portions of the stock market's capitalization that they are, effectively, the market.
"The Telmexes of the world are going to be very closely correlated with the Mexican market," she said, alluding to that nation's giant telephone company.

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By HUBERT B. HERRING 

 BODY:

THE STOCK MARKET
What Goes Up Goes Where?
It was the battle of the cliches last week on Wall Street: "What goes up must come down" vs. "You can't miss with stocks." The "can't miss" theory got a resounding vote on word that we keep pouring staggering sums into mutual funds. Watch the superlatives pile up: the first quarter's $80 billion take shattered the previous record, with the $72 billion that went into stock funds exceeding the total for 1995's first seven months. Still, come down the market did, relentlessly -- with no big next-day bouncebacks, like soothing hot chocolate, to make it all better. What's happening? "Inflation!" cried the doomsayers, while optimists pointed, yet again, at the aging-baby-boomer savings juggernaut. Irresistible force, meet immovable object.
 
SUBSISTENCE
A 'Living Wage,' Locally
It's called the "minimum" wage -- a name that's more appropriate by the day. Inflation so eroded this base wage in the 80's that even if the Clinton team manages to cajole it up to $5.15 an hour from $4.25, it'll buy less than it did in the 70's. But now this battle has gone local, to cities like Baltimore, and has a new name, the "living wage" movement. Baltimore now demands that companies with city contracts pay at least $6.10 -- it goes to $6.60 in July -- and more than 30 other cities are also looking for ways to do at the local level what Congress has not seen fit to do nationwide. Baltimore's rule affects few workers, though, so living-wage advocates are calling for broader local action.
 
THE TOBACCO WARS
Smoking Documents?
The Great Tobacco Wars are marked by a lot of facts, a lot of haze. Here's a fact: the F.B.I. just got some documents. After that, the haze descends. Some lawyers say they are Philip Morris documents, the executive who'd squirreled them away begs to differ, and Philip Morris calls their release a "bizarre stunt." If they're the real thing, they just might provide a -- pardon the expression -- smoking gun on one smoldering issue: whether tobacco companies manipulated nicotine levels. A lawyer said one note read: "determine minimum nicotine drop to keep normal smokers hooked." It was, he said, dated Feb. 1, 1965 -- soon after the landmark Surgeon General's report, as Philip Morris was trying to design low-tar cigarettes.
 
On other fronts, a Mayo Clinic study suggested that when alcoholics smoke, it's the cigarettes that are more likely to kill them. Marlboro will be named to the Marketing Hall of Fame, the first tobacco product to get that honor. And R.J. Reynolds is gambling on a nearly smokeless cigarette.
 
FOLLOW THE FORTUNE
Duke, Father and Daughter
Speaking of tobacco, James Buchanan Duke and his daughter are both in the news. The daughter you know all about: Doris Duke, whose $1.2 billion estate has been a battleground since her death in 1993. Last week came a tentative settlement in which Bernard Lafferty, the butler-come-lately who'd been living in her mansions and jetting about in her plane, would get millions but no longer rule the roost. And her father, "Buck" Duke? Well, he's the one who made that fortune, as the turn-of-the-century founder of American Tobacco, the colossus that dominated the industry until the trust-busters got at it in 1911. His rough-and-tumble story is told in detail in "Ashes to Ashes," by Richard Kluger, a history of the tobacco wars just out from Alfred A. Knopf.
 
THE AGE OF PLASTIC
Farewell, Loose Change?
Watch out. They're trying to make our lives easier again. Who's "they"? Well, this time it's Citibank, Chase, Mastercard and Visa, which last week offered to let the world try cash that's been computer-imbedded in a plastic card. Just swipe it through some machine, you're $1.78 poorer, and the store is $1.78 richer. Why? Faster sales, more sales to those not endowed with exact change, fewer bank tellers -- the list goes on. But think of small rituals lost: the math lessons for schoolchildren in figuring change, the triumph of pointing out that you've been shortchanged, the moral dilemma -- keep it, or give it back? -- when you get too much. And as one citizen, echoing the lament of the plastic-carrying masses, put it, "Why do I need another card?"
 
ROARING FOR DOLLARS
Numbers, Hollywood Style
The numbers boggle the mind -- but it is Hollywood, after all. When Jeffrey Katzenberg left Disney in 1994, it seems, he expected 2 percent of the profits from all those money machines like "Beauty and the Beast" and "The Lion King." Hollywood heavyweights normally work these things out in whispers, but there is apparently such bad blood between Mr. Katzenberg and Michael Eisner, Disney's boss, that they couldn't. So Mr. Katzenberg sued last week, saying those profits now exceed $12.5 billion -- which puts his 2 percent at, yes, $250 million. A lion's ransom indeed.
 
DEVELOPER PLUS
Building for Real People
A socially conscious real estate developer. Hmmm. Sounds like an oxymoron. But then there's James W. Rouse, who died last week at 81. He "did more to revitalize American cities than anyone this century," said Donna Shalala, Health and Human Services Secretary. How? For one thing, he created Columbia, Md., a city designed to carve some order out of the chaos of postwar sprawl. And he invented the idea of inner-city "festival marketplaces" by creating Boston's Faneuil Hall, which counts South Street Seaport among its numerous offspring. But he was proudest of his late-in-life efforts to offer affordable housing, with his Enterprise Foundation building more than 40,000 units. Through it all, he had one passion: he watched people walk, talk and shop; he wanted real people to live in places he built. What a quaint idea.
 
FUEL EFFICIENCY
Some Guzzle, Some Don't
The fuel-efficiency news was all over the map last week. At one extreme, the Energy Department said it expected gasoline demand to set records this summer. One culprit is Americans' bizarre infatuation with gas-guzzling sport utility vehicles. (Do ads picture them in odd, wild places because they're searching desperately for gas stations?). Another is higher speed limits (because faster driving erodes efficiency). At the far side of the map, Honda introduced a new electric vehicle, to appear in California in the spring of '97 -- the first to use nickel-metal hydride batteries. It says this advanced technology greatly improves range, though the Honda EV still goes just 125 miles on a charge. The price, a big sticking point as electrics yearn for actual buyers, was not disclosed.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 6; Column 4; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1023 words

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
The $1 Billion Cure For Civic Insecurity

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
THE nation's cities are desperate in their courtship of baseball and football teams. Downtown revival, tourism, tradition, civic pride -- whatever the reasons, they have pleaded and wheedled and offered the owners the world to make themselves at home.
Now New York City has trumped them all. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and his aides spent much of last week touting a proposal to build the Yankees a new baseball stadium on the West Side of Manhattan -- at a cost, from $800 million to $1 billion, even more staggeringly out of the ball park than the average slugger's salary. 
 And as commonplace as superlatives may be in New York, that has raised a fundamental question, with profound public policy implications: Is the city nuts?
Not at all, the Mayor says. He has not only taken up a consultant's recommendation that the city and state build the stadium, but also insists it can be done with very little taxpayer money. He says he will be happy to debate the Democrats who would make it a campaign issue. And while neither the Mayor nor the Yankees' principal owner, George M. Steinbrenner 3d, has publicly declared an intention to abandon the team's home in the Bronx, it appears that many developers and business leaders are behind him.
 
 
 
Dismal Scientists
 But as the game of musical stadiums forces cities to open their coffers to team owners, experts on stadium finance have largely concluded that the new ball parks are not worth their price -- at least in the strict equation of economic development.
For all the attention they get, they say, teams like the Yankees remain small businesses -- and extra-small employers compared to any large corporation or manufacturer. A report by the city's Comptroller estimated that the Yankees and the related business they bring into New York generated about $5 million a year in tax revenues, a mere drop in the city's $32 billion budget.
And yet cities are willing to dole out millions of dollars in subsidies -- often far beyond those given to other businesses -- not only to build new stadiums but to keep them running year to year.
"It's better than building a pyramid, but not much better," said Roger G. Noll, a professor of economics at Stanford University and a visiting fellow at the Brookings Institution in Washington who argues that cities only stand to lose money on municipally funded stadiums.
But to hear the Mayor tell it, the city and state have no choice but to do all they can to keep Mr. Steinbrenner from acting on his thinly veiled threats to move to New Jersey or beyond -- and, Mr. Giuliani hints, thereby plunge New York into darkness and despair.
"It's economic, but it's more than economic," said Charles Millard, the president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, the agency overseeing plans for a new stadium not just for the Yankees, but the Mets. "It's psycho-economic."
Mr. Giuliani even says that the losses of the Brooklyn Dodgers and New York Giants in baseball and the Giants and Jets in football have come to symbolize the city's "virulently anti-business attitude" going back four decades. Indeed, it was four decades ago that a Mayor last lost a baseball team, and Mr. Giuliani emphatically does not want to be remembered for the same thing.
The Mayor said on Friday that a new stadium -- he favors a retractable dome and room for football, conventions and other events -- would reverse the decline. "We should be a city that thinks about expansion, not a city that thinks about contraction," he said on his weekly radio show.
Opponents of a new stadium have nonetheless seized on the economists' arguments. Mr. Giuliani's political rivals have said the city should offer to renovate Yankee Stadium if need be, as the Lindsay Administration agreed to do in the 1970's, but resist Mr. Steinbrenner's entreaties -- even if he moves to New Jersey as a result.
Borough President Fernando Ferrer of the Bronx said it was crazy to pay such a large price -- for reasons the Administration has not been able to explain, a new stadium is estimated to cost three to four times as much as the highly praised new ball parks in Baltimore and Cleveland -- for some intangible benefits to the city's ego.
"When you have schools crumbling throughout the city, roadways and bridges in disrepair, parks and playgrounds in dangerous shape, it's difficult to provide a rationale for spending almost a billion dollars just for the vanity," Mr. Ferrer said.
While the Mayor has acknowledged the need for at least some public spending for roads and mass transit, he says bonds could be repaid with a mother lode of revenues from increased attendance, concessions and advertising -- although Mr. Steinbrenner has his eye on those as well, and most independent experts are doubtful that such increases would materialize.
 
 
 
The Brooklyn Example
 Mr. Giuliani, a famously nostalgic Yankees fan who can recount games he has attended since his boyhood in Brooklyn, has also appealed to history. He argues that Walter O'Malley absconded with the Dodgers because Mayor Robert F. Wagner resisted his demand for city land.
The Dodgers' departure in 1957 did hurt the borough's pride. It is harder to argue, as the Mayor does, that it precipitated an economic decline, which certainly stemmed far more from the flight of manufacturers and the middle class. And politically, the move had little effect. A month after Mr. O'Malley announced his team would leave, Mr. Wagner handily won re-election. (Four years later, he won a third term.)
Arthur T. Johnson, a professor of political science at the University of Maryland in Catonsville and the author of a book on cities' efforts to attract minor league baseball, said that civic boosters tend to overrate the effects of new stadiums. He noted that Camden Yards has created a lot of civic enthusiasm but not an urban miracle. "There's a bar or two that are doing better," he said, "but they were already there."
Mr. Johnson nonetheless said the Mayor was right to say there would be intangible benefits. "Now," he said, "whether it's worth a billion dollars . . . ."

HEADLINE: The World;
In British Race, Blair Fits Bill

BYLINE: By JOHN DARNTON 

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
POLITICIANS in Britain sometimes look to the United States the way New Yorkers look to California -- to peer into the possible future. With a mixture of fascination and dread, they train their telescopes on the horizon and wonder which trends of public fickledom will blow their way and which newfangled techniques can be lifted for their own campaigns.
Thus, John F. Kennedy's victory in 1960 augured well for Labor, the Democrats' natural affiliate here, and his "New Frontier" seemed to find an echo in Harold Wilson's 1964 campaign pledge to forge a new prosperous era through the "white heat of technology." 
 In 1992, President George Bush's defeat brought gloom to the Conservatives of Prime Minister John Major, who had sent some Tory strategists to lend him a hand. By the same token, Mr. Clinton's win buoyed the hopes of Labor -- starving in opposition ever since Margaret Thatcher's election in 1979 -- that their day might soon be at hand.
Among the Laborites who crowded into a ballroom at London's Dorchester Hotel to celebrate the inauguration of Mr. Clinton, none were happier than a group of young Turks in the party called "modernizers." In the same way that Mr. Clinton as Governor of Arkansas had helped create a more conservative and popular wing of the Democratic Party, they were prodding Labor to turn its back on a tradition of trade union domination and socialist egalitarianism. This old-time religion, they calculated, offended the country's swing voters among middle-class English, snatching defeat from the jaws of victory time and time again.
This process -- of moving the Labor Party to the mainstream of British life -- was called "Clintonization" and its prime practitioner, who took over the mantle of party leadership when John Smith died of a heart attack in 1994, was Tony Blair. Last week Mr. Blair sat in the White House as a guest of President Clinton while on a trip to New York and Washington to bolster his international credentials.
 
 
 
Campaigns Ahead

Mr. Clinton and Mr. Blair have met before (at the funeral of Yitzhak Rabin in Israel and during a Presidential visit here last November), but this was their first opportunity for substantive talks. At some point, surely, their conversation turned to politics, since each of them is effectively at the beginning of a campaign. Mr. Clinton's contest in November against Senator Bob Dole will likely come first, because Mr. Major is able to put off the showdown with Mr. Blair until May 1997, though he retains the option of calling a snap election before then.
In both countries, the campaigns will play out against an uncertain economic background. In Britain, as in the United States, economic growth has been restored and both inflation and unemployment are low (the British figures are 2.7 percent and 7.9 percent respectively). But, again as in the United States, economic insecurity is rife, thanks to downsizing and corporate benefit-trimming. The Conservatives' main hope is to institute a dramatic tax cut in the next budget to reinforce their image as the cost-conscious party that keeps money in the pockets of wage-earners.
One major difference between the two contests, of course, is that Mr. Clinton is the incumbent and Mr. Blair is the challenger. Superficially at least, the candidates are somewhat alike, fast-talking men able to sketch out a vision of the way things should be, running against opponents who embody stolid virtues of the status quo and do not arouse much excitement on the stump.
 
 
 
Parallel Lives
 Mr. Blair, 43, is resolutely middle class; his father was a barrister, he went to a private secondary school in Scotland and then to St. John's at Oxford (where the Mr. Clinton was a Rhodes Scholar). From his student days in a rock group, he still plays the acoustic guitar (compared with Mr. Clinton's saxophone). He lives in a Victorian house in Islington (London's equivalent of the Upper West Side), favors pinstriped suits and is married to a high-powered barrister, Cherie Booth, who was recently made a Queen's Counsel, a member of the profession's inner sanctum. Already the Tory press is trying to draw a comparison to Hillary Rodham Clinton, which does not seem to fit but has forced Mr. Blair to insist that she would play no role whatsoever in his government.
In some ways -- his clean-cut looks, his Oxbridge accent and a to-the-manor-born confidence -- Mr. Blair seems more appropriate as a Tory leader than Mr. Major, now 53 but so heavily gray that he seems years older. The Prime Minister still carries the flat, unpretentious accent of suburban South London where he was raised; his parents were once variety-show performers who went into the garden ornament business, and he lacks a university degree. A fundamentally decent and modest man who is charming in a small group, he is not an instinctive politician and he has failed to ignite enthusiasm in the country at large, suffering the successor syndrome in the wake of Mrs. Thatcher much as Mr. Bush did following Ronald Reagan. He is behind in the polls, by over 20 points in all surveys, and is widely expected to lose. Last week the Conservatives lost a by-election, reducing their majority in Parliament to a single vote.
If Mr. Blair has an Achilles' heel, it's one he shares with Mr. Clinton. As conciliators and reformers who have moved their parties from traditional positions and ignored some traditional constituencies, both are charged by critics with lacking in bedrock convictions. Mr. Blair, who has praised the single-mindedness of Mrs. Thatcher's vision and has backed away from ideological pledges, is sometimes called Tony Blur by his detractors.
In an interview before leaving for the United States, Mr. Blair denied that the problems of the Clinton Administration in passing some of its programs served as a "negative role model," asserting that the American Constitution often forces the President to negotiate with Congress to get legislation passed. "It's not like here, where you get a government elected that has a majority in the House of Commons, that proposes legislation and then just pushes it through."

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Your Tax Cut Is in the Mail . . .

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
INCOME taxes are due tomorrow, and tonight many of you will labor at the dining-room table, awash in old mortgage statements, pecking at the calculator, cursing silently at the insatiable Federal maw. Then you'll write us a check.
But we in the Government want you to know that relief is on the way. Soon, we are going to cut your taxes. 
 Yes, yes; we said that in 1992. And in 1994. This time we mean it.
Our Republicans have promised, at last count, $200 billion in cuts over seven years -- a $500-a-child tax credit for working folk; breaks for adoptions, retirement, small business. President Clinton pledges $117 billion in givebacks -- a child credit; small business breaks; dispensations for college education, health care and retirement.
"Give the American people their balanced budget, a tax cut, lower interest rates and a brighter future!" he exhorted in January, in his State of the Union address. This is the least we can do, the Republicans reply. But first, about that budget.
Because we are giving some much-needed relief to you, the average American, we will have a little less money for us, the Government, to spend. Nine, maybe 10 billion dollars a year, on average, as the President reckons it, more under the Republican plan. But we doubt you will feel a thing.
Transportation might be a good place to trim. Mr. Clinton cut bus and subway subsidies earlier in his term, and now Republicans want to as well. Local transit agencies will lose some grant money, of course, and they may have to hike fares or cut service. That is what they did in 1995, anyway; New York City's fares rose 25 cents, and the subway here in Washington cost a dime more. Over a 48-week work year -- four weeks off, right? -- 25 cents each way is a measly, lessee . . . $120. Heck, most of you don't even ride the train.
 
 
 
Go for Education
 Of course, wiping out transit subsidies altogether would only save $2 billion a year, hardly enough to finance even the "modest" tax reduction that Mr. Clinton supports. But huge chunks of the Government's domestic spending consists of grants to the states and other pass-throughs.
Cutting Education Department grants to school districts, most of them in low-income areas, would save $7 billion or more. Job-training programs, mostly grants, eat up $4.4 billion of Mr. Clinton's 1997 budget. Maybe these could go.
Many public schools do lean heavily on Federal aid to educate the poor; they could raise property taxes instead, assuming that residents of low-income districts can pay them. Wealthier districts will not find this a problem, and for most of you it wouldn't be more than a few hundred dollars a year.
The loss of job-training programs conceivably could push a few more workers onto the welfare rolls. But plans are to shift many welfare duties to the states anyway; this is their citizens' problem.
We in Government spent scads of money last year -- hundreds of millions of dollars -- insuring mortgages and guaranteeing home loans for certain people, like young families, that lack terrific credit or a big down payment. Curbing these programs would save us money. Of course, it would raise borrowing costs for those families; raise an 8.5 percent mortgage on a $100,000 loan by one point, and it racks up $25,920 in additional payments over 30 years.
No doubt you know some of these programs have already been trimmed, that others are politically sacrosanct, and that further deep cuts, much less abolition, are a chancy thing. Sadly, this may be true.
"Where are we after a year's bloodletting?" in the Republican-Democratic spending wars, Robert O. Reischauer, the Brookings Institution scholar and former congressional budget guru, asked last week. "Nowhere," he answered.
So a tax cut might better be paid for from the big pots of money -- like Medicare, Medicaid and such. Siphoning $10 billion from the $260 billion a year poured into Medicare and Medicaid would be a piece of cake, except that both programs also face major cost-cutting as part of the deficit-reduction program.
 
 
 
Old Complainers
 We in Government could pay for your tax cut by raising Medicare premiums by, say, $200 a year, but the elderly would protest. Or we could raise from 1.45 percent to 1.6 percent the payroll tax that swells Medicare's hospital trust fund; that would raise the bite on a $50,000-a-year salary from $725 to $800. It would be easier to reduce Government payments to doctors and hospitals that treat Medicare and Medicaid patients, and let them pass on the cost to other patients; how would they ever know?
The truth, however, is that benefit programs are even harder to cut than ordinary domestic spending. Witness this year's budget battle, in which Congress and Mr. Clinton failed to agree on a single spending reduction in a major entitlement program.
We could always finance your tax cut painlessly, as we have for decades, by adding to the Federal deficit. All right, not entirely painlessly: a $10 billion loan to the Treasury at 5.5 percent simple interest would cost $550 million a year before the first penny of principal was retired, and we would have to borrow another $9 billion or $10 billion every year.
A lot of economists argue that this kind of borrowing also saps productivity, by soaking up money that would otherwise be spent to update factories and educate workers, and thus lowers our standard of living. And they say it pushes up interest rates by reducing the amount of money available for other loans, thereby making everything more costly. Indeed, this is why we wanted to get the deficit down to zero to begin with.
You may be getting the impression that a tax cut is a lot like Bat Day at the ball park: an apparent freebie whose cost actually is tacked on to the hot dogs or the stadium parking or the souvenir program. You may think that there is no free lunch.
Well, you are wrong. There is one painless way to pay for a tax cut. It consists of eliminating pork in that packinghouse of political largess, the Federal highway program. We spend $19 billion a year to help states build roads. We shall cut it in half.
Granted, that is a bit stiff. Some states might raise income taxes to offset the loss, and many would probably pare back repairs and construction.
But a few more potholes or traffic jams would be little bother. Heck, most of you can take the train anyway.

HEADLINE: Ruling in Price-Fixing Case Provides a Look at Drug Industry

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Providing a look at rarely publicized internal discussions in the pharmaceutical industry, a Federal judge has quoted from sealed industry documents that compare the industry to a cartel, or "kind of an OPEC," which, the judge said, shared information on pricing and competition.
Judge Charles P. Kocoras of Federal District Court in Chicago included the remarks in a 76-page decision he issued last week in ordering a trial of drug manufacturers in a lawsuit brought by independent retail pharmacies. They are accusing 22 drug manufacturers of illegally conspiring to fix prices by offering discounts to health maintenance organizations and others but not to retail pharmacies. 
 The drug companies deny any wrongdoing. They say the retailers do not get the discounts because pharmacies do not influence sales volume and market share.
Lawyers for the pharmacies said hundreds of documents detailing industry practices had been produced since the first class-action suit was filed in October 1993. All these documents are sealed, but Judge Kocoras quoted from a number of them.
The judge said it was "unquestionable" that the companies "had the opportunity to conspire." He added that there was "evidence of seminars and trade association meetings, which virtually every defendant attended at one time or another, and a coordinated exchange of pricing and other competitive information shared among the manufacturers."
An internal memorandum from the files of Abbott Laboratories alluded to the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, a trade group, as "kind of an OPEC" -- the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. The writer, who was not identified, was summarizing a discussion about whether to provide discounts to mail-order drug distributors.
The first participant "that breaks away from the cartel will reap the maximum advantage," the Abbott memorandum said. It added, "Of course, we do not want to be perceived by our brethren on the P.M.A. as black sheep."
Judge Kocoras said, "Such evidence supports the plaintiffs' notions of manufacturer interdependence."
A spokesmen for Abbott declined to comment.
Abbott Laboratories quit the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association in 1993. Abbott did not respond to a request to explain its departure, and a spokesman for the trade group, now called the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers Association of America, also declined to comment on the case or on Abbott's decision to quit the group.
At a follow-up hearing on Thursday, Judge Kocoras indefinitely postponed the trial date and invited lawyers to comment on his ruling of April 4, when he ordered the trial. Lawyers for the manufacturers said they would ask the judge to allow an immediate appeal, based on his dismissal from the case of six drug wholesalers. At the same time, he also threw out a proposed $408.9 million settlement of the suit.
The judge said in his ruling that the independent pharmacies could seek damages from the manufacturers even though wholesalers supplied 80 percent of their drugs. Some lawyers said the class-action case could collapse if a higher court rejected this interpretation.
The retail pharmacies say they are entitled to the same type of discounts on drugs that health maintenance organizations and hospitals get. A recent study by an economist at the University of Minnesota, Stephen W. Schondelmeyer, said that giving such discounts to retailers could expand competition and reduce prices to consumers by 12 percent.
Chain drugstores, which have filed a separate suit accusing the manufacturers of price discrimination, said their case would not be affected. "Nothing happened in Thursday's hearing that reduces the strength of the evidence," said Phil Schneider, a spokesman for the National Association of Chain Drugstores.
Judge Kocoras also quoted from other documents from the manufacturers' files. For example, he said, a Ciba-Geigy memorandum on Sept. 4, 1985, concerned requests for discounts by retail-pharmacy buying groups.
"It would be hoped that all drug companies would reject these offers," the Ciba memorandum said. Replying the next day, a second Ciba memorandum called the issue a "potentially dangerous situation," and asked, "Is the P.M.A. taking steps to assure that companies are united on this issue, and can we put pressure on them toward this end?"
Rich Salem, a spokesman for Ciba, said the documents were "written by low-level field force personnel who neither understood nor directed Ciba pricing policies."
Some defendants, Judge Kocoras said, "strive to distinguish their pricing policies from the other defendants," and others "claim they were either not present or were not involved during critical meetings at which allegedly 'conspiratorial conduct' occurred."
He quoted from statements that appeared to undermine some of the company arguments: Abbott Laboratories listed "the power of retail pharmacies first" among market forces that "could negatively affect Abbott's market share and margins." Similarly, Lilly listed pharmacists first among people who are not doctors who would significantly influence decisions on prescription drugs in the 1990's.
And a January 1992 memorandum by the Searle unit of the Monsanto Company said that chain drugstores "can have a significant influence over dispensing Searle products."
A Merck & Company memorandum said the 368-store Big B Inc. pharmacy chain, based in Birmingham, Ala., had "the determination, the financing, the ability to shift market share" that would justify offering them Merck's special managed care "initiative." A spokesman for Merck declined to comment.
Janice Toran, a Searle lawyer, said that at this stage in the process: "The judge must look at the evidence in the light most favorable to the plaintiffs. We remain confident that the court will find that we did not engage in illegal pricing when it makes its decision on the merits."
