HEADLINE: Face-Off;
North Korea Wouldn't Invade the South, Would It?

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
EVERY evening, South Korean soldiers rake some beautiful white beaches, smoothing out the sand from one end to the other. It is not to make it prettier, for no one is allowed in the area at night: the point is to be able to check for footprints in the morning to see if a new Korean War is breaking out.
These days, the beaches are being raked more carefully than ever. Three times this month, heavily armed North Korean troops entered the demilitarized zone between the two Koreas, violating the terms of the armistice that has kept the peace since the end of the Korean War. 
 The incursions have also triggered a furious debate within American intelligence circles. The clear majority view, and the one that most top American officials subscribe to, is that North Korea would not be so foolish as to launch a suicidal attack on the South. The minority view is at the other extreme: these Government analysts argue that North Korea may be trying to desensitize the West to incursions in preparation for a major invasion in the coming months.
Yet even though policy makers subscribe to the majority view, and do not believe the North will attack, they worry enough that President Clinton has adjusted his schedule to extend talks with South Korean leaders during a visit to South Korea on Tuesday. While many believe that an invasion is highly unlikely, they also realize that they cannot afford to be wrong -- and the starting point for North Korea watchers is that no one really knows what is going on there.
 
 
 
Run, DMZ
 Everybody has a good reason for North Korea not invading: it would lose -- although it is not clear whether the North realizes this. Motivations for why it might invade are trickier and mostly have to do with its disastrous economic situation. The fear is that North Korea might attack in a desperate gamble to avoid collapse, perhaps even to force negotiations with the United States leading to a peace treaty and normalized political and trade relations.
"We worry that in a very short period, this country will either collapse or take aggressive actions against the South in a desperate attempt to divert attention from its internal situation," Gen. Gary E. Luck, the top American commander in South Korea, told Congress last month. "It is entirely possible that the leadership in Pyongyang is not, or will not remain, cohesive enough to make rational decisions."
For all the disagreement about the likelihood of war, there is a consensus about how it would begin. The North would infiltrate some of its 80,000-strong special forces into areas of South Korea far from the front lines, American and South Korean military experts say. The commandos would arrive by hovercraft, light planes, submarines and boats, and that is why the South Koreans still rake some beaches to check for footprints -- although these days they look more for radar images of infiltrators.
 
 
 
Havoc
 These elite North Korean troops would proceed to attack command posts, destroy American and South Korean military aircraft and create havoc in South Korea. At about the same time, North Korea would launch a huge artillery barrage against South Korean and United States military forces, as well as key Government ministries in Seoul. South Korea has the misfortune of having a capital just 30-odd miles south of the border.
North Korean tanks and trucks would also be expected to pour across the border. The southern side of the border is very well-defended with antitank ditches, concrete walls and other barriers, though, forcing North Korean tanks into narrow "killing zones" where South Korean and American forces would focus their firepower.
To avoid these South Korean defenses, North Korea's infantry would use tunnels dug by its army underneath the border. So far four tunnels have been found, the deepest 450 feet beneath the surface, but South Korean experts say that based on accounts by defectors they believe there are about 20 more such tunnels. Intelligence analysts estimate that just the four tunnels discovered so far would allow 10,000 troops per hour to enter South Korea.
To slow any invaders, South Korean bridges and roads either have explosives built in or have places for explosives to be inserted and detonated quickly. Huge rock fields have been built above key roads, so that an explosive can send boulders hurtling down to block the roads.
North Korean engineering teams would be charged with clearing the roads and fording the broad Imjin River to get to Seoul. Apparently with Seoul in mind, the North Korean Army has devoted considerable resources to river-crossing units, for it has 600 amphibious vehicles and 2,300 prefabricated sections for bridges.
The North Korean aim, military officers say, would be to capture Seoul in a blitzkrieg attack, before American reinforcements could arrive from Japan, Europe and the United States. One other way North Korea might try to slow reinforcements would be to attack American air bases in Japan, possibly with missiles.
Although North Korea may have a couple of nuclear weapons, it is not clear how they could be delivered, and American planners are more worried by the North's 1,000-ton stockpile of chemical weapons.
"I think you would probably see the first major use of chemical agents since World War I," said an American military expert who is in the minority predicting a strong chance of war. "If they were to decide to depopulate Seoul before taking it, they could probably do it with very little defense on our part."
 
 
 
Certain Defeat
 Still, American planners say that the United States and South Korea would quickly establish air and naval superiority. Most say that North Korea would be a far more credible opponent than Iraq was in the Gulf war, but there is virtual unanimity that in the end the North Korean regime would be destroyed. North Korea's invasion scenario now is not so different from the one that played out in 1950, when it launched the Korean War -- except that now South Korea has a formidable army, backed by the United States. And this time, China -- which is no longer particularly friendly to North Korea and even has border disputes with it -- almost certainly will not send its army to rescue the North when it gets in trouble.
That is the best argument for presuming that North Korea will not invade: it would be suicide. But does the North know that?
"The problem is not that North Korea can defeat us, but that they think they can," said the American Government expert who worries about an invasion soon. This official, like some others, is afraid that the North Koreans will find the alternative -- not invading -- also suicidal. Almost everyone believes that North Korea is on a trajectory toward collapse.
"The situation for the regime in North Korea is not sustainable, because their economy and their agriculture are continuing to get worse and worse, and then they had those horrible floods last summer," said Col. John W. Reitz, a spokesman for the American forces in Korea. "The end for that regime is in sight; we just don't know when."
 
 
 
Conflicting Signals
 One cause for concern is that North Korea last fall repositioned heavy guns and military aircraft closer to the border. One group of Il-28 bombers now can reach Seoul in just six minutes.
There are also many contrary signals: North Korea's military exercises have been at an unusually low level in recent months, and satellites have spotted no unusual mobilizations of North Korea's 1.2 million-member armed forces. On the other hand, its troops are already massed on the border, and so American military planners worry that they might not have much warning before their radar screens began lighting up with incoming missiles and artillery shells.

HEADLINE: Key Mandela Aide to Join Group Promoting Investment by Blacks

BYLINE: By SUZANNE DALEY 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, April 13

 BODY:
Cyril Ramaphosa, widely considered a possible successor to President Nelson Mandela, said today that he would be leaving the South African Government to become a senior executive in a business conglomerate.
The move would appear to enhance greatly the position of a Deputy President, Thabo Mbeki, as front- runner for the post-Mandela presidency. Some of Mr. Ramaphosa's supporters were quick to point out that he could make a comeback if he chooses to. He will not be giving up his position as secretary general of President Mandela's party, the African National Congress. 
 At a news conference in Cape Town with Mr. Mandela, Mr. Ramaphosa, 43, a lawyer and former trade unionist who played a key role in negotiations to end apartheid, said South Africa needed more competent blacks in the business sector.
"There is an overconcentration of capable people in Parliament and Cabinet," Mr. Ramaphosa said. "We need more black people at a senior level to begin to transform the economy, and I want to play a role."
Mr. Ramaphosa said he intended to join New Africa Investments Ltd., known as NAIL, after he finishes his current job, leading the committee that is writing South Africa's new constitution. The work is to be finished next month.
The details of Mr. Ramaphosa's new job were not announced, but it is widely understood that he wants to take part in one of South Africa's most interesting business efforts -- the transfer of major divisions of South Africa's multibillion-dollar conglomerates to blacks.
New Africa Investments, which already owns shares in a cellular telephone company, a major insurer and The Sowetan newspaper, is trying to buy 48 percent of the Johnnies Industrial Corporation (Johnnic), a division of the Anglo American Corporation.
Johnnic, which began as a mining house with interests in gold, diamonds, platinum and coal, has major investments in everything from business publications to breweries to Toyota of South Africa. Anglo American is offering the division only to black buyers.
But New Africa Investments, whose chairman is Dr. Ntatho Motlana, Mr. Mandela's personal doctor and a Soweto businessman and politician, is apparently having difficulty raising the money. Mr. Ramaphosa may be able to give the company the credibility to raise the $1 billion it needs to buy Johnnic.
Mr. Mbeki, the Deputy President, emerged as the front-runner for Mr. Mandela's job shortly after the 1994 elections, when Mr. Mandela picked him as his First Deputy President. Mr. Mbeki spent 28 of his 54 years in exile, many of them as an envoy of the African National Congress. He is known for his diplomatic skill and his charm, but is considered a shrewd, even ruthless politician.
When Mr. Mbeki was chosen as a Deputy President, Mr. Ramphosa, who is 11 years younger, declined a job in the cabinet and agreed to head the Constitutional Assembly.
At the news conference today, Mr. Mandela praised Mr. Ramaphosa's work in Government and seemed to suggest that joining the private sector was simply an extension of his political work. Mr. Mandela has forbidden members of the Government to hold directorships or take other lucrative offers from corporations.
The President said, "His presence in the private sector will further cement the critical partnership between the A.N.C. and Government on the one hand, and business, the trade union movement and the rest of civil society on the other."
Supporters of Mr. Ramaphosa say his shift to business may help him should he return to politics. While others struggle with the bureaucracies and fiscal difficulties of the Government, he should find it relatively easy to make impressive strides toward empowering black business executives, his supporters say.

HEADLINE: A Hospital Worries About 'People Who Fall Through the Cracks'

DATELINE: LONG BRANCH, N.J.

 BODY:
For most of his life, William Logan worked in heavy construction, and he was always able to get decent health insurance through the union. Then the heart problems started. He lost his job, and a succession of other jobs didn't pay well and didn't come with health benefits.
Without health insurance, Mr. Logan, 50, has been receiving free medical care at Monmouth Medical Center. Doctors here installed a pacemaker, and Mr. Logan returns regularly to the outpatient clinic for checkups. 
 "Any time you have a problem, you get taken care of here," Mr. Logan said on a recent clinic visit as nurses checked his blood pressure and lectured him on his diet.
Officials at Monmouth Medical Center, a 527-bed teaching hospital just a few blocks from the ocean and far from the state's large cities, said they have provided millions of dollars in free medical care to the uninsured this year without any reimbursement from the state. And the $6.9 million they received from the state last year, they said, did not cover the year's $11.9 million cost of charity care. New Jersey distributed $388 million for charity care last year to hospitals around the state, but Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and the Legislature have been unable to come up with a plan to pay for it this year.
Most of the beneficiaries are like Mr. Logan. They do not earn enough to afford private health insurance, and yet are ineligible for Medicaid, which serves the poor and disabled.
"These are the people who fall through the cracks," said Christopher M. Dadlez, president of Monmouth Medical Center. "When we had commercial insurers, some of this burden was passed off to the insurers. But the insurers don't want that burden. Managed care certainly does not want it, so the hospitals are taking it on the chin. The state is asking private, not-for-profit hospitals to assume the entire burden of care for the indigent. That is extremely difficult and extremely expensive."
In New Jersey, where there are no acute-care county or municipal hospitals, the state reimbursed 84 hospitals for a significant portion of the free care they provided last year. Most states do not.
Charity care in New Jersey was financed by a surcharge on patient bills until the state in 1993 began taking $1.6 billion from the unemployment compensation fund to pay the bill. But the authority to continue dipping into that fund expired on Dec. 31.
On April 15, the state will miss its third monthly payment. Mr. Dadlez and other hospital administrators around the state say that unless they begin receiving reimbursement, they will be forced to shut down outpatient clinics, close wards and lay off staff. Many hospitals have already delayed payments to suppliers.
Mr. Dadlez said the number of uninsured patients has risen 30 percent at his hospital in six years. While part of the increase is due to people losing decent-paying jobs with benefits, Mr. Dadlez attributed much of the increase to the expansion of Monmouth's outpatient clinics, a move intended in part to draw patients away from costly treatment in Monmouth's emergency room. The clinics have also drawn patients who might have gone to other nearby hospitals.
"As other hospitals are ratcheting down their accessibility to free care, we are assuming a larger percentage of that population," he said. He estimates the charity care bill will exceed $15 million this year.
Faced with plummeting payments from insurers, and huge cuts proposed in Medicaid and Medicare, Mr. Dadlez said the hospital has reduced costs by $27 million in recent years even as the uninsured patient volume has risen.
"We are trying to be very responsible community partners, and do our best," Mr. Dadlez said. "But it is very unreasonable for the public to think that the hospitals can carry this burden and survive and still have the type of facilities that the public expects in terms of the technology and the services."

GRAPHIC: Photo: William Logan, 50, has no health insurance but receives free care at Monmouth Medical Center in Long Branch, N.J. The hospital expects to spend $15 million on charity care this year, and administrators worry that if the state does not come up with a way to pay for it, they might have to shut clinics and lay off staff. (Norman Y. Lono for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Money Arriving Soon for Summer Job Programs

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 13

 BODY:
Cities and towns trying to set up summer jobs programs for poor youths will have to scramble because the $625 million from the Federal Government to pay for them are just becoming available after being held up by the budget fight.
Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said on Friday that the money would be released immediately to allow localities to find schools, teachers, supervisors, work sites and jobs and to recruit applicants. 
 California will receive the largest allocation, $111 million, to create 96,013 jobs, while $49 million will go to Texas to create 43,151 jobs, and $43 million will be sent to New York for 37,856 jobs.
The states receiving the lowest number of jobs are Delaware, Nebraska, North Dakota, South Dakota, Vermont and Wyoming. Under the guidelines issued on Friday, Connecticut will receive $5.26 million to create 4,544 jobs, while New Jersey is to obtain nearly $18.4 million for 15,889 jobs.
Because of the budget delays, Mr. Reich said, cities and states still will have to "work double time" to get their programs in place in time.
The programs are estimated to provide summer work for 539,500 youths 14 to 21 years old.
The Government is usually able to advise cities and states well in advance of summer how much money is available.
Congressional Republicans have now agreed to permit the Administration to give the program at 75 percent of last year's level, the Labor Department said. The money is still awaiting appropriation.
The program provides public-sector jobs for youths who live in areas with high unemployment. Participants can earn $1,100 to $1,400 during the summer.
Jobs include clerical positions, maintenance work, park and recreation activities, hospital employment, aiding the elderly and tutoring and assisting at day-care centers.
But Mr. Reich said despite the Government money, the private sector is urgently needed to create more summer jobs. He said a study indicated that there were more than two eligible youths for every public-sector job.
"Because our summer job funding is reduced this year, it is even more critical that farsighted business leaders create private-sector summer jobs as an investment in the future of their own companies, communities and the young people of this nation," he said.

HEADLINE: Swirling Around Unabom Suspect, an Environmental Dispute

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER 

DATELINE: LINCOLN, Mont., April 11

 BODY:
In the last half-dozen years that Theodore J. Kaczynski has lived his solitary, lonely life just outside this rugged mountain hamlet, a plan to gouge out one of the biggest open-pit gold mines has bitterly divided the people here.
Some said the mine proposed by Phelps Dodge, the principal partner in the project, would infuse much-needed cash into the hardscrabble local economy. But environmentalists argue that the mine would threaten the habitat of the Blackfoot River, the setting for the book and movie "A River Runs Through It," and endanger the range of the elk, deer, bears, antelope and bald eagles that roam the area. 
 The Seven-Up Pete Mine -- named for an old-time prospector who favored a poker game in which seven cards are dealt face up -- would drastically change the wilderness the suspect in the Unabom case chose as his refuge from modern technological society. Many mountain slopes in the area have already been stripped bare by logging.
In Lincoln, herds of deer, many known by pet names, roam the yards around the yellow blinking light that marks the center of town and nibble from feeders. Public spaces are like the inside of a diorama, filled with animals, most of them horned, that have been shot and stuffed. Men drink and eat with their hats on.
The hermit-like Mr. Kaczynski rarely spoke to anyone here, and then only briefly, so there is no clear public record of how he felt about the mine.
Becky Garland, a strong opponent of the mine and the town resident who seems to have had the longest personal conversation with Mr. Kaczynski -- a 20- to 25-minute talk -- says he talked about his need for a job, his lonely childhood and a lost love and did not even mention the mining project.
The controversy about the mine has taken on some significance in the Unabom investigation because since the project was proposed, the Unabomber appears to have shifted his targets, from people connected with universities, airlines or computers to those linked to environmental issues.
The last two victims killed were Gilbert P. Murray, the head of a Sacramento timber lobbying group who was killed in December 1994, and Thomas J. Mosser, a public relations executive killed in his New Jersey home in April 1995. Mr. Mosser's company did some work for Exxon, and the authorities believe that the bomber thought, apparently erroneously, that the company had tried to clean up the oil company's image after the Valdez oil spill in Alaska. Over all, the Unabomber has killed 3 people and injured 23.
In wondering whether Mr. Kaczynski is the Unabomber, people here have been asking themselves what he might have thought about the mine. Phelps Dodge says the mine would produce 3.7 million ounces of gold and 8 million ounces of silver over 15 years and would be expected to stay open for 25 years. The company says it would employ up to 390 people with an annual payroll of $13 million, although many of these would be heavy-equipment operators and other technically skilled personnel brought in from outside. It says it would spend around $45 million on goods and services locally.
To get at the gold, the mine would operate around the clock, grinding up a small mountain south of the Bob Marshall and Scapegoat Wilderness Areas, some of the nation's most pristine wild lands. The miners would set explosives in the rocks, grind up the debris and, finally, leach out the gold by sloshing a cyanide solution over the rubble. The mountain would be reduced to a huge pit; when the operation was finished, the mine company says, it would leave a recreational lake behind.
But environmentalists say the project would destroy the habitats of bull trout and wetslope cutthroat trout in the Blackfoot River. These fish depend on the clear, cold water of the river and its tributaries, which is already so polluted that the fishing scenes in the movie "A River Runs Through It" had to be filmed elsewhere.
The project could bring money here, but it has driven a wedge into the community, even splitting families.
At a family dinner on Easter Sunday, Tony Wood, whose relatives run the Lincoln Lodge Motel and hope that the mine would bring in business, shifted uncomfortably as he told of his opposition: "This is personal. I've hunted elk up there since I was old enough to carry a rifle."
In Lincoln, a wide space on Montana Route 200 that supports five bars, two snowmobile dealerships, an artist who carves figures of cowboys out of tree trunks with a chain saw and a very busy taxidermist, Mr. Kaczynski, with his matted hair, wild beard and gamy smell did not stand out at all.
In fact, he was nothing, a number of people volunteered, compared with a bunch called the Cabbage Patch Gang, so called because they live on Sauerkraut Creek. They really stink, townspeople said, and they wear long knives and sometimes come into town reeking of alcohol to tear up the bars.
Two years ago, in the summer, Mr. Kaczynski approached Ms. Garland, a lifelong resident who now has a business restoring ecologically damaged trout streams but was then managing Garlands, her family's dry goods and sporting equipment store. Mr. Kaczynski often stopped by the store for fishing lures, batteries and other necessities of his primitive backwoods life in an isolated 10-by-12-foot shack. But this time, he wanted to ask for advice and help in finding a job.
Ms. Garland was surprised, she said, because Mr. Kaczynski rarely spoke unless spoken to. When she agreed to talk, they set a time, and he arrived on the porch of the store to give her a three-page letter, handwritten on what she remembered as small note paper, describing his high I.Q., his advanced schooling in his early years and his education at Harvard, as well as briefly mentioning his loneliness.
"He talked of being very young, being younger than his classmates," Ms. Garland remembered. "He talked of not having friends. It seemed like he was unable to be a boy.
"He did write about having a relationship with someone at one time that didn't work out," she said. "I think he wrote the letter so he didn't have to speak about these things, so he didn't have to talk a lot. He wrote about being with classmates who were older and about being very shy."
The conversation lasted about 20 or 25 minutes, Ms. Garland said. "We sat and spoke about his wanting to get a job," she said, remembering the longest conversation she has had with a man who lived here for 20 years. "I assumed he would probably be best at research, and I gave him the names of a few organizations that I knew of.
"He was no different that day then any other day," she said. "He was just Ted. He was always quiet, shy and mannerly."
Most of the horde of journalists who stormed through Lincoln last week are gone now. But Federal Bureau of Investigation agents are still painstakingly combing through the small cabin where Mr. Kaczynski lived and where they have recovered what they say is a draft of the Unabomber's manifesto, one live bomb, a partially assembled one and what may be important evidence of handmade screws used to assemble bombs, which could provide an ironclad maker's signature. The agents have checked fly-fishing shops, interviewed a woman who sometimes cut Mr. Kaczynski's hair and even taken the envelope of wild white carrot seeds he once gave Ms. Garland's sister, Theresa.
Local entrepreneurs at enterprises like the bars and the volunteer fire department are doing a land-office business in "Home of the Unabomber" T-shirts. Local radio stations and newspapers have been running contests for new state slogans like "Montana -- the Last, Best Place to Hide," "Big Scare Country" and "At Least Our Cows Are Sane."
Theresa Garland remembers discovering a couple of years ago that Mr. Kaczynski, like her, was interested in gardening.
"I was really happy that after all these years, I finally had something to talk to him about," she said. "For all the years that Ted lived here, you could mush all our conversations into half an hour."

HEADLINE: $1.23 Billion Is Pledged In New Aid For Bosnia

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, April 13

 BODY:
Cash-strapped governments and international institutions around the world promised $1.23 billion more in aid today to help rebuild shattered roads, power grids and homes in Bosnia and Herzegovina, bringing the total pledged this year to more than $1.8 billion.
The Bosnian Serbs were invited, along with other Bosnian representatives, but refused to come as part of a single Bosnian delegation and spell out their needs. American officials here said their government, called the Republika Srpska, will get no money as long as men indicted for war crimes remain at the head of it. 
 "U.S. law presently precludes our assistance going to the Republika Srpska, or the U.S. supporting international financial institutions' loans to it," said Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers, who came with $21 million in addition to the $260.7 million in previously pledged or announced American funds for economic reconstruction in Bosnia this year.
But the European co-organizers of the conference said that international aid should eventually go to all three communities in Bosnia -- Serbs as well as Muslims and Croats -- if they comply with the peace agreement, including provisions barring the current Serb leaders from running in elections this fall.
"Assistance should be administered throughout Bosnia and Herzegovina, that is to all parties in the country, but it remains conditional on full compliance by all the parties," said the European Union commissioner, Hans van den Broek, who is co-chairman of the conference with the president of the World Bank, James D. Wolfensohn.
Carl Bildt, the international coordinator for civilian implementation of the Bosnia peace accords, said that, although "the forces of ethnic separation are still stronger than the forces of ethnic reintegration," aid for the right kind of projects -- the transportation, communications and power networks needed for economic recovery -- would encourage Bosnia's separate communities to draw back together.
Mr. Bildt blamed Radovan Karadzic, the Bosnian Serb leader, and Gen. Ratko Mladic, the Serb military commander, for preventing Serbs from attending the conference.
"Individuals indicted for war crimes are running loose on the territory of the Federation as well as of the Serb Republic," Mr. Bildt said, referring to the two loosely joined entities in postwar Bosnia, the Muslim-Croat Federation and the Republika Srpska. "But the fact that Mr. Karadzic and Mr. Mladic are still trying to hang on to public office is particularly provocative -- and cannot be tolerated for long."
Hasan Muratovic, the Bosnian Prime Minister and a Muslim, said: "The conference has met our expectations. There cannot be stable peace in Bosnia and Herzegovina until elementary social and economic problems are resolved."
He said that total physical damage amounted to $80 billion and that the main economic problems now were how to create jobs for 700,000 people, one from each family, and to accommodate millions of refugees.
The World Bank has estimated that about $5.1 billion in international aid will be needed over the next three to four years, about $3.7 billion for the Muslim-Croat Federation and $1.4 billion for the Serb-controlled Republica Srpska.
Mr. Wolfensohn said the World Bank would increase its contribution by $160 million to $200 million this year, bringing the total to $310 million to $350 million.
The bank has designed 14 priority reconstruction projects for this year and next that will cost an estimated $1.3 billion, with the seed money provided by the bank. These include such things as repairing water and sewer networks in major cities, repairing bridges and clearing mines, treating war injuries, repairing municipal heating networks, and helping people with home repairs and starting small businesses.
But so far, officials here said, projects affecting Serbian areas are only in the discussion stage.
Most American economic reconstruction aid will be disbursed in dozens of projects administered by the Agency for International Development. Craig G. Buck, director of the agency's programs in Bosnia, said that he hoped to start making $138 million in loans to Bosnian communities by June 15 for repairs to buildings, bridges and roads.
American officials here said they announced $21 million in new aid, on top of the $62.7 million President Clinton pledged last December and the $198 million recently approved by Congress.
Pledges of new aid also came from Japan, which said it would provide at least $130 million this year on top of $155 million it has already provided. The European Union said it increased its overall contribution this year by $260 million, to a total of $373 million.

HEADLINE: As Revenues Drop, Hospitals Talk of Forsaking Charity Care

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

 BODY:
With managed care driving down their revenues, many hospitals around the country say they can no longer afford to provide free medical care to the growing number of uninsured who have come through their doors seeking treatment for everything from the flu to heart disease.
More than a dozen states have stepped in to reimburse hospitals for a portion of the hundreds of millions of dollars they spend on free medical treatment, mostly to the working poor. But some states have yet to address what health care experts say is a looming crisis, particularly for hospitals in urban areas. 
 Until the last few years, most hospitals were able to pass much of the cost of treating the uninsured onto paying patients. Now, many hospitals say that without more public financing they will be forced to turn uninsured patients away for all but emergency care, which is required under Federal law.
New Jersey, one of the few states committed to reimbursing hospitals for treatment of the uninsured, paid $388 million to 84 hospitals last year. But state officials have been unable to agree on how to pay for hospital treatments this year, illustrating how difficult it is for states to help cover the cost of free medical care when taxpayers are pressuring politicians to reduce government spending.
With Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and the State Legislature at an impasse over a new financing plan, hospitals will go without their third state payment this year, which would have been due tomorrow. Since they have not been reimbursed for more than $100 million in free medical care, some hospitals have stopped payments to suppliers and are drawing up plans to close wards and lay off employees.
Keith J. McLaughlin, president of the Raritan Bay Medical Center in Perth Amboy, said the hospital's community health clinic as well as its substance abuse and methadone maintenance programs would be shut down if the state does not provide reimbursements.
"Providing health care for those in need is not a hospital problem," Mr. McLaughlin said. "It is a statewide social problem, and therefore the state's responsibility. Because of our inability to cost-shift, we can no longer subsidize their responsibility."
Until health maintenance organizations began forcing hospitals to cut rates and reduce hospital stays, hospitals were able to shift much of the cost of treating the uninsured onto paying patients. Hospital administrators said they have cut costs and many have opened out-patient clinics to reduce expensive emergency-room visits. Even so, hospital administrators say there is just not enough money to cover those who cannot afford private health insurance and who are not eligible for Medicaid and Medicare, the state and Federal programs for the poor, the elderly and the disabled.
Adding to the hospitals' woes, hundreds of billions of dollars in cuts to the Medicaid and Medicare programs over the next seven years are pending in Congress.
A hospital's ability to manage the growing financial pressures depends significantly on where the hospital is located. Health care experts say the hospitals facing the biggest strain are those in urban and poor rural settings where patients are less likely to be insured.
And proposed state and Federal cuts in graduate medical education training are expected to severely hamper the efforts of teaching hospitals that treat large numbers of uninsured patients.
"Over the last decade, we had been somewhat protected by a combination of methods to put together dollars to cover the cost of free care," said Dr. H. Richard Nesson, chief executive officer of Partners Healthcare System in Boston, the new name for the recently merged Brigham and Women's Hospital and Massachusetts General Hospital. "We are in a dramatic period of change, and as long as those of us who are responsible for these institutions believe that we have committed ourselves to caring for the community, and don't close our doors, we are going to be in great difficulty."
At the same time, many local governments around the nation are looking to reduce their costs at municipal and county hospitals, including selling and closing them. This growing trend is raising questions about where the increasing numbers of uninsured patients are to go for medical care and who is going to pay for their care in the absence of universal health coverage. Studies show that the number of Americans without health insurance has risen by 5 million, to almost 40 million, since 1989.
Although Federal law requires that hospitals provide emergency medical treatment until the patient is stabilized without regard to an ability to pay, some states also require that hospitals provide charity care to maintain their tax-exempt status as nonprofit organizations.
Some states, including New York, still cover most of the cost of free hospital care through surcharges on hospital bills to paying patients. But Gov. George E. Pataki is moving toward deregulating hospital rates, which means that insurance companies can negotiate discounts. New York hospital administrators worry that after deregulation they will be unable to pass the surcharge to the insurance companies.
"The entity that gets stuck with it is the hospital," said Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, a trade association. "Competitive forces and uncompensated care are antithetical to each other. Everybody has to realize that they have a stake in uncompensated care. But in the absence of a national solution, it is clear to me that each state and employer, self-insured company, as well as private insurers, has to step up to the plate and say this is our responsibility too. The key to this is to try to find revenue sources that are as broadly based as possible."
Some states have dedicated tax revenues to help reimburse free medical care. In Washington State, charity care is partly paid for through a 2.9 percent excise tax on motor vehicles. Indiana uses county property tax revenues to reimburse not only hospitals but doctors and ambulance services up to $35 million a year for free medical care.
In California, vehicle license fees and a portion of sales tax revenues are provided to counties to help pay for care for the uninsured. And a tax on cigarettes is also partly earmarked to pay public and private hospitals for charity care.
But many states do not have any public hospitals or any public financing system in place.
In Pennsylvania, there are no public acute-care hospitals and no source of state tax revenue, except for a small Medicaid subsidy program to those hospitals with the largest Medicaid caseloads. While Tennessee and Oregon are looking to cover some of the hospital costs of indigent care by extending Medicaid eligibility to the working poor, Gov. Thomas Ridge of Pennsylvania is seeking to remove 270,000 people from the state's Medicaid rolls.
Pennsylvania hospital industry officials estimate that the state's 207 hospitals provide $400 million in unreimbursed free medical care a year. Under Governor Ridge's proposal to reduce Medicaid spending, hospital officials say their burden will increase from $400 million to $700 million a year.
"Unless states come forward with funding mechanisms for uncompensated care, there is going to be greater and greater pressure on many hospitals," said David M. Frankford, a professor of law at Rutgers University who specializes in health care regulation and financing. "The buck keeps on getting passed downward. If they can't shift costs to the private insurers, then they are in trouble, particularly if you have hospitals with large Medicaid and Medicare populations."
Mr. Frankford said that one problem facing the nation's hospitals is that they have "tended to cry wolf" over the years about their inability to make ends meet. "But given the systemic pressures, they might not be crying wolf now," he said.
In Massachusetts, hospital administrators say they can no longer carry the burden of charity care alone. Until this year, insurance companies paid a surcharge on hospital bills that was distributed to those hospitals with the highest free-medical-care costs. But now that the state has deregulated rates, hospital administrators contend that the program is in jeopardy. They say the insurers are no longer paying the surcharge because they are now receiving discounted rates.
Until 1992, New Jersey imposed a surcharge on hospital bills. Since 1993, after the deregulation of hospital rates, the state has reimbursed hospitals for free medical care by diverting almost $1.6 billion from the state's unemployment insurance fund. But the state's legislative authority to take money out of that fund expired on Dec. 31 and both the business community and organized labor have strongly objected to proposals that the state continue to draw from the fund, which is supported by employer taxes and payroll taxes on employees. Governor Whitman, who failed to win support for a cigarette tax increase to help cover the costs of charity care, contends there isn't enough money in the state's operating budget to foot the bill.
Joseph Avellone, chief operating officer for Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Massachusetts, said that private insurers were under pressure from businesses to reduce the high cost of health insurance and that hospitals needed to do a better job reducing their costs.
"The challenge for the hospitals in our state is to become more cost competitive," Mr. Avellone said.
Yet Mr. Avellone said that Blue Cross recognized that it shared part of the responsibility of covering the costs of the uninsured and would like to be involved in drawing up a solution. "The reform ought to be around universal insurance coverage," he said.
Glenn Wilson, a professor of social medicine at the Cecil G. Sheps Center for Health Services Research at the University of North Carolina, said that it was unrealistic to expect that market forces will provide for the poor because a free market economy does not redistribute money.
"The market may make hospitals and health care more efficient, but it will not provide for the poor," Mr. Wilson said. "At some point, we will do without care or we will raise the money. The hospitals can't give it away."
"Whether the hospital is public or private, someone is going to have to pay for the people who have no money," he said. "Until we quit fantasizing that that is not true, we are not going to make any progress."

HEADLINE: Dole Assails Clinton for 'Crunch' of Low Wages and High Taxes

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WEST DES MOINES, Iowa, April 13

 BODY:
With tax-filing day fast approaching, Bob Dole today lambasted what he called "the Clinton crunch," which he said had squeezed most Americans between higher taxes and lower wages.
In a speech coinciding with antitax protests being staged by Republicans across the country, Mr. Dole told a rally of 300 people here that after Bill Clinton promised a middle-class tax cut in 1992, "he raised taxes $265 billion, the largest tax increase in the history of the world." 
 Now, he said, the typical two-income family pays more in taxes than it spends on food, clothing and shelter combined, with 38 percent of income going to Federal, state and local taxes, and 28 percent going to food, clothing and housing.
"The typical worker spends three hours of every eight-hour day just to pay his or her tax bill," Mr. Dole said. "That's how oppressive it is."
Reviving a theme he raised last spring but had rarely returned to since, he added: "Two incomes are now an economic necessity for families, not a choice. Real hourly wages are 5 percent lower than a decade ago, and they only increased one penny per hour since Clinton was elected."
Mr. Dole said Mr. Clinton had broken his promises to cut taxes, balance the Federal budget and overhaul welfare, and so "it may be necessary to elect me to keep the promises he made in 1992."
Mr. Dole, completing a three-day fund-raising swing through Tennessee, Texas and Iowa, returned here today for the first time since he nearly lost in the Iowa caucuses on Feb. 12. "I barely limped out of Iowa with a narrow victory," he said.
Still, he said, he came to thank Iowa for starting him on what turned out to be a rocky road toward wrapping up the Republican Presidential nomination, only to wake up this morning to a headline in The Des Moines Register that blared, "Clinton sprints past Dole.'
A new Iowa Poll, conducted last week for the newspaper, showed Mr. Clinton, who beat President George Bush here in 1992, trouncing Mr. Dole by 17 percentage points among Iowans likely to vote in November. If the election were held today, 53 percent would vote for Mr. Clinton and 36 percent for Mr. Dole, according to the poll.
"I saw the headline," Mr. Dole told his supporters at the rally. "Didn't bother me a bit. We're 206 days away from Nov. 5, 1996. We know it's not going to be easy."
He placed blame for his low standing on what he called the "Forbes onslaught" of negative television commercials last winter. "It's going to take a while to recover," he told reporters later. "I bet in 60 days those numbers will be very close together." He acknowledged that Steve Forbes, who popularized the flat tax, "had a message" of a "flatter, simpler, fairer system," and Mr. Dole said he would institute one as President.
The Senator also said he hoped to meet with Ross Perot soon and encourage him to support the Republican ticket in the fall instead of running for President again.
At a speech in Houston on Friday night, Mr. Dole gave a preview of the case he would make to the Texan: "If we want to change America, we need to change the occupant of the White House. It is that simple, Mr. Perot."
In Iowa, he also told his supporters that he did have a vision -- just not the one he said the news media wanted him to have. "If I had 10 new spending programs that would tax you more, I would be a visionary" in the media's view, he said.
"My vision for America is pretty much like your vision," he said, "for your family, your job or your farm."

HEADLINE: CHILDREN FOR SALE -- A special report.;
Asian Childhoods Sacrificed to Prosperity's Lust

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: SVAY PAK, Cambodia

 BODY:
She giggled for a moment, a 13-year-old girl, all sparkling eyes and white teeth, her laughter washing over the grunts from a pornographic video playing a few feet away. Then the brothel owner strutted over.
The owner, a hearty, friendly woman in her late 20's who paid good money to buy the girl, named Sriy, cheerfully and explicitly recommended her anatomical features and said the $10 fee was not so great because "she only just lost her virginity." 
 In fact, that is a lie. Sriy was sold into prostitution two years ago.
As if to prove her point, the owner of the brothel, in this town 50 miles northwest of the capital, reached out and tugged down on the girl's dress to display her left breast, or rather the nipple of what will become a breast if Sriy survives to maturity. "You like?" the owner asked in broken English. "You take girl?"
Sriy endures these indignities, along with up to 10 customers a night, because she is considered the brothel owner's property. Sold by her stepfather to another brothel, which then sold her to this one, the girl must work until the debt is deemed to be repaid. Or until she gets AIDS.
If she tries to escape, she will be caught, severely beaten, perhaps starved, and locked inside her room, while still being forced to have sex with many customers a night. A neighboring brothel burned down in mid-March, and the bodies of two girls were found in the wreckage. They had been locked inside, forced to have sex with customers in their rooms, and never allowed out because they showed signs of wanting to escape.
Sriy is one of tens of thousands of children who are slaves working in the plantations of the 1990's: the brothels of Cambodia, India, China, Thailand, the Philippines, Taiwan and other countries.
Americans and other Westerners helped build the child prostitution trade in Asia, and many of the brothel districts date from R&R breaks from the Vietnam War, or surround former American military bases. Now they sustain the trade with an appetite for what at home would be child molestation and rape. One result is a partnership between local people who run the brothels and Westerners like the one who posted an item on the Internet informing sex tourists that in Cambodia "a six-year-old is available for US$3."
 
Family
Mother and Sister Pimp for Young Ones
In the seedy Maleta district of Manila, near the waterfront and virtually in the shadow of a large church, lives a family with four daughters ranging from 8 to 18. Until a few months ago, the mother and oldest daughter procured for the 8-year-old and a 12-year-old among foreigners, social workers say. When a customer was found, the oldest daughter would go to school to bring her sisters home early, telling the teachers that they had some family business.
The 8-year-old was raped by American, Australian and Japanese men. When the 12-year-old tried to resist, her sister held her arms and another pimp held her legs so the men could rape her more easily.
It was not supposed to be this way. Six decades ago Asian cities like Shanghai, Hong Kong and Hanoi were notorious for their brothels, but it had seemed that economic development would allow countries to grow out of the worst of the squalor. Now Asia has enjoyed an historic economic boom, yet child prostitution is, by most accounts, increasing.
By estimates of social workers and Governments, more than a million girls and boys, aged 17 and younger, are engaged in prostitution in Asia, although all these figures are no more than wild guesses. The slaves, in the sense of those who are locked up or owned by a brothel, are a minority. But even among those teen-agers who now offer themselves on street corners, many first entered the sex trade unwillingly, sold by parents or simply kidnapped off the street.
Three factors seem to be aggravating the problem: rising economic development, which initially seems to increase the appetite for children more quickly than it reduces the supply; the rise of capitalism, so markets emerge not just for rice and pork but also for virgin girls; and, perhaps most important, the fear of AIDS, driving customers to younger girls and boys who are regarded as more likely to be disease-free.
All three factors merge in the person of a shy 14-year-old Vietnamese girl, Miss Nguyen, who one day recently was sitting in a brothel here in Svay Pak, waiting to be sold for the very first time. Her brothel is one of dozens in Svay Pak, all nice two-story brick buildings that contrast with the rutted dirt streets and open sewers of the surrounding neighborhood.
Miss Nguyen was wearing a long purple dress, and the other girls in Svay Pak were also dressed lavishly and adorned with cosmetics and jewelry that looked out of place on their tiny figures. Miss Nguyen's story emerged slowly, because the brothel owners often beat girls for telling anyone about their backgrounds and because this brothel owner was paying particular attention to Miss Nguyen to make sure she does not escape.
The owner, a dour woman in her 30's, had bought Miss Nguyen three days earlier and was holding her off the market until she found a foreigner willing to pay $500 for her virginity. "It's not so expensive," the brothel owner said. "After all, she only loses her virginity once. This is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity."
Miss Nguyen was smuggled across the border from Vietnam where, as in Cambodia, the collapse of strict Communist ideology has been accompanied by the rise of a huge flesh trade. The buyer of Miss Nguyen's virginity will probably be a foreigner, the owner said, most likely a newly prosperous ethnic Chinese from Taiwan, China or Singapore. A Chinese superstition holds that sex with a virgin helps makes a man young again, or that it can cure venereal disease.
A 15-year-old Vietnamese girl who is also new to the brothel, having been sold by her mother, piped up to say that a Singaporean man paid $500 for her virginity a few days earlier. It is eerie to hear the girls speak of these topics because, to Western eyes, they look several years younger than their ages, not like sexual beings at all, more like American 10-year-olds than teen-agers.
"It hurt a lot and I cried," the girl added. "It still hurts me, several days later. But it's not quite so bad now."
Miss Nguyen shuddered and leaned against the 15-year-old.
"I'm scared," she said softly. "I'm scared."
 
Fear
A Deadly Game Of Sexual Roulette
In another Cambodian brothel, a 14-year-old girl also said she was scared -- of AIDS. And with good reason. The girl said she was sold by her mother to the brothel a week earlier.
In this case it was a Cambodian, not a foreigner, who purchased her virginity -- a district police commander paid $500. The man, like many customers, did not use a condom.
Now the girl, as a fresh arrival, sells for $10, but in another week she will drop to $5 and then eventually to $2 or $3. She lay down on a bench, her long pink dress flowing over her, full of anger and helplessness.
"My mother needed money, because she was sick," the girl said, staring at the ceiling. "How can I be angry with her? She's my Mom."
A decade ago, such a slight young girl would not have been in much demand. But now men throughout Asia are turning toward younger and younger children, partly because they are deemed less likely to be infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS.
In fact, the children are greater risks because of their youth: their vaginas and anuses are easily torn, creating sores and bleeding that permit the AIDS virus to spread.
"Most men I know want younger girls, the younger the better, because then they can scare the hell out of us," said Tisay, a 14-year-old street-walker in Quezon City, the Philippines. "Older girls can set a price, can set conditions, but younger girls can't do that."
"I'd prefer safe sex," Tisay added. "But it's hard to insist that a man wear a condom. I'm small and I'm alone and I can't do anything about it if he doesn't want to."
Tisay has contracted gonorrhea, which increases the risk of acquiring AIDS, but she refuses to be treated. Partly she is afraid that if the other girls find out, they will tell her customers and drive them away, and partly, her behavior is simply self-destructive.
"My life's worth nothing now," a social worker quoted Tisay as telling her. "It's better for me to die."
The AIDS virus is spreading extremely rapidly among prostitutes in Asia. India had its first AIDS case in 1986, yet already some 1.6 million Indians are infected with H.I.V. Thailand may have 800,000 people infected with the virus, and Myanmar -- where condoms were banned until 1992 and are still rare -- has some 400,000 infected people. In Cambodia, one study found that 39 percent of prostitutes are infected with H.I.V.
The virus spreads rapidly from country to country in part because of trafficking of prostitutes across borders, but also because customers tend to hop from place to place. Sex tours started in Japan, allowing groups of men to visit brothels in South Korea or Taiwan, and now other countries are doing the same. Indeed, South Korean and Taiwanese men are now prosperous enough to travel on sex tours of their own to places like Bangkok or Manila.
Some Asian governments are beginning to prosecute foreigners caught having sex with minors, as Dr. Gavin A. M. Scott can attest. Dr. Scott, a tall, lean Briton who has lived in Cambodia practicing medicine since 1992, is still fuming over having to serve five months in a Phnom Penh prison last year on rape charges after paying five teen-age boys to have sex with him.
The police and the court said the boys were 14 to 16 years old, but Dr. Scott said that they were over 16 and that he simply engaged in sex with prostitutes.
"It was basically a case against homosexuality," said Dr. Scott, who is gay. "But it was misrepresented as a case about child sex, which it was not."
How do the customers regard their actions? From a conversation with Dr. Scott, who continues to practice medicine in Phnom Penh, and from materials published by pedophile organizations, it seems that customers sometimes offer two defenses.
First, they note that the age of consent in much of the world is 16 -- indeed, it is 14 in Pennsylvania and Hawaii -- and suggest that there is nothing wrong with people of such an age engaging in sexual acts. Second, they sometimes suggest that young prostitutes are at least earning substantial sums to help their families, and that the alternative would be backbreaking jobs that would be even more demeaning and dangerous.
A growing number of Westerners are, like Dr. Scott, being arrested for sexual abuse of children in Asia, although usually they are simply fined and deported. Prison sentences are very rare.
 
Betrayal
Selling a Daughter For a Karaoke System
What kind of a mother would sell her daughters?
Leonilla Olayres is a 33-year-old mother in a slum near Manila's airport. She sat on a plastic chair in her hovel, nursing her youngest child as other children scampered around the tiny room and the dirt street outside. The stench of garbage and an open sewer wafted into the room. Although the family is poor, it is not starving. An expensive new karaoke music system, costing hundreds of dollars, sits in a place of honor in the middle of the wall.
Where did the family get the money for such a purchase? Apparently in part from Mrs. Olayres's oldest daughters, aged 10 and 12. On five occasions over the last year, by Mrs. Olayres's own count, she handed over the two girls to a Japanese man, Hisayoshi Maruyama, for cash.
The most recent time was Feb. 23 when, according to the police report, Mrs. Olayres delivered the 10-year-old to Mr. Maruyama's hotel room, accepted $60 and left.
The police say that they responded to a complaint from a relative and found Mr. Maruyama and the 10-year-old girl, both naked, in his hotel room. The police report says that Mr. Maruyama had kissed the girl, undressed her, sexually abused her, tied her up, photographed her and forced her to perform oral sex.
"I didn't know," Mrs. Olayres said matter-of-factly. She insisted that she had believed Mr. Maruyama's explanation that he wanted to take pictures for a Japanese foster-parents organization. Anyway, Mrs. Olayres added, many neighbors had also hired out their daughters to Mr. Maruyama.
The two girls were taken to a Government-run shelter where, through a social worker, they declined to be interviewed about their mother. Mr. Maruyama, a 34-year-old with a mop of black hair and a modest paunch who identifies himself as a medical doctor at a Tokyo institute that seems not to exist, insisted in an interview in the Manila jail that he had been framed by the police.
Mr. Maruyama acknowledged that he had been arrested before in Manila, in 1991, in very similar circumstances. But he said he had been framed then, too.
Police reports from that time say that he forced a 10-year-old boy and his 11-year-old sister to engage in sexual acts together, and then further abused six young boys and a 7-year-old girl so he could take pornographic videos of them.
Mr. Maruyama argued that his main legal problem is that he did not have enough cash to pay a bribe. He said that when his hotel room was raided, he was not initially arrested, and police records confirm this. According to Mr. Maruyama's account, he was taken to a police office and asked for a $4,000 bribe. Only when he could not pay, he said, was he arrested.
 
Despair
Poisoned Cookies, Silent Fury
The way a child's fortunes can suddenly collapse was underscored by the case late last year of four Cambodian girls who tried to help a middle-aged woman who appeared to be ill on the road. According to a social worker who works, the woman offered the girls a cookie each, in a show of gratitude, but the cookie was drugged and the girls passed out.
Then the woman hired a taxi to take them to a brothel, which she entered to negotiate a sale. The taxi driver realized what was happening and felt badly because he recognized one of the unconscious girls. So he drove off and took the girls home before the woman came out. Otherwise, they very likely would have finished their lives in the brothels.
The role of fate is fully evident in the Cambodian brothel that houses Sriy, the 13-year-old whose owner pushed down the neck of her dress to show off her chest. A moment later, the owner did the same to Sriy's best friend, a 15-year-old Vietnamese who was sold to the brothel by a man who kidnapped her.
That girl's mother finally tracked her daughter down in March, and found her working in the brothel. But since the brothel owner had paid for the girl -- even if to a kidnapper -- the mother could not take the girl home. Instead the mother had to settle for signing a contract with the brothel owner, stipulating that when the girl earns back enough money, she will be returned to her family.
"If the mother tried to grab her daughter and take her out of the brothel, the owner would have them beaten up," said a Cambodian journalist who has written about the problems of child prostitution. "And if the mother takes on the brothel owner, she can't win. The brothel owner can just pay some money to the police, or give the girl to the police, and the parents will lose."
At least, Sriy seems to think, her friend eventually has a home to go back to. Sriy hates her stepfather, who used to beat her and who took the initiative in selling her to the brothel. All she has is the memory of her mother, who died recently.
What does she think of her mother for allowing her to be sold into a brothel? Sriy's eyes grew distant as her 13-year-old mind sorted through memories of her mother.
"Mom was sick and needed money," Sriy finally said hesitantly. "She had a lung disease. I don't hate her."
Sriy's peaceful expression did not change, and she seemed lost in thought. But she began to play with a piece of brittle plastic on the table, breaking it with her slender fingers, violently crushing it into smaller and smaller pieces.

HEADLINE: April 7-13;
The Unabomber's Pen Pal?

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

 BODY:
Last week, as a New Jersey prosecutor was named to coordinate the Unabomber case, a Mexican farmhand opened a window into the mind of Theodore Kaczynski, the Harvard-trained mathematician who is suspected of being the Unabomber and who was the farmhand's pen pal.
"If only I had a wife and children!" Mr. Kaczynski wrote to Juan Sanchez Arreola from his cabin in Montana. And he complained of his poverty. 
 To Mr. Sanchez, who labored for half a century at menial jobs in the United States, seven years of unemployment complaints by Mr. Kaczynski rang false. With only two years of primary school education, the sun-creased 68-year-old opined that the Mexican description for "el Doctor" would be "perezoso" -- lazy. JAMES BROOKE

HEADLINE: Future of Wainwright House in Doubt Despite Trust Fund

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON 

DATELINE: RYE

 BODY:
THE seasons present a shifting tableau along the waterfront at Wainwright House Inc. here, but the 44-year-old, nonprofit organization has traditionally focused on more timeless concerns.
Hundreds say they have found a second home in the French Provincial mansion that has been the group's headquarters since 1951, participating in programs intended to heal the spirit and unite body and mind. Now, however, many fear the organization, which has used up much of its $2.2 million endowment, is experiencing a financial and spiritual crisis from which it may not recover. 
 The good news, say Friends of Wainwright House, an ad hoc committee formed after the five-acre, $8 million property was put on the market earlier this year, is that public outcry led to an offer of a $1 million trust fund and an immediate gift of $10,000 to maintain the property, with an additional $10,000 to be given yearly for 10 years.
Committee members say they are disturbed, however, because the board of trustees has not agreed to the stipulation of the donor, Werner Mark Linz, who lives next door, that none of the property be sold.
Wainwright House was founded in 1941 by the Laymen's Movement, a group of business leaders, to bring ethical and spiritual values into professional and public life.
Ten years later, the house and grounds were donated to the group by Fonrose Wainwright Condict, who in 1983 left $2.2 million to the organization.
In addition to the 12,000-square-foot main house, the property consists of a 2,150-square-foot carriage house and a 3,000-square-foot stucco Colonial house. It was the Colonial house, named Condict House for Mrs. Condict, and two acres of waterfront land, that were to have been sold.
James S. Sutterlin, board president, said there was "no intention whatever to put the property back on the market." But, he said, "Whether a board can legally commit future boards is not clear to me." He said the trustees had thanked Mr. Linz, a former trustee and board president, but added that "the details haven't been worked out yet."
Members of the committee have complained that the board has not been open in its dealings in recent months and are asking to be included in discussions of the future of Wainwright House. Kathryn Clarke, a committee member, said that while the board had not provided a financial picture of the organization, data obtained through the Freedom of Information Act showed a $420,000 deficit last year and a $151,000 deficit in 1993. Mr. Sutterlin said in an interview that current deficit figures were not available.
Margot Dilmaghani, another committee member, questioned the board's financial-management policies. "Apparently, they have continued to spend the endowment, which should have been safeguarded," she said. "Why does this board continue to spend without covering the deficit? Given the current crisis, which the board has allowed to occur, I wonder why this board doesn't all just resign?"
Mr. Sutterlin said the crisis began soon after the endowment was received. "Some say it was a blessing, and some not," he said of the gift. "The volunteer aspects fell off, and the programs became more expensive." He added that the falling stock market in the late 1980's caused the property to begin losing $200,000 a year, which "had to be taken in part from the capital." In addition, he said, an $800,000 renovation of the main house, which was begun in 1994, cost three times the original estimate.
In recent years, the diverse programs at Wainwright House have been led by nationally known authors, therapists and spiritualists. Participants could learn to unravel their dreams, explore such new-age areas as eco-psychology and homeopathy or discuss sexual issues with Dr. Ruth Westheimer. The courses and workshops have been a beacon to those seeking personal enlightenment, particularly in the suburbs. Some programs have also appeared zany at times to the less adventuresome. In one course, for example. "Reclaiming the Juice and Mystery of the Pagan: Goddess and Earth Traditions," participants were asked to bring "drums, bells, rattles and any other instruments that are good in groups."
Currently, however, Mr. Sutterlin said there was "a pause" in programming because of "financial stringencies and staff reductions." A cancer-support group continues to meet as does a group of older adults, who recently discussed medieval warfare and the epic poem "The Song of Roland" in the Wainwright House Library.
Ronald C. Tocci, State Assemblyman from the 85th District, which includes Rye, has served as a liaison between the special committee and the board. Mr. Tocci said his wife, Patricia, had been involved with Wainwright House for many years and he was acting as a private citizen.
He described a meeting last month in which more than 100 people, some from as far away as Woodstock and Hartford, came to tell board members of their concern for Wainwright House. "Everybody just poured their heart out," Mr. Tocci said. "There was enormous enthusiasm and support for keeping the house and property intact without subdividing it. People felt upset that they hadn't been asked to be part of coming up with a solution, and said that given the chance to participate they could come with fund-raising ideas."
The committee has asked the board, which is self-appointed, to organize a new governing structure with the participation of members, as well as to provide members with a business plan. The group has also requested that a special task force, which includes committee members, be appointed to help with the reorganization. The committee has planned an open meeting next Sunday at Wainwright House to discuss the group's future.
Mr. Sutterlin said he was in favor of holding elections for the board but said that would not happen immediately. "Meanwhile," he said, "the broader public will have the opportunity to make nominations for members of the board." He said that in the future, Wainwright House would be relying heavily on volunteers. The organization also would like to raise funds by renting space to other nonprofit groups, he said.
Both Mr. Sutterlin and committee members said that Wainwright House had a special mission, although one that may be revised. "It is a spiritual mission of outreach and opportunity for self-improvement, but also for service to the community and the world," Mr. Sutterlin said. "The realization of the mission is bound to be in the programs."
Mr. Linz, who heads the Continuum Publishing Group in Manhattan and is currently working in Cairo as a consultant to the American University, said: "The hope is that members and friends of Wainwright House will generate new creative energy that seems to be lacking in a board under siege. This is a very interesting time -- full of pain and full of promise."

CORRECTION-DATE: April 21, 1996, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about Wainwright House in Rye misstated the amount that a donor has offered to keep the property from being sold. It is $100,000 a year for 10 years, not $10,000 a year.

HEADLINE: THE QUEST FOR COMFORT

BYLINE: By LAUREL GRADBER 

 BODY:
EVER since human beings learned to walk on their feet, it seems they've been trying to get off them. Apparently believing that rest couldn't be eternal without a place to recline, the anicent Egyptians filled their tombs with elegant chairs and beds. Chinese aristocrats of the Ming dynasty (1368-1644) could end an evening of revelry by falling into a portable reclining armchair: the zuiwengyi, or "drunken lord's chair." In Western culture, the English Knole settee, circa 1620, featured a cushioned headrest attached to each arm with hinges. If the occupant wanted a snooze, he just racheted a pillow into position. 
 But while comfort has always been a principle in furniture design, it hasn't always been a priority. The availability of ease has evolved, reflecting changes in society, economics and technology, as well as taste. What ease was - and who enjoyed it - could well define an era.
 In early Europe, "furniture was an unspoken way to establish your pecking order," says Melissa T. Gagen, vice president, European furniture, at Christie's in New York. "As you got closer to the king, you maybe got a back on my chair."
 Both rules and furniture, however, softened in the 18th century. Many historians point to this period as the first age of real ease. Much of the change had to do with a shift in emphasis, even at court, from a formal, stylized life to a more intimate, private one. "People began to make small desks, small tables, even ice buckets," says Herve Aaron, president of Didier Aaron, New York dealers in 18th- and 19th-century antiques.
 In response to the desire for convenience - a form of comfort - craftsmen also created a wide variety of mechanical furniture. Louis V, for instance, ordered a mechanied dining room for one of his cateaus, says Anthony G. victoria, owner of Fredericks P. Victoria and Son, New York dealers specializing in Continental decorative arts. Tables were engineered to arrive and disappear through trapdoors, bypassing servants.
 "This would have been the epitome of luxury and comfort - to have all that ease, and not have the eyes of your subjects upon you," says Victoria.
 An increasingly prosperous middle class began to enjoy comfort as well. All manner of chairs were devised, some with a high, hinged back so that a man could be shaved while seated; others with a scooped-out back so that a lady could have her hair dressed.
 Both Victoria and Thierry Millerand, Sotheby's senior vice president of European furniture worldwide, note that some settees were also designed for seduction - sometimes real, sometimes metaphorical. "One of Louis XV's daughters aid she was 'lost to a chair,' because it was so comfortable that she was getting nothing done," Millerand adds.
 One of the most remarkable pieces of Louis XV's era is the royal desk. The first recorded roll-top, it was designed and built by Jean-Francois Oeben and Jean-Henri Riesener so that different compartments would pop out with the turn of a key.
 Louis XVI and his court were not ones to stint on ease, either. The queen, Marie Antoinette, found mechanical furniture convenient for pregnancy: Unable to sit comfortably, she had a table made with an adjustable top, allowing her to sew or write while standing.
 ON the other side of the Atlantic, comfort also found expression. America's Queen Anne pieces were notonly commodious, they were also easy on the eye.
 In 1753, "William Hogarth wrote about the S-curve, while he compared to the shape of a woman in a corset," says Leslie B. Keno, senior vice president and director of American furniture and decorative arts at Sotheby's in New York. Considered lovely to behold as wellas to lounge in, the S-shaped curve was all the rage in mid-18th-century furniture.
 Certainly, leisure activities played a large role in easeful design: witness card tables, gaming tables with candle pockets, tables with places for gambling chips and others with built-in backgammon boards. There were even chairs called voyelles and voyeuses (literally "voyeurs"), which featured an armrest along the top of the back, a place for an observer to rest his forearms while watching over a player's shoulder.
 In the 19th century one particular form of relaxation greatly influenced furnishings: the taking of tea. "Tea was very expensive in the 18th century, but the 19th century was the peak of British colonialism," observes Larry Sirolli, director of English furniture at Sotheby's. "It was very abundant, and the ritual of tea crated a very intimate setting."
 Intimacy brought a desire for comfort, making the 19th century the age of upholsterer. Expanding trade routes made fabric more affordable, and a more relaxed style of entertaining required its own furniture. In fact, upholstered pieces reached their most voluptuous heights in an era not usually associated with sensuality: the reign of Queen Victoria.
 "The backs on Victorian furniture were stuffed better, with horsehair and cotton," says Sirolli. The industrial revolution also popularized the use of spring construction, forever transforming comfort in furniture.
 But while some see the mid-19th century as the triumph of comfort, others see it as the failure of taste. "Furniture makers thought it was the end of quality," says WilliamStrafford, assistant vice president, European furniture, at Christie's. The reason? "An overstuffed chair is pretty blobby and blurs all the outlines."
 Indeed, a certain tension between ease and esthetics has persisted throughout design. If ease is all, you might as well choose a beanbag chair, observes Strafford with a shudder. On the other hand, furniture designers most concerned with purity of line - from the proponents of the Arts and Carfts Movmeent in the 19th century to the modernists of the 20th - have often produced pieces that are famously uncomfortable.
 "A lot of Frank Lloyd Wright's stuff isn't comfortable for any length of time," says Sanford L. Smith, president of Sanford L.Smith & Associates, which produces New york's annual Modernism show at the Seventh Regiment Armory. "Neither is Charles Rennie Mackintosh's." their work, however, brings high prices, which illustrates a certain irony about the 20th century: in the 17th century, only the wealthy could afford comfort; now, it seems, only the wealthy can afford discomfort. Whereas the middle and working classes need chairs that function as chairs, the rich can indulge in pieces that are more works of art than places to sit.
 "All 'form follows function' means is that you can sit in it," says Smith, citing the Bauhaus credo. "But do you want to sit in it for 15 minutes - Andy Warhol's 15 minutes?"
 Some modern pieces, of course, do offer ease. In Smith's own bedroom he has the "Airline" chair by Kem Weber, a well-upholstered but highly sculptural cantilevered lounge chair designed in 1934-35. "I love the line - it's very streamlined and aerodynamic," Smith says. "And it also happens to be a very comfortable chair."
 That combination seems to be the ideal: beautiful and restful. Life, after all, is hard enough; who could blame the ancient Egyptians for wanting to make sure that the after life was comfortable furnished?

SECTION: Section 7; Page 16; Column 1; Book Review Desk
