NEW YORK
 
Improving Ties With Minorities
Howard Safir, the incoming Police Commissioner, said that one of his first goals would be to improve police relations with the city's black and Hispanic residents. Mr. Safir said he was troubled by the perception that the Police Department is abusive. [Page A1.]
 
The Homeless Leave a Tunnel
The sagging shanties that lined the cavernous two-and-a-half mile Amtrak tunnel hard by the Hudson River may be the oldest remaining homeless community in New York City. But now, some of the people who live in the tunnel have been encouraged to apply for Federal housing vouchers and try living above ground. [B1.]
 
With Spring, a Columbia Strike
It's April. The trees in Central Park sprout buds. Baseball is back. And students at Columbia University occupy a building. While not precisely an annual rite, demonstrations at Columbia are certainly a hardy perennial, passed immutably from one generation to the next. But today's protesting students sometimes find the inevitable comparisons with earlier upheavals more burden than inspiration. [B1.]
 
Business Tax Cuts Proposed
The Republican leadership of the New York State Senate plans to unveil a proposal to cut an array of business taxes by $75 million this year and much more in future years. Critics say it is irresponsible for the Republicans to propose new tax cuts in a year in which deep spending cuts are being considered. [B1.]
 
Lifting a Veil of Secrecy
Two months ago, after the beating death of 6-year-old Elisa Izquierdo, the State Legislature approved a measure to lift the secrecy that had shrouded child abuse cases. Last week, with the release of city and state reports about Elisa's death, came the most tangible indication of what the law will -- and will not -- mean to the public's knowledge of abuse cases. The two reports were blunt, but both stopped short of naming even one of the many cited for incompetence. Metro Matters by Joyce Purnick. [B1.]
 
Cardinal Criticizes Clinton Veto
In a sermon during Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral, John Cardinal O'Connor, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York, equated a controversial type of late-term abortion with outright infanticide and sharply criticized President Clinton's veto of a bill that would have outlawed the practice. [B2.]
 
Fordham Student Is Assaulted
A 21-year-old Fordham student was attacked and apparently raped in the basement of her off-campus apartment building in the Bronx. [B3.]
 
Reviving Subsidized Concrete
Ten years ago, in a novel plan to lower construction costs and damage the Mafia, the city began subsidizing a private concrete company in Manhattan. But the plan dissolved after the company collapsed in bankruptcy. Now the Giuliani administration is reviving the idea. It has begun advertising for a new company to open a plant on city-owned property and become the sole concrete supplier for all municipal construction projects in Manhattan. [B5.]
 
From Albany to Lobbying
Two days before he announced his retirement from the State Senate in 1995, Ralph J. Marino, the former Senate majority leader, signed a contract for $100,000 a year to help the beer and soda industries in their efforts to reduce state beverage-container taxes and repeal the state's bottle-deposit law. [B5.]
 
Sheik in Appeal to Followers
Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, the militant Egyptian cleric convicted in a plot to bomb the United Nations and other New York City landmarks, has appealed to his followers to help end what he called his humiliating treatment in prison. [B6.]
 
New Media Forge Ahead
The new-media industry in New York has more than doubled in the last three years to become a $3.8 billion-a-year business and a mainstay of the metropolitan economy, according to a new study. The metropolitan-area industry is a sprawling collection of more than 4,200 companies -- mainly small companies that develop and market Internet sites, multimedia software, on-line entertainment and other digital offerings. Business Day. [D1.]
 
REGION
 
Seeking Asylum, Enduring Jail
Fauziya Kasinga says she fled her homeland of Togo at age 17 to avoid the tribal rite of female genital mutilation and an arranged marriage. She has passed her 18th and 19th birthdays behind bars in the United States. Ms. Kasinga's two-year ordeal will reach a critical juncture when the Board of Immigration Appeals considers her asylum request. The case could influence the handling of a broad array of claims from women who have suffered because of discriminatory cultural practices at home. [A1.]

LENGTH: 245 words

HEADLINE: In Developing Nations, Buzzwords Fall Flat

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Bill McKibben (Op-Ed, April 10) rightly argues that in the Western industrial context, the term "sustainable development" will be biased toward growth. Given the dominance of industrial ideology in the United States, coupled with our consumer life style, it is no surprise that "development" has already displaced "sustainability" as the operative term in this formulation. 
 Mr. McKibben proposes that we replace sustainable development with "maturity," which he believes emphasizes restraint.
While restraint is indeed what we need to be thinking about, forgotten is the fact that the concept of sustainable development was initially invented to establish a global environmental dialogue between the developed and developing worlds. In the developing world, a discourse about "maturity" has simply proved to be a nonstarter.
Faced with exploding populations and high levels of poverty, the idea of giving up growth for moral and spiritual development is a hopeless cause. In this context the only strategy is to find a new model that sets a course for an environmentally "sustainable growth."
But the fact that we in the developed world are failing to do anything more than pay lip service to this concept is surely at the root of the forthcoming ecological crisis. On this point Mr. McKibben couldn't be more on target.
 
FRANK FISCHER
Newark, April 10, 1996
The writer is a professor of political science at Rutgers University.

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: As Clinton Visits Changing Asia, Military Concerns Gain Urgency

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 14

 BODY:
After his last trip to Japan three years ago, one dominated by vicious disputes over trade, President Clinton returns on Tuesday to a changed strategic landscape, with Japan seeming a reduced economic threat, and China seeming a larger military one.
With Beijing struggling to gain respect as a great power through displays of military prowess off Taiwan, and North Korea declaring the 1953 armistice between the Koreas dead, Asia appears more fragile, raising new questions about the American commitment to use its power to enforce the stability required for growth and trade. 
 So President Clinton's now extended drop-by visit to South Korea and then two full days in Japan are intended to highlight security reassurances rather than trade squabbles, to try to convince the region that America will remain Asia's closest ally and the most efficient restraint on China's ambitions and North Korea's desperation.
Mr. Clinton's new emphasis is an acknowledgment that diplomacy is something larger than trade, and that even in the post-Soviet world America's interests require demonstrations of military strength and political will.
As such, Mr. Clinton's trip to South Korea, Japan and Russia is another step in his revised self-definition of his presidency. These days Mr. Clinton presents himself not only as pastor to the nation, consoling it in times of grief, but also as the kind of reliable foreign-policy steward that centrist Republicans like his presidential rival, Senator Bob Dole, have traditionally represented.
In all three countries he visits, old assumptions are being questioned, and Mr. Clinton's task will be to bring reassurance, even if his own larger diplomatic goals are vague.
In the Koreas, the North is demanding a new relationship with the United States to end 43 years of stalemate even as it appears to be crumbling and dangerous. In Russia, the whole thrust of American policy is at stake in June's elections. Mr. Clinton, with other leaders like Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany, will try to help an ill, weakened and more nationalist-sounding Boris N. Yeltsin beat back the Communist leader, Gennadi A. Zyuganov. They will try to convince Russians alienated by Mr. Yeltsin's intermittent reforms that a modern, democratic Russia welcomed by the world is better than the aggressive nostalgia offered by Mr. Zyuganov.
The ground is shifting in Japan, too, with increasingly pointed questions about how much longer 47,000 American troops and their families must be based there, and how much say Tokyo will ever have in American strategy.
These questions were articulated forcefully in a speech here last month by former Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa. "One cannot expect the Japanese public to merely accept the current reality of expansion of military activities of U.S. forces stationed in Japan from the Far East to the Middle East without any discussions," he said. And then asked, "Why is it necessary to maintain a level of 47,000 U.S. military troops in Japan?"
Even on trade issues, the contrasts are clear from three years ago, when Mr. Clinton began his trip by embracing a new generation of politicians trying to overthrow the Liberal Democratic Party. But within a year, two rebels Mr. Clinton met then -- Mr. Hosokawa and Tsutomu Hata -- took successive, failed turns as Prime Minister. The Liberal Democrats are back in power with Ryutaro Hashimoto, who fought off many of the changes Washington demanded. "We misjudged the ability of the 'reformers' to deliver," a senior advis conceded.
Mr. Clinton and his new Commerce Secretary, Mickey Kantor, argue that the pressure resulted in more than 20 trade accords and sharply increased American imports in targeted areas.
But Mr. Clinton also benefited from other economic changes. The strong yen makes American goods attractive. Japanese companies have moved production to Southeast Asia and China at an astounding rate -- so that many Japanese imports to America are listed as trade with Malaysia or Thailand. Japan's carmakers have shifted more and more production to America.
While trade issues will not disappear, suddenly the world does not seem entirely safe for the marketplace. And there is increasing criticism of America's Asia policy as ad hoc and reactive. Gregory Treverton of the Rand Corporation research organization criticized Mr. Clinton for having "subcontracted" Japan policy for too long to Mr. Kantor, neglecting a comprehensive strategic dialogue.
It was the rape of an Okinawan schoolgirl by American servicemen last September that was the catalyst for the new concentration on security dialogue, United States officials say. The sharp protests about the presence of American troops so long after World War II shook the Pentagon.
Rapid moves to set up a special Japanese-American dialogue over Okinawa resulted in the announcement last Friday -- accelerated for political benefit by Mr. Hashimoto -- that the United States would return a major airbase on Okinawa within seven years and relocate some troops to mainland Japan.
[In an effort to smooth the way for Mr. Clinton's trip, the American Government signed the agreement in Tokyo on Monday. The return of several important military sites on Okinawa, which would take place during the next seven years or so, would reduce by 20 percent the land taken up by American bases there.
[Japanese hostility to the bases has been greatest on Okinawa, and the new agreement reflects an extraordinary effort to meet the objections of the Okinawans and reduce the antagonisms. The United States will return Futenma Air Station, as announced on Friday, as well as the Yomitan Auxiliary Airfield, the Sobe communications center, the Gimbaru Training Area and a major part of the Northern Training Area.
[Defense Secretary William Perry and Ambassador Walter F. Mondale, who represented the United States at the signing, both said the return of the land would not undermine American military preparedness in Asia.
While hailed in Japan, the agreement was an ambivalent message at best. Other countries in the region who are nervous about North Korean instability and Chinese military ambitions could see the return of the base as a waning of the American security commitment.
There are similar concerns, in spades, about Mr. Clinton's China policy. The United States has serious questions about China's intentions on the spreading of nuclear arms, stance toward Taiwan, and missile sales to Iran and Pakistan. But those problems have become entangled with equally serious economic issues about trade, budget deficits and respect for intellectual property rights.
Mr. Clinton will try to be reassuring about the coherence of America's policy of pulling China, like Russia, into the web of alliances and obligations that are normal for major powers while admitting the seriousness of United States-Chinese problems, which could lead to sanctions.
Japanese business leaders make it clear that United States economic sanctions against China would be unilateral. "Given our history with China, I don't see how we could join in anything like that," said Ryuzaburo Kaku, the chairman of Canon Inc. "It's not even being discussed."


GRAPHIC: Clinton visits South Korea, Japan and Russia, arriving in South Korea tomorrow and leaving Russia on Sunday.
 
1. South Korea
Mr. Clinton intends to show support for Korea's economically powerful democracy and American resolve to help defend the country. The stopover was lengthened after new tensions broke out with North Korea.
 
2. Japan
Mr. Clinton will spend two days in Tokyo, after canceling a summit meeting last November. He will unveil a new joint security declaration with Japan, promising to keep 100,000 American troops in Asia through this century while working -- as in Okinawa -- to lessen the burden on host countries.
 
4. Russia
Mr. Clinton will demonstrate support for what the embattled Russian President, Boris Nr. Yeltsin, has largely represented: a modern, democracy that is a part of the world community and not the aggressive expansionist Russia represented by his chief rival in June's elections, a Communist.

HEADLINE: Foreign Aid Makes A Visible Difference

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Donors of Foreign Aid Have Second Thoughts" (Week in Review, April 7): 
 While some aid has "fattened elites," some has also helped to improve living standards in poor countries. According to the United Nations Development Program, life expectancy in the developing world is 17 years longer than in 1960. Infant mortality has been more than halved. Primary and secondary school enrollment is 1.5 times higher.
The article gives the impression that nongovernmental organizations have been financed by government aid, with those funds used for the agencies back home. Church World Service, which you cite, is not dependent upon United States Government funds. A small part of our budget comes from the Government and is used to help resettle 7,000 refugees in the United States every year.
One reason Western governments have turned to partnerships with nongovernmental organizations is that they are seen to be best placed to facilitate the bottom-up development that is the key to reducing poverty.
 
R. LAWRENCE TURNIPSEED
Exec. Dir., Church World Service
New York, April 12, 1996

HEADLINE: New York Needs a State Smoking Law

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Leave the Smoking Ban Alone" (editorial, April 11): 
 You suggest that uniform smoking regulations for all of New York state make sense "only if restaurants acquire wheels and begin serving dinners from town to town."
Restaurant patrons do have wheels, and many of them, especially in the outer boroughs of New York City, are simply driving across the city line where they can dine and smoke.
A study just completed for us by Dun & Bradstreet shows that restaurant jobs declined in New York City while rising in surrounding counties, and while retail jobs and other economic indicators were going up in the metropolitan area. The smoking ban is the only logical explanation for city restaurant employment's going against the trend.
A patchwork of local smoking regulations is unfair to restaurant owners and confusing both to them and their patrons. The statewide legislation, in addition to creating a level playing field for restaurateurs, permits a practical way to address the sensitivities of nonsmoking diners, one that has been effective for many years: separate smoking and nonsmoking sections, with diners choosing where to sit.
Smoking is a legal, ingrained custom to many New York City residents and tourists, especially foreign visitors. It is unjust to punish them and hurt the livelihoods of restaurant owners to appease antismoking interest groups. We need a reasonable statewide law that permits restaurants to respond to the demands of customers.
 
SCOTT WEXLER
Executive Director, Empire State
Restaurant and Tavern Assn.
Albany, April 12, 1996

HEADLINE: Hospitals Sue New Jersey to Recover Millions Spent to Treat the Poor

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, April 15

 BODY:
The New Jersey Hospital Association, a trade organization that represents most of the state's hospitals, filed a lawsuit against the state today, seeking payment for free medical treatment to the uninsured.
New Jersey was supposed to have sent out its third round of checks today to reimburse 84 hospitals around the state for providing the free medical care. The state distributed $388 million to hospitals last year by dipping into the unemployment insurance fund, but the state's authority to continue using the fund expired on Dec. 31. Attempts to come up with a new financing plan, including the raising of the cigarette tax, have failed to gain legislative approval. 
 In its lawsuit, filed in State Superior Court in Essex County, the hospital association argued that the state had been improperly using private institutions to provide medical treatment without "just compensation."
The lawsuit seeks full reimbursement for all charity care services provided, estimated to be $600 million this year. State officials have proposed providing less than $300 million this year.
The lawsuit is the latest effort by hospital administrators to put pressure on Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and the New Jersey State Legislature to come up with a new plan.
"New Jersey hospitals have gone four months without charity care reimbursement," said Gary S. Carter, president of the New Jersey Hospital Association. "Governor Whitman and the Legislature have failed to resolve the charity care issue, with no concrete proposal to date regarding a viable funding source. We cannot in good faith wait any longer for a solution from the state."
Mr. Carter said that hospitals would continue to provide medical treatment without regard to a patient's ability to pay. But Mr. Carter said that it had become increasingly difficult for many hospitals to continue caring for the uninsured without any state reimbursement. So far this year, the state payments would have totaled $99 million.
Without the reimbursements, some hospitals, particularly in the state's urban areas, have slowed payments to suppliers. Several hospital administrators have threatened to close wards and outpatient clinics and lay off staff members next month if the state does not resume payments soon.
Governor Whitman met with Republican and Democratic leaders last week to discuss charity care, but no agreement on a new plan was reached. Both organized labor and businesses have objected to the state's continuing dependence on its unemployment insurance fund to pay for most of the charity care program. Almost $1.6 billion has been taken out of the fund to pay for charity care since 1993.
"I understand the hospitals' frustration," Governor Whitman said today. "We are all frustrated. We are narrowing down our differences, and I believe that we will come up with a solution in the not so distant future."
In the State Legislature, both the Assembly Speaker, Jack Collins, and the Senate president, Donald T. DiFrancesco, said that they were moving toward a solution and hoped that legislation would be ready for a vote when the Legislature returns in May.
"The legislators sympathize with the hospitals," said Rae Hutton, a spokeswoman for Mr. DiFrancesco. "They are making every effort to resolve the matter. There is recognition that the hospitals need to be compensated. It is just a matter of how."

HEADLINE: Rivals Bicker In Monrovia As Cease-Fire Holds, Barely

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: MONROVIA, Liberia, April 15

 BODY:
Liberian leaders tried to shore up a tenuous truce today even as sporadic sniper fire rang out in Monrovia and young thugs raced through the streets brandishing assault rifles.
With only an estimated 50 Americans remaining in Monrovia, American troops ended their full-scale evacuation effort on Sunday. About 500 Americans and more than 1,100 other foreigners were lifted to safety since violence convulsed the capital nine days ago. 
 Looters and militia members with grenades and machetes rode through the streets in stolen vehicles today, but they no longer appeared to be menacing civilians now that most shops have already been ransacked.
One militia leader, Charles Taylor, agreed to stop shelling a former military barracks in Monrovia, the Barclay Training Center, where his rival, Roosevelt Johnson, has been holding hundreds of hostages for more than a week.
But Mr. Taylor refused to negotiate with Mr. Johnson over the release of the captives, including 22 West African peacekeepers and some 50 Lebanese civilians.
"As a Government, we are not going to negotiate with these terrorists," Mr. Taylor, who is also a member of Liberia's ruling council, told reporters at his residence in the former Moroccan Embassy in a Monrovia suburb.
West African peacekeeping troops had been sent to the barracks today, Mr. Taylor said, and he urged Mr. Johnson to turn himself in to the United States Embassy or the United Nations.
Mr. Taylor, who touched off the country's civil war with a coup attempt in 1989, has agreed to maintain the cease-fire only if Mr. Johnson surrenders. It was an attempt to capture Mr. Johnson, who is wanted on murder charges, that had sparked the latest round of fighting here on April 6.
The battles since then have left some 60,000 residents of the capital homeless and hungry. No one knows how many people have been killed, but dozens of decaying bodies have been seen littering the streets.
Most of the shops and office buildings in the Liberian capital have been looted and many destroyed since the fighting began.
Liberia, founded by freed American slaves in 1822, had fought a nearly seven-year civil war until all sides accepted a peace accord last year. The war killed more than 150,000 people and ruined much of the economy. When lingering tension between rival groups moved to the capital from the countryside and erupted nine days ago, the peace quickly collapsed.
The United States Ambassador, William Milan, said that while the full-scale evacuations of foreigners had ended on Sunday, United States troops would continue to airlift people out when necessary.
Mr. Taylor's spokesman, Reginald Goodridge, criticized the evacuation operation today. "We do not think that the crisis is deep enough to warrant the airlift of people," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Despite a truce, violence continued yesterday in the streets of Monrovia, the Liberian capital. Young fighters of Charles Taylor's National Patriotic Front brandished weapons after a gunfight in the Mamba Point area. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar at Recent High vs. Mark On Comment by German Banker

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose to a 14-month high against the mark yesterday after the president of the German central bank, Hans Tietmeyer, said he would welcome a further decline in the exchange value of his nation's currency.
The dollar also rose against the Swiss franc and other European currencies, and was little changed against the Japanese yen. 
 Mr. Tietmeyer's comments, made on Saturday at a European Union conference in Verona, Italy, added impetus to a rally that has lifted the dollar 2.7 percent against the mark in the last month. He said a further decline in the mark would help bolster Germany's sputtering economy.
"When you hear Tietmeyer talk like that, it gives confidence for the market to buy dollars," said Don Quattrucci, a currency trader at the Boston Company, a money-management firm.
The dollar's recent gains against the mark have been spurred by the view that the American economy is strong enough to keep the Federal Reserve from cutting interest rates, at a time when many analysts think that rates in Europe are headed lower. Higher rates make deposits in a particular currency more attractive.
The dollar rose as high as 1.5136 marks yesterday, before settling in New York trading at 1.5127 marks, up from 1.5035 marks on Friday. Against the yen, the dollar was unchanged at 108.55.
The Swiss franc fell to a eight-month low against the dollar. Like Germany, Switzerland is grappling with sluggish growth and rising unemployment. The dollar rose as high as 1.2356 Swiss francs, before settling in New York at 1.2347 francs, up from 1.2260 on Friday.
The mark's weakness contributed to the dollar's dip against the yen. When traders want to sell marks and other European currencies for yen, they often do so by first converting their marks to dollars, the most liquid currency. They then sell the dollars for yen -- which gives the yen an indirect boost against the dollar.
Mr. Tietmeyer's comments also spurred speculation that the German central bank, the Bundesbank, would lower interest rates at its policy meeting on Thursday. "We're going to see a rate cut on Thursday," said Gary Sakamoto, a vice president at National Australia Bank. "We're going to see a considerable weakening of the mark."
But other analysts argued that the Germans would leave rates alone for now. "I think the market is 50-50 on this," said Belal Khan, head of corporate currency sales at the Royal Bank of Canada.

HEADLINE: A New Japan Policy?

BYLINE: By Richard N. Haass; Richard N. Haass directs the national security program at the Council on Foreign Relations.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
President Clinton arrives in Tokyo today on a mission to repair the United States' strained relations with Japan. Fortunately, the Administration has indicated he will jettison his longstanding trade-first focus and concentrate for now on the strategic relationship between the countries.
But this belated effort to reinvigorate our most important Asian alliance will be for naught unless both countries agree on specific steps to restore stability to the region, and the Administration shifts away from its trade-centered policy permanently. 
 President Clinton and his advisers -- especially Mickey Kantor, who served as United States Trade Representative until being named Commerce Secretary last week -- have largely ignored the political and military dimensions of the relationship and have focused almost exclusively on America's trade deficit. In this, the Clinton Administration is hardly unique. The Bush Administration also stumbled badly in an awkward attempt to force Japan to open its markets. But the situation has grown more tense, and at the worst possible time.
North Korea is on the verge of economic collapse, and three times this month its soldiers have entered the demilitarized zone separating it from South Korea. This may or may not be part of a larger plan, but we cannot rule out a suicidal attempt to force reunification. President Clinton and Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto should agree on a plan to deliver food and humanitarian aid to North Korea, but also publicly state that any attack would mark the North's demise.
China's economic boom is a major concern, as economic power tends to translate into political and military power. Only America and Japan, working together, could contain a belligerent China. This week, they should work out a plan for sanctions and Japanese support of possible American military action if China uses military force against Taiwan.
President Clinton must also help Japan become more active in world affairs. This means encouraging Tokyo to expand its Self-Defense Force to take on a more meaningful role in United Nations peacekeeping operations. In return, he might pledge to help Japan eventually get a seat on the United Nations Security Council.
And Mr. Clinton should press Japan to help isolate Iran's rogue Government, by refusing to reschedule overdue loans and refusing to provide further credits to the country's electrical industry.
It is vital that the United States not slip back into its trade-first ways when the current crises pass. An Administration that treats Japan like an adversary sends a powerful signal that our most important alliance in Asia has ended. Such an attitude is bad for trade. It feeds protectionist sentiment here and in Japan and ignores the fact that American exports to Japan have increased by 35 percent over the last three years.
Over time, a Japan alienated from the United States would become more assertive and independent in its foreign policy and economic expansionism. It would also be less likely to support American-sponsored regional efforts.
The United States would be smarter to take our trade concerns to the World Trade Organization, where we would gain the support of European and Asian nations that are also frustrated by Japan's protectionism. It is easier for Japan to make face-saving concessions in a global forum than to appear "defeated" in bilateral talks. When it comes time to talk trade in Tokyo, Mr. Clinton should enlist Mr. Hashimoto in working toward giving the W.T.O. broader jurisdiction over claims of unfairly restricted competition.
The cold war may be over, but political and military concerns are not obsolete. American foreign policy in Asia must be more than trade policy. Indeed, trade always suffers during instability and conflict.

HEADLINE: Big Steelmakers Shape Up;
U.S. Mills Win Back Business at Home and Abroad

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

DATELINE: SPARROWS POINT, Md.

 BODY:
Richard Moore was laid off from the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's sprawling mill here in 1981, one of tens of thousands of workers shed by the American steel industry as it fought to cut bloated costs and fend off surging imports.
Now, after a nearly 15-year stint selling auto parts, Mr. Moore is back on the job, one of 400 production workers hired here last year, the first new arrivals since 1979. More are expected to be hired soon. 
 "The work here is dirtier, hotter, more dangerous and strenuous" than the sales job, Mr. Moore said during a brief break. But, at $24 an hour in base pay and benefits, it is also "much better than what I was doing," he added.
The return of Mr. Moore and his colleagues -- and others like them at steel plants around the country -- marks the return as well of an industry that was nearly given up for dead in the United States a decade or so ago.
Slimmer now and better run, American steelmakers are taking back more and more pieces of their domestic business from competitors in Japan and other countries. And at levels not seen for half a century, they are going abroad with a vengeance, more than holding their own on foreign turf in terms of quality and price, even with the added expense of shipping.
Last year, they shipped 7.1 million tons of steel slabs, sheets and structural beams to foreign countries, nearly doubling the 3.8 million tons exported in 1994. It was the best export performance since 1940, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute, the principal industry trade group. And orders are booming this year.
As explanation of why he expects to stay on this time around, Mr. Moore pointed to the fact that the tin-plating line he works on had sold its full 1996 production capacity by mid-March. Last year, Bethlehem exported 500,000 tons of steel from the plant here, along the Chesapeake Bay about 12 miles southeast of Baltimore. That is up from just 50,000 tons the year before. All in all, the performance last year and the strong orders so far this year "confirm that the U.S. steel industry has become competitive on a world basis," said Peter F. Marcus, a metals analyst at Paine Webber.
To be sure, the United States still imports more steel than it exports, at least partly because so many outmoded mills have been closed that the domestic industry cannot fully supply the market. Imports totaled 24.4 million tons last year. And the bulk of the hiring here and at other plants is to replace retiring workers, not to add to the payroll.
Still, in one basic category, hot rolled sheet steel, the United States has been a net exporter since last June. And overall employment in the industry -- now thought to be around 170,000 -- has begun to increase as the first few of nearly a dozen new mills scheduled to open by the end of the decade have started production. Taken together, the numbers show just how far American steelmakers have come in changing their old ways, analysts and industry executives say.
Those ways were marked by a full plate of inefficiencies: overstaffing, outmoded production processes and poor quality control. Foreign steelmakers, led by the Japanese and the Europeans, saw their chance and moved in. But there were domestic threats to the steel giants as well, from so-called mini-mills, upstart operators that turned out low-cost steel from scrap rather than from raw materials. And some foreign companies bought plants in the United States and began to revamp them.
Eventually, the big American steelmakers got serious about survival. They slashed payrolls, shuttered the most antiquated of their hulking mills and spent billions on new technology and equipment.
With costs down and quality up, the industry has been positioned of late to take advantage of currency swings that have made American products cheaper abroad. Besides making American steel itself more attractive to foreign markets, the relative weakness of the dollar has helped many domestically made products, from cars to appliances, that contain steel. And that, in turn, has given the American steelmakers a chance to retake at least some of their home ground.
Noting that the Chrysler Corporation is exporting steel to Europe to make Jeeps there and that cars containing American steel are being exported in larger numbers than they used to be, Michelle Applebaum, an analyst with Salomon Brothers, said: "The Rust Bowl in the United States has become competitive again. The steel market is the primary beneficiary of the new competitive heartland in the United States and is stronger than it has been in decades."
The evidence of the shift is striking in sheet steel, the biggest category and a major component of cars, building materials and appliances. At the beginning of 1995, Ms. Applebaum said, imports accounted for a net market share (subtracting exports) of 17 percent. But by the end of the year that figure was down to 5 percent. "That means that a full 12 percent share was given back to the U.S. market," she said, equaling twice the output of one large steelmaker, Inland Steel Industries.
One measure of efficiency is the amount of labor it takes to produce a given quantity of steel. According to Mr. Marcus, the average integrated mill in the United States requires 4.42 hours of labor to produce a metric ton, or 2,200 pounds, of steel. That compares with 4.49 hours in Japan, 4.69 in Germany and 4.71 in Britain. Twenty years ago, when far more labor was required, Japan was the leader, at 11.36 hours, followed by the United States, at 12.49.
Steel executives say exports provide a long-term opportunity, though shipments are likely to vary from year to year, depending on domestic demand. Because it costs about $50 a ton to ship steel overseas, the profit margin is less than in a domestic sale. But because blast furnaces must be run continuously, disgorging ton after ton of molten pig iron, manufacturers like having an alternative market if demand falls at home.
"Right now, the domestic market is more attractive, so our exports will probably be less this year than in 1995," said Paul Wilhelm, president of the U.S. Steel Group of the USX Corporation. U.S. Steel exported 1.5 million of the 11.4 million tons of steel it made last year. But the company is a permanent player in the export business, with long-term overseas accounts, Mr. Wilhelm said.
John J. Connelly, the president of U.S. Steel International Inc., added, "We see this as an ongoing 4 to 5 percent of our business through thick and thin."
And while the cheap dollar helps keep that market open, industry experts say, there are other factors.
"Currency has an effect, but in the end if you are low-cost, high-quality and meet customer expectations, you will get business," said Curtis H. Barnette, Bethlehem Steel's chairman.
This newfound efficiency and quality will have increasing importance in coming years as the new mills begin opening in this country. If products from the new mills can push out imports rather than cannibalize older mills, as has been the case in the past, jobs at places like Sparrows Point look like a better long-term bet.
All the start-ups are patterned on mini-mills, which have small, highly efficient work forces. The Nucor Corporation, the mini-mill leader, can make steel at some of its mills with less than half an hour of labor a ton.
But the mini-mills may no longer enjoy the big advantage over traditional mills that they had in the past, some experts say. In part, that is because the traditional mills have become so much more efficient.
Another reason has to do with the production process of most mini-mills: They have to live with the impurities in the recycled materials they use, and the price of high-quality scrap has been rising. Integrated mills, because they work from raw materials, can better tune the chemistry of their products.
Because the price of scrap is likely to keep rising as new mini-mills add to demand, many companies are investing in ways to separate iron from ore that do not involve blast furnaces, which are costly to build and operate. Nucor, for example, is converting ore into iron carbide, a form of the metal that can be added to scrap.
As the mini-mills lose some of their edge, the slimmed-down integrated mills should be able to hold their own better on the domestic front, analysts predict.
At Sparrows Point, the changes have been profound. In the 1950's and 60's, it was more like an independent empire than a factory. The mill employed about 30,000 people and there was a company town, complete with company-owned housing, stores and schools. There was even a police force and a semi-professional football team.
In the late 60's, the company decided to end this paternalistic system and to gradually close down the town. New mill buildings swallowed the remains of the town, and the workers who stayed on the payroll moved to Baltimore and the surrounding area.
"There was a high school where the blast furnace is now," said Duane Dunham, the president of Bethlehem's Sparrows Point division.
Over the last decade, Bethlehem poured in $1.6 billion for improvements. Everything in the mill is automated and run by computer, allowing only a few people to control the movement of vast amounts of material by watching wall-sized displays. Today the plant employs just 3,250 people and can make 3.5 million tons of steel a year, about one-third of its capacity in the old days.
The attitude of the employees and their union, the United Steelworkers of America, has changed as well. At the tin plate plant to which Mr. Moore is assigned, for instance, the rigid union work rules of the past have become flexible.
"We are all cross-trained, so we can fill in for people who are not here," said Brenda Matthews, one of the new workers, adding that little distinction was made between men and women. "Women do the same jobs as men," she said, with one exception: Only the men load the heavy bars of tin needed in the electroplating process.
Even some of the veterans are whistling a new tune. James Henson has been at Sparrows Point for 25 years, mostly as an operator of a tractor that moves coils of sheet steel prior to shipment.
"In the old days, we had people chasing coils all over the place," he said, waving at a warehouse that is easily as long as three football fields. "Now it is all on computer and we are shipping to our customers on a just-in-time basis. Every tractor operator has a computer and every coil is logged in. It's better this way."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Gain On Treasuries For 3d Session

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were higher yesterday despite a lack of new economic data.
While bonds have now posted gains in three consecutive sessions, traders and analysts say the market has not shifted from its bearish tone. 
 Some investors were expecting a continuation of Friday's strong rally. But many stayed on the sidelines yesterday and trading was light, typical for a Monday.
Traders said market participants needed to see more evidence that the economy was expanding at a pace fast enough to prompt the Federal Reserve into raising short-term interest rates to keep inflation from accelerating. The market remains unsure what course the Fed will take.
After Friday's sharp gains, trading yesterday was largely in a crossfire between investors selling to take profits and short-sellers, who had bet on prices falling, buying to limit their losses.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond settled up 7/32, to 90 2/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 6.78 percent, from 6.79 percent on Friday.
At the Treasury's regular weekly bill auction yesterday, rates were lower as investor interest picked up because the offering was smaller, totaling $21 billion, down from $27 billion last week.
The three-month rate averaged 4.87 percent, compared with 5.03 percent a week ago, while the six-month bill rate averaged 5.03 percent, down from 5.19 percent.
Gary Thayer, senior economist at A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis, said it was hard to say what moved the market yesterday. He noted that the market was so concerned with inflation that an announcement that Post Cereals would cut prices was cheered.
"The action may have been interpreted by the market as a sign that the recent rise in commodity prices may not filter through as inflation," he said.
A decline in the Commodity Research Bureau's index of 17 commodities also helped ease concerns about inflation, he said. The index fell 0.89 point, to 259.26.
In any case, Kim Rupert, an economist with MMS International in San Francisco, said that "the market has probably overacted to the rise in commodities prices over the short term."
Greg Jones, also an economist with MMS International, said the market was behaving in April much as it did in March, appearing hopeless one day and then invincible the next. But this month, he said, the market has been able to recoup most of its losses after a stronger-than-expected employment report.
In the futures market, the June bond contract closed at its high price of 110 11/32.
"Now it looks like a consolidation pattern for the next few weeks is setting up," said Robin Mesch, chief fixed-income analyst with Thomson Research. "And the door is open for the bond price to rise to 111 6/32."
Following are the results of yesterday's Treasury bill auction of new three- and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
The WPP Group cautiously re-enters the acquisition arena.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
THE world's largest agency company, the WPP Group, is cautiously putting expansion back on its agenda -- including additional investments in new media ventures in the United States -- after returning from the brink of extinction.
"Given where our business is concentrated, it makes sense to grow through acquisition," Martin Sorrell, chief executive of WPP of London, said. He spoke last week in a wide-ranging, 75-minute interview during a visit to New York. 
 For instance, Mr. Sorrell said, WPP, which bought 5 percent of the Hotwired on-line service from Wired Ventures, plans to make a similar investment "in the next couple weeks," with the goal of having "investments of a couple million dollars in four or five situations."
Although "our objective is not to go into the venture capital business," he added, "if agencies behave like dinosaurs, they will become like dinosaurs." He said, "We need to explore how advertising content can be developed in the new media."
WPP billings rose 15.2 percent last year to $22.7 billion, from $19.7 billion in 1994, according to the trade publication Advertising Age. WPP holdings include the global agency networks Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide and the J. Walter Thompson Company as well as a smaller network, Conquest Europe, and shops that specialize in corporate identity consulting, direct marketing and health care advertising.
Mr. Sorrell said WPP was interested in acquiring an Asian-Pacific market research company, as part of efforts to "focus on the faster-growing parts of the world."
And, he added, the thought of buying a small, creatively focused agency -- one of the so-called hot shops so eagerly sought by cutting-edge clients -- was "a fairly seductive idea" that WPP executives were "actively thinking about."
Still, Mr. Sorrell, 51, who was burned earlier this decade, was discouraging any suggestions that WPP might embark on a buying spree. Debts taken on during an acquisition binge that began after Mr. Sorrell took control of WPP in 1986, which were aggravated by the worldwide advertising recession, forced WPP to within an eyelash of going under.
"Obviously, we've come through a difficult time," Mr. Sorrell said. "The point is: It has to be carefully done, carefully thought through."
Mr. Sorrell said he preferred "organic growth," such as a media-buying unit that WPP "is probably going to go ahead" and form by combining the separate media buying operations of Ogilvy and Thompson.
"Agencies have to work with the new media conglomerates like Disney and ABC and Turner and Time Warner to come up with greater solutions for clients to make brands famous," he added.
Analysts who follow the agency industry said Mr. Sorrell's low-key approach was the best -- and perhaps only -- course for WPP.
"There's no doubt they're out of the woods," said Lorna Tilbian at Panmure Gordon in London. She said that "impressive targets have actually been achieved" in profit margins, which climbed from 6 percent in 1992 to 9 percent in 1995 and a projected 10 percent this year -- on the way to 12 percent in 1998.
"But I don't think there are major acquisitions to be made," Ms. Tilbian said, adding that WPP would benefit far more from concentrating on "controlling costs as revenues rise, as the majority of that falls to the bottom line."
Alan J. Gottesman, managing director at West End Communications/Consulting in New York, said: "In recent years, if there was a critical problem at WPP, it wasn't on the advertising side, it was on the business side. And that seems to have gone away.
"But we're talking advertising here, not brain surgery," he added. "Very, very rarely does a major, major agency manage itself out of existence."
Mr. Gottesman said that "even if a deal made sense," WPP stock "would probably get clobbered" because investors would look askance at Mr. Sorrell and "give it a 'there he goes again' reaction."
Even so, he added, "is it in Mr. Sorrell's nature to show he's in the game? My guess is he's Sorrell-y tempted."
Mr. Sorrell said: "I will probably admit to never being happy, being a most discontented soul. The business is in pretty good shape, starting to fire on all cylinders. We're moving in the right direction. But we could always do better."
Mr. Sorrell said he judged WPP's performance against that of four other agency companies. Two are public: the Omnicom Group, No. 2 in the Advertising Age rankings with billings of $20.2 billion in 1995, and the Interpublic Group of Companies, No. 3 at $16.1 billion. Their profit margins last year ranged from 12 percent to 14 percent, compared with WPP's 9 percent to 10 percent.
The two private agency companies Mr. Sorrell uses as benchmarks -- Young & Rubicam Inc., No. 6 in 1995 at $9.9 billion, and the Leo Burnett Company, No. 10 at $5.4 billion -- do not release information about their profit margins.
This was the second time in a month that Mr. Sorrell, who had previously shied from reporters, gave an interview; the other was with Campaign, the British advertising trade publication.
"He's launched an aggressive campaign to communicate the company's turnaround story," Mr. Gottesman said.
There are already results: WPP stock, which traded recently around $26, closed at $30.50 yesterday in Nasdaq trading, near its 52-week high of $31.50.

HEADLINE: Wildcat Strike Shuts Down a G.M. Plant

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 15

 BODY:
A wildcat strike shut down a factory in Lordstown, Ohio, today that makes some of the General Motors Corporation's most popular cars, the latest sign of continued labor problems at the world's largest auto maker.
While there were several signs that the strike could prove brief, the work stoppage was another sign of the deep discontent on the floors of several large G.M. factories. That discontent could make it more difficult for the national leaders of the United Automobile Workers union to work out a compromise this summer with G.M.'s top management before the U.A.W.'s national contract with the Big Three auto makers expires on Sept. 14. 
 All 1,800 workers on the day shift at Lordstown walked off the job today at 9:30 A.M. to protest G.M.'s dismissal of the longtime chairman of the union's local bargaining committee, Al Alli. The reasons for Mr. Alli's dismissal were not entirely clear, with one version being that he did not clock in for duty properly. Only part of the evening shift reported for work tonight.
"Attendance is down, but we have enough people to run limited production," said Ray Deibel, a G.M. spokesman.
The union's national leadership did not authorize the strike and quickly urged the workers to return to work. Tony Zone, the president of the local in Lordstown, and Mr. Alli issued a statement also calling for an end to the walkout.
The Lordstown factory has a total of 5,500 hourly workers on three shifts, each of four 10-hour days, producing 6,500 to 7,000 cars a week.
Today's strike puts some pressure on G.M. because the Lordstown factory makes the Chevrolet Cavaliers and Pontiac Sunfires, which have been selling briskly even though G.M. offers few discounts on them.
"They are G.M.'s most successful cars," said Christopher W. Cedergren, an analyst at the Autopacific Group, a consulting and marketing company in Santa Ana, Calif. "That's a plant you don't want to be down for a long time."
But today's strike appears much less serious than the 17-day strike last month at G.M.'s two brake factories in Dayton, Ohio, which crippled the company's North American operations for an after-tax loss that the company estimates at $900 million. The Lordstown factory does not produce parts for G.M.'s other North American assembly operations, Mr. Deibel said.
In addition to the Lordstown factory workers, employees at G.M. factories in Janesville, Wis.; Doraville, Ga., and Oklahoma City have been threatening walkouts this year. But the U.A.W.'s national leaders have been resisted authorizing further walkouts, as they review the hard-line stance taken during the Dayton strike by the auto maker, which challenged the striking workers' unemployment benefits.

HEADLINE: Comptroller Approves Shift Of State Jobs From Albany

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 15

 BODY:
State Comptroller H. Carl McCall today approved a scaled-down version of Gov. George E. Pataki's plan to move thousands of state-financed workers from heavily Democratic areas to Republican districts, ending a bitter political standoff with the Governor.
Mr. McCall has been drawing intense criticism from the Pataki administration because of his decision last month to block the Governor's original proposal to move nearly 5,000 state-financed jobs from the Democratic bastions of New York City and Albany to Republican areas upstate. 
 Democrats had accused the Pataki administration of making a blatant political payoff in trying to shift the jobs to Republican areas. In blocking the original plan, Mr. McCall said it had so many fiscal gimmicks that it violated state law, and that moving workers to vacant office buildings owned by I.B.M. in Kingston and Glendale required legislative approval because it would add to the state's debt.
But today, Mr. McCall announced that he had approved a revised plan that would move only about 3,300 workers from Albany to the Hudson Valley city of Kingston. His latest decision disappointed the Comptroller's fellow Democrats, as Mr. McCall singlehandedly had power to block the deal.
But Mr. McCall said he had little choice but to approve the new plan, which he said did not have many of the flaws in the original one. The original deal had required the state to enter into a lease-purchase agreement to own the I.B.M. buildings, and thus obligated it to take on debt without legislative approval.
The new deal, however, simply allows the Fleet Financial Group, which processes state tax forms, to move 3,650 of its state-financed workers into the vacant buildings in Kingston under a lease agreement it reached with I.B.M. Fleet has been urging the state to allow it to move the jobs because the office space in Kingston, about 60 miles to the south in Ulster County, is cheaper and more suited for an expansion it is considering.
"This is not a perfect deal," the Comptroller said. "I do not approve of economic development policies that shift jobs from one region of the state to another. Cutting a branch of a tree in Albany and sticking it in the ground in Kingston doesn't mean you've planted a forest. The acrimony between communities that has been generated by this proposal will be difficult to heal."
Mr. McCall also said the deal would cost the state more, though he could not provide an exact figure.
At a news conference this afternoon, Mr. Pataki defended the deal, saying that it would save New York money and sent a message to businesses that the state would work to keep them. "It was clearly worth the fight," he said.
As Comptroller, Mr. McCall is required to review most new state contracts and changes in most existing ones. Mr. McCall's decision today involved amending the contract that the Fleet Financial Group already has with the state.
The Governor's original plan to transfer state jobs was proposed about a year ago as an effort to consolidate the state's data processing in the vacant I.B.M. buildings. The Pataki administration has estimated that the original plan would have saved $52 million a year -- a claim that Mr. McCall has viewed skeptically.
The job-transfer plan has been one of the administration's most controversial proposals, with cities and towns either attacking it or applauding it, depending on whether they gained or lost the jobs.
The original deal was even criticized by Mr. Pataki's most powerful ally in the Legislature, State Senator Joseph L. Bruno, the Republican majority leader, whose district, the 43d in nearby Rensselaer County, includes many state employees who work in Albany.
Today's decision by the Comptroller stirred an outcry among Democrats, who in the end acknowledged that Mr. McCall could not have made any other decision, lest he be accused of being political.
"The Comptroller's hands were tied," said Michael G. Breslin, the Albany County Executive. "They snuck this deal by him on a technicality. It's clear that the Governor is directing what on the face appears to be a simple contract between Fleet and I.B.M."

NEW YORK
N.R.A. Affiliate Gave to Goetz
A legal group founded by the National Rifle Association gave $20,000 for the defense of Bernhard H. Goetz, who is being sued by a man who was left paralyzed after Mr. Goetz shot him in a Manhattan subway 12 years ago. The contribution is part of the tens of thousands of dollars that the group gives each year to criminal and civil defendants who have used handguns in self-defense. [Page A1.]

Mayor Giuliani swore in his new Police Commissioner, Howard Safir, with pageantry worthy of a mayoral inauguration -- and indeed it was the Mayor, as the city's premier crimefighter, who was the focus of the event. [B1.]

Altogether, there are at least 50 Holocaust memorials, research centers and libraries in place or being planned across the country. Increasingly, one hears Jewish voices asking whether they are all necessary. NYC by Clyde Haberman. [B1.]

Success Story Ends in Death
There was a time when they would do anything for each other. But as Yakov and Rita Gluzman grew older, they papered over chasms in their marriage. HEADLINE: Benefits From Transit Spending Said to Outweigh Costs by 5 to 1

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE 

 BODY:
For every dollar that local officials spend on mass transit in the New York region, residents get back about five dollars in economic benefits, a Federal report states.
The report, released this week by the Federal Transit Administration, found that residents in areas with large mass transit systems, like New York City, already save $30 billion each year in transportation costs by relying more on mass transit, and that improvements in public transit would increase these savings. 
 The study is the first time Federal officials have attempted to quantify the economic and related benefits of spending on mass transit. And at a time when mass transit agencies across the country are competing with public schools and the health care industry for scarce public funds, officials say they hope this report will highlight mass transit's importance and its economic worth.
The report estimated that while officials in New York and northern New Jersey spent $4.2 billion on mass transit in 1994, the region received $20 billion in benefits because of cheaper public transportation, more vibrant neighborhoods and business centers, and less traffic.
"This report makes the case why we should subsidize transit," said Gordon J. Linton, the administrator of the Federal Transit Administration, which distributes Federal money for mass transit. "While transit does not pay for itself, the benefits far outweigh the investment," he said.
The report looked at the economic impact of mass transit on major cities and small towns across the country. In Chicago, for instance, officials spent roughly $1 billion on mass transit, and received an estimated $5 billion in benefits; Philadelphia spent half a billion dollars and got $2 billion in benefits, and Washington spent about the same amount and got about $3 billion.

HEADLINE: Dole and Ethanol Industry Count on Each Other

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS FRANTZ 

 BODY:
Last September, just as the House was set to gut the billion-dollar subsidy that supports the ethanol industry, Senator Bob Dole paid a call on Speaker Newt Gingrich.
"Senator Dole was there to say this thing was going nowhere in the Senate," recalled Gov. Terry E. Branstad of Iowa, who attended the meeting. 
 Faced with opposition from Mr. Dole, the majority leader, and other farm-state Congressmen, the Speaker had the bill killed. Mr. Dole had preserved the subsidy and saved the ethanol industry $1.8 billion.
At a time when Congress has been overhauling the nation's systems of agricultural subsidies, and public officials across the country have considered huge cuts in benefits to big corporations, ethanol has been untouched. Largely through the efforts of Mr. Dole, it has remained one of the most subsidized American industries. The meeting with Mr. Gingrich was only the most recent occasion in which Mr. Dole has rescued ethanol, a corn-based alcohol that is mixed with gasoline to create gasohol.
Gasohol was first touted in the 1970's as a miracle product that would ease American dependence on foreign oil, improve income for farmers and help the environment. Those assertions have been challenged, but Mr. Dole, both in public and behind closed doors, has exerted his political muscle to protect the industry, saying that by doing so, he was helping Midwestern farmers. Along the way, he has also helped his biggest financial patron, Dwayne O. Andreas.
Mr. Andreas's company, Archer Daniels Midland Company, dominates an American ethanol industry that by most accounts would not exist without the estimated $6 billion in Federal subsidies it has received since Mr. Dole sponsored legislation establishing the tax break nearly 20 years ago.
Mr. Dole has never concealed his relationship with Mr. Andreas, one of the most politically active executives in the country. Now, as Mr. Dole closes in on the Republican Presidential nomination, an examination of his unwavering backing of ethanol provides a window on how the Senator operates at the intersection of business and politics.
Mr. Dole's efforts on behalf of the ethanol industry have come even in the face of opposition from powerful Republicans like President Ronald Reagan. Mr. Dole has helped erect trade barriers to foreign ethanol and has engineered an anonymous amendment that effectively shuttered the Caribbean ethanol industry for three years.
"As a national leader on agriculture policy, Senator Dole is a longtime supporter of this clean-burning all-American renewable fuel to promote new markets for American grain, jobs for our nation's farm belt, and energy self-sufficiency," his office said in a statement released last week, which added that Kansas has 13,500 corn farms and four ethanol plants.
Over the years, Mr. Andreas, his family and his colleagues have been among Mr. Dole's most generous political supporters, contributing $228,800 to Mr. Dole's political organizations since 1979.
They have also given $1 million to the American Red Cross since Mr. Dole's wife, Elizabeth Hanford Dole, became its president in 1990.
Mr. Dole has also flown often on A.D.M. jets and collected thousands of dollars from the company for speeches before such payments were banned.
Mrs. Dole bought the couple's beachfront apartment in Florida from Mr. Andreas for a price that was questioned as possibly below market value.
A.D.M. has other political allies. Indeed, Mr. Andreas, the wealthy chairman of A.D.M., has been a well-known contributor to both parties since the early 1970's, when he gave President Richard M. Nixon $100,000 in cash and was acquitted of illegally donating $100,000 to Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey's 1968 Presidential campaign. From 1988 to 1994, he and others associated with A.D.M. contributed $1.6 million to the Republican Party and $814,000 to the Democratic Party.
In 1994, Mr. Andreas was co-chairman of a Democratic fund-raising dinner and contributed $100,000 to the event.
A few days later, under prodding from the White House, the Environmental Protection Agency issued a ruling requiring that one-tenth of all gasoline contain ethanol.
The White House denied any connection between the events. A Federal appeals court overturned the rule.
"Ethanol is a textbook example of an industry that simply would not exist were it not for very generous tax subsidies and pure political muscle," said Stephen Moore, a director at the Cato Institute, a research organization based in Washington that is opposed to subsidies.
 
Friends in High Places
From Its Inception, Industry Had Help
From the start, ethanol has depended on its friends in Washington, and none has been more loyal than Mr. Dole.
When the Arab oil boycotts created long gas lines in the 1970's, gasohol, which is one part ethanol and nine parts gasoline, was seen by some as an alternative to foreign oil. Today Americans burn 1.4 billion gallons of ethanol a year in their gas tanks.
Mr. Dole has promoted ethanol since 1970 when he urged President Nixon to study grain-based fuels to help fight pollution. By then, he also was close enough to Mr. Andreas to have pushed the Environmental Protection Agency to hire his son-in-law, William McMurtrie, as an enforcement lawyer.
"Senator Dole's office called and absolutely insisted on the appointment of William McMurtrie," according to a memorandum written by John D. Ehrlichman, an assistant to Mr. Nixon, on Aug. 25, 1971.
In fact, while another memorandum shows that Mr. Dole was frustrated during those years by his inability to land Federal jobs for his own constituents, he pushed hard enough at the E.P.A. to assure Mr. McMurtrie's appointment.
Mr. McMurtrie, who kept the E.P.A. job for about a year, said in an interview that he did not know whether Mr. Andreas had intervened on his behalf.
The first major Federal outlay for ethanol, a $60 million loan program for new distilleries, was passed by Congress in 1977 over the objections of the Department of Agriculture. Mr. Dole was one of the bill's sponsors, and A.D.M. started ethanol production that year.
"Bob Dole and Dwayne Andreas argued that there was a national security issue here, and it was on that basis that it was sold to the Congress and the public," said Bob Bergland, Secretary of Agriculture at the time under President Jimmy Carter. "Our studies showed that ethanol took more energy to make than it produced."
A year later, Mr. Dole sponsored legislation creating the ethanol subsidy. President Carter signed the bill in 1979.
The subsidy provided gasoline marketers with a tax credit for the ethanol they used in gasohol. The exemption has since risen to 54 cents a gallon.
The subsidy translates into less tax revenue for the Highway Trust Fund, which finances road and bridge repairs.
The Treasury Department has calculated that the exemption has cost the fund $5.9 billion since 1983.
A.D.M. has dominated the industry from the start, and controls roughly 50 percent of the American market today. Analysts estimated that about 10 percent of its $12.6 billion in revenues last year came from ethanol.
 
Cost-Benefit Analysis
Its Value Is Unclear, But Support Is Firm
For years, Government studies have questioned ethanol's value. A 1986 Department of Agriculture study said that, by driving up demand for corn, the subsidy raises food costs for consumers. "Direct cash payments to corn growers would be more economical than attempting to boost farm income through ethanol subsidies," the report concluded.
Advocates argue that ethanol burns cleaner than gasoline, and studies show that it does reduce certain pollutants. But the Congressional Budget Office said last year that ethanol's quick evaporation, especially in hot weather, contributes to ozone pollution.
Mr. Dole dismisses the criticisms. "Senator Dole's support for ethanol is quite simple," said the statement from his office. "It's good agriculture policy, it's good energy policy, it's good for the environment."
Mr. Dole has gone to some lengths to protect the industry. In 1980, he pushed through the Senate a bill to impose tariffs on Brazilian ethanol and later forced the reversal of a Customs Service ruling that would have allowed some Brazilian ethanol into the country duty free.
In 1982, President Reagan told Congress he wanted to eliminate "ineffective business subsidies," including ethanol tax breaks. Mr. Dole, then chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, pledged publicly to save the subsidy. He did so.
The year Mr. Dole saved the subsidy, his wife bought a three-room apartment in the Sea View Hotel in Bal Harbour, Fla., from Mr. Andreas, who was chairman of the corporation that controlled the hotel.
When the transaction was disclosed in 1987, questions were raised about whether the $150,000 price was the fair market value. The purchase would have to have been at market value to comply with Senate rules.
A Sea View official, who asked not to be identified, said Mr. Andreas had set the price "as a personal thing." A similar unit two floors below the Doles' apartment had sold a few months earlier for $190,000.
Mr. Andreas declined through a spokeswoman to be interviewed for this article. In 1987 he and the Doles defended the price as fair.
 
Working Things Out
Dole's Persistence Has Often Paid Off
Not all Mr. Dole's efforts on behalf of ethanol have been public. Buried within the 1986 tax reform bill was Amendment 423, one of many measures protecting special interests inserted during closed-door talks.
Former Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Chicago Democrat who was the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee then, said Mr. Dole was so predictably loyal to ethanol that it could be used against him in negotiations.
"Archer Daniels Midland is an Illinois company, but I was never supportive because they had a champion in Bob Dole," Mr. Rostenkowski said in an interview. "I'd argue against ethanol because I knew I could get something for it from Dole."
The stage was set for the Dole amendment in 1983, when Congress approved a development plan dropping import duties on Caribbean products under certain conditions.
American ethanol producers complained that the plan gave the Caribbean producers an unfair advantage.
When the tax bill was passed, Amendment 423 required that Caribbean ethanol be 70 percent locally produced to qualify for the duty-free status. Meeting that proved too expensive to allow the Caribbean producers to compete.
In 1989, Mr. Dole attached to a trade bill a provision extending the domestic ethanol subsidy to 2000.
Mr. Dole temporarily blocked a vote on the trade bill in an effort to win passage of the extension. Eventually he accepted a deal in which the extension was eliminated and he was promised hearings on the issue in 1990. But then Mr. Dole simply attached the 10-year extension to the 1990 tax bill.

HEADLINE: New York's Dynamic New Media

 BODY:
New York City is justly proud of its world-class television, book publishing and newspaper industries, which are mainstays of the regional economy. But according to a study released yesterday by a state development agency, these traditional businesses are not the largest media industries in the region. That honor belongs to the new-media industry, the typically small businesses that sell interactive software and on-line computer services.
The study, based on surveys, interviews and analysis by the accounting firm Coopers & Lybrand, estimates that there are more than 4,000 new-media companies in the metropolitan region, employing over 70,000 workers. In New York City alone there are about 1,350 such businesses with more than 18,000 full-time employees. By comparison, television hires about 17,000 workers and the book industry accounts for fewer than 14,000. 
 New-media companies are clearly becoming a dynamic core of the regional economy. The question that emerges is whether the city is nurturing or squelching the industry's vibrancy.
New York has the potential to become the nation's focus of this new industry. New-media companies write entertainment and business software and design services that businesses provide over the Internet, the worldwide network of computer users. These companies hire creative and technical personnel who work with advertisers, publishers, educators, financial services experts, broadcasters, fashion experts and artists. New York offers a rich array of people for new-media companies to hire and an equally rich array of customers, especially in advertising and publishing, who seek computer outlets for their products.
Interactive computer companies in the region expect to double or triple their employment over just the next three years. However, they pinpoint threats that could stymie these rosy projections. One threat is taxes -- in particular the stiff taxes the city imposes on small-business owners. The unincorporated-business tax and related measures hit entrepreneurs with a second layer of taxation, on top of personal income taxes. New-media companies are almost all entrepreneurial-based. They also complain of infrastructure roadblocks, such as the excessive time and expense of installing high-speed telecommunications lines for computer data.
New-media owners are not calling for special tax breaks, subsidies or targeted infrastructure projects. Instead they want measures, such as reducing small-business taxes, that companies in most industries would find useful. Mayor Rudolph Giuliani will find it hard to accommodate that request in a budget that is already cash-starved and underfinances education and other key services.
New York is ideally positioned to incubate interactive computer business as it roars into the 21st century. It need not do anything special for these companies. But it has an even harder task -- removing the barriers that face every small business struggling to survive in a high-cost city.

HEADLINE: Clinton Visits Korea and New Peace Talks Are Proposed

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: CHEJU, South Korea, Tuesday, April 16

 BODY:
Against the backdrop of recent North Korean military incursions into the demilitarized zone between the two Koreas, President Clinton and President Kim Young Sam of South Korea today proposed four-party talks intended to bring about a permanent peace agreement that would replace the 1953 armistice that ended the Korean War.
The two leaders unveiled their plan for the talks -- which would include the two Koreas, China and the United States -- as Mr. Clinton, who has styled himself an international peacemaker in this election year, began a one-week trip focusing on security issues in Asia and Russia. 
 A joint statement released after Mr. Clinton and Mr. Kim met on this resort island off the southern coast of South Korea said the two Presidents had proposed to convene a four-party meeting "as soon as possible and without precondition" to "initiate a process aimed at achieving a permanent peace agreement."
"North Korea has said it wants peace," Mr. Clinton said at a joint news conference with Mr. Kim. "This is our proposal to achieve it and we hope and expect Pyongyang will take it seriously."
North and South Korea have been at a stalemate for 43 years following a bitter war on the peninsula that was ended with a 1953 armistice agreement that imposed a cease-fire and set up a demilitarized buffer zone but stopped short of a permanent peace.
Mr. Kim said the proposal had already been conveyed to China and North Korea. "Of course we do not expect that North Korea can respond to our proposal positively tomorrow," he said. But he added: "Time is on our side and I think that this is perhaps the last choice that North Korea can make to resolve the Korean question. I believe that eventually North Korea will accept our proposal."
As part of the joint statement, Mr. Clinton also pledged "the steadfast U.S. commitment" to the security of South Korea and reafffirmed the strength of the security alliance under which 37,000 American troops are stationed in South Korea. And he reiterated several times at the news conference that the United States would not negotiate a bilateral peace agreement with North Korea. "We have made it abundantly clear that there will be no separate agreement between North Korea and the United states on the matter of the armistice," he said.
United States officials said that China had shown "understanding" of the desire to iniaite a North-South peace dialogue and that Japan and Russia has also been briefed on the proposal. A South Korean official said the reaffirmation of the United States support for South Korea combined with the peace overture was intended to "make North Korea not feel able to reject the offer."
North Korea has made little secret in recent years that it wants to dismantle the armistice that ended the Korean War and replace it with a peace treaty between itself and the United States, bypassing South Korea. In late February North Korea proposed an "interim peace agreement" to be negotiated with Washington. The United States pronounced the idea unacceptable.
Since then North Korea has taken steps that American officials have interpreted as an attempt to force direct talks with the United States by creating a crisis atmosphere on the Korean peninsula, where the cold war has never thawed.
Recently North Korea announced that it would no longer honor the terms of the Military Armistice Agreement, and its troops stripped off their required armbands. Then over successive Friday, Saturday and Sunday nights this month, North Korea moved an increasing number of troops -- up to 300 -- into the demilitarized zone 30 miles north of Seoul, setting up offensive positions with mortars before leaving.
The movements violated the armistice, which allows no more than 35 soldiers and 5 officers with side arms to enter the demilitarized zone. And they underscored the continuing conventional military threat on the peninsula despite 1994 and 1995 negotiations that led North Korea to halt its nuclear weapons program in exchange for being supplied with modern atomic power plants and fuel oil.
As part of the initiative by the United States, South Korea and Japan to provide North Korea with substitute nuclear reactors to secure the shutdown of reactors producing weapons-grade plutonium, North and South Korea were supposed to move into direct dialogue. But the talks have never begun.
Administration officials said the United States and South Korea began exploring a way to start a dialogue between the North and the South two months ago, before North Korea began its incursions into the demilitarized zone. Mr. Clinton added the South Korea stopover to his itinerary once it became clear that the leaders would have a proposal to unveil.
A similar proposal for six-way peace talks offered under the Bush Administration did not produce any results. But the Clinton Administration seems to feel that the economic situation in the North has deteriorated to the point that its leaders might now grasp at some way to become more integrated into the world.
Mr. Clinton's visit to South Korea and Tokyo comes at a time when not only the North Korean incursions but also China's recent military exercises in the Taiwan Strait have caused ripples of concern across Asia. The President is expected to pledge during his visit that the United States will remain the dominant military power in the Pacific, despite recent base closings in the region.
Later today Mr. Clinton was to fly to Tokyo for a two-day state visit. Its centerpiece is to be the signing of a joint security declaration that reaffirms the alliance between the United States and Japan and calls for Tokyo to increase its logistical support for American troops.
