HEADLINE: Kennedy Introduces Measures To Cut Layoffs From Mergers

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 15

 BODY:
Senator Edward M. Kennedy introduced tax legislation today intended to discourage layoffs resulting from corporate mergers, as part of a package of proposals designed to help workers.
The bill would disallow tax deductions for interest paid to finance mergers and acquisitions. "In the 1980's it was commonplace for financiers to borrow the funds to make the acquisition with the express intent of selling off the assets and casting off the workers to raise the money to pay back the debt," Mr. Kennedy, a Massachusetts Democrat, said. 
 The bill also sought to broaden antitrust laws so that when a potential merger was challenged in court, the judge would have to consider not only its effect on competition but also "the interests of workers and local communities." It would require that when stock buyers notify the Securities and Exchange Commission of acquisition of major blocks of stock, they must also notify it of plans for layoffs and shutdowns that could result from the acquisition.
Stressing the themes that Congressional Democrats hope President Clinton will emphasize in this year's campaign, Mr. Kennedy told the Senate, "The 'quiet depression' facing American workers is the central economic, social and political issue of 1996. When the economy is wrong, nothing else is right."
The measure would also establish tax breaks and preferences in Government contracts for companies with above-average records of wage increases, investment in training and education for workers along with health care, retirement benefits, profit sharing, as well as provision of child care for all employees by companies with more than 500 workers.
Mr. Kennedy also proposed establishing an individual pension program so workers in companies not providing pensions could put up to $9,500 of their own money into portable pensions that would be operated by groups like chambers of commerce. The only burden on employers, he said, would be to require them to deduct a worker's pension payment from the pay.
Mr. Kennedy conceded that Republicans were unlikely to hold hearings on his proposals, let alone bring them to the floor. But he said the tax and pension plans would be offered as amendments if any tax legislation came before the Senate. The antitrust plan, he said, would be proposed as an amendment to unrelated legislation this year.
Senate Republicans then underscored their unwillingness to deal with Democrats on work issues by insisting that no amendment to increase the hourly minimum wage to $5.15 from $4.25 by July 4, 1997, be offered today.
Unless Democrats agreed to put that issue aside at today's session, Republicans said, they would refuse to take up the illegal immigration bill and instead spend the day in meaningless roll-calls.
The most complicated provision of Mr. Kennedy's bill concerned worker-friendly companies, and it was drafted in hopes of encouraging support by stockholders. Qualifying companies would be allowed to deduct from their taxable profits 25 percent of dividends paid to stockholders. They would also be able to win Federal contracts if their bids were no more than 10 percent above the low bid.
Companies would qualify by certifying to the Labor Department that they met or exceeded the bill's standards, including putting 8 percent of payroll into employee health care, 8 percent into retirement benefits and 2 percent into education and job training.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator Edward M. Kennedy leaving the Senate yesterday after introducing a measure to discourage layoffs in mergers. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Nairobi Journal;
Take (On) the Minibuses, if You Dare

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, April 15

 BODY:
Forget this country's flagging economy and rampant corruption. The hottest political issue in Kenya these days is what to do about the local version of mass transit: those speeding, overloaded, exhaust-belching minibuses and minivans known as matatus.
A plan to install speed-recording devices on the minivans to reduce the number of traffic deaths has set off a political storm that has been felt all the way up to President Daniel arap Moi's office. The devices are small computers that record speed, braking distances, fuel consumption and other data, and the police can tap into them when they stop a vehicle. 
 The matatu owners and drivers, a powerful and volatile lobby, have staged strikes, held rallies and promised to make the gadgets -- nicknamed black boxes -- a litmus test in the coming presidential election. Earlier this month, the President shelved the plan indefinitely.
"If the Government insists about the black box, we will be on the move," said Jonas Kariuki, who directs passengers for several matatu operators in downtown Nairobi. "It will be a strike."
Matatus (the Swahili term roughly translates as "cooperatives") are ubiquitous in East Africa. In Kenya, where the public bus system barely functions and most people cannot afford cars, they are the main means of transportation.
The colorful little buses swerve in and out of traffic, boldly scoot along the wrong side of the road, pass on hills and career along the potholed city streets at speeds of 75 miles an hour or more. Custom-built on the top of truck chassis, they are emblazoned with names drawn from popular culture: Wing Commander, Boyz II Men, Love Boat, Banana Peel.
At rush hours, the minivans are usually packed with 10 or 11 more people than they can legally hold. Having paid 30 cents to climb aboard, the riders are crammed in four and five abreast on seats meant for three. Some sit on top of each other, some even in the driver's lap.
The conductors cling to the outside, riding with their feet on a running rail and singing out to passengers. On some buses, disco music is pumped at deafening volume.
But if most Africans depend on matatus to get around, they also fear them. The drivers are legendary for their recklessness, and the police blame them for Kenya's high death toll on the road -- 2,617 last year. Kenya has a death rate several times higher than Europe or America, with one death for every 166 vehicles per year. (California averages one fatality for every 6,200 vehicles.)
George Karioki, 48, an accountant who commutes on matatus every day, said he never feels safe on them. "They are reckless in driving and they don't observe the traffic rules," he said.
So motorists and matatu patrons greeted with joy the Government announcement earlier this year it was going to require the speed recorders. President Moi was seen by many as finally taking a tough stand.
Not so fast, said the matatu operators. They were incensed about the $1,400 price tag for each device and a little suspicious of the deal. The Government, no stranger to sweetheart contracts and kickbacks, had given the franchise for the devices to a single company.
Opposition politicians quickly asserted that the Government had given special treatment to the company. Transportation officials and the company denied any wrongdoing.
"It was something fishy," said Jimmy Mzee, a 36-year-old matatu owner. "I believe this is a deal between these influential businessmen and these big men at the ministry."
Last month, the matatus rebelled, employing one of the ruling party's top officials, Kuria Kayingi, as a lobbyist. Thousands rallied against the black-box plan. Mr. Kayingi led a delegation of 600 noisy matatu operators to visit the President at his residence. Then came a work stoppage on Easter weekend.
Though their union was banned in the 1980's, the matatu workers still vote as a bloc. In the 1992 elections, they threw their weight behind the opposition candidates. But at the rally, they made it clear they would stand behind President Moi's party this time, as long as he rejected the black boxes.
On April 7, the President, suspended the black-box idea and directed the Transportation Commissioner to come up with a new plan. President Moi suggested that speed governors, which limit how fast a car can go, might be a better solution.
Waiting in long lines in downtown Nairobi, several riders said their interests had been forgotten in all the political maneuvering. Many said they prayed every time they boarded a matatu that they would live to see their homes.
"They never care about safety," said Linda Kagwiria, a 35-year-old store clerk. "Too many people are always in the car. You can't breathe."
For their part, the matatu drivers blame the poor condition of the roads and police corruption for the daily road carnage. Potholes and bubbled-up pavement are everywhere, while shoulders and traffic signs are nonexistent, they said.
But the biggest problem, operators say, is that the police care more about extorting payments than enforcing traffic laws. The black boxes, they contend, would just give officers one more pretext for extracting bribes at the many roadblocks the police set up during rush hours.
Once bribed, the drivers say, the police turn a blind eye to bad brakes, speeding, overloading, drunken drivers and other safety hazards.
"They just stand there and ask for money," said one driver, Charles Karau, a 14-year veteran. "If you speed or you don't, they don't care."

CORRECTION-DATE: May 24, 1996, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article on April 16 about attempts to improve the safety record of the taxi fleet in Nairobi, Kenya, misstated the etymology of the Ki-swahili colloquialism for the minivans that make up the bulk of the fleet. Matatu, literally meaning threes, derives from the fare of 30 cents (mateni matatu, or three 10-cent pieces) originally charged by drivers, not from the practice of people banding together to operate the taxis. This correction was delayed for consultation with authorities on Kiswahili.

HEADLINE: Feasting on Crumbs of America's Love Affair With Bread

BYLINE: By JACK BISHOP 

 BODY:
TRADING up from squishy white bread to artisanal loaves has had an unforeseen consequence in many kitchens. All over America, stale hunks of crusty bread are being tucked away in bakery bags or thrown in the back of the refrigerator, growing older and harder by the day. Handmade loaves are superior to sliced white bread in every respect but one -- staying power.
So what's an economical cook to do with leftover country-white and whole-wheat bread? 
 Italian cooks have been confronting this problem for centuries and have developed strategies for recycling stale bread. These tricks can't resuscitate a week-old, rock-hard loaf, but will give new life to bread that is a few days old.
In Italy, homemade bread crumbs often take the place of grated cheese in pasta dishes. This is especially true with seafood sauces, since Italians consider the marriage of fish and cheese to be odder than that of Michael Jackson and Lisa Marie Presley. (Just try asking a Roman waiter for cheese with your linguine and clam sauce.) Traditionally, stale loaves are grated by hand, and the coarse crumbs are toasted in a skillet to a rich golden-brown color. A food processor fitted with a metal blade speeds the grating.
Homemade bread crumbs are coarser and more flavorful than commercial varieties. They are also used with vegetable pasta sauces. Southern Italians who could not afford Parmesan from the north relied on this embellishment in dishes like linguine with garlicky spinach.
A second option for stale bread is to use it as a flavor absorber in salads, soups and sweet puddings. Tuscans add stale bread cubes to a tomato salad called panzanella. The bread soaks up some of the dressing, as well as juice from the tomatoes. The tough cubes swell and soften to make a delicious and filling salad.
Stale bread also adds bulk to peasant soups. These recipes, many of which originated in hard times, show the Italian passion for transforming simple foods into transcendent meals. For instance, stale bread turns a basic potato and spinach soup into a meal. A drizzle of olive oil adds luxury to this modest dish.
Finally, stale bread can live again in baked puddings. Cubed bread absorbs the custard and helps cut the richness in eggy desserts. Grappa-soaked raisins give bread pudding a characteristic Italian flavor.

Spaghetti With Scallops, Lemon and Bread Crumbs
 Total time: 30 minutes

 2 cups stale bread cut into half-inch cubes
 1 pound spaghetti
 Salt to taste
 6 tablespoons olive oil
 3 medium garlic cloves, minced
 2 tablespoons lemon juice
 2 tablespoons minced fresh parsley leaves
 1/2 teaspoon dried hot red pepper flakes or to taste
 1 pound sea scallops, tendons discarded, cut into 3/4-inch cubes.

 1. Bring 4 quarts of water to a boil in a large pot.
 2. Place the bread cubes in a food processor fitted with the metal blade, and grind into coarse crumbs, about 1 minute. Place the bread crumbs in a large skillet set over medium heat. Toast, shaking the pan often, until the crumbs are golden brown. Remove the crumbs from the pan, and set aside.
 3. Add the spaghetti and salt to taste to the boiling water.
 4. While the pasta is cooking, briefly heat the oil in the empty skillet. Add the garlic, and cook until golden, about 1 minute. Stir in the lemon juice, parsley, hot red pepper flakes and salt to taste. Cook for 30 seconds. Add the scallops, and cook, stirring often, until they are opaque and cooked through, 3 to 4 minutes. Do not overcook the scallops. Adjust seasonings and keep sauce warm.
 5. Drain the spaghetti when al dente, but do not shake bone dry. Transfer the spaghetti, still dripping with a little cooking water, to a large bowl, and toss with the scallop sauce. Sprinkle with the bread crumbs and toss well. Divide pasta into individual bowls, and serve immediately.
 Yield: 4 servings.
 Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 745 calories, 25 grams fat, 50 milligrams cholesterol, 330 milligrams sodium (before salting), 40 grams protein, 95 grams carbohydrate.
 Potato, Spinach, and Bread Soup
 Total time: 50 minutes

 1 1/2 pounds Yukon gold potatoes, peeled, cut into half-inch cubes
 4 1/2 cups chicken stock or water (see note)
 4 cups packed stemmed spinach
 leaves, washed, dried, and cut into 3/4-inch-wide strips
 Salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste
 2 cups stale bread cut into half-
inch cubes
 2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil or to taste.

 1. Place the potatoes and chicken stock or water in a medium pot. Bring to a boil, and simmer briskly for 15 minutes.
 2. Add the spinach, salt and pepper to taste, and cover the pot. Continue cooking until the potatoes are falling apart and the spinach is tender, about 10 minutes.
 3. Turn off the heat, stir in the bread cubes and cover the pot. Let stand for 5 minutes or until the bread is very soft. Adjust the seasonings, and add hot water to taste to thin the texture if desired. (This soup is designed to be quite thick but can be thinned to any consistency.)
 4. Ladle the soup into bowls. Drizzle 1/2 tablespoon oil over each bowl, and serve immediately.
 Note: This peasant soup is traditionally made with water. Homemade chicken stock adds richness and flavor and is a first choice. Avoid canned chicken broth, which does not nearlyadd the flavor of homemade.
 Yield: 4 servings.
 Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 285 calories, 10 grams fat, 8 milligrams cholesterol, 225 milligrams sodium (before salting), 9 grams protein, 40 grams carbohydrate.
 Panzanella (Tuscan Tomato and Bread Salad)
 Total time: 50 minutes

 4 cups stale bread cut into 1-inch cubes
 1 1/2 pounds ripe tomatoes, cored and cut into 1/2-inch cubes
 1/2 small red onion, peeled, halved and sliced thin
 1/2 cucumber, peeled, halved lengthwise, seeded and diced small
 6 large green olives, pitted and chopped coarse
 8 large fresh basil leaves, cut crosswise into thin strips
 1 teaspoon minced fresh oregano leaves
 Salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste
 1 1/2 tablespoons red-wine vinegar
 3 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil.

 1. Place the bread, tomatoes, onion, cucumber, olives, basil and oregano in a large bowl. Sprinkle with salt and pepper, and toss gently.
 2. Drizzle the vinegar and then the oil over the salad. Mix gently, and set aside at room temperature until the bread softens somewhat but is not mushy, about 30 minutes. (If the bread is quite stale, you may be able to set aside the salad for an hour or two at room temperature before the bread becomes limp.) Adjust the seasonings, and serve immediately.
 Yield: 4 servings.
 Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 230 calories, 13 grams fat, 0 milligrams cholesterol, 345 milligrams sodium (before salting), 5 grams protein, 25 grams carbohydrate.
 Bread Pudding With Grappa-Soaked Raisins
Total Time: 2 hours, plus at least 30 minutes for cooling

 1/2 cup raisins
 1/4 cup grappa, brandy or rum
 Butter to grease baking dish
 6 large eggs
 3/4 cup sugar
 3 cups milk
 2 teaspoons vanilla extract
 4 cups stale bread cut into half-inch cubes.

 1. Place the raisins and grappa in a small bowl. Soak for at least 1 hour, or overnight if desired.
 2. Preheat the oven to 375 degrees. Butter a shallow 2-quart ceramic baking dish. Place dish in a roasting pan large enough to hold it.
 3. Whisk eggs and sugar together in a large bowl until smooth. Whisk in milk and vanilla. Stir in bread cubes, along with raisins and grappa.
 4. Pour the bread mixture into the baking dish. Place the roasting pan and baking dish in the oven. Fill the roasting pan with hot tap water so that the water reaches about halfway up the sides of the baking dish.
 5. Bake until the pudding is set and a knife inserted in the center comes out clean, about an hour. Remove the baking dish from roasting pan and cool it on a rack. Bread pudding may be served warm or chilled. (Pudding can be refrigarated for a day.)
 Yield: 8 servings.
 Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 275 calories, 7 grams fat, 170 milligrams cholesterol, 170 milligrams sodium, 9 grams protein, 40 grams carbohydrate.

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
A consolidation of offices for the Gay Men's Health Crisis in a new lease on West 24th Street.

BYLINE: By Mervyn Rothstein 

 BODY:
THE Gay Men's Health Crisis, the country's oldest and largest AIDS service organization, has leased a 150,000-square-foot building at 119 West 24th Street, between the Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue.
The organization plans to consolidate its offices, now spread out at five sites in the Chelsea/Midtown South area of Manhattan, and offer all its services at the new location. The 15-year lease was valued at $25 million. 
 Mark Robinson, the executive director of the group , said it had decided to stay in the Chelsea area, "as long as we could work it out economically," because "we were spawned in Chelsea, and the majority of our clients come from here and the Greenwich Village area."
"From an economic and space standpoint," Mr. Robinson said, "this building met all our requirements."
The organization will initially use 108,000 square feet of the building. Stephen Soba, a spokesman, said that two floors occupied by other tenants would be taken over when the leases expired and that the organization was looking into collaborating with a medical center to provide medical care on another floor.
Mr. Robinson said that no money allotted for programs would be used for renovation and construction. A campaign to raise capital funds has begun, he said, with the move to the new building expected to be completed within a year.
Louis Bradbury, the board president, said the move would provide improved services with "significant savings in our overall occupancy costs." He said it would also allow the organization to open the David Geffen Center for H.I.V. Prevention and Health Education.
The agency, which is entering its 15th year, now has space at 20, 121 and 129 West 20th Street, 11 West 19th Street and 160 Eighth Avenue, at 18th Street.
Jeffrey A. Bernstein of the Edward S. Gordon Company, who with his colleague Laurence Elbaum represented the tenant, said the building, which was formerly used primarily for manufacturing and as a warehouse, provided a "very efficient office layout."
The 12-story loft building has 12,000-square-foot floors and a basement, Mr. Bernstein said. "From the sixth floor up, there are generous windows on all four sides," he said. "Even though it's a midblock building, the buildings around it are all low-rise, and there is light all the way up the back." Frank Ring represented the owner, F. M. Ring Associates.
 
Infinity Broadcasting Move
 The Infinity Broadcasting Corporation, the nation's largest independent broadcasting company, has leased 27,000 square feet, the 14th and part of the 15th floor, at 40 West 57th Street, a 700,000-square-foot office building between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas. The building is owned by the LeFrak Organization.
Infinity, which broadcasts the Howard Stern and Don Imus shows and owns 34 radio stations nationwide, including WFAN in New York, will be moving its corporate headquarters from 600 Madison Avenue, at 58th Street. The 15-year lease was valued in excess of $12 million.
Susan Kahaner of the Edward S. Gordon Company, who represented the tenant with her colleague Mary Ann Tighe, said Infinity had "very strict requirements" for its new offices. "Howard Stern and the other stars were seeking privacy and discreet access," Ms. Kahaner said. "So they were looking for a building with a garage where the limos could pull right in and the stars could go up through the service elevator and avoid fans waiting outside."
In the new offices, she said, Mr. Stern is to get the "studio of his dreams -- a duplex, with very high ceilings."
Mitchell Rudin, director of Gordon's owner-representation division, who represented the building, said it was now 98 percent leased.
 
Technology Center Lease
 The Westcon Services Corporation, a computer training and development company, has leased 16,000 square feet, the entire eighth floor, at 55 Broad Street, the New York Information Technology Center. Neil Joffee of Newmark & Company Real Estate Inc., who represented Westcon, said the 10-year lease was valued at $2.6 million. Westcon, based in Eastchester, N.Y., is to move its New York City office from 3,500 square feet at the Empire State Building.
The new lease is the biggest so far at the technology center, a 400,000-square-foot, formerly vacant office building at Beaver Street in lower Manhattan. Nine months after the Rudin Management Company announced it was spending $15 million to renovate the building and install modern telecommunications equipment, more than 184,000 square feet, or close to half the building, has been accounted for.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
The High Cost of a Fine Smoke

BYLINE: By DAVID J. MORROW 

 BODY:
The fall of the Soviet Union and rising American animus toward one of Marxism's last bulwarks are taking a sharp toll on an illicit pleasure: the consumption of Cuban cigars.
Though illegal to import, buy or sell here since President John F.Kennedy imposed a trade embargo on the Castro regime in July 1963, Cuban cigars had always remained relatively plentiful -- until late February. Now, smokers say, a box of Cubans is extremely difficult to find. And with prices doubling and tripling, only an elite few can afford those that are available. 
 The roots of the shortage are in the confluence of ideology and economics, experts and connoisseurs say. Since the Soviet Union's collapse in 1991, Cuba's increasingly isolated tobacco farmers have suffered shortages of raw materials, from fuel and fertilizer to twine and boxes. Production fell to 50 million cigars last year from 90 million in 1990.
This winter, the industry appeared to be on the mend. Several European importers -- notably Tabacalera, Spain's state-owned tobacco company -- had written checks to needy Cuban tobacco farmers, but the money apparently arrived too late to avert another disaster. Despite a strong tobacco crop in January, farmers failed to produce enough quality capas, the leaves that provide the outer wrappers for cigars.
Meanwhile, the Clinton Administration, outraged after the Cuban military shot down two American civilian planes in February, has tightened enforcement of the trade embargo, through which cigars habitually had slipped. Recent seizures of illegal Cuban cigars in Florida and en route from Mexico to Texas appear to have stymied many smugglers, United States Customs Service officials believe, further diminishing the thin supply of Havanas.
The results of all this are prices that catch in the throats of the most devoted smokers.
Those who want a box of Cuban large brands -- Cohiba Robustos, Romeo and Julieta Churchills, or Double Coronas, cherished for their 8-inch lengths -- may have to shell out $400 to $700 for a box of 25 on the black market, up from $250 last year, according to cigar industry officials and suppliers in the Caribbean. A price list of black market Cuban cigars, seized by United States Customs last fall, had a box of 50 Coronas going for $650. Two Cuban cigar suppliers said that same box of 50 Coronas would fetch at least $850 today.
"The prices of all cigars have gone up within the past year," said Marc Tassy, the manager of Havana House, the exclusive distributor of Cuban cigars in Canada. "On the black market in the U.S., these smugglers have discovered a product they can get a ransom for."
Smokers say normal supply channels have been disrupted. Some of the business executives recently savoring Cubans at Beekman Bar and Books, a plush smoking room on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, said the only Havana cigars they could come by lately were those they sneaked home from European business trips.
"I can't tell you how much I enjoy the taste of a Cuban cigar," said Michael, a Manhattan investment banker who declined to be identified by his last name. "The trouble is that it's really tough to get a Cuban cigar in the States these days. The ones you can find all cost too much. When I go to Europe on business, I'll buy a couple and stick them in my luggage. I don't have another way of getting them."
The shortages are not limited to the United States. "The worldwide demand for these cigars is still around 100 million," said Simon Chase, marketing director for Hunters & Frankau, the distributor of Cuban cigars in Britain. "Cuban cigars are hard to come by even in countries where they're legal. In Havana some of the tobacco shops can't get them."
The acute shortage of Havanas has transformed the American cigar market. Smokers could once be confident that a Cuban cigar purchased from a tobacco store or smuggler was authentic, but no more. Of the seven million cigars posing as Cubans that are expected to be smuggled into the United States this year, cigar industry officials believe that two million will be fakes.
"Counterfeiting Cuban cigars is now a big business," said Norman Sharp, president of the Cigar Association of America, an industry group. "All the counterfeiters have to do is say a box of cigars is Cuban and then try to rake in all these exorbitant prices. A lot of inexperienced smokers won't be able to tell the difference."
The best of the counterfeit Havanas are made in Honduras or the Dominican Republic, where the tobacco quality closely resembles Cuba's, then sent to the United States or Mexico to be boxed. Some get new cigar bands before being sold to unsuspecting tobacco stores.
All this infuriates American cigar makers, who estimate that they lose $50 million to $75 million each year to Cuban smugglers and counterfeiters. "A fellow can't smoke two cigars at once," said Richard DiMeola, executive vice president of Consolidated Cigar Corporation of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., America's largest premium cigar maker, and a unit of MacAndrews & Forbes Holdings. "For every Cuban cigar sold, that's one that we didn't sell."
Part of the increased interest in Cubans can be traced to the recent boom in cigar smoking. Americans bought 163 million premium cigars last year, according to the Cigar Association of America, up from 97 million in 1991. But American cigar makers point fingers at another source: Marvin Shanken and his Cigar Aficionado magazine.
Mr. Shanken, the son of a New Haven jewelry retailer, rolled out Cigar Aficionado in September 1992, just as the United States premium cigar boom was beginning. The magazine soon became a sort of Town & Country for cigar smokers, featuring photos and profiles of cigar-chomping celebrities like Lauren Hutton and Matt Dillon.
But critics in the industry say the magazine has a bent for Cuban cigars. The spring issue, currently on newsstands, includes an article arguing for an end to the Cuban trade embargo and another by Leslie H. Gelb, a former New York Times columnist who is now president of the Council on Foreign Relations, in which he describes his "mooching" of Cuban cigars.
What is especially galling to American cigar makers is Mr. Shanken's rankings of the best smokes, in which Cubans always come out on top. In the spring issue, Mr. Shanken rates Coronas, and indeed, Cuban brands receive the top two scores. The top American Corona -- a La Gloria Cubana -- finished 16th.
"To say that Cigar Aficionado promotes a black market product is silly," Mr. Shanken said. "How can I put out a serious cigar magazine that's an international publication and not include Cuban cigars? A lot of the people in the business frown on it because they can't participate in that market. But when our readers travel to Europe they can buy a box of Cubans and smoke them there."
For those who have yet to try a Cuban cigar, finding one in the United States will not be easy. Federal regulators have been cracking down on most of the popular smuggling routes. "This isn't a very sophisticated network of smugglers," Mr. Sharp said. "It's not like the smugglers who bring in cocaine."
The Office of Foreign Assets Control at the Treasury Department, which enforces economic embargoes and sanctions, believes most of the Havanas come by boat through the Caribbean. Others come across the Canadian and Mexican borders in cars and trucks. Smugglers commonly change the labels on the cigars from Cubans to Hondurans and then repackage them in boxes from South America. Once the cigars are in the United States, they are reboxed and relabeled to reflect their Cuban origins.
American cigar makers are especially riled by cigars sold through the mail -- mainly by well-known European retailers. "I bet more than half of the Cuban cigars that make it into this country are delivered by the U.S. Post Office," said Lewis Rothman, president of JR Tobacco of Statesville, N.C., whose mail-order, wholesale and retail businesses provide 40 percent of the premium cigars sold in the United States. "The Customs people can't look at every box, and if the cigars have had a make-over -- new label, for instance -- they might not be spotted."
There is only one legal way to bring Cuban cigars into the United States People who travel to Cuba legally -- to visit family members, conduct academic research or on a journalist's visa -- are allowed to carry home up to $100 worth of Cuban goods as gifts, according to the Customs Service.
At today's prices, however, $100 may buy only enough cigars to whet a smoker's yearning for more.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Bonds In the Shadow Of Inflation

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended slightly lower in moderate trading yesterday, despite a drop in commodity prices that eased some inflation concerns.
A report showing a slump in industrial production in March failed to generate optimism in the market that the economy was growing slowly enough to prevent inflation from accelerating. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 3/32 of a percentage point, to 89 31/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, edged up to 6.79 percent, from 6.78 percent on Monday.
Prices for Treasury bills were stronger, with the rate on the three-month bill dropping to 4.81 percent from 4.83 percent.
The Federal Reserve reported yesterday that industrial output fell five-tenths of 1 percent in March. But the slump was attributed to a strike and subsequent shutdown of assembly plants at General Motors.
"Auto and truck production will rebound in April," said Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, "and it will come on top of an industrial sector that grew at a half a percent per month pace during the first quarter, excluding the motor vehicle sector."
Christopher A. Low, senior economist at HSBC Group in New York, said that industrial production "on full evaluation was just about in line with expectations" and agreed that industrial production would bounce back.
"However, there is no evidence of significant strength outside of the auto sector," he noted.
Bond prices did receive some support from sharp declines in several commodity indexes.
The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 17 commodities, which was at eight-year highs two weeks ago, dropped 3.44 points yesterday, to 255.84, led by falling corn and crude oil prices. The energy-weighted Goldman Sachs Commodity Index fell 4.85 points, to 208.55, its biggest drop since early February.
"The bond market has been watching commodity prices closely, worried about inflation, so this came as very good news," Mr. Low said.
Still, Robert T. Parry, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, told the Reuters news service that he was not optimistic about inflation this year. But Mr. Parry is considered an inflation hawk and, in any case, is a nonvoting member of the Fed's committee that sets interest rates.
The market will look for more clues to the direction of the economy in today's report on housing starts in March. And tomorrow, the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia is scheduled to release its survey of regional business conditions.
The Philadelphia Fed survey is the last significant report to be released until United States trade balance data on Tuesday. "The Philly Fed survey could certainly have a greater market impact than normal given the data vacuum following its release," Mr. Fine of Chase Asset Management said. "In the meantime, the Fed remains on hold."
He added: "While the rate of inflation as measured by the Consumer Price Index has lifted modestly as of late, moderate economic growth should keep inflation restrained over time. But make no mistake about it, the Fed is at a heightened state of alert vis-a-vis inflation and inflationary expectations, which certainly reduces the already lowered probability of the Fed easing even further, while at the same time keeps the bond market ever vigilant toward potential Fed tightening."

HEADLINE: Swastikas and Similar Graffiti Spread in the Nation's Capital

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 16

 BODY:
A problem that has long plagued downtown Washington, the defacement of newspaper boxes and trash bins by spray-painted swastikas and SS logos, appears to be spreading into residential communities where many of the city's Jews live.
And while the increasing number of Nazi insignias in those neighborhoods is raising concern about the message of hate that the symbols convey, there is also a growing concern that the city is not responding adequately. 
 The District's financial crisis has forced the Department of Public Works to abandon a war against graffiti of any kind, and the Police Department has only rarely arrested anyone for painting Nazi symbols on public or private property. That combination has led some residents to take matters into their own hands, by spray-painting over the offending symbols.
"We are poor," said Linda Grant, a spokeswoman for the Public Works Department. "We are without the kinds of funds that we can arm public works employees with the supplies to go out there and remove these things."
Officer Anthony O'Leary, a spokesman for the Police Department, said the department took all hate crimes seriously, including the painting of such graffiti. As for investigations, "we do what we can," he said.
That has not been enough to calm an outcry from residents who feel threatened by the symbols. Laura Kam-Issacharoff, special projects coordinator of the Washington office of the Anti-Defamation League, said that in recent months her office had been flooded with telephone calls from District residents, most of them Jews living in the northwest section of the city, complaining about the appearance of Nazi symbols in their neighborhoods.
"They're coming from all over the northwest," Ms. Kam-Issacharoff said of the calls as she walked along streets there today, pointing to swastikas painted in white or neon-orange on newspaper boxes. "To say there's no money, that's like giving a license to people to do it and giving them a platform for hate."
She said her usual response to the callers was to urge them to paint over the symbols -- "I tell them, 'We'll bail you out if you get arrested' " -- or to join the A.D.L.'s third annual volunteer effort to remove the graffiti, scheduled for next week.
The spread of Nazi symbols in the nation's capital, some just blocks from the White House and the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum, comes at a time when by some estimates the number of anti-Semitic incidents around the country has declined.
In an audit of acts of bigotry toward Jews in 1995, the national office of the Anti-Defamation League found that the number of incidents nationally had declined by almost 11 percent from 1994, the first drop in three years and the largest in the 10 years that the organization has taken such surveys.
But in the District of Columbia, the number of anti-Semitic incidents rose. Indeed, in a breakdown of all 50 states and the District, the increase in the number of such incidents here, 22, was second only to California's increase, 32.
The spray-painting of Nazi symbols is one kind of act monitored by the A.D.L., and an exception to the rarity of arrests for it here occurred recently: Esyededeea Aesfyza was charged in early January with one count of destruction of property, a misdemeanor, accused of spray-painting a swastika on a traffic-signal box near the Capitol.
Mr. Aesfyza, a native of Greece who was homeless at the time of his arrest, is free in his own recognizance and faces a maximum of 180 days in jail if convicted.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Lower Over Prospect That Japan May Increase Rates

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar slipped yesterday after the head of Japan's central bank hinted that Japanese interest rates might be heading higher.
The dollar sold off in Tokyo after the governor of the Bank of Japan, Yasuo Matsushita, said a prolonged easy monetary policy helped create Japan's "bubble economy" of inflated stock and land prices in the late 1980's. 
 While Mr. Matsushita's comments appeared simply to reflect the conventional economic wisdom, currency traders inferred his words as a signal that rates would rise.
"The comments out of B.O.J. appear to be putting the market on some kind of warning that the low interest rate monetary policy that has been pursued, and which has been supporting dollar and yen, may be coming into question," said Stephen Flanagan, currency trader at Credit Agricole in New York.
In trading in New York late yesterday, the dollar fell to 108.15 yen, from 108.55 on Monday. The dollar was quoted at 1.5089 marks, down from 1.5127. The British pound rose to $1.5077 from $1.5075.
Mr. Flanagan said the prospect of higher interest rates in Japan had prompted investors to reverse a so-called yen-carry trade.
In such a trade, speculators borrow in yen at low Japanese interest rates to buy higher-yielding non-Japanese assets. In reversing that trade, they buy back yen. That helped push the yen broadly higher against the United States and Australian dollars and European currencies.
"The Bank of Japan is clearly putting the market on notice that this yen-carry trade could have some risk," Mr. Flanagan said.
Currency traders said there was strong interest from Japanese banks and corporations to buy dollars at about 108 yen, which kept the dollar above that level.
The dollar's weakening against the mark came as doubts crept into the market about a German interest rate cut this week, traders said. Of 15 economists surveyed in Germany, only 3 predicted that the Bundesbank would cut its important discount and Lombard rates at today's council meeting.
The diminishing prospects for a rate cut lifted the mark against the dollar. Lower interest rates tend to make a country's assets relatively less attractive.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Prices Reverse as Corn and Oil Plunge and Gold Follows Drop

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Corn and crude oil prices plunged yesterday on indications that low inventories of both commodities would be replenished in coming months.
Falling commodities markets also pushed gold lower as the drop in raw materials eased concerns that inflation would accelerate. The Commodity Research Bureau index fell 3.44 points, to 255.84, its largest drop since March 1, as 14 of its 17 components fell. The energy-weighted Goldman Sachs Commodity Index fell 4.85 points, to 208.55, its biggest drop since Feb. 5. 
 Corn prices plunged as warm weather and generous rains begin to provide farmers with excellent planting conditions.
Rain totaling as much as 1.5 inches in some areas is forecast for the Corn Belt this week, according to Accu-Weather Inc., moistening the soil for farmers who begin planting the bulk of this year's crop next week.
With corn reaching record prices this month, and the new farm bill removing many restrictions on what farmers must grow to qualify for subsidies, analysts are now expecting an above-average crop.
"The feeling is with this moisture they are going to get after plantings and we are going to get every acre we can," said Don Roose, analyst at U.S. Commodities Inc. in West Des Moines, Iowa.
Corn for July delivery fell the 12-cent daily trading limit, to $4.30 a bushel, on the Chicago Board of Trade. The drop in corn pulled wheat prices lower. The active July wheat contract plunged 19.5 cents, to $5.3125 a bushel.
Crude oil settled lower, after first reaching its highest price since the 1991 Persian Gulf war, amid speculation that Iraq would eventually agree to a limited oil sale being offered by the United Nations.
May crude oil fell 59 cents, to $24.47 a barrel, at the New York Mercantile Exchange, after trading as high as $25.70 a barrel earlier in the day.
Gold fell as the declines in commmodity indexes eased concerns about a pickup in inflation. Some investors buy gold when inflation threatens the value of other assets.

HEADLINE: Dole Wavers On Extending Trade Rights For China

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 16

 BODY:
In the first indication that Washington's dealing with China could become a major campaign-year argument in Congress, Senator Bob Dole appeared to back away today from years of support for extending broad trade privileges to Beijing, saying he had not decided whether to oppose the Clinton Administration's efforts to renew those trade rights this spring.
Mr. Dole has been under sharp pressure from the right wing of his party to abandon the traditional Republican position that the best way to influence China's behavior is to engage it economically. But as recently as a few days ago, when he canceled a major speech on his policy toward China, his advisers insisted that he was still firmly in favor of "most-favored nation" status for China, on which billions of dollars of trade with American companies -- and perhaps the economic futures of Hong Kong and Taiwan -- depend. 
 Today, however, Mr. Dole wavered. Emerging from a meeting with former President George Bush, who has just completed a trip to China, Mr. Dole said, "We'll be developing our position on it very soon."
For Mr. Dole, as for Mr. Clinton, China's trade status poses some agonizing problems. His home state of Kansas is the site of a major Boeing plant, where one in seven jets goes to China. Agricultural companies, among his biggest supporters, have warned that ending China's trading preferences would be a disaster for them.
And Mr. Dole has a long record of statements in support of trade concessions that sound much like Mr. Clinton's arguments.
"I strongly support most-favored nation status for China," he said on "Larry King Live" on March 23, 1994. "I think we make a mistake when we tie it to human rights." Cancellation, he said, would "cost us a couple of hundred thousand American jobs." In 1992 and 1993, when Mr. Clinton was wavering on the issue, Mr. Dole was urging him to "move ahead on most-favored nation status for China where, again, Republicans would support the President if he'll come out and do that."
Some Republicans have urged Mr. Dole to turn the extension of trade privileges into a referendum on Mr. Clinton's dealings with China, with an eye toward putting Mr. Clinton in the embarrassing position of vetoing a Congressional resolution to end China's trading rights here.
"It would be a very tough veto in an election year," one of Mr. Clinton's top aides said recently, worrying that the President could appear to be defending China's leadership.
American business has strongly urged the extension of China's trading rights, and successfully pressed Mr. Clinton two years ago to reverse himself and "delink" favorable trade status from China's human rights performance. Until today, Mr. Dole -- whose Kansas constituencies include major exporters to China -- seemed firmly in the Clinton camp.
Like Mr. Dole, the Administration is also concerned that its policies not cost America lucrative contracts. Just today the Export-Import Bank of the United States approved a $160 million loan guarantee for a Chinese airline to buy three Boeing jets. In February, Secretary of State Warren Christopher had asked the bank to suspend consideration of loans for all projects in China for 30 days until he decided whether and how to sanction China for selling $70,000 of ring magnets to Pakistan. But Mr. Christopher is still weighing his decision, both because of legal complexities and because the Administration is still trying to hone in on a sanction that would show American toughness but not prompt retaliation.
No decision is expected until he meets Foreign Minister Qian Qichen of China on Friday, American officials said. Mr. Christopher is to break off from President Clinton's trip to Russia to meet Mr. Qian in The Hague. Officials at the Ex-Im Bank, an independent agency, said they had to move ahead because China was already giving more aircraft contracts to Europe.
The sanction Mr. Christopher has in mind would prevent the Ex-Im Bank from aiding a Chinese company that was linked to the ring magnet sales. But it would also hurt two major American companies, Westinghouse and Bechtel.
The Administration had hoped that its threats of sanctions against China would defuse the calls for the repeal of favorable trade status, which permits the Chinese to get the benefits that America extends to its other major trading partners -- including low tariffs for its goods. But liberals outraged by the human rights record of China and conservatives outraged by its threats against Taiwan are aligning in the House of Representatives to vote against the trading rights after Mr. Clinton formally notifies Congress of his intentions. He must do so by June 3.
"We're going to lose the House on this," a top Administration official said recently. "The issue is the Senate, and specifically Bob Dole."

HEADLINE: Korea Convergence

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: CHEJU, South Korea, April 16

 BODY:
With their proposal for peace talks with North Korea today, President Clinton and his South Korean counterpart, Kim Young Sam, have broken new ground and raised a spark of hope that the last front of the cold war will finally see what Mr. Clinton called "an ultimate reconciliation."
Such hopes have tantalized all concerned in the past only to be dashed, so people in South Korea are greeting the announcement today with caution. Still, American and South Korean officials say a constellation of factors -- the economic troubles and famine in North Korea and election-year politics in the United States and South Korea -- make this a propitious time to try once again to achieve the elusive peace that would formally end the Korean War. 
 The two leaders, after a brief meeting this morning on this resort island, publicly invited North Korea to take part in peace talks involving four countries -- the two Koreas, the United States and China. The talks would begin as soon as possible and without preconditions.
"North Korea has said it wants peace," President Clinton said at a news conference with President Kim. "This is our proposal to achieve it. And we hope and expect Pyongyang will take it seriously."
In agreeing to four-way talks, South Korea has relaxed its insistence that any peace treaty be negotiated only by the two Koreas.
"The South Korean position is showing more flexibility than in the past," said Lee Jong Suk, a North Korea expert at the Sejong Institute, a private research organization in Seoul. "So even if North Korea rejects the proposal, the possibility of future negotiations is now open, and in this sense it is a breakthrough."
But Moon Chung In, a professor of political science at Yonsei University, said the proposal has "no real impact, only symbolic impact."
Turning even a symbolic advance into an actual peace treaty will be difficult. It is still not known whether North Korea, which was informed of the proposal in advance, will accept it. The Russian news agency Itar-Tass quoted North Korea's Ambassador to Moscow, Song Sung Pil, as saying North Korea would reject the offer and insist on talks only with Washington.
Even if the Communist nation accepts the proposal, negotiations no doubt will be arduous, as were the 1994 talks over ending North Korea's nuclear weapons program. And even if an agreement is reached, there is no guarantee it will be honored.
China has also not yet agreed, although American officials said Beijing had expressed "understanding." Russia, which would be left out of the talks, has expressed an interest in having a role, South Korean officials said. Japan, meanwhile, expressed support for the proposal.
But American and South Korean officials are gambling that North Korea will come to the table to help ease its economic woes.
"Time is on our side," President Kim said, adding that he believed the proposal might be the only choice that North Korea can make "to resolve the Korean question." "And I believe," he said, "that eventually North Korea will accept our proposal."
A peace treaty would clear the way for increased economic ties for North Korea with South Korea and the United States. But even before a treaty would be signed, Washington and Seoul said they would consider interim "confidence-building measures." These could include economic aid as well as military moves such as pulling some troops back from the front lines.
But the two leaders today announced no immediate aid for North Korea. A South Korean official said his nation had decided not to give any more rice to North Korea unless it responds positively to the proposal for peace talks.
President Clinton also reaffirmed today that the United States would not hold talks with North Korea alone, thereby seeming to rule out the option that North Korea prefers.
On the military front, signing a peace treaty would help eliminate the threat that war could be re-ignited. North Korea has already denounced the 1953 armistice agreement that has governed the truce. Two weekends ago, it sent heavily armed troops into the joint security area in the demilitarized zone, a violation of the armistice.
American and South Korean officials insist that today's proposal was being discussed by them for two months and is therefore not a response to North Korea's recent actions. But the incursions heightened the sense of urgency to replace the armistice with a permanent peace.
Prospects for peace have been raised before. In late 1991 and early 1992, the two Koreas negotiated and signed an agreement calling for reconciliation, nonaggression, cooperation and denuclearization of the peninsula. But the agreement broke down once North Korea threatened to pull out of the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty in 1993.
In 1994 Kim Young Sam and Kim Il Sung, the North Korean leader, agreed to hold their first summit meeting. But the North Korean died before such a meeting could be held.
The Geneva agreement later that year defused the threat of North Korea's nuclear weapons program and raised great hopes of reconciliation. But the North-South talks outlined in that agreement were never held.
The proposal for talks among four parties or among six parties -- with Russia and Japan included -- have also been bandied about for years. The United States proposed such ideas in 1988 and 1991 but neither the Koreas nor China were interested.
Election politics appeared to play some role in bringing forth today's proposal. Some South Korean officials said President Clinton, who was not even intending originally to visit South Korea on his current trip to Japan and Russia, needed something concrete to announce here to show that he is keeping American troops from being killed in a conflict.
President Kim was able to announce the proposal because elections for South Korea's National Assembly are now behind him, with his party having done better than expected despite losing its majority. Until the election last Thursday, Mr. Kim feared taking any conciliatory steps toward North Korea because it would alienate conservative voters.
But pressure has been building on South Korea to become more flexible, in part because its resistance has prevented the United States and other countries from giving more food aid to North Korea that could help prevent an economic collapse.
"There's no question who our ally is," an American official said recently with some exasperation. "We just wish our ally would be more forward-looking."

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Quarterly Net Is Up 20% At Times Co.

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
The New York Times Company reported yesterday that its first-quarter earnings rose nearly 20 percent, slightly exceeding the expectations of most Wall Street analysts.
The main reason for the higher-than-expected profits, analysts said, was the ability of the company's newspapers to increase advertising rates and circulation charges over the last year without losing large numbers of advertisers or readers. 
 The success of that strategy, analysts said, reflected the strength of the company's two largest newspapers, The New York Times and The Boston Globe. "The growth in advertising and circulation revenues, especially at The Times and The Globe, is impressive," said Mary Ann Winter, an analyst at Brown Brothers Harriman & Company. "The quarter's results show that the company was correct in aggressively raising its circulation and ad rates."
The Times Company's net income for the first quarter totaled $32.7 million, or 33 cents a share, up from $27.4 million, or 28 cents a share, in the 1995 first quarter. The latest quarter's results exceeded an average estimate of 30 cents a share by Wall Street analysts, according to Zacks Investment Research.
Revenues increased 9 percent, to $622.5 million, from $571 million in the quarter a year earlier.
The Times Company's shares rose 50 cents yesterday, closing at $31.625 on the American Stock Exchange.
The company's earnings rose despite a decline in profits at the magazine group and a 45 percent increase in the price of newsprint, the main raw material used to produce newspapers.
Operating profits for the magazine group, whose titles include Golf Digest, Tennis and Cruising World, fell to $7.1 million in the latest quarter, down from $10.2 million in the 1995 quarter. Revenues slipped to $40.7 million, from $40.9 million in the quarter a year earlier. Analysts said magazine advertising was soft this year.
The company's broadcast group, which has six network-affiliated television stations and two New York City radio stations, reported improved results. The broadcast group increased its operating earnings to $3.4 million in the latest quarter from $2.7 million a year earlier. Revenues rose to $21.5 million from $17.2 million.
The Times Company derives about 90 percent of its revenues from the newspaper group, which in addition to The Times and The Globe includes 21 regional newspapers. Operating profits for the newspaper group rose to $61.1 million, from $50.9 million in the 1995 quarter, while revenues rose to $560.3 million from $513 million.
At The Times, revenues increased nearly 12 percent, to $322.3 million. The size of The Times's revenue gain was at least twice the expected increase for most other big newspapers, according to John S. Reidy, an analyst at Smith Barney Inc.
Executives of the Times Company were also encouraged by the increasing share of the newspaper's advertising and circulation revenues that now comes from outside the New York metropolitan area, making the paper less dependent on swings in the local economy.
Today, about half The Times's revenues come from the rest of the Northeast and from its national editions. "The Times has become more a demographic product and less a geographic product, not a local newspaper per se," said Diane Baker, the company's chief financial officer.
The Times Company is also investing more aggressively in new ventures, like electronic versions of its newspapers on the Internet's World Wide Web. In the newspaper group alone, the new-venture investment translated into a loss of nearly $2.4 million for the first quarter. In the 1995 quarter, the loss attributable to new ventures in the newspaper group was $103,000. The new ventures are expected to break even within three years, Ms. Baker said.

HEADLINE: Cab Owners Fight Order To Get Costly New Cars

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE 

 BODY:
It might be called "The Case of the Vanishing Taxi Fare Increase." Ask passengers about the 20 percent rise in fares in March, and they will say they certainly feel the difference. But thousands of independent taxi owners who drive their own cars or lease them out say the bonanza they were promised by the Taxi and Limousine Commission has disappeared. And they say it doesn't take a Sherlock Holmes to figure out where it went.
They say they will lose most of the extra $15 to $25 they earn every day because of the commission's new rule, linked to the fare increase, that requires owners to replace old cars with new ones every four to five years. And, cabbies will have to buy brand-new cars instead of used cars, as was common. 
 "They give you a raise and they take it right back," said Rafael Maysonet, president of the Association of Independent Taxi Drivers, a group of 500 Hispanic drivers. "We're really hurting."
As a result, a group of small taxi owners has taken steps to sue the city over the new-car requirement.
In retaliation, the Taxi and Limousine Commission is considering repealing a 14 percent increase in the rental fees that cab owners can charge individual drivers for leasing their taxis. The increase was a central component of the commission's decision to raise fares.
The commission's vote on the issue, due tomorrow, could begin unraveling the carefully wrought fare structure instituted in January. The commission's idea was to improve service for riders, both because cabs would be newer and because experienced cabbies making more money from higher fares would be encouraged to stay in the business longer.
"They agreed to the terms and conditions of the increase," said Marvin Greenberg, the senior Taxi and Limousine commissioner. "For them to enter the courts and try to stop this is deplorable. If they don't want the requirements, they should have none of it."
The issue hardly concerns large fleet owners, who routinely replace their cars every two and a half years. But the independent owners are not only suing the city, they are lobbying city officials to reverse the rule. On April 22, the City Council's Transportation Committee will begin a hearing on a bill to repeal the regulation, said Councilman Noach Dear, chairman of the committee.
Mr. Dear, a Democrat of Borough Park, Brooklyn, called the regulation unfair and unnecessary. The condition of the car is more important than its age, he said.
But Taxi and Limousine officials insist that the fare increase, the first since 1990, will bring drivers enough extra money not only to meet the new-car requirement, but to earn up to $5,000 a year more.
"Even with the new-car requirement, at the end of the day, there is plenty of money to afford these basic and reasonable requirements," said Christopher R. Lynn, the chairman of the commission.
By setting a mandatory retirement age for cars, the commission is tacitly admitting that its monitoring of the condition of taxis is inefficient, said Edward G. Rogoff, a professor of management at Baruch College who studies the taxi industry.
"I think they should regulate the condition of the car, not its age," Mr. Rogoff said. "It's a reflection of their inability to monitor the conditions of the vehicles."
On March 1, the price of a yellow taxi ride increased to $2 for the first one-fifth of a mile, up from $1.50. The cost of each additional fifth of a mile in unclogged traffic became 30 cents, up from 25 cents. The charge for being stopped or moving slowly remained at 20 cents.
That increase was necessary without any additional strings attached, drivers said. They said that a car in good condition that passes the commission's inspection, which three times a year examines everything from exhaust to the color of the car, should not have to be replaced automatically because of its age.
Under the commission's rule, to take effect Nov. 1, fleet owners must replace their cars every three years. An owner-driver who shares the car with another driver has to replace the car every four years, and a sole owner-driver is required to change that car every five years.
Many owner-drivers say they are barely getting by now and will be even worse off if they have to buy a new car every five years. According to commission records, 1,154 cabs, or roughly 10 percent of the city's 11,787 cabs, are driven by owner-drivers who own both the car and the medallion. Perhaps 3,000 more drivers also own their cabs but lease the medallions from someone else.
Most people at the wheels of yellow cabs are lease drivers, who rent their cabs for the day or the week from the people who own them or from middlemen. These drivers have benefited from the increase.
"It's been better than before," said Gerard Paul, 42. "Hopefully, it will be even better."
To insure that lease drivers benefit from the fare increase, the commission for the first time limited to 14 percent the rise in lease rates that medallion owners could charge drivers. The owners have often raised their leasing fees whenever fares have gone up.
Adding to the owner-drivers' usual anxieties is that the city will auction 100 medallions for the first time in 60 years. And a month or two after a fare increase goes into effect, riders are usually reluctant to ride and tend to tip less generously, said Mr. Rogoff. Eventually, riders return to their old pattern, he said.
Marcel Fils-Aime, a cabby for eight years, said that his insurance payment went to $277 a month from $229 a month a few months ago. About three years ago, the city's Finance Department increased by tenfold a tax stamp that cabbies pay, to $1,000 from $100.
"When I heard we were going to get a raise, I was very happy," Mr. Fils-Aime said. "But now when I look at it, it's not much. I don't feel the difference at all."
Drivers now pay $75 to $100 for a 12-hour shift, or about $450 to $650 for a weekly lease. The driver must also pay for gas, at $15 to $20 a shift. Drivers keep whatever fares and tips they collect.
The average cabby collects 30 fares per 12-hour shift, the commission says, so the higher fares would mean an extra $30 a day on average.
That figure is hotly disputed by the drivers, whose lawyer's survey put the increase closer to $2,500 a year, or about $15 more per shift. And that figure is offset by inflation and higher cost of doing business, they said.

HEADLINE: G.M. Strike Drags Down Industrial Output

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 16

 BODY:
Weighed down by a 17-day strike at the General Motors Corporation, industrial output slumped five-tenths of 1 percent in March to match the biggest declines since the final stages of the 1990-91 recession, the Federal Reserve reported today.
But excluding the lost output of vehicles and parts, production climbed three-tenths of 1 percent to support the growing consensus that the economic boiler has picked up steam but is no danger of overheating. 
 "All things considered, the industrial production data indicate slow but steady growth," the National Association of Manufacturers said in a statement. After flirting with a downturn in late 1995, it added, "we are back on a slow-growth track."
Looking beyond the month to the full first quarter, output climbed at a 2.7 percent annual pace, compared with a six-tenths of 1 percent rate in the last quarter of last year, the central bank's figures showed. The step-up was less than it appears, however, since the earlier period was depressed by a strike at the Boeing Company.
Unlike many recent statistics, today's results were largely as expected and had no discernible effect on securities markets.
In addition to the output data for March, which showed gains for mines and utilities but a decline of eight-tenths of 1 percent for factories, the central bank reported a decline in the operating rate of American industry.
Plants ran at a relatively comfortable 82.5 percent of capacity, markedly below the 85.1 percent peak for this expansion reached just over a year ago and seven-tenths of a point under the February pace.
"There's a lot of capacity that we could use before we have price pressures," said Maria Fiorino Ramirez of the Wall Street firm bearing her name. "The Fed's going to stay status quo for a while."
The G.M. strike showed up throughout the report, pushing output of automotive products down about 15 percent, transit equipment down 11.7 percent, consumer goods down nine-tenths of 1 percent and factory durables down 1.4 percent.
Vehicle assembly tumbled to an annual rate of 9.9 million vehicles from 11.9 million, with autos, light trucks and heavy and medium trucks all lower, the report showed. In the second quarter, G.M. plans to recover nearly a third of the production it lost during the strike.
The computer and office equipment category was again a star performer, rising 3 percent to bring the 12-month gain to a stunning 38.9 percent as companies seek to raise productivity by substituting machinery for labor wherever possible.
Output of consumer goods, by contrast, declined slightly over all during the last year, with production of clothing -- facing strong competition from imports -- down 9.1 percent.
Production of construction supplies rose four-tenths of 1 percent last month and at a 2 percent pace for the first quarter, down from a 6 percent pace in the final three months of 1995.
Total output was revised upward by one-tenth of a point for each of the first two months of the year, the Fed also reported, with January's decline now put at three-tenths of 1 percent and February's gain now 1.3 percent.
The eight-tenths of 1 percent decline in factory output, reflecting the G.M. strike, was the biggest monthly drop in five years. The rise for mines and oil wells was 2 percent last month while utility output advanced seven-tenths of 1 percent.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
CATERPILLAR INC. (CAT,N)

 BODY:
Caterpillar Inc.'s first-quarter earnings fell 1.3 percent, to $296 million, from $300 million in the corresponding quarter of 1995, though per share earnings rose to $1.53 a share, from $1.50, as the company bought back shares through the quarter.
The per share earnings exceeded analysts' predictions of $1.49 a share, based on the average estimate of 17 analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research. Still, Caterpillar shares fell $1.125, to $70.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. 
 Caterpillar, based in Peoria, Ill., said sales fell 1.8 percent, to $3.84 billion. The company said United States sales declined 5 percent because of a lingering economic slowdown that it expected to continue. Sales outside the United States, which account for 49 percent of the total, were roughly unchanged.
The company said it expected worldwide sales to be somewhat lower this year because improved sales in developing nations and in Europe would not offset lower sales in the United States, Canada and Australia.
During the latest quarter, more than 8,000 striking members of the United Automobile Workers union returned to Caterpillar without a contract. (Bloomberg Business News)

HEADLINE: Federal Reserve Turns Aside Criticism in G.A.O. Report

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 16

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve Board dismissed most of the criticisms of its management today that had been included in a recent report to Congress, and said that it ran itself as efficiently as any company or Government agency.
The Fed was responding to a draft report from the General Accounting Office, the Congressional auditing agency, released last month by two Democratic Senators. The report said that the central bank had been lax in controlling its costs and questioned whether the Fed was adequately preparing itself for changes in the financial world. The report did not address the Fed's conduct of monetary policy. 
 In a letter accompanying the Fed's 12-page rebuttal, the chairman, Alan Greenspan, said that the G.A.O. report included some suggestions about how to find more cost savings that were "potentially quite helpful" and that the Fed would apply them "where appropriate." Among these were recommendations that the Federal Reserve study harmonizing the policies on travel expenses among its 12 regional banks and find ways to share more information among the banks about effective procurement practices.
But in a clear indication that the report would not prompt the Fed to make drastic changes in the way it operated, the central bank said either that it was already doing what the report suggested or that it disagreed with the report's analysis and recommendations.
Addressing a central conclusion -- that the Fed had allowed operating expenses to grow too quickly at a time of belt-tightening throughout the Government -- Mr. Greenspan said the Fed's performance, by at least one measure, was in line with the Federal Government over all.
The Federal Reserve's operating expenses rose 50 percent from 1988 to 1994, to $2 billion a year, a rate of increase that was twice that of inflation and nearly triple the rate of growth in overall Federal spending. But Mr. Greenspan said the rate of growth during the period in discretionary Federal spending was a fairer comparison, and that by that measure, the growth in the Fed's operating expenses was slightly below those of the Government.
The Fed also took issue with the G.A.O. report's conclusion that the growth in its employee-benefits payments was much greater than for Government employees. Using a different method of calculating the growth than the G.A.O. did, the Fed said that growth in benefits costs from 1988 to 1994 was about the same as for the Government.
The G.A.O. report said that the Federal Reserve had amassed a surplus on its books of $3.7 billion, ostensibly to cover losses, despite the fact that the Fed had never come close to a loss. The Fed responded that "the appropriate level of the Federal Reserve surplus is open to debate."
But it went to say that turning the surplus over to the Treasury would have little economic advantage for taxpayers, and could create risks. It said that it had on many occasions suffered short-run losses that required borrowing from the surplus, and that any perception among investors of even the most temporary problems "could prompt questions in the minds of some investors in dollar assets, including holders of Federal Reserve notes, about the continued ability of the central bank to conduct monetary policy."
The report's recommendation that some of the 12 Fed regional banks and 25 branches be consolidated was all but dismissed. Such a process, the Fed said, would be "very costly, and the long-term savings would have to be substantial to offset the transition costs."

HEADLINE: Wildcat Walkout Is Ended At Big G.M. Assembly Plant

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 16

 BODY:
Striking workers returned to their jobs at a General Motors Corporation assembly plant tonight hours after G.M. once again displayed its aggressive new approach to labor relations, obtaining a Federal court order for an immediate end to the wildcat strike.
It was unclear how much effect the temporary restraining order from the Federal District Court in Cleveland had in ending the strike. Jim Tripp, the financial secretary of the United Automobile Workers union local in Lordstown, Ohio, said in an interview before the court order was issued that the union wanted a quick end to the strike. 
 The strike was not authorized by the national leadership of the U.A.W. and was prompted largely by G.M.'s dismissal of a popular local union leader.
Today's actions by G.M., the world's largest auto maker, were the latest evidence that G.M. had broken ranks with the Chrysler Corporation and the Ford Motor Company in pursuing a confrontational policy toward the U.A.W., aimed at reducing G.M.'s labor costs, the highest in the industry. G.M. not only sought and obtained the court order today but also publicly accused the dismissed U.A.W. official in Lordstown of fraud, a charge the union denied.
The test of G.M.'s tough approach to labor relations will come this summer, when all three auto makers must negotiate three-year national contracts with the U.A.W. to replace agreements expiring on Sept. 14.
G.M. held out for 17 days last month when 3,000 workers walked out at two brake factories in Dayton, Ohio, and tried with mixed success to block state governments from paying unemployment benefits to U.A.W. workers laid off because of the strike. Earlier this month, G.M. announced that it would close an automotive generator factory in Michigan and try to sell three other parts factories in Michigan and Ontario.
That announcement provoked a lament last Friday by Richard Shoemaker, the U.A.W. vice president in charge of relations with G.M. "I am disappointed, I am disgusted," he said in a speech. "That action obviously diminished the quality of the relationship that our union has with the corporation."
Chrysler and Ford continue to pursue warm relations with the U.A.W. in hope of limiting costly strikes. Both companies contend that they need to keep their workers happy because cars and trucks are becoming ever more complicated to build. And assembly plants are now more vulnerable to strikes at parts factories because parts inventories are being kept lean to save money.
G.M. today announced that last Saturday it had dismissed Al Alli, the chairman of the U.A.W. bargaining committee at the huge Lordstown plant, contending he had fraudulently used his time card to obtain pay for time not worked. "This is fraud, and it will not be tolerated by General Motors," said James R. Wiemels, a G.M. vice president, in a statement issued this afternoon.
Mr. Tripp denied that Mr. Alli had misused his time card or engaged in any fraud. He said that G.M. managers had demanded that Mr. Alli tell them where he was going every time he left the factory on union business, and that Mr. Alli refused to do so. G.M. executives said that more was involved, but declined to elaborate on Mr. Wiemels's statement.
Under G.M.'s national contract with the U.A.W., some local union officials are on G.M.'s payroll but work full-time on union business.
Mr. Alli's dismissal provoked the wildcat strike, which began on Monday morning when 1,800 workers on the day shift walked out. The U.A.W.'s national leadership in Detroit had not approved the work stoppage -- which violated the union's national contract with G.M. -- and urged with limited effect that the strike end immediately.
Part of the evening shift reported for work Monday night and part of the day shift reported today, not enough, Mr. Tripp said, to produce any cars.
But Ray Deibel, a G.M. spokesman, strongly denied this, saying that a "very limited" production of cars had taken place. Mr. Deibel and Mr. Tripp said tonight that full production had resumed on today's evening shift.
The Lordstown factory has at least 5,500 workers and normally assembles 6,500 to 7,000 Chevrolet Cavaliers and Pontiac Sunfires a week.
