HEADLINE: Mr. Clinton's New Agenda in Asia

 BODY:
When President Clinton first visited Japan in 1993, acrimonious trade issues dominated the agenda. Mr. Clinton is back in Tokyo this week, but the subject has changed. This time, both sides are stressing efforts to reinforce the United States security alliance with Japan. The shift is appropriate, given new military tensions in the region, and it promises to produce more harmonious relations between Washington and its leading Asian ally.
While both the Japanese and South Korean Governments welcome the American military presence on their territory, resentment has increased in some areas where the troops are concentrated. That is particularly true on Okinawa, which contains a disproportionate share of American bases and where resistance was fanned by the rape last year of a Japanese girl by American servicemen. To ease political pressures on Tokyo, Washington has agreed to shift some forces out of Okinawa to other Japanese locations. In return, Japan agreed today to stretch the limits of its pacifist Constitution with a joint declaration offering broadened support to United States military operations. 
 During a brief stop in South Korea, Mr. Clinton rightly rebuffed North Korea's latest bid to drive a wedge between Washington and Seoul. Rejecting direct peace talks between the United States and North Korea, Mr. Clinton joined South Korea's President in proposing four-party talks, involving the United States, China and the two Koreas. The North may not accept the proposal. But broad regional talks are the right approach, and they should include Japanese and Russian participation.
The remarkable economic advance of East Asia over the past two decades has been built on the peace and stability assured by a strong American military presence. Victory in World War II, followed by interventions in Korea and Vietnam and the long vigil of the cold war, left the United States at the center of East Asia's security calculus. Washington, with no ambitions of its own in the region today, is a reassuring presence to small and medium-sized countries anxious about a newly powerful China or the possibility that Japan might someday rearm. The American presence is also a vital guarantor of South Korean security.
America maintains 100,000 troops in the Western Pacific, 47,000 of them in Japan and 37,000 in South Korea. Financial support by the host countries makes the cost of stationing these troops in Asia roughly the same for Washington as basing them in the United States. The Clinton Administration has pledged that the number of American troops will not be reduced. But uneasy Asian countries worry less about numbers than about Washington's constancy.
Mr. Clinton's dispatch of two aircraft carrier groups to the seas off Taiwan during Beijing's recent military exercises was greeted by most Asian governments with public silence and private relief. Ideally, American firmness should require neither military displays nor economic sanctions but steady insistence that all countries respect international laws and treaty obligations. America's goal with China should not be containing or isolating Beijing, but integrating it more fully into the international community and encouraging it to use its power responsibly.
Looking out for American business opportunities and enforcing trade fairness are still important American interests. But security issues cannot be neglected. The timing and substance of Mr. Clinton's visit are good. After the Chinese belligerence in the Taiwan Strait and reckless North Korean troop movements, it is not surprising that Mr. Clinton has found his Asian hosts receptive to American ideas for keeping their region calm, peaceful and prosperous.

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Doctor's Specialty Turns Out to Be Masquerade

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 16

 BODY:
Colleagues remember him as witty and charming, a crisp professional with a confident bedside manner, a flair for storytelling and a generosity of spirit that led him on risky overseas trips to provide free medical care for the poor.
Gerald Barnes, who held the post of chief physician at a prominent health clinic here, seemed to many the very embodiment of Hippocratic virtues. But he is not a doctor and has never attended a medical school, the authorities say, adding that, in fact, his only formal training in a health-related field is a bachelor's degree in pharmacology. 
 On Monday, Mr. Barnes, 62, was charged in Federal court with, among other crimes, fraud and practicing medicine without a license at the Executive Health Group, a downtown Los Angeles medical center specializing in preventive care and annual physicals, where he has worked since July 1995.
But he has long been masquerading as a doctor. In the late 1970's, according to court documents, after he legally changed his name from Gerald Barnbaum, he began impersonating an orthopedic surgeon from Stockton, Calif., named Gerald Barnes. And as Dr. Barnes, he embarked upon a career that was halted in 1981 with his guilty plea to involuntary manslaughter and practicing medicine without a license. He was sentenced to three years in a California prison and after serving 18 months, was released on parole in 1983. But then, the authorities say, he picked up where he had left off. Behind his smooth mask, they say, is a prodigiously talented con artist.
"For a person to try to assume the identity of a licensed individual is very unusual," said Candis E. Cohen, a spokeswoman for the medical board of California.
While the current complaint against Mr. Barnes does not name specific victims or incidents of harm, a person close to the case said that among Executive Health Group's clients are senior officials of the Federal Reserve Bank, the California Highway Patrol and other agencies, and major companies including Arco, Citicorp, Nissan, Ernst & Young and Hughes Aircraft.
Court documents also disclose that Mr. Barnes is believed to have performed medical examinations on "hundreds" of employees in the Los Angeles office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, including special agents, which is the likely reason the investigation has led to Federal charges.
In a resume about Mr. Barnes that the company provides to prospective clients, he is listed as having received a doctorate in pharmacology from the University of Illinois and a medical degree from the University of Wisconsin. The resume also gives an extensive professional background for him, including 17 years of practicing general family medicine at the Garfield Medical Center in Illinois.
But this is the background of the real Dr. Gerald Barnes.
"Everyone who had contact with him thought he was a remarkable individual and an excellent physician," said Paul W. Frankel, a medical doctor who is president of the Life Extension Institute, a New York based company that owns the Executive Health Group, which has a contract to do physical examinations of senior executives of dozens of large companies, including The New York Times. "He was just the best."
Responding to the new accusations involving the other Barnes, the real Dr. Gerald Barnes said in Stockton, "It's the same guy who has been impersonating me."
"When it happened the first time," he continued, "I was driving home, and I heard that I had been picked up for manslaughter. It was kind of frightening."
In a crowded courtroom on Monday afternoon, Mr. Barnes, looking nervous and somewhat frail, clutched the podium with one hand and his forehead with the other as he stood before a Federal Magistrate, Rosalyn M. Chapman. Asked by the Magistrate if he was all right, Mr. Barnes responded in a barely audible voice, "I have diabetes and prostate cancer."
Magistrate Chapman set a bail hearing for Wednesday. Mr. Barnes is being held in a Federal holding unit in downtown Los Angeles, and officials close to the case said he was on a suicide watch.
Mr. Barnes was born and grew up in Chicago. As a youth, he was a talented actor, and even appeared in several traveling professional shows, said Frank Heckl, a retired senior investigator with the California Medical Examiners office who worked on the inquiry that led to the 1981 case.
After Mr. Barnes received his degree in pharmacology, Mr. Heckl said, he worked in a medical office in Chicago where he was known for being amiable and easy-going. Some colleagues even suggested that with his knowledge of medicine, he should try medical school and some patients referred to him as Doc, according to a 1985 article in Medical Economics, a trade journal, about people who falsely present themselves as doctors.
In the mid-1970's, Mr. Barnes lost his pharmacist's license, law-enforcement officials said, after being accused of Medicaid fraud. He then moved to California where he legally changed his name and began his career impersonating the real Dr. Barnes.
Much of the detail about how he was able to impersonate the real Dr. Barnes comes from the Medical Economics article, which said that he wrote California medical authorities on letterhead bearing the name Dr. Gerald Barnes and requested copies of records the doctor was required to file with the state. He explained that he needed the copies, Mr. Heckl said, because he had recently gone through a bitter divorce battle with his former spouse, and she had destroyed the originals.
With copies of these credentials, he worked back from the information he found in them, and wrote to request copies of the real Dr. Barnes's medical school degree and other credentials on Wisconsin and California. Armed with these documents, he obtained a job at a clinic in East Los Angeles, and later, a better-paying position at a medical center in Irvine, Calif.
The charade began to unravel in 1980, according to court documents, when a 29-year-old man came to him complaining of dry mouth and lips, sudden weight loss, dizziness and insatiable thirst -- classic symptoms of uncontrolled diabetes. Mr. Barnes ordered blood and urine tests, but sent the patient home, prescribing rest and a drug to treat the vertigo.
Two days later, the patient, John McKenzie, was found dead in his Anaheim apartment after lapsing into a diabetic coma. Mr. Barnes was subsequently charged with murder. He pleaded guilty to involuntary manslaughter and practicing medicine without a license.
Upon his release from the California Institution for Men at Chino, a minimum-security prison, Mr. Barnes got a job as a salesman for a industrial maintenance supply company in Anaheim, but by 1984 was working at a clinic in Orange County where he was arrested.
He pleaded guilty that year to two counts of grand theft for taking money from patients who believed that he was a doctor, and six counts of writing prescriptions without a license. He was sentenced to three years and four months in prison.
"Here was a very likable person who people generally enjoyed being with," said a colleague who has worked closely with him, but who spoke only on the condition that he not be identified. "He handled himself extremely well and seemed to know a good bit of medicine."

HEADLINE: Is North Korea Turning to Counterfeiting?

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 16

 BODY:
With North Korea so poor that people are going hungry, some experts are worried that the Government there may be turning to a novel approach to raising hard currency: peddling counterfeit American money.
The evidence is far from conclusive, and North Korea denies that it is moonlighting as a counterfeiter. But the accusations have been boosted by the indictment last week in Thailand of a Japanese man who has close ties to the North Korean Government on charges of passing fake $100 bills. 
 At least three North Korean defectors also have charged that the country prints counterfeit dollars in a factory in the capital, Pyongyang.
President Clinton visited South Korea this week in part to discuss North Korea's recent behavior, particularly its incursions this month into the demilitarized zone that separates North and South Korea. If it turns out that North Korea is challenging the West not only with guns but also with bogus currency, the pressure to punish and isolate North Korea will grow, leading to further instability on the Korean Peninsula.
Extremely good reproductions of United States $100 bills have been turning up around the world in recent years, but investigators apparently made a big break early this year when Thai police arrested two local men on charges of passing phony bills and who, in turn, identified as one of their sources for the bills an alias for the man who was indicted in Thailand, Yoshimi Tanaka.
Mr. Tanaka was one of a group of Japanese leftists who hijacked an airliner in 1970 and defected to North Korea. Recently he has been spending much of his time in Cambodia, living at least part of the time in the North Korean Embassy there. He reportedly flew to Cambodia again late last month.
As soon as United States intelligence found out about this, American officials asked the Cambodian Government to arrest him. Apparently forewarned, Mr. Tanaka fled in a car with North Korean diplomatic license plates, carrying a North Korean diplomatic passport, and tried to drive across the border to Vietnam.
Prodded by the Americans, the Cambodian Government detained Mr. Tanaka, who is not an accredited North Korean diplomat, and handed him over to Thailand, where he has been interrogated by Thai and American officials. At a court hearing, Mr. Tanaka denied the charges and said that he was a North Korean who had never been in Thailand before.
North Korea, for its part, denounced as a "smear campaign" the suggestions that it is involved in counterfeiting. It did not deny that former hijackers like Mr. Tanaka may have been involved in counterfeiting, but it said that they remain Japanese and that any misconduct was their own affair.
"It is entirely according to their own will what they do anywhere outside" North Korea, the country's official press agency declared.
Still, there have been a number of other cases in which North Korea has been linked to high-quality counterfeit $100 bills. In 1994 police in the Portuguese enclave of Macao, near Hong Kong, detained four North Korean diplomats and businessmen who had deposited counterfeit money in a local bank. Police searches later found $250,000 in bogus American currency, but the North Koreans pleaded ignorance and were later released.
In addition, a Tokyo trading company that sold used cars to North Korea last year reportedly was paid $50,000 in counterfeit $100 bills. The notes in these cases were extremely well made, able to fool bank machines and many bankers. Other recent counterfeits have been dubbed "supernotes" because of their high quality, and have led the United States Treasury to rush the introduction of a redesigned $100 bill, which entered circulation last month.
Some intelligence experts say that the supernotes are being printed by Iran or Syria, and that North Korea may have obtained some as part of deals whereby North Korea sells weapons to Iran in exchange for crates of counterfeit currency.
Another theory is that North Korea is printing counterfeits on its own. Last year, a defector from North Korea, Kang Myong To, who identified himself as the son-in-law of North Korea's Prime Minister, charged that North Korea has been counterfeiting American $20, $50 and $100 bills since 1987.
Mr. Kang said that North Korea prints between $8 million to $10 million of counterfeit dollars each year and ships them by diplomatic pouch to China and the Middle East for distribution there. At least two other North Korean defectors have also accused North Korea of printing counterfeit Japanese yen and German marks as well as dollars.

HEADLINE: Pataki Weighs Alterations For Workers' Insurance

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 16

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki proposed legislation today to revamp the state's troubled workers' compensation system, saying his plan would reduce soaring insurance costs at least 30 percent.
The Governor's bill is his opening foray into what is considered one of the most important and complex issues facing the Legislature this year. Under intense pressure from business leaders, both parties have agreed that New York's high premiums -- which are paid entirely by employers -- are stifling job growth and driving companies out of the state. But they remain far apart in their solutions. 
 Mr. Pataki's proposal would restrict employers' liability in certain types of lawsuits, establish a uniform system for determining an injured workers' disability and prohibit workers from simultaneously collecting workers' compensation and unemployment insurance.
It would also increase penalties for defrauding the workers' compensation system and establish a new state agency to ferret out fraud. And it would create new penalities for employers with poor safety records.
"Our system is clearly broken," Mr. Pataki said, noting that New York's workers' compensation fees are 57 percent above the national average and higher than in all surrounding states.
Democrats, lawyers' groups and labor leaders were quick to criticize Mr. Pataki's plan, saying that high insurance costs resulted from price-gouging by insurers. They said that Mr. Pataki's plan would benefit insurance companies but jeopardize worker safety by restricting litigation against employers. "This isn't reform, it's robbery," said Edward J. Cleary, president of the New York State A.F.L.-C.I.O., which represents 2.3 million workers.
The Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, a Republican of Rensselaer County who is among Mr. Pataki's strongest allies, called the Governor's plan "a solid basis for negotiations" and said that it included provisions similar to a plan being developed by the Senate.
Privately, however, Senate Republicans said that elements of Mr. Pataki's plan would face stiff opposition in their chamber, particularly the proposal to bar injured workers from collecting workers' compensation and unemployment insurance.
But business groups applauded the Governor's plan. "This bill will provide dramatic savings that small business needs right now to be able to afford to hire new employees," said Mark Alesse, the director of the New York chapter of the National Federation of Independent Business.
The state's workers' compensation system was created in 1914 to provide weekly payments to workers injured on the job until they could return to work. It was designed to be "no fault," meaning that employers would assume all liability for workplace accidents, regardless of fault. In exchange, workers could not sue employers for workplace accidents.
But over the years, the courts have broadened employers' liability in workers' compensation. In the most important case, known as Dole v. Dow, the state's highest court, the Court of Appeals, allowed so-called third-party suits against employers. Under the decision, a maker of defective equipment who is required to pay damages to an injured worker can in turn sue the worker's employer to collect part of those damages.
Business groups contend that the Dole v. Dow decision has led to expensive and protracted litigation between companies. Mr. Pataki said that third-party lawsuits account for about 6 percent, or $300 million, of the $5 billion in premiums paid by state businesses each year.
In what is likely to be the most hotly contested part of his plan, Mr. Pataki calls for repealing the Dole decision. Almost all other states prohibit such lawsuits, and Mr. Pataki contends that New York will be hurt in the competition for new companies if it does not bar them as well.
But union leaders contend that repealing the Dole decision would remove an important incentive for employers to keep their workplaces safe. "We're talking about billions stolen in this system," Mr. Cleary said. "They are trying to slough it off on Dole v. Dow? That's too simple."
Aides to the Governor said a major savings in his plan was a proposal to limit judges' discretion in deciding an injured worker's benefits. Under the Pataki plan, judges would have to use guidelines established by the American Medical Association.

HEADLINE: New Boat People Exodus: Back to Vietnam

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, April 16

 BODY:
Two decades after the fall of Saigon, the biggest flood of Vietnamese boat people in years is under way. But this time the flow is being reversed, as refugee camps around Southeast Asia begin closing down and tens of thousands of asylum-seekers are sent back to the country they fled.
In an effort to be done with this last chapter of the Vietnam War, the United Nations agreed at an international meeting last month to cut off financing for the camps on June 30. The people who remain in the camps are no longer considered eligible for resettlement, and officials say the only option for the Vietnamese now is to go home -- willingly or not. 
 This week officials here plan to march as many as 500 holdouts onto a ship and send them back across the South China Sea. It would be the largest single group yet to be sent home and the first to be returned by sea.
Vietnam, while still Communist, has changed, refugee officials say, and the last 35,000 people in camps around the region are not true refugees fleeing repression but "economic migrants" who do not have a claim to resettlement in the West.
"We have tried to make it very clear to them: there is no more hope," said Rear Adm. Yaacob bin H. J. Daud, the director of the Malaysian Government task force on refugees. "They cannot extend this thing anymore."
It may still be many months before the camps are empty, but with the cutoff in international financing, conditions in the camps will become increasingly harsh.
In Vietnam, the Government is preparing to receive, process and resettle a flood of reluctant returnees, many of them hostile or broken in spirit, many without homes or jobs to return to.
"The last ones will be the most difficult," said Nghiem Xuan Tue, who oversees the return of refugees for the Vietnamese Ministry of Labor. "We will try our hardest. The most important thing is for their local community to welcome them as long-lost relatives who have come home."
He said Vietnam had streamlined its procedures for processing the returnees and was prepared to receive as many as 3,600 a month, straining its bureaucracy and social services.
"It will be a monumental undertaking," said Court Robinson, an American consultant to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. "This population has been in the camps for seven years now, and if we know anything about reintegration it becomes more difficult the longer one has been away -- and even more difficult when one is really dead set against coming back."
As the return of the first boat, scheduled for Thursday, approached, Erika Feller, the United Nations refugee representative in Kuala Lumpur, voiced a worry shared by officials around the region: "We hope it does not boil down to the model that you have seen in Hong Kong, where protesting refugees are carried horizontally onto airplanes."
The longer that people have remained in the camps, the more desperate their fears have become. There have been riots in camps in Malaysia and the Philippines. The police have used tear gas and batons to battle protesters in Hong Kong. In Indonesia two years ago refugees set themselves on fire to protest plans to send them home.
 
Camps Are Closed To All Visitors
"We need help here!" one man called out to reporters as Philippine officials prepared to send a planeload of refugees back to Vietnam in February. "Help! Help!"
And another said: "We won't be safe in Vietnam. We're scared."
Here in Malaysia, in Thailand, the Philippines and elsewhere, officials have closed the camps to visitors as they lobby intensely to persuade the refugees to leave without a struggle.
"We are talking to them," Admiral Yaacob said. "We have gone deep into their hearts to tell them: 'This is the time to go. If you keep delaying, it will only get worse.' "
Since the Communist takeover of Saigon in 1975, more than 800,000 Vietnamese have passed through the camps in Southeast Asia, most on their way to resettlement in the United States, Canada, France, Australia and other "third countries."
To the consternation of those countries, the flood of boat people continued through the decades, and in 1989 a screening system was set up under which the West would accept only true refugees. Some 115,000 people were deemed to be economic migrants and were refused resettlement. As of this month, about 77,000 of these had been sent home by plane.
That policy has helped bring a virtual halt to boat departures from Vietnam. Since 1989 most refugees have left by plane under the Orderly Departure Program.
About half the remaining holdouts are in camps in Hong Kong, and officials there are counting on the persuasive power of an unusual local deadline: June 30, 1997. On that date the British colony is to be handed over to the Chinese, who have demanded that the camps there be empty when they take control.
The United States is also pressing Hanoi to accept a "Track II" policy in which returnees will be allowed a final interview with American officials once they are back in Vietnam. Such a policy would add one more incentive to return and would address concerns in Washington that some refugees have been unfairly denied asylum.
In a carefully worded statement last month, the Vietnamese Government suggested that such interviews might be possible within the framework of the Orderly Departure Program, a statement that one Western diplomat called "highly significant."
Vietnamese officials are concerned that "Track II" could complicate the already delicate task of resettling reluctant returnees. "It is very dangerous, very dangerous to give them hope that they can still go to America," Mr. Tue said. "Instead of settling in, they will spend the day gathered in front of the United States Embassy asking for visas and creating disorder."
The fate of the returning refugees is a delicate issue that has caused alarm among Vietnamese emigre groups as well as panic among the people who remain in the camps. But United Nations officials insist they are tracking the returns closely and have found no cases of political persecution by the Government.
Catherine Bertrand, the United Nations refugee agency's representative in Hanoi, said a team of seven foreign monitoring officers, all fluent in Vietnamese, had interviewed 23,000 returnees since 1989. "We are witnesses that these people have returned to Vietnam and have not been persecuted for leaving illegally," she said.
Returning refugees receive cash assistance and loans from the United Nations and the European Union, and their home communities receive help for local construction projects that is intended to cushion any resentment against the new arrivals.
 
Not All Succeed In Restarting Lives
Though most returnees have managed to restart their lives with the help of their families and communities, Mr. Tue said: "There are 25 to 30 percent who are not stable. They keep thinking about leaving again. Some are lazy. And some who left here with criminal records must now face justice."
There are many kinds of problems, Mr. Robinson said, including delays in receiving reintegration help, problems with community members, problems with local party officials and "the inevitable corruption."
"Not everybody will hit the ground running and say, 'Where's my cash grant; I'm off to start a business,' " he said. "There's going to be a lot of decompressing, a lot of depression. Many of them will just veg out."
Nguyen Minh Quan, a 39-year-old mechanic, spent nearly seven years in a refugee camp in Hong Kong with his wife and two children before giving up and returning to Hanoi last November.
When a Vietnamese-speaking United Nations monitor named Dirk Hebecker visited him last month, he made no pretense about being a political refugee. "Things were hard here back then," he said of his departure in 1988. "We were looking for a better life."
 
Counting the Cost Of a Perilous Trip
Like other returnees visited on this day by Mr. Hebecker, Mr. Quan had not found a job and was living with relatives. In a long and relaxed conversation, he volunteered that he had had no difficulties with local officials.
He said he had received a $960 resettlement allowance from the United Nations for his family of four and $550 from the Hong Kong authorities as an incentive to volunteer to return.
"That's not peanuts in this country," Ms. Bertrand said in describing grants that can add up to well over a year's pay. "It gives them the means to find another job or help them start to build a house or buy a field or start a small business." But like many other refugees, Mr. Quan said he had used the money not to begin a new life but to survive.
People like Mr. Quan and his family gained little from their aspirations for a better life. The perilous boat journeys, the wasted years in a refugee camp and the hardships of their return have left them mostly worse off than they were before.
Those who remain in the camps today may face an even rougher final chapter, Mr. Robinson said.
"The picture of people being dragged crying and screaming to airplanes may become not the occasional exception but the norm," he said. "These are people who are essentially innocent of any crime. No matter what we feel about their status -- no matter whether they are actually refugees or not -- that is still very sad."

GRAPHIC: Map showing number of Vietnamese boat people remaining in camps in Southeast Asia, as of February 1996. (Source: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees) 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: VIET NAM (96%); SOUTH-EASTERN ASIA (93%); MALAYSIA (93%); ASIA (93%); VIETNAM (92%); UNITED STATES (79%);

HEADLINE: U.S. MILITARY ROLE IN EAST ASIA GETS SUPPORT IN TOKYO

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Wednesday, April 17

 BODY:
Defying anti-American sentiment fanned by the rape of an Okinawa girl by American servicemen last fall, President Clinton and Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan today reaffirmed the United States' military presence in the Far East as "essential for preserving peace and stability" in the region.
In a joint declaration signed by Mr. Clinton and Mr. Hashimoto at a midday ceremony, the two leaders proclaimed that the security relationship between America and Japan "remains the cornerstone for achieving common security objectives and maintaining a stable and prosperous environment" in Asia. 
 The declaration states that the United States has determined that it will need to maintain its current force structure of 100,000 troops in the region, "including about the current level in Japan." Anthony Lake, Mr. Clinton's national security adviser, said Mr. Hashimoto's signature would signal Japan's endorsement of the American position.
"The relationship between the United States and Japan is better and stronger than ever,"' Mr. Clinton said after the signing. "Our security alliance is key to maintaining a Pacific at peace."
The declaration also incorporates the plan struck by the United States and Japan on the eve of Mr. Clinton's state visit, to return an air base, two communications centers, a port and other military properties on Okinawa, where the rape provoked huge protests against the United States military presence.
Annoyance at the American military bases lingers, as shown by a rally by thousands in Tokyo Tuesday, during which the United States was branded an "illegal occupant" of Japanese territory. Such sentiment is even stronger in Okinawa, where most people want all American bases closed eventually.
The document opens the door for Japan to consider broader ways of cooperating with the United States during a war in East Asia, with the two nations agreeing to review 1978 guidelines for military cooperation. American officials have called the review a potential breakthrough since Japan has held that its Constitution would prohibit any involvement in such a military operation.
The signing of the declaration is the centerpiece of Mr. Clinton's two-day state visit to Japan, intended to reaffirm that the United States has a major security role to play in Asia even after the cold war and to showcase Mr. Clinton's prestige as a foreign-policy maker.
This morning, before his session with Mr. Hashimoto, Mr. Clinton and his wife, Hillary, were welcomed at the Akasaka Palace, the official state quest house modeled after Versailles, by Emperor Akihito and Empress Michiko. With the two men in front and the women walking behind, the Clintons were then escorted to a limousine waiting to take them to the Imperial Palace.
Mr. Clinton's trip has also underscored some of the foibles of political timing. Mr. Clinton was originally supposed to make his visit in November but canceled because of the confrontation with Congress over the budget. Japan now has a new Prime Minister more attuned to America's view of regional security. And China's recent military exercises in the Taiwan Strait as well as North Korea's incursions into the demilitarized zone separating it from South Korea have raised new fears throughout the region and a new focus on military policy.
Trade issues -- a usual flashpoint between America and Japan -- were barely on the agenda. Laura Tyson, Mr. Clinton's economic adviser, said she expected no breakthroughs in three areas of contention: semiconductors, photographic film and insurance. Over the weekend, American and Japanese negotiators abandoned efforts to reach an insurance accord before the President's visit.
Arguing that Japan's shrinking trade surplus and the growth of American exports demonstrate a marked increase in access to Japan's markets, Clitnon Administration officials have worked hard to promote their record of forging trade agreements with Japan. But the American Ambassador, Walter Mondale, was blunter this morning, telling reporters, "Japan continues to be too closed, over regulated, too resistant to market forces and I think that will be true for a long time."
Mr. Clinton arrived here on Tuesday after a stop in South Korea, where he and President Kim Young Sam proposed four-party talks -- including the two Koreas, China and the United States -- intended to replace with a permanent peace agreement the 1953 armistice that ended the Korean War.
Before he leaves Japan on Thursday evening Mr. Clinton plans to address Parliament and visit a Chrysler branch to showcase his efforts to open Japanese markets to American autos and auto parts.
A key component of the security declaration is the American decision to hand back 20 percent of its holdings on Okinawa in the coming years. The functions and personnel of the bases that are closing are to be transfered to bases in other Japanese towns so that the number of American troops remains 47,000.
Japan has agreed to pay virtually all of the costs of the base closings and transfer of American personnel. And the security declaration also incorporates an agreement for Japan and the United States to share food, transportation, refueling, medical care and weapons parts during peacetime, bringing Japan's self-defense forces into greater partnership with the American military.

HEADLINE: Hanoi Journal;
A Vietnamese Uprising, to Keep Out High-Rises

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: HANOI, Vietnam

 BODY:
Battered by war, crumbling from poverty and neglect, this faded, tree-lined capital remains one of the last beautiful cities in Asia, a relic of French colonial elegance surrounded by the raucous new mega-cities of the region's economic boom.
Now Vietnam has begun to develop, and just a year or two ago local planners and foreign architects were voicing despair that Hanoi, with a population of more than two million, was about to go the way of Bangkok, Singapore, Jakarta and Shanghai -- bustling, new and increasingly indistinguishable. 
 High-rise developers had demolished the colonnaded shopping arcade by the edge of Hoan Kiem Lake, at the city's heart. They had begun to rip down the historic prison known to Americans as the Hanoi Hilton. And the drawing boards were filled with projects that threatened the narrow streets of its 1,000-year-old Ancient Quarter and the shaded villas of its French section.
But today those same projects have been scaled back or halted, and city officials are increasingly saying no to ambitious proposals that would make a lot of money very fast. They have established a Chief Architect's office and published a new urban plan, and they are directing high-rise developers toward the city's western district, where they have set virtually no limits on growth.
The planners and architects who watch over Hanoi now say this could be the first major city in the region to modernize without losing its character and its low-rise charm.
"We have a new policy," said Ha Van Que, the assistant to the city's Chief Architect. "We are trying to preserve our city and develop it at the same time."
This approach appears to be part of an urgent effort by the Government to control the potentially chaotic development it has unleashed in the 1990's with new market-oriented policies. The Government is working to disperse new industries around the country and to avoid the urban concentrations that have brought problems elsewhere in Asia.
"We think we're getting somewhere," said Lawrie Wilson, an Australian urban planner who is an adviser to the Chief Architect. "I'm quite optimistic that what is left remaining today of the character of the city will be conserved and enhanced."
Mr. Wilson said the question as Vietnam suddenly opened its economy to rapid development was: Is it possible to modernize without becoming Bangkok?
He called that city a case study in the ruinous effects of rapid, chaotic development, with its congestion and traffic jams, its pollution, its squatter colonies, its overburdened services and the loss of its character.
"There is no model where you can say, yes, it can be done," he said. "It hasn't been done."
But Hanoi has the advantage of starting 20 or 30 years late. It has been preserved from development by the hardships of war and poverty, and it has the opportunity now to learn from its neighbors.
"We want to avoid the mistakes of Bangkok and other cities in Southeast Asia," Mr. Que said. "They developed too quickly."
Hanoi also has the benefit of the strict planning and tight controls of the country's Communist Government. The word of Prime Minister Vo Van Kiet -- who appears from his speeches to be a dedicated urban conservationist -- carries the power of fiat.
"There are decrees that say the character of the Ancient Quarter and the French quarter must be preserved," Mr. Wilson said. "No other city has had that. In other cities it was just 'we must develop and the sky's the limit.' "
For a time, it was argued here that the graceful avenues of the French section were a vestige of colonialism that should be demolished, as happened in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. But the Vietnamese seem now to have embraced this heritage, taking Yangon, the still-undeveloped capital of Myanmar, formerly known as Burma, as a model of low-rise, colonial-style beauty.
Part of their motivation is economic, Mr. Que said. There is an understanding that tourism can be a big money-earner if Hanoi preserves its distinct character. But some conservationists say a more basic motive is also involved -- a sentimental attachment to a beautiful place.
The fight for the city's character has not yet been won, though. Widespread corruption and the quicksand of Vietnam's bureaucracy can swallow Government decrees.
And there remains a strong lobby for rapid, unfettered growth. There are many people here, after decades of lagging behind other nations, who want nothing more than to look like Bangkok.
"I don't like these ugly old houses," said Nguyen Thanh Thuy, a dressmaker who lives in the clamorous, winding lanes of the city's Ancient Quarter, where the streets are named for the artisans who once populated them, Shoe Street, Gold Street, Fan Street, Basket Street.
The Ancient Quarter is home to a fascinating form of architecture, low, narrow buildings called tube houses that have lengthened over decades or centuries as new generations have added to them. But they have become overcrowded and unsanitary and there is nothing many residents wish more than to knock the old dwellings down.
"I like beautiful tall, tall buildings," Miss Thuy said, taking a deep breath. "Tall, tall is beautiful, beautiful. The people who live here want to live in tall new buildings."
Development is taking a different path in Ho Chi Minh City -- as bustling now as during the wartime years when it was named Saigon. In that city, there is a sense that the battle for conservation was already lost in the 1960's, when the war economy fueled a frenzy of new construction.
But it is also a less fragile city than Hanoi, with broad thoroughfares that may be able to support the architectural power of high-rise construction. And planners there are working to avoid the congestion of Bangkok by directing new development to the suburbs.
In Hanoi, the first rounds went to the developers, who rushed in before the Government had a framework for assessing their dazzling proposals. Before anyone really understood what they were doing, they had knocked down the two-story shopping arcade by Hoan Kiem Lake and prepared to put up twin 20-story apartment towers -- 14 stories taller than any other building in the city.
"It's called progress," Peter Purcell, the project's Australian developer, said at the time.
But his towers will not now be built. The newly created City Architect's office stepped in, and Mr. Que said the project's design has now been limited to a five-story building by the side of the lake with an eight-story annex in the back "That's all," he said.
The arcade's colonnaded facade is to be restored.
"There is a learning curve going on," said Leigh Scott-Kemmins, a founding director of Friends of Hanoi, a nonprofit Australian-backed group that lobbies for architectural conservation.
"It was not until some dreadful mistakes were made, horrible things growing up out of the ground, that they started to panic," he said. "They kept talking about losing their culture -- not just the architecture but the soul of the city. There was a concern that they had fought long and hard for this place and they didn't want it to slip away before their eyes."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A scene in Hanoi, which stands as a graceful relic. The city fathers want the old capital to keep its character and its charm. Says one city architect, "We are trying to preserve our city and develop it at the same time. (Seth Mydans/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Slips on U.S. Stock Selloff And Doubts on German Rate Cut

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against most leading currencies yesterday, weakened by new uncertainty over the German interest-rate outlook, a selloff in the United States stock market and a surge in demand for Mexican pesos.
Traders said the volume of foreign-exchange dealings was thin ahead of a regularly scheduled meeting of the Bundesbank, the German central bank, thus exaggerating the movement of currency values. 
 In trading in New York late yesterday, the dollar fell to 1.5060 German marks, from 1.5089 Tuesday, and was lower against most other European currencies. The British pound rose to $1.5095, from $1.5077. The dollar traded at 108.20 Japanese yen, up slightly from 108.15 yen. .
"Everyone is waiting to see what the Bundesbank does," said Richard Vullo, vice president at the New York offices of Hypo Bank, a German bank.
Speculation has intensified in recent weeks that Germany's central bankers will have to ease interest rates to stimulate the country's anemic economy. A rate cut would diminish demand for marks and indirectly bolster the dollar's value. The expectation of a rate reduction has been an important underpinning in the dollar's recent strength.
But some currency traders were increasingly skeptical that the Bundesbank would ease rates today. They said Germany's central bankers were probably more worried about a large expansion in Germany's money supply. "There's no pressure for them to ease right away," Mr Vullo said. "They'd rather be cautious and wait."
Others said that it was only a matter of time before the Bundesbank cut rates, if not today than in the next few months.
A retreat in the American stock market after three days of gains also may have contributed to the dollar's weakness. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 70.09 points and most other market indexes fell.
Added pressure on the dollar came from Mexico, where demand for pesos surged on word the Government was issuing as much as $2.5 billion in new bonds in a debt refinancing managed by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The refinancing was seen as a strong sign of Mexico's recovery, and investors sold dollars and bought pesos to buy the new securities. It took 7.428 pesos to buy a dollar yesterday, down from 7.430 on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The drive to put cost limits on regulatory benefits isn't dead yet.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
REGULATORY reform, shorthand for the Republican push to require regulators to take account of economic costs as well as benefits in rule-making, crashed and burned in the Senate last summer. But there is a glimmer of hope that a coalition of Republicans and moderate Democrats can fashion a compromise -- reform lite, if you will -- before it is hopelessly mired in election year politicking.
Much depends on the willingness of Democrats to sacrifice what has become a dandy partisan issue. Even more turns on the resourcefulness of Bob Dole, the Senate majority leader and the Republican choice to challenge President Clinton, who has very good reasons at the moment to demonstrate his ideological flexibility. 
 What a difference a year makes. With conservative Republicans riding high, Mr. Dole led the charge for sweeping changes that would have required Federal agencies to show that the benefits of all regulations exceeded the costs.
As an abstraction the concept is unassailable. By definition, rules that exact costs in excess of benefits are bad rules. Besides, Robert Stavins, an economist at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, notes that even where the law prohibits consideration of costs in pursuit of mandated goals -- the Clean Air Act, for example -- regulators never truly ignored them. "Surely it would be better," he argues, "to consider costs in the front room rather than the back room."
But some benefits are very difficult to quantify. It is hard to say, for example, how much it is worth to make post offices accessible to wheelchairs, or how much Americans would lose if pollutants from distant power plants reduced visibility on the rim of the Grand Canyon to 20 miles from 100 miles. Relying on the courts as the arbiter would, at very least, be cumbersome. "It would amount to a full employment act for regulatory lawyers," says Robert Hahn, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute.
Democrats charged that the Dole bill was an invitation to nullify a quarter-century of health, safety and environmental rules and to tie up new regulatory initiatives indefinitely. They frightened enough fence-sitting senators to make it impossible to stop a filibuster, effectively killing the bill before Mr. Clinton got to veto it. Indeed, polls suggest that the bill was a disaster for the Republicans in general and Bob Dole in particular, tarring them as lackeys of business interests.
But regulatory change is not quite dead. For one thing, policy wonks from both parties are still beating the drums for it. Last week, a who's who of mainstream economists ranging from the Nobel laureate Kenneth J. Arrow to Richard L. Schmalensee of M.I.T., who was an adviser on regulation to President George Bush, published a statement in Science magazine defending the role of cost-benefit analysis in Government rule-making. And today, the Center for Innovation and the Environment, a nonpartisan arm of the influential Democratic Leadership Council, plans to call for a "second generation of environmental protection" -- one that faces up to the costs of greening America.
More important, the politics of regulation remains volatile. Mr. Dole needs to find a way back to the middle if he is to win the support of the mineral water and granola crowd in the suburbs. Meanwhile, centrist Democrats, including Senator Carl Levin of Michigan, understand that last summer's triumphant rejection of change could become this summer's failure to save factory jobs in the swing states of the Midwest. He argues that for the moment, environmentalists have a chance to negotiate from a position of strength, compromising to "get the issue behind us."
Mr. Levin fashioned a kinder, gentler alternative to the Dole bill that would mandate cost-benefit analysis, yet give the executive branch considerable leeway to use other criteria in judging proposed rules. And while he notes that "it was unacceptable to business, environmental groups and the White House," the political risks of delay could still drive the parties to the bargaining table.
Mr. Stavins of Harvard, one of the signers of the Science magazine statement, would like to see a compromise that forces the agencies to weigh costs against benefits and explain themselves if, in the end, they choose to override the policy dictated by the numbers. That way, the political risks in ignoring costs would increase. At very least the public would learn whether it cost, say, 21 cents or $21,000 for each visit by a wheelchair-bound American to the post office.
What is most frustrating in this debate is that the stalemate serves hardly anyone's interest. Mr. Hahn argues that "we have the technical know-how" to refine rule-making, clarifying the facts undermining rational debate over issues ranging from asbestos to airline safety. Still lacking, apparently, is faith among competing interests that more information is better than less.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Mexico Set to Issue New 30-Year Bonds

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, April 17

 BODY:
Mexico said today that it was issuing up to $2.5 billion of new bonds that it would swap for United States-backed Brady bonds in a sign that the country's status had improved in financial markets.
The news immediately sent Mexican bond prices and the peso higher as investors scrambled to get in position to buy the new securities. 
 Mexico plans to issue between $1 billion and $2.5 billion worth of the 30-year dollar-denominated bonds, said Goldman, Sachs & Company, the lead manager of the offer.
The offer, which expires on April 30 unless Mexico extends it, is meant to let Mexico achieve longer terms and lower interest rates on its debt, as well as eliminate a need to keep collateral on hand to repay the loans.
"This operation emphasizes that the perception of Mexico in the international markets is changing," said Jose Luis Gomez Pimienta, director of the Mexico Fund Inc., an investment group.
Standard & Poor's gave the new bonds a junk-bond rating of BB, the same currently assigned to the Brady bonds.
The Brady bonds lost much of their value in late 1994 and early 1995, in large part because of Mexico's economic crisis.
The Brady bonds are named for the former Treasury Secretary, Nicholas F. Brady, who developed a plan to overhaul Latin American debt. Repayment of the principal on Brady bonds is backed by United States Treasury bonds owned by the issuing country and held by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Coca-Cola's First-Quarter Net Rose 12% on 9% Revenue Gain

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, April 17

 BODY:
The Coca-Cola Company reported a 12 percent increase in first-quarter earnings today, but sluggish sales increases in Latin America and Africa continued to be a drag on its international profits.
The company also said that it had repurchased about four million shares during the quarter and that shareholders had approved a 2-for-1 stock split. 
The world's largest soft drink company said net income rose to $713 million, or 57 cents a share, from $638 million, or 50 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1995. The latest earnings matched the average forecast of 15 analysts polled by Zacks Investment Research.
Revenue rose 9 percent, to $4.19 billion from $3.85 billion.
Coca-Cola's share price fell $1.25, to $80.125, in trading today on the New York Stock Exchange.
Total beverage shipments rose 7 percent in the first quarter. The size of the increase met expectations and was smaller than the 9 percent gain in last year's first quarter.
Sales in Latin America, one of the company's biggest markets, rose only 2 percent, below Coca-Cola's forecast of an increase of between 3 percent and 4 percent and well below the 16 percent increase of a year earlier. Growth was hurt by sagging economies in some of the region's biggest markets.
In Mexico, the world's second-largest consumer of soft drinks, Coca-Cola's case sales fell 2 percent.
Results should improve by the second half of the year as Mexico, as well as Argentina, pulls out of recession and as the company continues to increase growth in developed countries, analysts said.
Overall sales growth in the first quarter was fueled by business in the United States, the world's largest soft drink consumer, where unit sales rose 8 percent. Sales growth in Europe, the Middle East and Asia exceeded levels a year earlier, with some countries, including China and India, registering gains of more than 40 percent.
In Africa, though, sales rose only 1 percent, compared with a 12 percent gain a year earlier. The company had forecast sales growth of 1 percent.
Coca-Cola noted that the dollar had risen 7 percent against some key foreign currencies over the last 12 months. As the dollar strengthens, sales denominated in other currencies yield fewer dollars.
The company said it lost $7 million from its holdings in bottlers in the quarter, compared with profit of $24 million a year earlier.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Drop On Treasuries For a 2d Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities dropped for a second straight day yesterday, despite a Government report that housing starts fell 3.9 percent last month. Much like the weak manufacturing report earlier this week, it failed to ease investor concern that the economy might be poised for an inflationary rebound.
The 30-year bond fell 7/32, to a price of 89 24/32 to yield 6.81 percent, up from 6.79 percent on Tuesday. 
 Traders report that the market is requiring more assurances that the economy will not rebound too strongly. Even though oil and commodity prices have subsided somewhat, investors would like to see further declines before buying. The Commodity Research Bureau index, after falling more than a point yesterday on top of the huge three-point slide on Tuesday, closed up 0.60 point, at 256.44.
According to the Commerce Department, housing starts ran last month at an annualized pace of 1.447 million homes, less than the 1.467 million expected by economists polled by Bloomberg Business News.
The issue of securities supply also raised market concerns as the Treasury Department announced the details of its April 23 and 24 sales of new two- and five-year notes, raising the volume of each maturity by $500 million, to $18.75 billion and $12.5 billion, respectively. In when-issued trading ahead of the sales, the two-year issue was being offered at a price to yield 5.99 percent and the five-year at a price to yield 6.34 percent.
Kenneth J. Kaplan, portfolio manager, at Spare, Kaplan, Bischel & Associates, a San Francisco-based money management firm, attributed the current weakness in the bond market to a widespread overoptimism that inflation was under control and the Fed would cut interest rates.
"There is still a lot of speculation in the bond market," Mr. Kaplan said, "but now for the first time people are talking about a tightening. So there is a psychological change taking part in the market."
Mr. Kaplan does not foresee a return to the double-digit inflation of the late 70's and early 80's, "but it will be higher than it has been over the last couple of years," he said.
"Currently anything that knocks the market off its optimistic views is punished with a disproportionate negative reaction," Mr. Kaplan said. "We think rates could get above 7 percent, but basically you still have to feel that bonds are more attractive today than they were at the beginning of the year."
Josh Stiles, senior bond strategist at IDEA, a British financial consulting firm, said the big issue over the next week would be "the absorption of the two- and five-year notes and one-year bills, with dealers well aware the May quarterly refunding will quickly follow."
"This will happen in an environment where concerns have grown that the Fed may tighten by autumn despite an election year," he said. The Fed, he recalled, tightened aggressively during the 1988 campaign.
Mr. Stiles said the rise in long-term interest rates would act as a natural brake on growth, but with a considerable lag.
A Federal Reserve governor, Lawrence B. Lindsey, speaking to members of the National Association of Business Economists in Washington, said yesterday that he saw slow-to-moderate growth without accelerating inflation. His views contrast with many in the market, who expect the economy to overheat and produce inflation.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Economies of Europe Eroding Amid Gains Elsewhere

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 17

 BODY:
While the United States remains on a path of stable if moderate growth, the condition of the big West European economies has significantly deteriorated over the last six months. And Japan is showing increasing signs of strength, the International Monetary Fund reported today.
Developing nations continue to post growth rates about three times as high as industrial nations, with the strongest growth still in Asia, the fund said in its twice-yearly assessment of the world's economies. 
 Inflation remains low in the industrial world, and is falling rapidly in the third world, the I.M.F. said. And with global financial markets exerting strong discipline, nations everywhere are adopting stricter policies to reduce budget deficits.
Indeed, although its forecasts for the full year reflect the difficulties now being encountered by European nations in particular, the I.M.F. said that by the second half of this year, growth in many nations should begin accelerating.
"We believe the slowdown is largely behind us and that a pickup in the rate of economic expansion should become visible going forward," Michael Mussa, the fund's director of economic research, said at a news conference here.
The report was issued at the start of a weeklong meeting of the I.M.F. and the World Bank, at which representatives of most nations will discuss economic and development issues.
The fund predicted that the American economy would grow 1.8 percent this year, slightly below the consensus of around 2 percent. It said Japan would grow 2.7 percent, three times its rate last year. Among other major trading partners of the United States, Mexico is forecast to grow 3 percent after shrinking 6.9 percent last year, and Canada is projected to grow 1.9 percent, down slightly from last year.
The health of other economies is important to the United States because weakness among big trading partners brings a decline in American exports. Mexico's economic woes last year led to a big deficit for the United States in its trade with Mexico. A revival in Japan is good news for American exports, although the renewed strength of the dollar against the yen is likely to diminish the price competitiveness of American goods in Japan.
The most severe downturn in outlook among the biggest economies was in Germany, Europe's industrial powerhouse and the linchpin of efforts to forge a single European currency and monetary policy. The fund cut its estimate of German growth this year to 1 percent, down from its estimate last October of 2.9 percent growth for 1996.
Germany's currency is strong, relative to those of some other European nations. And upward pressure on wages has hurt the investment climate in Germany, and consumer confidence has sagged as unemployment has risen above 11 percent.
France, which is being battered by many of the same forces afflicting Germany, will grow only 1.3 percent this year, the fund said. In October, it was predicting 1996 growth of 2.7 percent. For the 15-member European Union as a whole, the I.M.F. projected that 1996 growth would be 1.8 percent, down from its projection in October of 2.8 percent.
The fund put particular weight in its analysis on attempts by governments to keep their deficits under control. "Budgetary problems are a threat to durable and satisfactory growth performance in almost all industrial nations," it said. "The risk of slippages in consolidation efforts is all the more disquieting since the fiscal burden of public health and pension systems as presently structured is projected to increase considerably throughout most of the industrial world in the coming decades."

HEADLINE: Housing Construction At Slower Pace in March

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 17

 BODY:
Housing construction slowed in March, partly because of a sharp drop in new apartments, as rising mortgage rates threatened to weaken the housing market in coming months.
"Builders are continuing to build," said David Lereah, an economist at the Mortgage Builders Association. "But I get nervous going forward. Eventually, interest rates will win this war" if they continue to rise and price buyers out of the market. 
 So far, however, higher mortgage rates have not yet depressed the housing market seriously. Although now at a 10-month high, rates are still at relatively affordable levels. That has resulted in healthy sales of new and existing homes recently.
David Berson, an economist with the Federal National Mortgage Association, said an expanding economy, including modest job and income growth, was offsetting some of the impact of higher financing costs.
Some analysts also say fears of even higher rates are driving some buyers into the housing market.
Housing starts fell 3.9 percent in March, to a seasonally adjusted 1.45 million annual rate, the Commerce Department reported today. It was the steepest decline since starts fell 6.2 percent a year earlier.
But activity was mixed regionally, rising in the Northeast and Midwest while falling in the South and West.
Single-family starts, which are interest-sensitive and represent about 80 percent of residential building activity, slipped 1.4 percent, to a 1.16 million rate. But construction of apartments and condominiums, an often volatile category not as subject to interest-rate changes, plunged 12.7 percent, to a 288,000 rate.
Despite the overall decline, housing starts remained above 1.4 million for a fifth straight month. And the February rate was even stronger than initially estimated -- 1.51 million rather than 1.49 million.
Joe Blalock, an economist at America's Community Bankers, said the housing starts rate in the first quarter -- "typically not one of the stronger quarters" -- averaged 1.47 million, higher than the 1.46 million single-family homes and apartments built in 1994. Starts dipped to 1.35 million last year.
But many analysts believe the housing market is reaching a plateau.
Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 7.68 percent in March, up from 7.17 percent in February and 7.03 percent in January. They have continued to climb and averaged 8.05 percent last week, highest since 8.27 percent in May 1995. The monthly payment on a $100,000 mortgage with a 7 percent interest rate is $665, while the payment on the same loan with a 8 percent rate is $734 -- an increase of $69.
"I don't think rates will keep going up," Fannie Mae's Mr. Berson said. "But on the other hand, I don't think the strong housing market will continue. It will get modestly weaker. There's not much pent-up demand left" as the economy enters its sixth year of expansion.
Analysts said the number of applications for building permits also suggested new construction might be leveling off. They inched up a barely perceptible one-tenth of 1 percent, to a 1.41 million rate.
Regionally, housing starts shot up 10.2 percent in the Northeast to a 140,000 rate, highest since 169,000 in November 1994. Cheryl Katz, an economist at Merrill Lynch & Company, said the surge most likely was a rebound from weather-depressed levels in December and January.
Starts rose 3.5 percent in the Midwest, to 322,000. But they sank 16.1 percent in the West, to a 349,000 rate, the biggest drop since falling 20.7 percent in March 1995. And they slipped 2.3 percent in the South, to 636,000.

HEADLINE: And They All Came Tumbling Down;
Short-Seller Levels a Wall St. Institution

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES 

 BODY:
For years, the promoters of small public companies have complained about "bear raids" by short-sellers, investors who strive to profit from declining stock prices. But despite tales of bears who go even further, illegally conspiring to drive prices down, actual evidence of such misbehavior has been scarce.
That may be about to change. According to a letter and an affidavit filed with a bankruptcy judge in Manhattan, Federal prosecutors are conducting a criminal investigation of whether illegal short-selling on a huge scale caused the collapse of two Wall Street firms last year. The Securities and Exchange Commission and the enforcement unit of the National Association of Securities Dealers are also examining whether the short-selling violated market rules, the documents submitted to the court show. 
 These inquiries all focus on the collapse in February 1995 of Hanover Sterling & Company, a penny-stock firm, and the consequent failure of the Adler, Coleman Clearing Corporation, a firm that guaranteed and processed trades for Hanover and 41 other small retail brokers. The assets of Adler, Coleman are now being liquidated in bankruptcy court.
Firms like Hanover Sterling that deal in inexpensive and typically unseasoned securities known as penny stocks collapse with dreary regularity. The unexpected collapse of Adler, Coleman, however, strained the Wall Street safety net: Adler is the first major clearing firm to fail in the 25-year history of the Securities Investor Protection Corporation, the industry-financed agency that insures brokerage customer accounts. With some 66,000 accounts affected, it is one of the largest liquidation cases the SIPC has ever faced, and the fund's potential losses run as high as $40 million.
The case is crucial to the small but important community of professional short-sellers. Though almost always controversial, many of these investors buttress their skeptical attitude with thorough research; their contrary trades often provide a check on the hyperbole and euphoria of the marketplace.
Only a few small brokerage firms in the short-selling community are involved in the Adler case. Those short-sellers have denied any misbehavior and have, in fact, gone into bankruptcy court to accuse the trustee unwinding the mess for SIPC -- Edwin Mishkin, a partner in the law firm of Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton -- of improperly shifting SIPC's losses onto their backs. If their challenge fails, the risks of being contrarian may rise. And if any of them are later found to have committed a crime, the pressure to curb all short selling may intensify.
Luckily for the future law students who will have to study this complicated case in years to come, the players in the Adler, Coleman bankruptcy are fighting over these critical issues with all the decorum of the folks who organized the gunfight at the O.K. Corral.
In a deposition, John Fiero, owner of Fiero Brothers Inc., one of the short-sellers challenging the trustee, recalled threats he said he had received from the officers of Hanover before it collapsed. John T. Moran, who pleaded guilty in 1991 to securities fraud but who was nevertheless an adviser to Hanover in its final days, testified that he was offered a bribe to withhold his testimony from Mr. Mishkin. And, Mr. Mishkin said, the officers of Adler, Coleman had received anonymous warnings against cooperating with his efforts to liquidate the firm's estate.
For their part, in legal complaints filed in the bankruptcy case, the short-sellers have accused Mr. Mishkin of securities fraud for his handling of the estate. And Mr. Mishkin has responded with a blistering counterclaim that accuses the short-sellers of using "unlawful and criminal acts of extortion, economic coercion, threats of physical violence and destruction of business" and various other means to deliberately kill Hanover and Adler.
The criminal investigation detailed in the court documents was discussed this week by lawyers at a hearing before the bankruptcy judge, James L. Garrity Jr., who is handling the Adler case. At the hearing, lawyers for short-sellers had asked the judge to order that information gathered in the bankruptcy case not be shared with Federal investigators or market regulators. After the judge balked, they withdrew the request.
Eric Hershmann, a lawyer for Fiero Brothers, said yesterday that he had had no direct contact with law enforcement. He said, however, that he was convinced that there was a continuing investigation of the events that had caused the collapse of Hanover Sterling. "Is Fiero probably one of the parties being investigated? Yes," he said. "Do I think there are numerous others? Yes."
But, he said, "our client has done nothing whatsoever wrong to warrant those investigations."
The seeds of the case were planted late in 1994, when prices were soaring for Hanover's "house stocks," shares of the flimsy companies the firm aggressively marketed to retail customers. Regulators have already charged that at least one of the stocks -- All-Pro Products Inc., founded by Lawrence Taylor, the former football star -- was illegally manipulated by Hanover. Then the bears started to sell those shares short in huge amounts.
Anyone who thinks a stock is headed for a fall can bet on that prospect by selling short. To legally effect a short sale, an investor arranges to borrow stock from a securities firm and sells it in hopes that the price will fall substantially before he has to "cover his position" -- that is, buy shares to replace those he borrowed. If he bets correctly, his profit will be the difference between the price he sold the shares for and the amount he spent to cover.
But the stock may rise in price or the shares may be difficult to find in the market when it is time to cover. If the short-seller cannot make good on his promise to return the shares he borrowed, the person owed the shares conducts what is called a "buy-in," which entails buying the shares elsewhere and charging the short-seller whatever that costs.
As the short sales grew on its house stocks, Hanover did not drop the price it was willing to pay for the shares on the open market -- perhaps because that would have reduced the value of its own inventory of those stocks and put it out of business. Instead, it kept buying until its capital was exhausted.
When Hanover failed, its customer accounts became the obligation of Adler, Coleman, one of the more venerable clearing firms on the Street.
The world of clearing firms is a mystery to most investors. Indeed, the largest securities firms clear for themselves and their customers are not even aware of how crucial clearing brokers are to the machinery of the market. A clearing broker, sometimes called "a broker's broker," guarantees the trades entered into by its client firms, who are called "introducing brokers." If an introducing broker cannot immediately meet its obligations, its clearing firm must do so.
Any Wall Street firm not large enough to clear for itself must contract with a clearing broker to back its trades; the cash balances the introducing broker must deposit as security with the clearing firm will vary with the volume and riskiness of the introducing broker's trades. If those trades become too risky, the clearing broker can demand a bigger deposit or force the firm to take its business elsewhere.
Whether by simple mismanagement or by deliberate design -- the issue is one now being litigated in bankruptcy court -- Adler did not push Hanover out the door in time. When Hanover failed, Adler was on the hook for trades that not only exceeded Hanover's cash deposit but that also exceeded Adler's own resources. On Feb. 27, 1995, Adler was forced into bankruptcy.
At that moment, the 41 other brokerage firms that had hired Adler to clear their trades were suddenly unable to conduct business. An important strand in the safety net was near the breaking point.
Behind the phalanx of clearing brokers is a sort of "broker of last resort": the National Securities Clearing Corporation, owned equally by the New York Stock Exchange, the American Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq stock market. The N.S.C.C. is the ultimate guarantor of stock trades, and it was suddenly left with $1.6 billion in trades that Adler's introducing brokers could not complete.
The N.S.C.C. froze all those trading accounts until other clearing firms were found that were willing to take them on. But what of the Hanover accounts? Ultimately they will be the responsibility of the last component of the Wall Street safety net: the SIPC, which up to certain limits protects retail customers from the loss of cash or securities when their brokerage firm fails.
In part because Mr. Mishkin, the SIPC trustee, had serious doubts about the validity of some trades done during Hanover's death throes, the Hanover accounts remained frozen.
At the same time, Mr. Mishkin saw that the Adler estate had one unusual asset: virtually the entire available supply of all those flimsy stocks Hanover had promoted and bought so heavily from short-sellers.
With all those shares tied up in frozen accounts, Mr. Mishkin turned the tables on the short-sellers by demanding that they cover their short sales to Hanover -- which they could only do by buying the shares in Adler's accounts at prices he would dictate. Mr. Mishkin set those prices at roughly the same levels that Hanover had paid when it bought the shares from the short sellers before the firm collapsed.
Thus, he deprived the bears of their profits and sent them stalking into court to argue that Mr. Mishkin had taken advantage of an illegal "corner on the market" to gouge the short-sellers. Mr. Mishkin insists his buy-in was legal and that it was the bears' massive short-selling that was illegal.
The rules that govern short sales are few and flexible. Except for smaller Nasdaq stocks, short sales can be made only after an uptick in prices. And any broker who sells short must first make an "affirmative determination" that he will be able to find and buy the shares he needs to cover his short sale. Clearing firms maintain lists of securities that are "hard to borrow," to guide short-sellers in assessing their risks -- and all of the Hanover securities were on those lists.
But brokerage firms are exempt from the affirmative determination rule provided they are engaged in "bona fide market making," as many of the short-selling firms contended they were. Mr. Mishkin argues that the shorts had signed up as market-makers in the Hanover stocks only to sell short more abundantly, not to genuinely make a market in the shares.
But the line between abusive short sales and bona fide market making is clearly not well defined.
Only a handful of criminal cases have cited illegal short-selling, according to securities lawyers, and regulatory cases are only slightly more common.
Judge Garrity will ultimately decide whether the trustee's buy-in was legal. If he upholds the short-sellers, SIPC will face much larger losses in the Adler case. If he backs Mr. Mishkin, short-sellers everywhere will face the new risk of an Adler-style buy-in that would wipe out their profits. And if investigators find widespread misbehavior by the bears in the Adler case, there could be new pressure to tighten the rules on short-selling.
But more important, the Adler case challenges the widespread Wall Street belief that the battles between obscure short-sellers and third-rate penny-stock hustlers do not matter much to the rest of the market because they only kill each other.
The death of Adler, Coleman showed that sometimes important components of the Wall Street safety net can become caught in the crossfire.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Edwin Mishkin, at center, is in midst of a bankruptcy battle that is shedding light on the role of short sellers. He is with his lawyers, Mitchell A. Lowenthal, left, and Thomas J. Moloney. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)
 
Chart: "The Cascade Effect"
 When a penny-stock promoter failed in February 1995, the resulting mess unexpectedly claimed its clearing agent as well, leaving stock speculators and a bankruptcy trustee at war over the wreckage, and the blame.
 
1. THE BEAR RAID
 
What Happened: Bearish speculators sold short a flood of shares in penny stocks promoted by Hanover Sterling ("house" stocks).
 
The Bears Say: The trades were legal, made for customers or in the course of legitimate market making.
 
The Trustee Says: The trades were part of an illegal conspiracy; the bears' "market making" was a sham.
 
2. THE BROKER COLLAPSED
 
What Happened: Hanover exhausted its capital buying house stocks in a losing effort to prop up prices.
 
The Bears Say: Hanover was illegally trying to rig the market.
 
The Trustee Says: The bears blackmailed Hanover and then pushed it over the brink anyway, hoping to profit when prices of the house stocks crashed as a result.
 
3. THE CLEARING AGENT COLLAPSED
 
What Happened: Adler, Coleman, which cleared and guaranteed Hanover's trades, could not fulfill its obligations. 12,000 Hanover accounts are among 66,000 frozen by the bankruptcy.
 
The Bears Say: Adler, Coleman took part in Hanover's market rigging.
 
The Trustee Says: The same illegal short sales that swamped Hanover overwhelmed Adler too.
 
4. DAMAGE CONTROL
 
What Happened: The trustee for the Securities Investor Protection Corporation, which inherited the mess, demanded delivery of the shares sold short, without unfreezing the accounts that contain almost all those shares.
 
The Bears Say: The trustee is trying to use an illegal "corner" on the market to benefit SIPC at their expense.
 
The Trustee Says: The bears put themselves on the hook by trying to profit from the illegal short sales. (Patrick J. Lyons/The New York Times)
