HEADLINE: Stavros Niarchos, Greek Shipping Magnate And the Archrival of Onassis, Is Dead at 86

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
Stavros S. Niarchos, the shadowy Greek shipping magnate who spent much of his life battling his archrival Aristotle Onassis for supremacy on the high seas, in conspicuous consumption and at the altar, died on Monday at a hospital in Zurich. He was 86.
Officials of Niarchos Ltd., the shipping company he built into an international behemoth that once operated more than 80 tankers, disclosed his death through its London office yesterday but gave no details. He was reported several weeks ago to have had a stroke. 
 Although he was known as a mystery man, there was little mystery in the way Stavros Spyros Niarchos built a personal fortune estimated at $4 billion.
Mr. Niarchos, whose name means "master of ships," was quite simply a master at seizing the moment and turning it to his advantage, especially if it involved the complex world of shipping. What others perceived as disaster, he recognized as opportunity, whether it be economic depression, war or a shortage -- or glut -- of oil.
The secret of his shipping success was deceptively simple: buy cheap and buy big.
Mr. Niarchos, who was conceived in Buffalo, N.Y., where his Greek-born parents had become naturalized American citizens, was born in Athens on July 3, 1909, three months after his parents had returned from the United States.
Growing up in the adjacent port city of Piraeus, he developed a lifelong love of the water, swimming frequently and sailing his first boat at the age of 9.
Although he earned a law degree from the University of Athens at age 20, his father's financial reversals forced him to seek a more immediately promising career; he joined a flour-milling operation operated by his maternal uncles. The business imported grain from Argentina, and seeking to keep costs down in the 1930's, Mr. Niarchos recognized that the family could save freight fees by operating its own ships.
At his urging, his uncles bought seven battered freighters at the Depression-level prices of $20,000 each, and the Niarchos fleet was born. He soon added to the holdings, always buying the largest ships available.
World War II proved a bonanza for him. He leased his ships to the Allies in 1941 and spent the rest of the war in the Greek Navy. When the war ended in 1945, Mr. Niarchos, who had become the assistant Greek naval attache in Washington, did not grieve over the loss of six of his ships to German bombs and submarine attacks, but took his $2 million in insurance proceeds and began buying up surplus Liberty and Victory cargo ships and T2 tankers that had been mass produced during the war.
To get around American restrictions on the sale of such ships to foreigners, Mr. Niarchos formed a company in which his American-born sister and some American friends owned a three-quarter interest. But after Mr. Niarchos compounded his audacity by leasing the ships to a Panamanian company to avoid American taxes, the Government sued and he agreed to pay a $12 million fine, give up some of the ships and have three supertankers built at American shipyards.
As usual, the settlement ended up to his advantage. It came as Mr. Niarchos, who had foreseen the postwar boom in trade, was beginning a shipbuilding spree. Not only did the three large tankers prove far more profitable than the smaller ships he had to surrender, but he also ended up commissioning others, each generally larger than the one before.
Mr. Niarchos was one of the first shipowners to grasp the economies of scale: that is, a ship that could carry twice as much oil at twice the fees did not cost twice as much to build or to operate.
But he was not the only one to understand the concept. So did another upstart Greek shipping magnate, Aristotle Socrates Onassis, and in the decade after the war the two began a rivalry that amounted to a global game of one-upmanship.
If Mr. Onassis built a 30,000-ton ship, Mr. Niarchos was sure to respond with one of 31,000 tons. The shipbuilding competition continued until 1956 when Mr. Niarchos launched the 47,750-ton Spyros Niarchos, then the largest tanker afloat.
And Mr. Niarchos, who became a hero in Greece by building the country's first shipyard after the war, found himself upstaged when Mr. Onassis became an even bigger hero in the jet age by creating Olympic Airways.
For Mr. Niarchos, who savored his title as the owner of the largest private tanker fleet, 1956 was to prove the high-water mark in his competition with Mr. Onassis. Curiously, his very success caused his setback. When the Suez crisis of 1956 closed the canal, created a huge new demand for tankers and doubled shipping rates, much of his own vast fleet was tied up in long-term contracts at the pre-crisis rates, while Mr. Onassis, who had largely been locked out of the market by Mr. Niarchos, was able to take advantage of the crisis and cash in on the higher rates.
But the Onassis advantage proved short-lived. Mr. Niarchos simply bullied his way out of the old contracts, arguing that conditions had changed.
By then the personal rivalry between the two men had extended beyond the world of commercial shipping. Mr. Onassis, for example, was clearly jealous at glowing magazine reports pointing out that Mr. Niarchos, who maintained numerous palatial homes around the world, preferred to run his business from the 190-foot Creole, invariably described as the world's largest and most beautiful sailing vessel.
The Onassis response was to commission the 325-foot Christina, a motorized vessel, to be sure, but one that became the cynosure of prying eyes, at least until Mr. Niarchos abandoned the Creole in favor of the motorized Atlantis, 50 feet longer than the Christina.
And when Mr. Niarchos bought the Aegean island of Spetsopoula and stocked it with rare plants and game, making it a hunting paradise where he entertained royalty, heads of state and members of the jet set, Mr. Onassis bought an island of his own, Skorios, six years later.
Mr. Niarchos's good sense of timing saved his fortune. He sold off most of his fleet of tankers before the bottom fell out of the industry in the 1970's. But he and Mr. Onassis were both bruised by the protracted downturn. In 1970 they even entered into a rare joint venture, to build an oil refinery in Greece.
Mr. Niarchos stayed in the business, but the fleet of Niarchos Ltd. whose offices are in London, is a mere shadow consisting of about eight oil tankers. His family had remained deeply involved in the business, including his three sons, who are expected to continue managing the fleet.
In their personal rivalry, when Mr. Onassis scored a social coup by marrying Tina Livanos, the daughter of the long-reigning Greek shipping czar Stavros Livanos, Mr. Niarchos, who had been married and divorced twice, responded by marrying the other Livanos daughter, Eugenie.
It was a rivalry Mr. Niarchos was destined to lose, but he had his moments. In 1965, for example, he divorced Eugenie and at the age of 56 married Charlotte Ford, the 24-year-old daughter of Henry Ford 2d, the American automobile industry leader. She gave birth to a child a few months later and they were divorced in 1967.
The next year Mr. Onassis played his matrimonial trump card by marrying Jacqueline Kennedy, the widow of the slain American President, John F. Kennedy, and widely regarded as the world's most admired woman.
Since the Greek Church had not recognized Mr. Niarchos's Mexican divorce, he blithely resumed his marriage to Eugenie. After she died of an overdose of sleeping pills in 1970, Mr. Niarchos obtained some consolation by marrying Mr. Onassis' former wife, Tina.
Her death in Paris in 1974, also from an overdose of sleeping pills, created something of a scandal when her daughter, Christina Onassis, demanded an autopsy with the implication that Mr. Niarchos may have had a hand in her death. The investigation cleared him.
The death of Mr. Onassis in 1975 left Mr. Niarchos without a rival to fuel his ambitions.
Although he invested huge sums in various industries, he seemed to spend more time spending his money in the last years of his life, savoring his art collections, for example, and cheering on his racehorses. He also gave some of his money away, in 1979 donating $5 million to New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center to help repay the cost of heart surgery performed over the years on more than 100 Greek children.
His survivors include two daughters, Maria and Elena Anne; three sons, Philip, Spyros and Constantine, and several grandchildren.

HEADLINE: States Are Arenas on Minimum Wage

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, April 17

 BODY:
At a time when both major political parties are trying to speak to people's fears about the economy, Democrats here and in other state capitals across the country are using proposals to increase state minimum wages to try to reclaim their mantle as the defender of working people.
In states like Minnesota and Nebraska, Republicans have been forced to go on the record opposing measures to increase state minimums, and in Connecticut today, the Democratic-controlled House voted in favor of an increase, putting Republicans in what can be a politically uncomfortable position of opposing a raise of 88 cents, to $5.15 from $4.27. 
 Connecticut's Legislature is one of at least 17 that have seen measures to increase the wage introduced this year. Labor unions have also pushed to place the issue on ballots in states like California and Missouri and in cities like New Orleans, Washington and Denver.
The measure here still faces opposition in the Republican-controlled Senate and from the Gov. John G. Rowland, a Republican, but Democrats consider the mere fact of a vote being taken as something of a victory. Democratic leaders here and across the nation call the issue a powerful cudgel to hammer Republicans as insensitive to the plight of the working poor. "That sort of 'let them eat cake indifference' to the real life of the working poor says an awful lot about a politician," said William E. Curry Jr., an adviser to President Clinton and former Democratic gubernatorial candidate here.
Republicans here dismissed the vote as a cynical effort aimed solely at the next election. "It's being done for only one reason, and I think it's important for people to understand why it's being raised now," said State Representative Chris DePino, the state Republican Party chairman. "It's an election year."
According to the state's Office of Legislative Research, 43 states, including Connecticut, have minimum wage laws, though only 10 are above the Federal standard of $4.25. Generally, states pass higher minimums citing higher costs of living.
In the remaining states, 25 have provisions that mirror the Federal standard. In the eight states with a minimum wage below the Federal minimum, the Federal standard pre-empts the state's, and the state law applies only to employees, like agricultural workers, who are not covered by the Federal provision.
To some extent, the debate in state legislatures involves the same arguments that are heard in Washington. Generally, Democrats argue that a higher minimum will improve workers' standard of living, while Republicans maintain that it will cost jobs.
But the move to increase the minimum has gained momentum in recent years as new research has broken the view held by many economists that the raise would lead employers to hire fewer people.
Although some economists still hold that a nationwide increase of 75 cents -- President Clinton has proposed a 90-cent rise -- would cost 60,000 jobs, others dispute these findings. Last year, Robert M. Solow, a Nobel Laureate in economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said, "The evidence of job loss is weak, and the fact that the evidence is weak suggests that the impact on jobs is small."
In state legislatures, the debate takes on a slightly different focus. Here in Connecticut, lawmakers today were not so much worried about losing manufacturing jobs to cheaper competition abroad but about preventing workers in places like 7-Elevens and fast-food restaurants from losing their jobs. They also expressed fears that an increase in Connecticut would mark the state as a place that is not friendly to business.
State Representative Robert Ward, the Republican minority leader, remarked on Tuesday, "Executives aren't going to want to go to a state where they see an activist General Assembly that tells them how to run their businesses."
But State Representative David Pudlin, a top House Democrat, dismissed such concerns, asserting that more money in people's pockets meant that more people would be spending more money. "It is wrong to say that out of affection for poor people you have to oppose the bill," he said today.
In a preliminary vote, largely along party lines, the higher state minimum for Connecticut was backed by a vote of 85 to 62. Final passage is required for the measure to reach the State Senate.
Under the measure, the minimum wage would be increased 50 cents in October and another 38 cents in October 1997, to $5.15 from $4.27.
New Jersey's minimum wage was increased to $5.05 in 1992. On Monday, the New York State Assembly approved an increase to $5.05 from $4.25, though Gov. George E. Pataki has said he opposes raising the minimum wage at this time.
Yet the Connecticut measure faces extremely steep hurdles before it can become law. Gov. Rowland has said that he would veto any increase, and it is unlikely that Republicans in the Senate will even let it be considered there.
Still, for Democrats, simply getting a vote on the measure is considered something of a victory.
Sheldon Silver, the New York Assembly leader, said, "It clearly defines the Democrats as to where they are and what they stand for."
Before today's vote in Connecticut, State Representative Ronald S. San Angelo, a Republican, resisted entreaties by his Democratic colleague, Mr. Pudlin, to cross the aisle and support it.
"Not everyone has your courage," Mr. Pudlin said with a smile. "Some of us want to win the next election."
Already in Massachusetts, Senator John F. Kerry, a Democrat, has attacked his Republican challenger, Gov. William F. Weld for vetoing a one dollar increase in the minimum wage, a move that the Legislature overrode.
In Minnesota, where Gov. Arne Carlson, a Republican, vetoed a minimum wage bill last week, the State Senate sponsor, Kevin Chandler, remarked, "This is a softball right over the plate for the Democrats."

HEADLINE: World Bank Gets Bosnia Aid Role

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 17

 BODY:
As they embark in earnest on efforts to rebuild Bosnia, the United States and the European Union have handed over much of the job to the World Bank, an institution widely criticized for its slow-moving bureaucracy and its spotty record in similar programs.
The bank played a key role in raising the $1.2 billion pledged to the reconstruction program for the rest of this year at a conference this weekend in Brussels, including more than $200 million from the United States. 
 Established in 1944 under American leadership with its main purpose the reconstruction of a war-shattered Europe, the bank later became almost solely devoted to helping impoverished third-world countries.
Now the bank has taken on the monumental role in Bosnia and Herzegovina of overseeing what is expected to be $5.1 billion of reconstruction projects, drawing up plans to rebuild roads, railways, power plants, phone systems and the other basic components of a functioning economy.
With its long experience in the world's poorest countries, the World Bank was not a surprising choice. But in Bosnia, where war has left behind not just hatred but land mines, millions of refugees, billions of dollars in damage and a decimated economy, the job is by most measures bigger and more critical than any the bank has previously taken on.
"I've been saying for some time that development banks are to the new world order what security organizations were to the old," said Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers. "The World Bank's role in Bosnia surely illustrates that."
The bank, which is used to taking years to draw up plans and then waiting additional years for results, must make substantial, visible progress in Bosnia by the end of the year, when NATO troops are scheduled to leave, or the risk of resuming war will be high.
"The challenge is to move quickly, especially for organizations like the World Bank where time frames are usually longer," said William D. Montgomery, the State Department's special adviser for carrying out the Bosnian peace plan.
By its own standards, the bank has moved quickly in Bosnia. It had made the only comprehensive study of Bosnia's economic needs even before the peace accords were signed last fall. It committed $150 million of its own funds to emergency short-term measures at the end of January. It is helping to match money from donor nations, which usually comes with strings attached, to specific programs. And in recent weeks it gave the go-ahead to three long-term programs covering transportation, agriculture and sewers and water supply, taking only a few months for an approval process that normally takes a year.
James D. Wolfensohn, the former Wall Street investment banker who became the World Bank's president last June, said that while concerns about the bank's ability to move quickly were valid, he is trying to make the institution more nimble and responsive.
"The institution has a merited reputation for being long-term and bureaucratic, but along with my colleagues I'm trying to cut that down," Mr. Wolfensohn said. "There is a growing and significant consensus in this institution that we need to move more quickly, that we need to have greater accountability and that we need the capacity to do things in an urgent time frame. It's particularly important to do that in post-conflict situations, but we're also trying to do it generally."
The bank is already well into a similar program in the West Bank and Gaza, trying to create jobs and economic hope there as those regions adapt to autonomy from Israel. But it has had little success there, analysts and some members of the bank's staff said, especially in its goal of creating jobs. As a result, there are doubts about the bank's ability to succeed in Bosnia, where the scale of the problem is so much bigger.
"Put me down as skeptical," said Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, a Republican who has raised questions about whether the American contribution will be used effectively. "I'm not opposed to the World Bank. But the World Bank is not always very effective, and it certainly hasn't been very effective in the West Bank and Gaza multilateral effort."
But others, including senior bank officials, argue that because the former Yugoslavia had a relatively advanced economy and an educated work force, Bosnia has a more solid foundation for rapid development than exists in Gaza or the West Bank.
Another problem will be financing in Bosnia. While the United States, Western Europe, Japan, some Islamic countries and others have pledged enough to finance the programs that bank deems essential for this year, bank officials and diplomats said it is unclear whether the necessary money will be available in coming years.
For the World Bank and for other international organizations playing a big role in Bosnia, including the International Monetary Fund and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, there is another big issue at stake in Bosnia. Their efforts to bring stability and improved living standards to the region amount to the biggest test yet of their ability to play the broader role in the economic side of foreign policy that many governments, constrained by budget and political problems at home, want them to assume.
"The real test for the international community is whether it can respond effectively enough immediately, and in the medium term to get these countries moving on a self-sustaining basis," Mr. Wolfensohn said. "The bank is a front line player, but the bank cannot do it alone."
In Bosnia, as in the West Bank and Gaza, Mr. Wolfensohn said, the World Bank is adapting to new responsibilities and pressures. It has given its managers who are on the scene much greater authority and responsibility than ever before. Rather than reporting through a bureaucratic maze, they report to a single person at the bank's headquarters in Washington, who in turn reports to the board. Most important,they can make most decisions on their own, Mr. Wolfensohn said.
But even as he gives the bank's staff more freedom and authority, he is broadening its task. Instead of concentrating just on the big construction projects for which the bank is best known, he has been promoting development of programs intended to create jobs and contribute to social stability.
Mr. Wolfensohn said a primary goal of the reconstruction program in Bosnia should be to create as many as 300,000 jobs through a combination of public works programs and narrowly targeted projects to support small businesses and farmers, among others. In addition, he called for a program to provide cheap materials plus a stipend to people who are willing to rebuild their own homes.
The World Bank has come under increasing criticism in recent years. Critics contend that the bank has failed in its efforts to fight world poverty, and that many of its construction projects in developing nations are environmental disasters.
In Bosnia, the bank's reputation has clearly been put further at risk.
Even though he sees his institution as one of several key players, Mr. Wolfensohn admits, "It's there that people may blame the bank."

HEADLINE: F.T.C. to Fight Rite Aid-Revco Drugstore Merger

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER 

 BODY:
The Federal Trade Commission said yesterday that it would seek to block the Rite Aid Corporation's planned $1.8 billion takeover of Revco D.S. Inc., holding that the merger of the nation's biggest drugstore chains would raise drug prices for consumers.
The unanimous decision by the agency's commissioners means that Government lawyers will seek a Federal court injunction barring the merger, pending an administrative hearing on whether it violates antitrust laws. 
 Attorneys general of several states, including New York, also said they would sue to block the merger, citing its potential anticompetitive effects.
One analyst said that he saw scant opening for compromise given the tough positions taken by the F.T.C. and the state attorneys general.
"On the face of it, this has all the signs of a deal that is ready to blow up," Gary Vineberg, a retailing analyst with Merrill Lynch, said.
George S. Cary, the deputy director of the Federal agency's Bureau of Competition, said the agency believed that the merger would create a dominant market force in numerous areas because many stores of the chains serve overlapping markets.
As a result, the newly formed company may command enough market share to lift prices both to individuals and to discount drug plans that companies offer as employee benefits, the agency found.
"These two companies are head-to-head competitors, and they cover virtually the same territory," Mr. Cary said.
Rite Aid, based in Camp Hill, Pa., said it planned to extend its $27.50-a-share tender offer for Revco, which is due to expire tomorrow, through Wednesday. The company said it planned to use that additional time to negotiate for an out-of-court settlement with the agency, which generally waits until tender offers expire before seeking injunctions.
Officials of Revco, which is based in Twinsburg, Ohio, declined to comment. "These discussions are between the F.T.C. and the Rite Aid Corporation," said Tom Dingledy , a company spokesman.
In trading on the New York Stock Exchange, Rite Aid stock closed at $30.875 a share, down 12.5 cents. Revco stock closed at $26.75 a share, down 37.5 cents.
The proposed merger had come under intense scrutiny by the agency. Rite Aid, the nation's largest drugstore chain, operates 2,760 stores nationwide. Revco, the second largest, has 2,100.
The agency last sought to block an acquisition of this size in 1994 when B.A.T. Industries moved to buy the American Tobacco Company from American Brands Inc. for $1 billion. Under an agreement, B.A.T and its Brown & Williamson subsidiary agreed to sell several discount cigarette brands and a manufacturing plant. But the F.T.C recently rejected the company's attempt to sell those properties to Lorillard, a unit of the Loews Corporation.
Yesterday's action comes amid a swirl of investigations and lawsuits over the issue of drug pricing, with much of the focus on the growing role of prescription drug sales to group plans.
The F.T.C, for example, is investigating whether drug makers are selling drugs at preferred prices to health maintenance organizations and other big buyers. Discount chains like Rite Aid have filed lawsuits against drug manufacturers, making similar allegations. Meanwhile, Merck-Medco Managed Care Inc., a unit of Merck & Company, filed suit in February, accusing Rite Aid and other pharmacies of antitrust violations in Maryland. Rite Aid has denied the allegations.
Keith Shugarman, a lawyer in Washington who specializes in antitrust matters, said that he was not surprised by the agency's decision that the proposed merger between Rite Aid and Revco would have an anticompetitive effect.
"The F.T.C seems to have the law, the economics, the evidence and the politics all in their favor and things don't usually line up so neatly," Mr. Shugarman said.
Mr. Cary, the regulator, said that in some cities, like Cleveland and Erie, Pa., the largest competitor to a combined Rite Aid and Revco would be half its size.
Rite Aid has had its share of troubles with the F.T.C of late. After the agency challenged a 1994 acquisition, Rite Aid, as part of a consent agreement, said it would shed certain assets. But in February, the agency appointed a trustee to oversee the company's sale of pharmacy assets in several stores it owned in Maine and New Hampshire after finding that Rite Aid had failed to meet its deadline.

HEADLINE: REPUBLICANS TOLD TO BRACE FOR VOTE ON MINIMUM WAGE

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 17

 BODY:
The wall of Republican opposition to raising the minimum wage cracked today when Speaker Newt Gingrich told House Republicans that they should prepare themselves to face a vote on the issue -- a vote that would almost surely lead to an increase.
In both the House and the Senate, lawmakers of both parties agree that an increase will pass if there is a vote on the proposal. Though the issue came to a boil in the Senate this week when Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, blocked a vote, the rules and leadership in the House had seemed to be the most serious obstacles on Capitol Hill. 
 Mr. Gingrich spoke at a closed-door caucus this morning. According to several lawmakers present, he said he expected the Senate to vote on the minimum wage issue and pass an increase. When that happens, the Speaker reportedly said, the House can no longer duck it, and many members will vote for a raise.
Mr. Gingrich said that when the issue was last brought up, in 1989, only 37 Representatives opposed it. All but two were Republicans.
His comments were precipitated by defections yesterday and today of 20 House Republicans, who introduced a bill to raise the current Federal hourly minimum wage from $4.25 to $5.25 over 15 months. That is 10 cents more per hour than President Clinton and Congressional Democrats have proposed.
A high Administration official said he was "virtually certain" Mr. Clinton would agree to the higher figure.
After the caucus meeting today, Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, the fourth-ranking House Republican, said the leadership could not thwart a determined majority. "There appears to be an awful lot of support, even though it is horrible economic policy," Mr. Boehner said. He contends that an increase would cost jobs.
Mr. Gingrich's caucus remarks came after discussions on Tuesday with Mr. Dole, the presumptive Republican Presidential nominee. Senator Dole said today that he and Mr. Gingrich had discussed the issue, and that he was studying it and seeking advice. But he added that he had not told the Speaker that the Senate would vote on the issue.
On Tuesday, Mr. Dole angrily pulled an immigration bill from the Senate floor to prevent Democrats from offering an amendment to raise the minimum wage.
Other Senate Republicans, however, seemed to think a vote was inevitable. They spoke scornfully of Democratic efforts to use the wage issue as a means to embarrass Mr. Dole's Presidential campaign, but many consider the issue a loser, for him and for themselves, and want to get it over with.
"You can't just leave it at $4.25," said Senator Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming. Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum of Kansas agreed. "Be realistic," she said. "It would carry here."
They also acknowledge that Democrats can keep on pressing the issue, as Republicans did on their causes in years past. "We sort of wrote the book, and now they are reading it," said Senator Daniel R. Coats of Indiana.
Still, the lack of a Republican consensus in the Senate was clear. Senator John McCain of Arizona said: "Some people want to compromise. Some people want to go ahead and have a vote. Some people want to keep on stalling. There is no cohesion."
Another Senator, insisting on anonymity, said, "It's ring around the rosy."
Democrats used the developments in the House to press Mr. Dole for action. Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, the chief sponsor of the increase, said: "Opposition to the minimum wage is clearly dwindling in both the Senate and the House. The case for a fair increase is gaining strength every day. I don't know why the majority leader would climb on a sinking ship."
Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich joined the fray, saying: "Senator Dole has it in his power to bring this to a vote and get this done in the Senate. I don't believe he wants to be seen any longer blocking a modest increase in the minimum wage."
Mr. Dole said tonight, in an interview on the Public Broadcasting Service program "NewsHour With Jim Lehrer," that he was considering legislation that would combine a minimum wage increase with some other legislative proposal that Republicans liked but Democrats disliked. But he said that while there were strong economic arguments against a higher minimum wage, "you can't explain it," and an increase is very popular politically.
Asked later at a news conference to explain what other legislation he might add to a bill raising the minimum wage and whether he would suggest a lesser increase, Mr. Dole said, "We are looking at some options, may or may not pursue them." Then he added, "It won't happen this week."
Most of the 20 House Republicans who announced their bill today are from the Northeast.
One of seven New Yorkers in the group, Representative Jack Quinn of Buffalo, said: "People who work a 40-hour week ought to make a wage they can live on. The minimum wage hasn't been increased in seven years. Even welfare pays much more. We must correct this so people are not forced to choose between work and supporting their families."
Another upstate New Yorker, Representative Amo Houghton of Corning, said: "This is not a complicated issue. It should not be a partisan issue. It's timely. It's right and I think we should do it."
Representative Rick A. Lazio, a Suffolk County Republican, stressed the argument that inflation has cut the value of the minimum wage. If it is not changed, he said, "the real value of the minimum wage will be at a 40-year low by next January."
Ten years ago, the minimum wage was $3.35 an hour. In today's dollars, that would be $4.64.
But among other House Republicans, there were sharp arguments that raising the minimum wage would be bad policy.
The House majority leader, Representative Dick Armey of Texas, who opposed the 1989 increase when Mr. Gingrich voted for it, said: "Raising the minimum wage won't benefit working Americans; it will only increase the number of non-working Americans by destroying crucial entry-level jobs. The whole issue is a sham on the part of the Washington union bosses that fund the Democrat Party."

HEADLINE: In Summit Silences, a Truce In U.S.-Japanese Trade Wars

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Thursday, April 18

 BODY:
What is striking about the summit meeting this week between President Clinton and Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto is what is not being heard or seen.
No Japanese cars are being smashed in front of the Capitol in Washington, no trade negotiators are wielding crowbars, and, most important, there are no mutual recriminations about protectionism. Instead of threatening each other over trade disputes, the American and Japanese leaders are hailing the virtues of cooperation. 
 Indeed, the battlefront of trade here is so quiet these days that some people are declaring an end to the era of trade wars. Now, the United States has more disputes with Canada than it has with Japan. When Commerce Secretary Mickey Kantor met on Tuesday with the Japanese Trade Minister, Shunpei Tsukahara, the talks lasted a pleasant 10 minutes.
"The era of bilateralism is over," Yoshihiro Sakamoto, a deputy minister of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, said in a speech last month.
So, is this just a short-lived truce? Or are there more fundamental factors at work that have rendered the American-Japanese relationship more cordial?
Even President Clinton was somewhat ambiguous when he acknowledged in a speech to Parliament today that the trade relationship was "not entirely free of friction."
Experts disagree about the longer term, although they are united that the relationship for now is unusually peaceful on the trade front. Even those who fear new skirmishes will erupt soon say some of the heat and anger may have dissipated.
"Looking over the next two years at the Japanese economic cycle, there is less reason to be fearful over a trade war," said Michael J. Hartnett, senior economist at Merrill Lynch Japan Inc. "The final hurrah would come if Japan's Government would decide to deregulate the economy strongly."
For a relationship that for decades has been fraught more with acridity than amity, it may seem almost impossible to trade in peace, and perhaps Mr. Sakamoto's declaration is a dream. Certainly there are several disputes bubbling, ranging from film to semiconductors to some insurance issues like medical care.
Japan still has a long way before it sheds its protectionist reputation and opens its markets as wide as other developed countries. And critics assert that this trade truce is politically orchestrated and will be just a lull before another storm breaks out after the American elections.
"The Administration wants to take credit till November," said an American business executive, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "It's only a very short lull, until next year."
"Because of the recession here and growth elsewhere, the view of Japan as a threat and a rival is low," he added. "There is less of a sense of urgency about Japan, but the view of Japan as a serious rival is going to resurface."
If the strength of the American economy, for instance, leads to a surge of buying Japanese products, like machinery and electronic goods, then America's trade deficit with Japan could bounce back up again.
Still, however testy the trade disputes may grow, it is difficult to imagine Americans as infuriated about the tertiary insurance market as they were about cars. As the issues become more complex, they arouse fewer passions.
Moreover, Japan's trade surplus is dropping dramatically both with the United States and with the world as a whole. This is partly the effect of the strengthening yen, which makes American imports cheaper and Japanese exports more expensive. Furthermore, structural changes finally seem to be taking hold in the Japanese economy.
Since 1992, Japan's current account surplus, which occurs when a country exports more goods and services than it imports, has slid from 3.2 percent of real gross domestic product to 1.9 percent in the fourth quarter of last year, dipping below the psychological barrier of 2 percent. And the monthly bilateral trade surplus with the United States has also steadily fallen.
According to Government statistics released today, the trade surplus with America dropped to $3.28 billion in March, down 35.6 percent from the $5.09 billion of March a year ago.
Moreover, American exports to Japan surged about 20 percent last year over the previous year. In some areas, like cars, they rose by 80 percent. So it is becoming more difficult for American officials to call Japan a looming threat or a dirty trader or to mount an attack against Japan.
"Without a large Japanese surplus, any strident campaign wouldn't work," Masaru Yoshitomi, a top economist at the Long Term Credit Bank Research Institute, said in a telephone interview from the Wharton Business School in Philadelphia, where he is currently teaching.
"Politics can only play a small role," he said. "It can talk up or talk down and can only last a few weeks, but it has to be supported by the fundamentals."
The current sticky disputes are also much smaller than the trade balance in cars, which represents nearly half of Japan's bilateral trade surplus. Cars were the subject of the big trade dispute that was finally resolved last June.
"The automobile issue was a kind of symbolic issue for the two nations," said Makoto Kishida, an economist at Mitsui & Company's trade institute. "Insurance, maybe photofilm and semiconductors -- these items are less symbolic."
Some economists and business leaders argue that distaste for America's bilateral pressure tactics might force United States trade negotiators to turn to international forums like the World Trade Organization to resolve disputes. Already, there is talk of that route for the battle over color film, though that could also result in a confrontation.
"Ideally this is the direction we are moving in," said an American official who insisted on anonymity.
The battlefield approach to Japan is in some ways also being eclipsed by new challenges for America elsewhere in Asia. In China, for instance, the trade surplus with America is expanding rapidly, and troubles have increased over intellectual property rights and piracy of creative products like software and CD's.

HEADLINE: Clinton Urges Broad Global Role for Japan

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

DATELINE: TOKYO, Thursday, April 18

 BODY:
Bringing a state visit to an end, President Clinton today urged Japan to forge an alliance with the United States for the next century, with a growing commitment to free trade and to an expanding international leadership role that "flows from its place as a great nation."
In an address to Parliament this morning, Mr. Clinton also said the American people "profoundly regret" the rape of a Okinawan schoolgirl by three American servicemen last September, an attack that shook the security alliance by provoking an anti-American backlash. 
 But he strongly defended the American presence in Asia, which was ratified in the joint declaration he signed on Wednesday with Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto.
"Consider what might happen if the United States were to withdraw entirely from this region," Mr. Clinton said. "It could spark a costly arms race that could destabilize northeast Asia. It could hinder our ability to work with you to maintain security in a part of the world that has suffered enough in the 20th century through world war and regional conflicts and that is now in the midst of profound change."
Mr. Clinton discreetly avoided any reference to China, whose military exercises in the Taiwan Strait recently sent tremors through Asia. But he noted that a United States withdrawal from Asia "would weaken our power to deter states like North Korea that may still threaten peace."
Much of the President's speech was devoted to urging Japan to end its economic protectionism and hesitation about a role in world affairs. Noting that Japan had sent peacekeepers to Cambodia and minesweepers to the Persian Gulf, and had committed $500 million in reconstruction aid to Bosnia, he said, "We are all better off for your commitment to this kind of leadership."
"Today, to a great Japanese people whose pride in the past is now matched by your focus on the future, I say, stay true to that commitment to lead," Mr. Clinton said. "Make it even stronger. We have come so far in the last 50 years. Think about it: from the waste of war to the wealth of peace, from conflict to cooperation and competition, from mistrust to partnership."
Mr. Clinton acknowledged that American-Japanese trade relations were "not entirely free of friction." But as he has throughout his visit here, he played down the many areas of specific disagreement. Instead, he argued that open markets and American exports would benefit both nations.
"For Americans those exports mean more jobs at better pay," he said. "For the people of Japan, allowing these American goods and services to compete for the favors of the Japanese consumer means greater choice at lower prices."
Mr. Clinton was only the second American President to address Japan's Parliament; Ronald Reagan spoke here 1983. He received a standing ovation when he finished his speech and another one as he and his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, stood at the front of the chamber of the House of Representatives bowing their heads slightly in a Japanese-style gesture of courtesy.
Mr. Clinton's visit to Japan came midway through a weeklong tour that will now take him to Moscow, where he is to attend a nine-nation summit meeting on nuclear security and meet with President Boris N. Yeltsin, who is in an election struggle.
The crucial centerpiece of Mr. Clinton's visit to Japan came on Wednesday when he and Mr. Hashimoto signed a joint declaration endorsing the American military presence in the Asia-Pacific region as "essential for preserving peace and stability" in an area rattled by North Korea's incursions into the demilitarized zone separating it from South Korea and China's military maneuvers in the Taiwan Strait.
The security declaration affirmed that the United States would maintain its troop strength in the region at 100,000, the same number it maintains in Europe. The declaration also incorporated a plan for the American military to return an air base, two communications centers, a port and other military properties on Okinawa, where the rape of the girl set off anti-American protests.
The leaders also signed a separate document setting forth areas of cooperation between the two nations on regional disputes and in the United Nations.
On Wednesday afternoon, Mr. Clinton visited an aircraft carrier that had recently been deployed in the Taiwan Strait in order to thank the American forces serving in Japan.
On the carrier deck of the Independence, the oldest active ship in the service, under the banner "Don't Tread on Me," Mr. Clinton told the sailors and marines that their presence in the strait during China's military exercises "reassured nations all around the Pacific."
The President also saluted the crew of the Japanese cruiser Myoko, who had joined the ceremonies at the Yokosuka Naval Base outside Tokyo.
"Fifty years ago no one would have believed that an American carrier and a Japanese cruiser could be berthed side by side, that our forces would work shoulder to shoulder, day in and day out," Mr. Clinton said.
On Wednesday night the President and his wife were welcomed by Emperor Akihito at a white-tie state dinner in the Imperial Palace. Toasting the Emperor and his wife, Mr. Clinton remarked on how far the alliance had come since Japan's defeat in World War II.
"History offers very few examples of two peoples who have forged such a powerful relationship in the short period of half a century," he said. "We have indeed traveled far together. We have created in modern times a great democratic tradition."
At a similar official dinner in 1992, President Bush fell ill, his discomfort recorded by a television camera. This time, according to an American official familiar with the arrangements, the Japanese required that television cameras be turned off after an official photo session and pointed away from the tables.

HEADLINE: Voters Approved More Than Two-Thirds of School Budgets

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY 

DATELINE: HACKENSACK, N.J., April 17

 BODY:
For the second year in a row, more than two-thirds of New Jersey's local school budgets were approved Tuesday, suggesting that voters generally are in a mellow mood about education spending and the property taxes that help finance it.
Statewide, 67.8 percent, or 374 of 552, budgets passed, slightly below the 72.3 percent that were approved in school elections last spring. Suburban counties with school systems regarded as the state's best and costliest had the highest rates of approval, including Essex (93.8 percent), Bergen (79.7), Morris (82.1), Somerset (78.9), Monmouth (75.9) and Union (75). In Middlesex County, usually a hotbed of school-budget hostility, voters accepted 65 percent of the budgets. Last April, Middlesex voters approved only 39 percent of district budgets and in 1994 only 26 percent. 
 In recent months, the issue of financing schools has been relatively calm across New Jersey, free of the angry taxpayer revolt that hobbled the Florio administration in 1990 and doomed many budgets in 1994. That year, the Whitman administration initiated a policy of minimal annual increases in state education aid to local districts. Total state aid of $4 billion for the 1996-97 school year remains flat, and many wealthier districts have tightened spending.
Statewide turnout for the elections was about 18 percent of registered voters, slightly higher than usual. Neil Upmeyer, president for the Center for Analysis of Public Issues in Princeton, said he believed voters were in a "positive mood." He said he attributed that to a slowly recovering economy, the popularity of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, and property taxes increasing only at the rate of inflation.
"I think there's less incentive for taxpayers to rise up in arms against school budgets," Mr. Upmeyer said. "If they don't feel threatened by taxes, they don't vote against them."
Even voters in Belleville, a blue-collar neighbor of Newark, were upbeat. They approved the school budget for only the third time in 30 years, 1,064 to 1,010. "For us, that's a landslide," said the superintendent, Michael Lally. "I'm euphoric."
He said Belleville's budget of $32 million was up only 2.45 percent, controlled by eliminating some supervisory positions, consolidating others and requiring some students with learning disabilities to attend less costly local public schools.
But in some school districts, local issues helped doom budgets. Voters in Edison, a sprawling suburb of 30 square miles in Middlesex County, rejected a $104 million budget overwhelmingly, partly because of a squabble over busing students, the superintendent, Melindo Persi said. About 7,000 of Edison's 12,000 take buses to their schools, even though only about 3,500 are required to be bused. Edison's Town Government now pays the $500,000 cost of the so-called "courtesy busing" program. But it will not renew the financing, and the school board refuses to pick up the cost. The defeated school budget will be reviewed by the Town Government.
And in Florence Township, a community on the Delaware River south of Trenton, voters angry about high taxes rejected the budget by a 5-to-1 margin and elected the high school's senior class valedictorian, Jaime Fauver, to the school board. The town's two senior-citizen groups had endorsed Ms. Fauver's platform of reducing taxes and cutting administrative costs. Ms. Fauver said she plans to commute to college and will be able to make board meetings.
